 title : Samba 4 : Samba 4 - Open Hub
 title : The cleantogether Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>Mission statementTo create, as a community, a web site that will let people report their contribution into the worldwide effort of cleaning up the environment. </p>

<p>Motivation for the projecthttp://cleantogether.com :  This web site lets people post their environmental cleanup experiences. Whether you go to a beach, to a picnic, or on a hiking trip, think about how to bring some trash back home from the outdoors -- not only &quot;what you bring to nature, take back home&quot; kind of things, but think about the other stuff that gets left behind by others. You don&#39;t have to make your outdoor trip purpose to clean up (unless you want to) -- go have some fun, and at the end of the day contribute as much as you can (every bit counts). As you carry trash out, take a picture of your bag full of trash on- site (or it could be a picture of some really interesting finding that does not naturally belong to the environment), and post a blog story to the web site. Don&#39;t forget to tell where you found it and how much it weighs. Over time, some interesting statistics will accumulate, and the world will see our cleanup progress. </p>

<p>The project is built with Ruby on Rails version 2.0.1 . Some of the cool technologies the Cleantogether project uses are: Google Maps integrated with Rails Ajax, server-side updates, etc... </p>

<p>The code is free to share -- everyone is welcome to look at the code as well as to contribute cool ideas. The site is hosted at http://cleantogether.com </p>

<p>Unique Software Development ModelCleantogether.com is a unique project. How many other web sites do you know that are developed with an open source model? This project is pioneering the concept. Yes, there are thousands of open source projects hosted on Google Code, or sourceforge, or somewhere else. Most of these projects have one thing in common -- they develop a product that can be installed. Whether it&#39;s a framework like Struts (yes, good old Struts), or an OS like Linux, they all have a file that can be downloaded and installed on your local computer. Cleantogether.com has no end product that can be downloaded -- the result of collaborative development is a web site. </p>

<p>Motivation for developersSo, why as a developer should you care about contributing your talents and time to this particular project?  First of all, this project makes a difference to the world we live in. Everyone can contribute by going out there and cleaning up the environment and reporting on their progress. Developers can use their unique set of skills to make the web site nicer, to add new functionality that makes the web site experience better for the rest of us, or simply to fix a bug. Currently, the web site has very basic design, content and functionality. Some might argue that there is not much to add. Actually, in our view the possibilities are endless. For example we can add features like the DIGG.com style discussions, we can also add all sorts of statistics to the site so everyone can monitor the cleaning progress (and awareness level) around the world. We can also add features like creating cleanup projects where a group of people can get together and compete with each other or even challenge some other groups. And we can even start thinking about charging some fee to companies that want to organize their employees for an environmental cleanup day, in return for publicity (see about this in the next section). Individual contributors will always be able to use this site for free. And the last-but-not-least reason for developers to contribute -- this project is built on some of the coolest technologies out there: Ruby on Rails, Google maps, Ajax, MySQL, etc... So if you are a developer as passionate as we are about web technologies and keeping the world we all live in clean -- please roll up your sleeves and help! </p>

<p>Software as a ServiceFrom the very beginning cleantogether.com is taking a &quot;software as a service&quot; approach. Delegating responsibilities to other services that can do it better, rather then writing everything in house, seems to be the right way to go. We already use two third-party services. One is http://captchator.com , that generates and verifies captcha images to keep spammers away. The other one is a google maps which does not require special introduction (simply one of the best web based mapping solutions). This is great because it does take some load off of our server and allows us to concentrate on our business. The next service we are going to be integrating with is an authentication/authorization solution offered by http://RootLocusInc.com hosted as a service at http://preallowed.com </p>

<p>Potential profitabilityIt is not unusual to make a profit off of open source project. Red Hat is one remarkable example. Also, Google has open-sourced most of its code but still has been able to build a remarkable and wealthy technological empire. Our project has all of it&#39;s code open sourced. Right now the site is maintained by a few enthusiasts who really believe in what we do, and who want to make the world a cleaner place. Eventually, in order to be able to keep the site up and running we will need to pay our bills. For now, while the site is very basic in functionality and the traffic is very low, we can afford to fund it ourselves. But we envision that down the road it will change (a good thing), and then we will need to consider some way of generating a cash flow. All the money earned will be invested either in web site support and maintenance, or in other environmental projects. We might even consider making fair rewards to the developers who contributed to the project (at this point it&#39;s too early to talk about, but is definitely a possibility). </p>

<p>Copyright (c) 2007 Root Locus, Inc.</p>

 title : The cleosite Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>DescriptionUsing annotations you can make very succinct main methods that don&#39;t need to know how to parse command line arguments with either fields, properties, or method based injection. </p>

<p>Very simple to use, very small dependency. </p>

<p>LOC </p>

<p>Example from the Tests    public static class TestCommand {
<br/>        @Argument(value = &quot;input&quot;, description = &quot;This is the input file&quot;, required = true)
<br/>        private String inputFilename;</p>

<p>        @Argument(value = &quot;output&quot;, alias = &quot;o&quot;, description = &quot;This is the output file&quot;, required = true)
<br/>        private File outputFile;</p>

<p>        @Argument(description = &quot;This flag can optionally be set&quot;)
<br/>        private boolean someflag;</p>

<p>        @Argument(description = &quot;Minimum&quot;, alias = &quot;m&quot;)
<br/>        private Integer minimum;</p>

<p>        @Argument(description = &quot;List of values&quot;, delimiter = &quot;:&quot;)
<br/>        public void setValues(Integer[] values) {
<br/>            this.values = values;
<br/>        }
<br/>        public Integer[] getValues() {
<br/>            return values;
<br/>        }
<br/>        private Integer[] values;</p>

<p>        @Argument(description = &quot;List of strings&quot;, delimiter = &quot;;&quot;)
<br/>        private String[] strings;</p>

<p>        @Argument(description = &quot;not required&quot;)
<br/>        private boolean notRequired;</p>

<p>    }</p>

<p>    public void testArgsParse() {
<br/>        TestCommand tc = new TestCommand();
<br/>        Args.usage(tc);
<br/>        String[] args = {&quot;-input&quot;, &quot;inputfile&quot;, &quot;-o&quot;, &quot;outputfile&quot;, &quot;extra1&quot;, &quot;-someflag&quot;, &quot;extra2&quot;, &quot;-m&quot;, &quot;10&quot;, &quot;-values&quot;, &quot;1:2:3&quot;, &quot;-strings&quot;, &quot;sam;dave;jolly&quot;};
<br/>        List extra = Args.parse(tc, args);
<br/>        assertEquals(&quot;inputfile&quot;, tc.inputFilename);
<br/>        assertEquals(new File(&quot;outputfile&quot;), tc.outputFile);
<br/>        assertEquals(true, tc.someflag);
<br/>        assertEquals(10, tc.minimum.intValue());
<br/>        assertEquals(3, tc.values.length);
<br/>        assertEquals(2, tc.values[1].intValue());
<br/>        assertEquals(&quot;dave&quot;, tc.strings[1]);
<br/>        assertEquals(2, extra.size());
<br/>    }</p>
 title : The cli-parser Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>What Is It?Using the Clickatell API its possible to send text, flash and data messages using application code.  This component provides that ability using Clicktell&#39;s POST method as part of a CakePHP component. </p>

<p>RequirementsPHP5 - Web scripting language. CakePHP - MVC web framework. Clickatell account - they&#39;re free and provide a few credits for testing their service. ContributionsAll comments, patches and suggestions are welcomed. </p>

<p>NoteI&#39;m not in anyway affiliated with Clickatell and they haven&#39;t been involved in this components development.</p>

 title : The clovercash Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>CloverCash is a personal finance management and budgeting tool. It&#39;s written in Java, using the Eclipse RCP. </p>

<p>This is my second attempt at creating a money program. The first was a one-off program I created while learning Ruby on Rails and messing around with AJAX. I gave up on it after using it for 16 months, because it was a pain to maintain. </p>

<p>I used GnuCash before that, and some of the concepts are based on those in GnuCash, but I&#39;ve tried to keep things simple, and focused on speed and automation when possible. Of especial import to me was a quick and easy reconciliation interface, since that is what usually takes the longest, and keeps me from keeping things up-to-date.</p>

 title : The cmc2 Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>CMC is an open source .NET application for managing computers in Windows environments. Using CMC you can monitor and configure all aspects of PCs either in domain or standalone environments. </p>

<p>cmc remote administration features: </p>

<p>Operating system information and configuration Hardware information Network configuration and management Services information and management Processes information and management Software information Software deployment Remote performance monitoring Printer management - add and remove printers (local and network) Mapped drives information  - add and remove users network drives Send messages to remote users with either netsend or vbscript Manage startup programs Active Directory user and group management Rename computers and accounts - standalone and domain Join computers to a domain Easy access to Microsoft mmc snap ins, remote registry editing Telnet sessions - even when service is disabled (XP sp2) </p>

 title : The cminus-compiler Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>There are a variety of C unit testing frameworks available however many of them are fairly complex and require the latest compiler technology.  Some development requires the use of old compilers which makes it difficult to use some unit testing frameworks.  In addition many unit testing frameworks assume the code being tested is an application or module that is targeted to the same platform that will ultimately execute the test.  Because of this assumption many frameworks require the inclusion of standard C library headers in the code module being tested which may collide with the custom or incomplete implementation of the C library utilized by the code under test. </p>

<p>Cmockery only requires a test application is linked with the standard C library which minimizes conflicts with standard C library headers.  Also, Cmockery tries to avoid the use of some of the newer features of C compilers. </p>

<p>This results in Cmockery being a relatively small library that can be used to test a variety of exotic code.  If a developer wishes to simply test an application with the latest compiler then other unit testing frameworks may be preferable. </p>

<p>For more information check out the manual and the discussion group</p>

 title : The cmpt310-autumn2006-assignment5 Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>Fall 2006
<br/>CMPT 310: Introduction to Artiﬁcial Intelligence                            Instructor: Greg Mori
<br/>Assignment 5: Learning
<br/>Due Dec. 4 at 11:59pm
<br/>This assignment can be done in pairs.
<br/>Important Note: The univeristy policy on academic dishonesty (cheating) will be taken
<br/>very seriously in this course. Students will work in pairs on this assignment. You may not
<br/>discuss the speciﬁc questions in this assignment, nor their solutions with any other group.
<br/>You may not provide or use any solution, in whole or in part, to or by another group.
<br/>You are encouraged to discuss the general concepts involved in the questions in the context
<br/>of completely diﬀerent problems. If you are in doubt as to what constitutes acceptable
<br/>discussion, please ask! Further, please take advantage of oﬃce hours oﬀered by the instructor
<br/>and the TA if you are having diﬃculties with this assignment.
<br/>Part 0: Handwritten Digits
<br/>Download the images from the course website. There are two paths to follow, the MATLAB
<br/>path (which I believe to be easier), and the Java path (which you may be much more familiar
<br/>with). Choose one of the following:
<br/>1. Tarball 1.1 (data java.tar.gz) contains a huge set of 60000 training images, examples
<br/>of handwritten digits. The binary ﬁle format is a pair of integers giving the height h and
<br/>width w of the image, followed by a list of hw integers. Tarball 1.2 (code java.tar) contains
<br/>code for reading in these images, written in Java. Along with the directory of images is a
<br/>ﬁle containing 60000 labels (integers in {0, 1, . . . , 9}) in the same format as the image ﬁles h
<br/>is 60000, w is 1. Again, code for reading these in Java is available.
<br/>2. Tarball 2.1 (data matlab.tar.gz) contains 2 data ﬁles, and Tarball 2.2 (code matlab.tar)
<br/>a matlab function for reading in these data ﬁles. Running the function [train images,
<br/>train labels] = readData; will store a 28-by-28-by-60000 array in train images and a
<br/>60000-by-1 array in train labels. Each entry train images(:,:,i) corresponds to one
<br/>image. An image can be viewed by simply typing figure; imshow(train images(:,:,i)).
<br/>If you do not have large amounts of RAM, instead load train1000.mat (load(’train1000.mat’)),
<br/>which will load only the ﬁrst 1000 images and labels into variables train images1000 and
<br/>train labels1000. If you also don’t have a newer version of matlab which allows compressed
<br/>.mat ﬁles, use load(’train1000v6.mat’) after gunzipping said ﬁle.
<br/>For your viewing pleasure, all 60000 training images have been converted to JPEG format,
<br/>and are available as a tarball on the course website. It is not recommended that you use
<br/>these as input to your program, as this JPEG compression is lossy.</p>

<p>Part 1: Perceptron Learning
<br/>Train a single layer perceptron to recognize the digit 7 in your chosen programming language.
<br/>There should be M = 28 ∗ 28 + 1 = 785 input units (xi ), one for each pixel in an image,
<br/>plus a bias term (which is set to -1 for all inputs). There is one output unit, which should
<br/>be trained to be 1 if the image is of a digit 7, and 0 otherwise.
<br/>Your method should initialize the 785 weights Wj to some random values, and use the
<br/>Perceptron Learning algorithm to ﬁnd (locally) optimal weights using gradient descent.
<br/>Use a subset of the 60000 images to train your perceptron (perhaps the ﬁrst 100, or ﬁrst
<br/>1000, or ﬁrst 10000).
<br/>Pseudocode for perceptron learning:
<br/>W = random initial values
<br/>for iter = 1 to T
<br/>&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;for i = 1 to N (all examples)
<br/>&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;x = input for example i
<br/>&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;y = output for example i
<br/>&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;Wold = W
<br/>&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;Err = y − g(Wold · x)
<br/>&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;for j = 1 to M (all weights)
<br/>&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;Wj = Wj + α · Err · g′ (Wold · x) · xj
<br/>For your testing output, show the learned weights Wj (without the bias term) as an image
<br/>(use reshape(W(1:end-1),[28 28]) in MATLAB, or write a pgm image using the provided routine in Java). Comment brieﬂy on what you see.
<br/>A test example with input x is classiﬁed as a 7 if the output g(W · x) of the ﬁnal perceptron
<br/>is greater than 0.5.
<br/>Also show the results of testing your perceptron on a test set chosen as subset of the provided
<br/>data (disjoint from the training set you use). Report the classiﬁcation results for at least 5
<br/>diﬀerent training set sizes. For each training set size, run at least 5 diﬀerent experiments
<br/>with a diﬀerent random training set of the given size. Note that a “random” subset can
<br/>be obtained using randperm in MATLAB, or by starting from a random index (Java or
<br/>MATLAB). Plot % correct on test set versus # training examples on a graph by hand, in
<br/>MATLAB, or using your favourite program.
<br/>Part 2: Neural Networks
<br/>Create a neural network that attempts to recognize all of the digits 0 through 9. There should
<br/>be 10 output units, one corresponding to each of the 10 digits. The rest of the structure of
<br/>the network is up to you.
<br/>There should be at least 1 hidden layer of nodes in between the input and output layers. The
<br/>input layer does not have to be all 784 input pixels (plus a bias term), it can be something
<br/>else of your choosing.
<br/>Train this network using back-propagation (see lecture slides).
<br/>Again, train using some subset of the 60000 images, and use a disjoint subset to test your
<br/>trained network. Again, show recognition rates on using at least 2 diﬀerent sizes of training
<br/>set (one run for each is suﬃcient this time).
<br/>I will use a completely separate set of images to test your networks for the digit recognition
<br/>contest. For the contest:
<br/>1. If you are using Java, please create a class RecognizeDigits XX YY, with your student
<br/>numbers in place of XX and YY, as before. This class should extend the template class
<br/>RecognizeDigits provided.
<br/>2. If you are using MATLAB, please create a function recognizeDigits XX YY, with your
<br/>student numbers in place of XX and YY as before. Use the template provided without
<br/>changing the function header.
<br/>In short, your function/class should work with the run tournament ﬁle provided, with
<br/>absolutely no modiﬁcations.
<br/>Submitting Your Assignment
<br/>You must create your assignment in electronic form. For each part of the assignment, submit
<br/>the source code as well as the test output mentioned in each question. For part 2 give a brief
<br/>summary of the structure of the network used, and any other design choices made. Submit
<br/>these in one of the formats listed below.
<br/>In total, you should submit:
<br/>• All source code for parts 1 and 2
<br/>• Error rate plot for training perceptron
<br/>• Visualization of learned weights for perceptron for one of these training sets, with brief
<br/>comments
<br/>• Error rates (don’t have to plot) for training neural network with ≥ 2 sizes of training set
<br/>• Brief summary of structure of neural network and inputs
<br/>The accepted text formats are:
<br/>• ASCII Text
<br/>• HTML
<br/>• PDF (Portable Document Format)
<br/>And the accepted image formats are:
<br/>• GIF
<br/>• JPEG
<br/>• PDF
<br/>You must include a completed cover sheet along with all the ﬁles from your completed
<br/>assignment. This ﬁle is available from the course main page: http://www.cs.sfu.ca/
<br/>~mori/courses/cmpt310/a5/cover_sheet_a5.txt This ﬁle will be used by the TA to give
<br/>you feedback on your assignment, so don’t forget to complete it. This cover sheet also
<br/>includes the grading scheme.
<br/>All ﬁles should all be labeled appropriately so that the markers can easily follow and ﬁnd
<br/>your work. Create an archive (either *.zip or *.tar.gz) containing all relevant assignment
<br/>ﬁles, plus the cover sheet. When you are done, go to the Assignment Submission Page at
<br/>https://submit.cs.sfu.ca/ and follow the instructions there.</p>

 title : The cnip Open Source Project on Open Hub

 title : The cnlexizer Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>简介cnlexizer是一个基于统计语言模型的中文分词系统。 </p>

<p>LATEST RELEASECNLexizer 1.0beta1 发布: Download </p>

 title : The cobble Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>Project Cobble aims to offer a high quality, easy to use library of data structures. </p>

<p>It is written entirely in C, and it offers various functions to efficiently create and manipulate common data structures, like lists, stacks, queues, trees, graphs and many more. </p>

<p>Although the main purpose of this project is to serve as an additional support for the Data Structures course taught in The Faculty of Automation and Computer Science, University &#39;Politehnica&#39; of Bucharest, Cobble can be used as well in any non-academic applications and purposes.</p>
 summary : <p>CocoaAsyncSocket supports TCP and UDP.  The AsyncSocket class is for TCP, and the AsyncUdpSocket class is for UDP.  Each class is described below. </p>

<p>AsyncSocket is a TCP/IP socket networking library that wraps CFSocket and CFStream.  It offers asynchronous operation, and a native cocoa class complete with delegate support.  Here are the key features: </p>

<p>Queued non-blocking reads and writes, with optional timeouts. You tell it what to read or write, and it will call you when it&#39;s done. Automatic socket acceptance. If you tell it to accept connections, it will call you with new instances of itself for each connection. You can, of course, disconnect them immediately. Delegate support. Errors, connections, accepts, read completions, write completions, progress, and disconnections all result in a call to your delegate method. Run-loop based, not thread based. Although you can use it on main or worker threads, you don&#39;t have to. It calls the delegate methods asynchronously using NSRunLoop. The delegate methods include a socket parameter, allowing you to distinguish between many instances. Self-contained in one class. You don&#39;t need to muck around with streams or sockets. The class handles all of that. Support for TCP streams over IPv4 and IPv6. The library is public domain, originally written by Dustin Voss.  Now available in a public setting to allow and encourage its continued support. </p>

<p>AsyncUdpSocket is a UDP/IP socket networking library that wraps CFSocket.  It works almost exactly like the TCP version, but is designed specifically for UDP.  This includes queued non-blocking send/receive operations, full delegate support, run-loop based, self-contained class, and support for IPv4 and IPv6.</p>
 title : The cocoaasyncsocket Open Source Project on Open Hub
 title : The cocoahttpserver Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>Sometimes Cocoa developers need an HTTP server in their code. Perhaps they&#39;re writing a file-sharing app, or maybe they want to allow website links to communicate with built-in software similar to iTMS links. Obviously the built-in apache server is not an option. Thus the need for a small, lightweight, embedded HTTP server. This is what we needed for Mojo and we found a few available solutions: </p>

<p>Apple&#39;s CocoaHTTPServer CultureCode&#39;s Simple HTTP Server WuffHTTPD for $100 USD We liked Apple&#39;s the best because it was free and was built using standard networking sockets and streams. However, it didn&#39;t have everything we needed, and it seemed to have a few memory leaks. (We patched a few, but it still looked like it was leaking somewhere...) So with Apple&#39;s framework for an HTTP server tucked under our arm we set out to make our own. We wanted the following: </p>

<p>Built in support for bonjour broadcasting IPv4 and IPv6 support Asynchronous networking using standard Cocoa sockets/streams Digest access authentication TLS encryption support Extremely FAST and memory efficient Heavily commented code Very easily extensible This is the result of our hard work. </p>

<p>Please support this free and open source project</p>
 title : The cocoanav Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>CocoaNav parses OSX frameworks and makes them searchable in a nice Core Animation View. </p>

<p>CocoaNav is mostly written in RubyCocoa, with two ObjectiveC classes : CNItem and FrameworkViewBackground. It&#39;s a document based app. </p>

<p>Download CocoaNav </p>

<p>InternalsModel and controllersApplicationController manages data : handles FrameworkParsing, preferences, computing the ClassTree, WalkingTheTree, and FrameworkColors CNItem is the all purpose data class : it stores parsed class names, methods, protocols and categories  CNDocument backs document windows : specifies DocumentType and UserFrameworks FrameworkColor : CoreData class for managing text and background colors of frameworks WindowsCNWindow is the main window : handles coordination between the 3 views : FrameworkView, CrumbView, ItemTableView CNAboutWindow : the about window showing a WebView, backed by a Core Animation Quartz Composition CNPreferencesWindow : handles FrameworkColors editing ViewsViews ShareSelection. </p>

<p>FrameworkViewBackground : draws a radial gradient as a background. This class exists because I couldn&#39;t figure out how to draw the gradient with RubyCocoa FrameworkView : the meat of what you&#39;ll see. For each Objective C class, creates a matching layer. Two view modes : framework (classes inside their frameworks) or ClassTree (classes linked to their parents) CrumbView : for each class, draws inheritance crumb. For NSButton, draws NSObject &gt; NSResponder &gt; NSControl &gt; NSButton.  ItemTableView : displays every framework/class/method/protocol/category loaded and search them </p>

<p>TODObetter parsing, to handle C methods and structs. Maybe via Pygments. (Then we&#39;ll be able to index stuff like CATransform3DMakeScale) when parsing user frameworks,  parse .m files BACK / FORWARD ! maintain a history list, a la Safari it&#39;s taking too long on load -&gt; move CNItem to CoreData  better refresh on color change (?) UserFrameworks : load all files and make them visually searchable - just like in FrameworkView, to see each instance of a search term UserFrameworks : compute function depth usage and order. Trace usage of one function trough the code, see how deep it&#39;s called (call stack), where it&#39;s called, by whom parameter use : for each method or function, index its parameters -&gt; see what&#39;s being called by whom stuff like Demeter&#39;s Law : trail an object to see how deeply it&#39;s used real bindings between views : right now it sucks.  save document window positions AND contents. via Core Data ? On relaunch, you get exactly what you quit from. framework stats : classes count, method count, … allow user framework removal search within help webview</p>
 summary : <p>Cocoatron </p>

<p>The suite of Automator Actions for Mac OS X that brings drag-and-drop simplicity to creating and automating complex XML Processing Pipelines.&#39; </p>

<p>To install, download Cocoatron and unzip. Then drag the Cocoatron .action and .definition files to ~/Library/Automator. You may need to create this folder. Inspired by XProc and SXPipe, Cocoatron is a simple way to create XML pipelines visually - without writing a line of custom &#39;glue&#39; code in Java, C++ or other languages. </p>

<p>Conceptually, Cocoatron is a combination of XProc and Apple&#39;s Automator application. XProc is the W3C&#39;s spec for high-level descriptions of XML processing pipelines. Automator is Apple&#39;s graphical application for creating scripting pipelines with drag-and-drop simplicity. </p>

<p>Cocoatron consists of six Automator Actions (composeable, configurable pipeline stages): </p>

<p>Load XML Documents Process XIncludes of XML Documents Validate XML Documents (DTD, XSD, RNG) Transform XML Documents (XSLT) Query XML Documents (XQuery) Serialize XML Documents Implemented using the powerful libxml2 framework, Cocoatron includes support for XInclude, XSLT 1.0, EXSLT, XQuery, and validation against DTD, W3C XML Schema, and RELAX NG XML syntax.. </p>

<p>Much like SXPipe, these actions deal strictly with XML Infosets. Under the hood, the XML Infosets created and returned by Cocoatron Actions are actually libxml2 xmlDocPtr structs contained in Cocoa object wrappers. An Infoset is constructed using Load XML Documents and serialized back to text using Serialize XML Documents. To create pipleines, place other, built-in Apple Actions before and after these two Actions. </p>

<p>For example, start an XML pipeline with local XML documents using Get Specified Finder Items (Finder) or remote ones using Get Specified URLs (Safari). Finish a pipleine with New Text File (Finder) or New TextEdit Document (TextEdit). </p>

<p>Each Cocoatron Action includes a collapsable Console text field that will show you any errors or warnings that occur during that Aciton&#39;s processing. This allows for easy debugging. </p>

<p>As compared to the Beta release last week, v1.0 significantly improves behavior of Load XML Documents and fixes a nasty bug where dragging a Cocoatron Action into a Workflow would temporarily disable the &#39;Run&#39; button. </p>

<p>Implementation Details </p>

<p>Cocoatron is written in Objective-C and C, and is based on: </p>

<p>libxml libxslt libexslt Apple&#39;s Cocoa Frameworks Apple&#39;s NSXML Framework Cocoatron requires Mac OS X 10.4 Tiger or later. </p>

<p>Cocoatron is developed by Todd Ditchendorf. Have feedback? Email me.</p>

 title : The cocotron-tools-gpl3 Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>Cocotron Development Tools which are under the GPL v3, </p>
 summary : <p>CocoXml is inspired by Coco/R and modified from it. </p>

<p>Coco/R is released under GPLv2 and written by Hanspeter Moessenboeck, University of Linz. Its homepage is http://www.ssw.uni-linz.ac.at/coco/ . </p>

<p>CocoXml is released under GPLv2 too. </p>

<p>Coco/R can read an atg file and tempalte files, then generate scanner and parser for user. Different versions are implemented for different languages, such as C#, Java and C++ and so on. </p>

<p>Firstly, I modify Coco/R so it can accept a different atg. This new atg can be used to parse the tag/attribute structure base on the result of SAX parser, just like XCC does. For the detail of XCC, please access: ftp://plasma-gate.weizmann.ac.il/pub/xcc/. CocoXml use the EBNF to describe the syntax of tags, attributes and other XML elements. It is a strict way and can parse complex XML structure easily. </p>

<p>Then CocoXml-0.9.0.tar.gz is released. </p>

<p>After that, it is realized that if CocoXml is provided in the Coco/R way, the core algorithm has to be implemented in all supported languages again and again. This is not a necessitation. And I also need a stronger implement of Coco/R in C, so it can be used to generate various parsers in C. </p>

<p>So I decide to re-implement Coco/R in pure-C and split the output schemes from algorithm completely. And when a new programming language support is required, define a new output scheme is enough. </p>

<p>Another advantage of C implemented Coco/R is there are least dependencies, so the user can install it easily. And linux distribution can distribute it easily too. </p>

<p>Now the new implemented Coco(in c) and CocoXml are combined into one binary. If the extension of the input is .atg, it is treated as a syntax of the original Coco. If the extension of the input is .xatg, it is treated as a syntax of CocoXml. </p>

<p>Some more improvements are introduced too. For the details, please refer to the wiki of CocoXml, which can be accessed at http://code.google.com/p/cocoxml/w/list . </p>

<p>The source of CocoXml can be checkout with the following command: </p>

<p>svn checkout http://cocoxml.googlecode.com/svn/trunk cocoxml-read-only.The referenced Coco/R code are committed into svn too, so my modifications can be show easily. :)</p>

 title : The coldrails Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>ColdRails is a ColdFusion MVC framework that is loosely based on Ruby on Rails. At its core, ColdRails utilizes Reactor (an ORM) and Coldspring (for dependency-injection) along with a novel controller &amp; view system. This framework is being developed from the perspective of &#39;the least code is best&#39;. Before working on a new extension, the developers imagine how they like to write the code for a particular functionality and then code the framework to meet that standard. </p>

<p>Current release version: 0.2 </p>

<p>Development FocusPerformance Tune Core Code Continue UI Component Development (ActiveComponents)</p>

 title : The colorediffs Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>This is an extension that colors boring diffs sent by SVN/CVS notificators. </p>

<p>PrerequisitesA lot of developers use CVS and/or SVN version control systems. Most of also receive special notifications from the system about changes other people do. They might be useful in various ways: someone wants to check if there are bugs in the new code, someone just wants to keep knowledge of code base up-to-date. But looking over that black-on-white letter is so boring. That&#39;s why I decided to color it up a bit. </p>

<p>What it can do already </p>

<p>Well, not so much... It can color your diffs, it can show them in side-by-side mode if you like. Also it converts all the filenames in message log into links so you can quickly jump to the file you want to review. Ah, and it can make space and tabs chars visible. You can look through list of SupportedFormats and if your format isn&#39;t there write me an email. </p>

<p>What it will doIn the future I want this extension to be able to do following: </p>

<p>Highlight the actual difference between the lines Color the syntax of the language used Check new code against few rules in order to estimate quality of it But that&#39;s pretty big tasks, it could take a while to implement them. </p>

<p>ContributionIf you know how to do something better, whether it&#39;s code, icons, default color scheme, just contact me. Also please visit the issues list and star or comment the issues you&#39;d really like to be done first. </p>

<p>Firefox extensionThere isn&#39;t one and probably never will be, sorry. I could make it work for diff in  sections (most mail lists archives format them like this) but it would never work in GMail and other Web mail systems where it would be actually useful. It&#39;s just plain hard to find the code between the lines of normal text. But you could ease you pain with Bookmarklet I wrote when your needs is simple (like mail list archives) and GreaseMonkey script written by Fabrice Bellingard for GMail. Thanks for understanding. </p>

<p>NoteVersion 0.5 is the last one with support for Thunderbird 2. I&#39;m too tired of more than two years old JavaScript engine.</p>
 summary : <p>Coming soon..., </p>

 title : The commando-for-flex Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>What&#39;s Commando?Commando is an extension to Adobe Cairngorm that provides developers with the tools to parse command lines with options into Cairngorm Commands. Command lines can look like: </p>

<p>command-name -o command-name --long-option command-name --option-with-arg argvalue command-name -a &quot;long arg value&quot; </p>

<p>Commando is currently in Beta and is built using Flex 3. Commando is not a branch of Cairngorm, but depends on Cairngorm for compilation and at runtime. This means that the Cairngorm swc needs to be present to compile Commando and to run a project that uses Commando. </p>

<p>An example can be found at http://labs.effectiveui.com/commando</p>

 title : The common-lisp-protobuf Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>This project implements a Common Lisp target for Google Protocol Buffers. Given a protocol message description, it will provide a decoder to translate a stream to a CLOS instance, and an encoder to serialize a message back to a stream. </p>

 title : The common-oss-binary-dist Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>This is a non-source project that is encouraged to be used by other source based projects. It represents a container for binary distributions and their accompanying licenses. The purpose of this repository is to enable other projects to be able to conveniently reference a specific distribution’s release binaries using “svn:externals”.  Hence, this shared repository thus reduces the foot print of other source based repositories (typically their included libraries). Please note, this repository will only contain specific releases of distributions that have been linked into sources. You should always visit the original publishers site for other all releases of a given product.</p>

<p>The reason why this repository is needed:
<br/>* Most distribution bundles are either source or binary, but not both
<br/>* Many source distributions force builders to go fetch their specific releases of their dependencies. This unnecessarily complicates the process of building a code base
<br/>* Some binary distributions disappear with abandoned projects
<br/>* Not all open source software is published under a subversion repository</p>
 title : The commoncache Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>CCache(Common Cache) is a cache libary writing for the one who would like to cache data for frequent visiting.It caches data using mmap and makes you operating (insert, find, update, delete etc.) data very fast. Unlike memcached, it is a static libary, not a server, and if you want to use it, you must write server by youself, ccache does not care the protocol between server and client, and you must write your function pointer to compare the key in cache when you want to operate it(see demo in the test/testcache.c). </p>

<p>CommonCache Main feature using mmap to cache data in file, so it can be used in multi-thead and multi-process application. support unfix size key node support hash-rbtree and hash-list structure use LRU algorithm to eliminate nodes when it is running out of its memory size fast, 100W/read operation on fix-size key node in no more than 0.5 second CommonCache documentFollowing is the Commoncache document: </p>

<p>Desing And Implementation Of Ccache a simple demo show how to use ccache</p>
 title : The commontemplate Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>1. What is commontemplateCommonTemplate is a open source template engine, a generic tool to generate text output: HTML, XML, Mail, Java source code, etc. Project Home: http://www.commontemplate.org </p>

<p>2. How to use commontemplate(1) Standard syntax
<br/>    
<br/>        $if{users != null &amp;&amp; users.size &amp;gt; 0}
<br/>        
<br/>            $for{user : users}
<br/>            
<br/>                ${for.index + 1}
<br/>                ${user.name}
<br/>                ${user.coins}
<br/>            
<br/>            $end
<br/>        
<br/>        $end
<br/>    
<br/>package com.${project.company}.${project.name}.domain;
<br/>$if{project.framework != project.name}
<br/>import com.${project.company}.${project.framework}.domain.BaseEntity;
<br/>$end
<br/>public class ${entity.name} extends BaseEntity {
<br/>  $for{field : entity.fields}
<br/>  private ${field.type} ${field.name};</p>

<p>  public ${field.type} get${field.name.capitalize}() {
<br/>    return ${field.name};
<br/>  }</p>

<p>  public void set${field.name.capitalize}(${field.type} ${field.name}) {
<br/>    this.${field.name} = ${field.name};
<br/>  }
<br/>  $end
<br/>}  (2) Comment syntax
<br/>    
<br/>                
<br/>                        
<br/>                1                james                2.00            
<br/>                    
<br/>            
<br/>package com.${project.company}.${project.name}.domain;
<br/>/*$if{project.framework != project.name}*/
<br/>import com.${project.company}.${project.framework}.domain.BaseEntity;
<br/>/*$end*/
<br/>public class ${entity.name} extends BaseEntity {
<br/>  /*$for{field : entity.fields}*/
<br/>  private ${field.type} ${field.name};</p>

<p>  public ${field.type} get${field.name.capitalize}() {
<br/>    return ${field.name};
<br/>  }</p>

<p>  public void set${field.name.capitalize}(${field.type} ${field.name}) {
<br/>    this.${field.name} = ${field.name};
<br/>  }
<br/>  /*$end*/
<br/>}  (3) Tag syntax
<br/>    
<br/>        
<br/>            
<br/>                
<br/>                
<br/>                    1
<br/>                    james
<br/>                    2.00
<br/>                
<br/>                
<br/>            
<br/>        
<br/>    
<br/>(4) Attribute syntax
<br/>    
<br/>        
<br/>            
<br/>                1
<br/>                james
<br/>                2.00</p>

 summary : <p>What is CompagerCompager is a Content Management System (CMS) powered by PHP and MySQL. Compager is extremely lightweight, simple and customizable. Compager allows you quickly and easily build website, webblog, corporate portals. In addition, Compager even allows you build a online shop (see the demo online shop). </p>

<br/>Online Sale Module Compager allows you sell products online, and allows the user pay online via Paypal or Alipay. 
<br/>Flexible Site Structure Unlike many other blogging engines Compager allows you to arrange pages according to any hierarchy. A website in compager can be as simple as a collection of child pages underneath a parent page. 
<br/>High Performance Template Engine Templates are created from standard HTML and PHP coding, so it dos not need compile and superior perfermance, and you don&#39;t have to learn a obscure templating language. 
<br/>Multi-byte Language Support Fully supports multi-byte languages, including Japanese, Simplified and Traditional Chinese, Korean, etc.

 title : The compcache Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>This project creates RAM based block device (named ramzswap) which acts as swap disk. Pages swapped to this disk are compressed and stored in memory itself. </p>

<p>Compressing pages and keeping them in RAM virtually increases its capacity. This allows more applications to fit in given amount of memory. </p>

<p>The usual argument I get is - memory is so cheap so why bother with compression? So I list here some of the use cases. Rest depends on your imagination :) </p>

<p>Embedded Devices:  Memory is scarce and adding more memory increases device cost.  Also, flash storage suffers from wear-leveling issues, so its useful if we can avoid using them as swap device. Netbooks: Market is now getting flooded with these &quot;lighweight laptops&quot;. These are memory constrained but have CPU enough to drive on compressed me</p>

 title : The components-js Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>Components is a high-level JavaScript framework. It helps you write cleaner, clearer applications with less code and less effort. </p>

<p>It revolves around having a model for the interface instead of tons of CSS queries. The model gives you all the page access you need, with simple conventions for describing Requests, Updates and Events. </p>

<p>It looks like this...Here&#39;s a rewrite of an example from jQuery: </p>

<p>bind(&#39;gallery&#39;, {</p>

<p>  onLoadFocal: function() {
<br/>    this.clear(&#39;loading&#39;);
<br/>    this.focal.appear();
<br/>  },</p>

<p>  load: function(source) {
<br/>    this.apply(&#39;loading&#39;);
<br/>    this.focal.fade(function() {
<br/>      this.replace(&#39;&#39;).element.src = source;
<br/>    });
<br/>  }
<br/>});</p>

<p>bind(&#39;focal&#39;);</p>

<p>bind(&#39;thumb&#39;, {</p>

<p>  onClick: function() {
<br/>    this.gallery.load(this.element.src);
<br/>    return false;
<br/>  }
<br/>});
<br/>  Click on an image to view it full size.</p>
 title : The compressedbitset Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>DescriptionThis implements RLE compressed bitset for Java. The RLE compression scheme is Word-Aligned Hybrid compression scheme from LBNL. </p>

<p>This package exists because of general lack of compressed bitset implementations in Java. This package implements the Word-Aligned Hybrid (WAH) compression scheme from LBNL, which compresses the bitsets without sacrificing performance. The code is derived from the original authors&#39; FastBit software and pseudo-codes in the paper.  </p>

<p>LimitationsCurrently the WAHBitSet class allows appends only and the number of operations implemented on the bitsets are also limited to AND, OR operations.  </p>

<p>Performance NoteIn the compressed bitset, checking for every single bit is expensive, but doing operations such as AND and OR with other compressed bitsets is quite fast (They work on compressed bitsets, without uncompressing them at all). Use -server option while starting Java to get the most performance.</p>
 summary : <p>This project is an exploration of documented AI agents and other models within the cognitive sciences. It is currently in a very early stage of development with only a simple environment for agents, random mazes, complete as of this writing.  </p>

<p>The code is being developed using SBCL, an implementation of Common Lisp, within a Eclipse/CUSP environment. The author&#39;s primary development platform is Ubuntu 8.04 on a dual core AMD. However, the code is largely platform independent. </p>

<p>Building/Using: -Install the C/C+ SDL libraries on your system from http://www.libsdl.org/. </p>

<p>-Install the lispbuilder-sdl library. I strongly recommend using asdf, http://common-lisp.net/project/asdf-install/, for this. The lispbuilder installation documentation appears pretty far out of date. As of this writing, the following commands worked for me. (require &#39;asdf-install) (asdf-install:install :lispbuilder-sdl) (asdf-install:install :lispbuilder-sdl-gfx) </p>

<p>-Load the project asd files. lisp-utils.asd should be loaded prior to any others.  </p>

<p>Known Issues: -The SDL bindings do not behave well on OS X when using Lisp with SLIME (this applies to Eclipse/CUSP as well). This is thought to be due to window eventing issues due to threading (SDL window does not update). The problem does not manifest on Linux/X platforms. I haven&#39;t tried Windows.</p>

 title : The concurrentlinkedhashmap Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>A high performance version of java.util.LinkedHashMap for use as a software cache. </p>

<p>DesignA concurrent linked list runs through a ConcurrentHashMap to provide eviction ordering. Supports insertion and access ordered eviction policies (FIFO, LRU, and Second Chance). StatusTesting new algorithm. Original AlgorithmThe Sept. 2008 jar contains the initial version, which uses a concurrent deque that runs through a ConcurrentHashMap. For simplicity, the implementation used a lazy removal strategy to allow focusing on validating the doubly linked list. A backtracking eager removal strategy was initially prototyped, but not adopted due to concerns over management of the data races. </p>

<p>According to Greg&#39;s benchmarks, he found up to a 92.5x performance gain when compared to the previous version of Ehcache (v1.5). </p>

<p>Note: A rare race condition was uncovered by Greg Luck (Ehcache). This algorithm is deprecated. </p>

<p>Current AlgorithmThe design document describes a newer approach based on per-node spin-locks. </p>

<p>Note: The algorithm needs further testing and is not deemed production ready. It is functional under concurrent tests, but needs additional load testing to assert correctness. </p>

<p>Production VersionDue to popular demand and accidental usages in production environments, a certified production-ready version is provided for download. This version is will provide the desired performance without using experimental code intended for personal education. The modifications are documented outside of the repository. </p>

<p>FutureAfter the current algorithm is released, work will begin towards maturing it into a lock-free algorithm. A lock-free algorithm is non-blocking, maintains the list in an acceptable but not always perfect state, and coerces to the desired state. This changes the thought process of trying to block concurrent operations from corrupting shared state to making them work together to arrive at a final state. </p>

<p>LicenseThe algorithms and code are provided as-is under the APL-2. They were built primarily for fun and as a hobby project. The main motivation was that the puzzle of how to implement a concurrent linked hashmap sounded quite enjoyable (and educational). </p>

<p>To figure it out for myself, I avoided venturing into certain academic literature. While this may make progress slower, it allows me to understand the algorithms rather than copying them. That said, others are free to use this structure as a template and make the necessary changes to implement one of those algorithms.</p>
 title : The conecta4 Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>El famoso de juego de conecta 4 implementado en LISP, utilizando el conocido algoritmo de inteligencia artificial minimax. </p>

<p>-Consideremos un tablero con forma de retícula de 7 columnas con 6 celdas en cada una. </p>

<p>-Hay dos jugadores que juegan por turnos. Las piezas se colocan dejándolas caer desde lo alto de una columna que no está completa, y la pieza se coloca en la posición libre más baja de dicha columna. </p>

<p>-El juego acaba cuando algún jugador logra tener en el tablero 4 fichas adyacentes alineadas en horizontal, vertical o en diagonal, y ese jugador gana la partida. En caso de que el tablero se llene y ningún jugador haya logrado ganar, se acaba la partida con resultado de empate.</p>

 title : The contactserv Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>Latest version: - from - (ChangeHistory). </p>

<p>IntroductionPersonal tool to work with contacts, it&#39;s the main reference implementation service of the semap semantic bus. It contains the console and Firefox plugin versions. </p>

<p>RequirementsThe semap installation only. FeaturesURI-based Semantic Web style; FOAF vocabulary based records; Multilingual support. DownloadNot available yet, the output of  1.0-M1 version planned to the end of autumn of 2007. </p>

<p>Quick StartRead the getting start tutorial to start to use contactserv quickly. </p>

<p>News2007/08/13 - the initial version of contactserv console tool specification has been completed. </p>

 summary : <p>End-user applications that take advantage of users&#39; current context and respond appropriately have traditionally been the exclusive domain of HCI researchers working in university or research labs. An extensive and robust literature describes architectures and techniques for making daily computing calmer and more humane, but these findings and tools thus far have not made the jump from the research lab to daily use. </p>

<p>The purpose of this project is to adapt and implement the results of this research as useful frameworks and tools that real-world end-users may employ to improve their daily computing experiences. </p>

<p>Current ToolsSound Effects Growl Plugin: This plugin builds upon Matthew Walton&#39;s popular Smoke plugin by adding a simple rule-based system for selecting different sound effects to accompany different kinds of notifications. This plugin may be used to add sound effects to applications that previously had none, in addition to customizing the audio and visual intrusiveness of incoming notifications. This plugin is available within the Downloads tab above. </p>

<p>Shion: Shion is a simple MacOS X Cocoa application for controlling Insteon-compatible devices. Shion uses a user-mode USB HID driver that controls the SmartHome PowerLinc USB controller. Shion&#39;s feature set reflects the current state of the local Insteon protocol implementation.</p>

 summary : <p>Coot is a suite of programs for macromolecular model-building using X-ray data incorporating interactive molecular graphics including refinement, rebuilding and model validation. </p>

<p>Coot is built on top of several layers, including the GNU Scientific Library, GTk, Guile, guile-gtk, coordinate handling libraries (mmdb), crystallographic object handling libraries (clipper), GNOMECanvas and OpenGL.</p>
 summary : <p>The purpose of this project is to create linguistically annotated text collections (treebanks) on the basis of the dependency-based grammar formalism Discontinuous Grammar. The treebanks created in the project can be used to train natural language parsers, syntax-based machine translation systems, and other statistically based natural language applications. </p>

<p>The project hosts the following treebanks: </p>

<p>the 100,000 word Danish Dependency Treebank, which was used as training material in the CoNLL shared task in 2006; the 100,000 word Copenhagen Danish-English Dependency Treebank; work-in-progress with respect to Copenhagen Dependency Treebanks for Danish, English, German, Italian, and Spanish. The treebanks are released to the computational linguistics / natural language processing community under an open-source license (LGPL).</p>

 title : The coreavc-for-linux Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>CoreAVC is a proprietary Windows codec for H.264 video decoding.  It is much faster than any currently available open-source codecs.  Being multi-threaded, and able to play PAFF streams, it can handle HD H.264/AVC streams that no freely available codecs can.  CoreAVC is reasonably priced at ~$15, but it is Windows only. </p>

<p>2010-01-03: CoreAVC-for-Linux has been updated to support all versions of CoreAVC from 1.0 through 2.0.  Using Wine is now a requirement for installation and using dshowserver.  The old mplayer based Win32 code is still available but is no longer supported.  Dshowserver should now work on any platform that Wine can run on. </p>

<p>NOTICE: I am direly in need of help.  I no longer have the time to work on this project much, and there is quite a bit to do.  If you think you can meaningfully contribute, please contact me.</p>
 summary : <p>CoreDC The aim of the project is to produce a well documented and simple to use library implementing the Direct Connect p2p protocol. Mainly in order to simplify the process of writing programs to communicate over the DC protocol. </p>

<p>We are closing in on a first release, but you already download the latest source from the svn and compile your own, fully working version. Some things are not yet implemented, but basic functionality works. </p>

<p> </p>

<p>CoreDC currently features simple methods to:Connect / disconnect to a specified DC hub. Send / recieve raw hub messages. S/r mainchat messages. S/r private messages. S/r passive searches. Recieve passive searchresults. It automatically handles login procedure and tcp communications and works with all major hubsofts (not tested with all minor ones yet).</p>

 title : The coriander-spokentext Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>SpokenText API, </p>
 summary : <p>Cornell&#39;s DARPA Urban Challenge VehicleThis is the repository for Cornell&#39;s 2007 DARPA Urban Challenge Vehicle, Skynet. The full source code for all relevant components of the vehicle is available here. The code is written in Visual Studio 2005/2008 with a mixture of C++ and C#. All the libraries used are for Windows 32 bit with the exception of the pose estimator, which can run in either 32 or 64 bit mode. </p>

<p>Major ComponentsArbiter - High level route planning Operational - Low level vehicle control and obstacle avoidance Local Map - Low level sensor fusion Scene Estimator - Posterior positioning and high level target tracking Pose Estimator - a tightly coupled pose estimator fusing wheel speed, IMU measurements, HP corrections and raw GPS psuedoranges Sensors - These are the low level sensing engines which feed to either the local map or scene estimator. They include lidar clustering, road and lane finding in camera data, and other lidar based feature detectors. Utilities - Data playback engine, Messaging and Name services, Other utilities Simulation - Allows for simulation of the AI components (Arbiter and Operational) Further documentation will be available in the wiki. </p>

<p>Major Change LogOctober 1, 2008 - Initial snapshot of repository deployed.</p>

 summary : <p>The Cortex project aims to provide a set of high quality C++ libraries and Python modules tailored for software development in the visual effects industry. Rather than producing end user tools, the project focuses on creating a reusable set of modules of use to TDs and programmers in a broad range of scenarios - allowing them to focus on the more interesting or innovative aspects of development. </p>

<p>Originally the brainchild of Andrew Chapman, the Cortex project is now being developed around the IECore library developed in house at Image Engine and subsequently released as open source. Initially, Image Engine are providing the core library and Python bindings, along with their RenderMan, Maya, OpenGL, and Nuke support libraries. </p>

<p>It is hoped that the Cortex project will attract contributions from the wider visual effects community, and grow to provide a rich set of functionality and support for further 3rd party applications.</p>

 title : The couchdb4j Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>An updated java library for interacting with the newer JSON-based CouchDB. </p>

<p>After looking into CouchDB, I attempted to use the existing couchdb-lib project from egor.margineanu.  However, the original CouchDB used an XML document  format, but the latest uses JSON for it&#39;s document format.  The URL schemes have also  changed since then.  Basically, it didn&#39;t work. </p>

<p>So, since that wasn&#39;t going to work, I set about to write my own. </p>

<p>If you have questions, or find bugs, let me know! </p>

<p>Update: June 2009: Repository is now available on GitHub at: http://github.com/mbreese/couchdb4j </p>

<p>This will be the main repository from here on out. </p>

<p>Thanks! </p>

<p>mbreese@gmail.com</p>

 title : The couchprojects Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>Counterpart is an application server based primarily on the V8 JavaScript (ECMAScript) compiler and the FastCGI library. Its goal is to enable a safe, fast, curly-brace-friendly programming environment for web development, including a robust set of extensions (JavaScript, binary shared library, or a combination thereof). </p>

<p>Counterpart is presently being built on Ubuntu Linux, but support is planned for BSD (including Mac OS X) and some reasonably modern flavor of Windows (IIS, not that we don&#39;t love Cygwin). </p>

<p>Counterpart bootstraps itself at first with C++, but its goal is to let JavaScript do the heavy lifting, even to the point of taking over much of bootstrapping. </p>

<p>The name refers to the fact that it&#39;s only reasonable to write client-side and server-side code in the same language. Counterpart began life named &#39;rainforest&#39; for obscure historical reasons. Thanks to Daniel Bogan for helping brainstorm the new name and logo. </p>

<p>Related projects: </p>

<p>V8, the JavaScript engine on which Counterpart is based. v8r, a command-line processor. llv8call, a native library for V8 we are hoping to be able to build as an extension. Dino Engine, a &quot;web framework&quot; which uses V8. The documentation is in French, so I can&#39;t really compare and contrast Counterpart.</p>

 title : The cpsalsa Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>IntroductionThe CPSalsa web project is a redesign of the current website (found at www.cpsalsa.com) to be more usable and more sustainable.  By usable, we mean upgrading from the current forms-based application to one that is more intuitive, more responsive, and less tedious.  By sustainable, we mean well-documented code that other developers can contribute to so that the project does not rely on one or two individuals. </p>

<p>Update  The initial version has been released.  It currently supports basic content management of events, the gallery, and club members.  Future work involves hooking the administrative tasks into Google Documents/Spreadsheets. </p>

<p>TechnologiesFor our purposes, we decided to implement the back-end in Ruby on Rails using a MySQL database, which is a legacy database from the original site design.  The database will be modified to fit the new web application, using the Rails migration feature.  On the front end, we use AJAX as well as plain old HTML as the UI for the user.  Future implementations may makes use of Adobe Flex. </p>

<p>Table of ContentsMilestones Developer&#39;s Guides Coding Style/Standards Testing Plans and Strategies</p>

 title : The crashma Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>The CrashRpt library is a light weight error handling framework. This module will intercept any unhandled exception generated by an application, build a complete debug report and send the report to the software author.  The library can also be used to gather and send user feedback. </p>

<p>Figure 1 - Main Dialog </p>

<p>OverviewIf you&#39;ve ever been tasked with debugging a fatal exception, you probably know how difficult it can be given only the user&#39;s steps to reproduce. Many factors such as the application&#39;s version, user&#39;s operating system, and dependent modules may contribute to the eventual crash. This makes duplicating the user&#39;s environment and thereby the crash, nearly impossible for all but the most obvious bugs. </p>

<p>The CrashRpt library is a light weight error handling framework. This module will intercept any unhandled exception generated by your application, build a complete debug report, and optionally, mail the report to you. </p>

<p>UsageIn this article, a crash report refers to a collection of files intended to help the developer quickly diagnose the cause of a crash. Specifically the crash report includes a minidump, a crash log and up to ten additional application specific files supplied by the application via a crash callback. Of these the most useful will most likely be the application minidump. The minidump contains the call stack, local variables, details all of your application&#39;s modules, and can even help pinpoint the source line number that generated the exception. </p>

<p>The CrashRpt DLL works like the new Dr. Watson utility that ships with XP. It intercepts unhandled exceptions, creates a minidump, builds a crash log, presents an interface to allow the user to review the crash report, and finally it compresses and optionally emails the crash report back to you. </p>

<p>When an unhandled exception is detected, CrashRpt notifies the user and allows them to review the report contents. First the main dialog shown above is displayed. From here the user can enter their comments and email address or review the report contents by clicking the hyperlink. This takes them to the details dialog, where they are presented with the files that make up the report. Double clicking on the filename will open that file in its associated program, if an association exists for that file type. </p>

<p>Figure 2 - Crash Details Dialog </p>

<p>Once the user is satisfied, he may close the details dialog and click the &#39;Send&#39; button on the main dialog, which will email his complete crash report to you. </p>

<p>Using the CrashRpt library in Your ApplicationBuilding the libraryDownload and unzip the source code attached to this article. Open the complete.dsw workspace located in the top level directory. This workspace contains the source for the two sample applications and the CrashRpt library. You only need to build the CrashRpt project - crashrpt.dsp. </p>

<p>Notes: </p>

<p> CrashRpt library uses the WTL for its GUI components, so WTL must be installed and properly configured in order to build the CrashRpt library. You can download the WTL here. If you&#39;re new to the WTL then CodeProject has some article here, and there is a good starting guide here. 2. CrashRpt library uses Microsoft&#39;s Debug Help library (dbghelp.dll). The proper h and lib files must be installed and properly configured in order to build the CrashRpt library. These files are available in the Debugging SDK, which can be downloaded here (be sure to select the SDK setup option).  
<br/>After the build completes, you should end up with the following: </p>

<p>crashrpt\include
<br/>crashrpt.h </p>

<p>crashrpt\bin\debug or crashrpt\bin\release
<br/>crashrpt.dll
<br/> 
<br/>crashrpt\lib
<br/>crashrpt.lib </p>

<p>crashrpt\src
<br/>[all source files...]Linking against the libraryTo implicitly link against the library, you need to include the crashrpt.h file and link in the crashrpt.lib file. I find it easiest to add the following two lines to my main application file. </p>

<p>#include &quot;[whateveryourpath]/crashrpt/include/crashrpt.h&quot;
<br/>#pragma comment(lib, &quot;[whateveryourpath]/crashrpt/lib/crashrpt&quot;)Figure 3 - Integrating CrashRpt with your application </p>

<p>Initializing the libraryThe library needs to be initialized before it will catch any exceptions. You do this by calling the Install method, usually from your main function. The Install method is detailed below. </p>

<p>//-----------------------------------------------------------------------------
<br/>// Install
<br/>//    Initializes the library and optionally set the client crash callback and
<br/>//    set up the email details.
<br/>//
<br/>// Parameters
<br/>//    pfn         Client crash callback
<br/>//    lpTo        Email address to send crash report
<br/>//    lpSubject   Subject line to be used with email
<br/>//
<br/>// Return Values
<br/>//    If the function succeeds, the return value is a pointer to the underlying
<br/>//    crash object created.  This state information is required as the first
<br/>//    parameter to all other crash report functions.
<br/>//
<br/>// Remarks
<br/>//    Passing NULL for lpTo will disable the email feature and cause the crash 
<br/>//    report to be saved to disk.
<br/>//
<br/>CRASHRPTAPI 
<br/>LPVOID 
<br/>Install(
<br/>   IN LPGETLOGFILE pfn OPTIONAL,                // client crash callback
<br/>   IN LPCTSTR lpTo OPTIONAL,                    // Email:to
<br/>   IN LPCTSTR lpSubject OPTIONAL                // Email:subject
<br/>   );Figure 4 - The Install() function </p>

<p>All of the parameters are optional. The first parameter is a pointer to a crash callback function defined as: </p>

<p>// Client crash callback
<br/>typedef BOOL (CALLBACK *LPGETLOGFILE) (LPVOID lpvState);Figure 5 - Client crash callback </p>

<p>You would define this callback only if you wanted to be notified of an application failure, so that you could perform some basic clean up (i.e. close db connections, attempt to save, etc). Otherwise, you can simply pass NULL for this parameter. </p>

<p>The second parameter defines the email address you want the crash report mailed to, or NULL if you prefer the reports be saved to the user&#39;s workstation. </p>

<p>The third parameter is the subject line used in the generated mail message. </p>

<p>The Install function returns a pointer to the underlying object that implements the real functionality of this library. This value is required for all subsequent calls into the library. </p>

<p>If, after you have called Install, you decide to unhook the CrashRpt library, you would call Uninstall. </p>

<p>//-----------------------------------------------------------------------------
<br/>// Uninstall
<br/>//    Uninstalls the unhandled exception filter set up in Install().
<br/>//
<br/>// Parameters
<br/>//    lpState     State information returned from Install()
<br/>//
<br/>// Return Values
<br/>//    void
<br/>//
<br/>// Remarks
<br/>//    This call is optional.  The crash report library will automatically 
<br/>//    deinitialize when the library is unloaded.  Call this function to
<br/>//    unhook the exception filter manually.
<br/>//
<br/>CRASHRPTAPI 
<br/>void 
<br/>Uninstall(
<br/>   IN LPVOID lpState                            // State from Install()
<br/>   );Figure 6 - The Uninstall function </p>

<p>You would only ever call Uninstall if you decided, after calling Install, that you did not want the CrashRpt library to intercept exceptions. So, basically you will probably never call this method directly. </p>

<p>Adding custom files to the reportThe client application can, at any time, supply files to be included in the crash report by calling the AddFile function. </p>

<p>//-----------------------------------------------------------------------------
<br/>// AddFile
<br/>//    Adds a file to the crash report.
<br/>//
<br/>// Parameters
<br/>//    lpState     State information returned from Install()
<br/>//    lpFile      Fully qualified file name
<br/>//    lpDesc      Description of file, used by details dialog
<br/>//
<br/>// Return Values
<br/>//    void
<br/>//
<br/>// Remarks
<br/>//    This function can be called anytime after Install() to add one or more
<br/>//    files to the generated crash report.
<br/>//
<br/>CRASHRPTAPI 
<br/>void 
<br/>AddFile(
<br/>   IN LPVOID lpState,                           // State from Install()
<br/>   IN LPCTSTR lpFile,                           // File name
<br/>   IN LPCTSTR lpDesc                            // File desc
<br/>   );Figure 7 - The AddFile function </p>

<p>This is useful when your application uses or produces external files such as initialization files or log files. When a report is generated, it will include these additional files. Manually generating a report </p>

<p>You can force report generation by calling the GenerateErrorReport. This is useful if you want to provide an easy way to gather debugging information about your application to help debug a non-fatal bug. </p>

<p>//-----------------------------------------------------------------------------
<br/>// GenerateErrorReport
<br/>//    Generates the crash report.
<br/>//
<br/>// Parameters
<br/>//    lpState     State information returned from Install()
<br/>//    pExInfo     Pointer to an EXCEPTION_POINTERS structure
<br/>//
<br/>// Return Values
<br/>//    void
<br/>//
<br/>// Remarks
<br/>//    Call this function to manually generate a crash report.
<br/>//
<br/>CRASHRPTAPI 
<br/>void 
<br/>GenerateErrorReport(
<br/>   IN LPVOID lpState,
<br/>   IN PEXCEPTION_POINTERS pExInfo OPTIONAL
<br/>   );Figure 8 - The GenerateErrorReport function </p>

<p>If you do not supply a valid EXCEPTION_POINTERS, structure the minidump callstack may be incomplete. </p>

<p>Generate debug symbolsTo get the most out of the minidump, the debugger needs your application&#39;s debug symbols. By default release builds don&#39;t generate debug symbols. You can configure VC to generate debug symbols for release builds by changing a couple of project settings. </p>

<p>With the release build configuration selected, on the C/C++ tab under the General category, select &#39;Program Database&#39; under Debug info. </p>

<p>Figure 9 - C++ Project Settings </p>

<p>On the Link tab under the General category, check the &#39;Generate debug info&#39; option. Figure 9 - Link Project Settings </p>

<p>Now release builds will generate debug symbols in a PDB file. Keep all executables and PDB files for each release that ships to customers. You will need these files to read minidump files in the debugger. </p>

<p>Using the Crash ReportUsing the Crash LogThe crash log is an XML file that describes details about the crash including the type of exception, the module and offset where the exception occurred, as well as some cursory operating system and hardware information. I wrote the crash log to make it easier to catalog crashes. A crash can be uniquely identified by the module, offset and exception code. This information could be inspected by a developer or an automated process, and compared against previously reported problems. If a match is found, the developer or automated process, could inform the user of the solution without having to debug the error again. </p>

<p>The log is divided into four different sections or nodes. The first node is ExceptionRecord we discussed earlier. </p>

<p>Figure 10 - ExceptionRecord Node </p>

<p>Next is the Processor node, which contains a little information about the user&#39;s CPU. </p>

<p>Figure 11 - Process Node </p>

<p>Next is the OperatingSystem node, which contains the user&#39;s operating system version information. </p>

<p>Figure 12 - OperatingSystem Node </p>

<p>Last is the Modules node. This node contains the path, version, base address, size, and time stamp for every module loaded by the deceased application. </p>

<p>Figure 13 - Modules Node </p>

<p>Using the Crash Dump FileThe crash dump file is a minidump created with the help of the DbgHelp DLL&#39;s MiniDumpWriteDump function. The minidump contains various information about the state of the application when the error occurred including the call stack, local variables, and loaded modules. For more on creating minidumps, check out Andy Pennell&#39;s article. </p>

<p>You can view minidump files in VS.NET or the WinDbg debugger. Because WinDbg is free, I&#39;ll use it in the following example. You can download WinDbg from here. I&#39;m using version 6.1.0017.0 in the example. </p>

<p>The sample application included with this article does nothing but generate a null pointer exception. I&#39;ll use the sample to generate a crash and demonstrate how to use the resulting minidump. </p>

<p>When you run the sample application, click on the bomb button to generate a null pointer exception, and save the resulting crash report. Then extract the crash.dmp file from the crash report, launch WinDbg, and open the crash dump by pressing CTRL+D. </p>

<p>Next, you need to set the symbol path for WinDbg with the .sympath command. Switch to the command window (ALT+1) and enter .sympath followed by a space followed by the semi-colon delimited list of directories to search. </p>

<p>.sympath c:\downloads\CrashRptTestFigure 14 - Setting the symbol path </p>

<p>Similarly you need to set the executable and source search paths with the .exepath and .srcpath commands. </p>

<p>.exepath c:\downloads\CrashRptTest
<br/>.srcpath c:\downloads\CrashRptTestFigure 15 - Setting the source and executable paths </p>

<p>The final step is to change the debugger context to the context record associated with the exception by entering the .ecxr command. </p>

<p>.ecxrFigure 15 - Setting the exception context record </p>

<p>If everything is configured correctly, you should now be able to walk the call stack, see local variables, and loaded modules. You can even have WinDbg highlight the offending line of code by double clicking the CrashRptTest frame in the Call Stack window (ALT+6). Note: The exact line number may be a little off due to linker optimizations. </p>

<p>Figure 16 - The Promised Land: Using WinDbg to Locate the Cause of a Null Pointer Exception </p>

<p>DeploymentThe CrashRpt library relies on a couple of redistributable libraries. To be sure the library has access to the required files, you can distribute the ZLib and DbgHelp I&#39;ve included. </p>

<p> Library  File Version  Description   CrashRpt.DLL  3.0.2.1  Crash report library   ZLib.DLL  1.1.3.0  ZLib compression library   DbgHlp.DLL  6.1.17.1  Microsoft debug help library  Figure 17 - Redistributable Libraries </p>

<p>What to ship and what to saveAs I mentioned earlier, to debug a crash you need not only the minidupmp file, but also the symbol and executable files that make up your application. When preparing a build to be released to clients, you should always save the exact executable modules you ship to clients, along with the corresponding debug symbols. This way when a crash report comes in, you will have the modules and debug symbols that the debugger will need to properly interpret the minidump. </p>

<p>I&#39;ve received several comments/inquiries about shipping debug builds or debug symbols. You should never ship debug builds or debug symbols as they will not only take up more space on your CD/download/client&#39;s workstation, but they will also make reverse engineering your code a trivial exercise. To be clear, what I&#39;m suggesting is modify your release build configuration so that it generates debug symbols, saving both the release builds of your modules and their corresponding debug symbols in your source control system and delivering only the release builds of your modules to clients (as you do today). When a crash report comes in, you use the release build and debug symbols you archived, along with the minidump included in the crash report, to debug the crash. </p>

<p>Note: CrashRpt uses Microsoft&#39;s Debug Help library (dbghelp.dll). This library was shipped with Windows XP, but certain versions are redistributable. I recommend you to install the dbghelp.dll file, included in the source/demo attachments, along the crashrpt.dll into your application&#39;s directory to avoid the possible conflict or missing dependency issues.. A word about preferred base load addresses </p>

<p>Every executable module (EXE, DLL, OCX, whatever) has a preferred base load address. This is the address in the application&#39;s process space that the loader will try to map that module. If two or more modules list the same base load address, the loader will be forced to relocate the modules until each module loads at a unique address. Not only does this slow down the start up time of your application, but it also makes it impossible to debug fatal exceptions. In order to use the minidump file, you must ensure that your application&#39;s modules do not collide. You can use rebase.exe or manually override the preferred base load address for each conflicting module. Either way you need to make sure that your application modules always load at the same address for the minidump file to be useful. You can find more information about this in John Robbin&#39;s April 1998 MSJ column. </p>

<p>ReferencesFor additional information about topics directly related to this article, see the links below: </p>

<p>Debugging Tools for Windows. WTL Download. ZLib Compression Library. Reading Minidump Files with VS.NET. John Robbins on Crash Dumps. April 1998 MSJ Bugslayer Column. WTL Reference.  </p>

Details dialog preview window now uses system defined window color instead of white. Directory structure not saved in ZIP.  Support for use by multiple apps. Buffer overrun error when previewing files &gt; 32k. Main dialog now displays app icon.  01/12/2003 Initial release.</p>
