 title : The crest Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>CREST is an automatic test generation tool for C. </p>

<p>It works by inserting instrumentation code (using CIL) into a target program to perform symbolic execution concurrently with the concrete execution.  The generated symbolic constraints are solved (using Yices) to generate input that drive the test execution down new, unexplored program paths. </p>

<p>CREST currently reasons symbolically only about linear, integer arithmetic.  CREST should be usable on any modern Linux system.  It is usable on recent Mac OS X versions, as well, although some small modifications are needed for the code to build. </p>

<p>For further building and usage information, see the README file.  You may also want to check out the FAQ. </p>

<p>Further questions?  Contact Jacob Burnim (jburnim at cs dot berkeley dot edu) or e-mail the  CREST-users mailing list (CREST-users at googlegroups.com). </p>

<p>A short paper and tech report about some of the search strategies in CREST are available at the homepage of Jacob Burnim. </p>

<p>News:  CREST 0.1.1 is now available.  It can be downloaded from the Downloads section (or the menu bar on the right).  This is a bug fix release -- the biggest change is a fix for incorrect instrumentation for functions returning structures by value.</p>

 title : The crosswalk Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>Simple Social NetworkingCrosswalk is an engine for web-based social networking applications. </p>

<p> </p>

<p>At it&#39;s core, Crosswalk is very simple. It contains the least amount of features needed to be a fully functioning social networking application. These features include the ability to support Users, Friendships, Accounts, Tags, Comments, and, most importantly, extensions. </p>

<p>The sky&#39;s the limitWant to add photo or video sharing? How about allowing each user to have their own blog?  </p>

<p>Future DevelopmentCrosswalk is currently being developed in php(!) on top of the CodeIgniter framework. Once version 1.0 is released, a python, ruby, and java implementation will soon follow.</p>

 title : The crush-tools Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>CRUSH (Custom Reporting Utilities for SHell) is a collection of tools for processing delimited-text data from the command line or in shell scripts. </p>

<p>For help getting started using CRUSH, or to see a demo of what it can do, try the CrushTutorial.  For a list of the utilities provided in CRUSH and links to their documentation, see the UserDocs.  Or see ApplicationDevelopmentWithCrush for a detailed look at writing applications using the CRUSH toolkit. </p>

Check out the sourcecode, read the development guidelines, be sure to sign the CLA, and post your patches to the discussion group.  If you want to help but don&#39;t know what to work on, the &quot;Issues&quot; tab above may contain items that interest you.</p>
 title : The crusty Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>C.R.US.T.Y.a.k.a. &#39;Consoles &#39;r us- thank you!&#39;Tools for Travelers to the TextyverseThere are many  excellent console-based tools and CRUSTY packages lots of them together into one convenient make file that includes  config files, installers,  tools and tips to make best use of: </p>

<p>svn w3m screen snownews midnight commander   emacs, vim, or even nano (if you are so inclined) bash On install, CRUSTY&#39;s  files are placed under $(DESTDIR)/opt/crusty/xyz  </p>

<p>so its easy to uninstall CRUSTY.    Not currently included, but coming soon, is support for: </p>

<p>script-based XML tools dot mutt latex gnuplot procmail Good old-fashioned UNIX  text processing languages like m4, gawk, etc And all those other neat tools for text mode.  </p>

<p>Why CRUSTY?But why travel to the textyverse? Well, maybe you never left it: </p>

<p>Despite decades of construction of more elaborate tools, 80% of the documents in most organizations aren&#39;t organized any better than plain old text files.  So, reality check, we already live in the textyverse. And that&#39;s a very good thing: </p>

<p>text is configurable :   automation is possible as per your requirements (use of Perl/ Ruby/ Rexx/ Python/ Gawk/ shell scripting/ etc/ etc) text is inter-operable : look at the amazing success of XML and RSS; text works anywhere : with an xterm or putty, you can rule the world from  at any coffee shop or trailer park; text is accessible : to  folks with visual impairment. text tools are mature : midnight commander, emacs, vim, screen, all those wonderful UNIX version control tools, etc etc etc; text is fast :  using commands from command line is faster than gui-ing. low bandwidth, roars down those internet pipes into, say, PDAs- which can be  crucial in crisis situations;  best of all,  text looks so dull : so  no one   pollutes the textyverse with garish eye-candy (read pop-up ads)  so no  brain decay (but it may cause cancer of the semi-colon).    </p>

<p>Too Many MetaphorsAnd we aren&#39;t the only ones to sing the praises of the textyverse.  Neil Stephenson argues in  &#39;In the beginning was the command line&#39; that: </p>

<p>By doing everything with GUIs rather than simply words,  we are  limiting ourselves.      Working at command line level --working with words -- is completely different from working with GUIs, and Stephenson is concerned with what is lost in the transition.   When we are buying a GUI-focussed operating system: What we&#39;re really buying is a system of metaphors. And -- much more important -- what we&#39;re buying into is the underlying assumption that metaphors are a good way to deal with the world.  </p>

<p>To be sure, there are limits to Stephenson&#39;s argument: </p>

<p>  </p>

<p>Ultimately, there is no escape from metaphors. What we see and do is constrained by the tools used to look and touch. And those tools have their own ghosts:  e.g.  The UNIX textyverse is governed but its own metaphors  in particular: pipe-and-filter.     From a usability perspective, many users would thank you for... Building them a  simple environment that succinctly supports their standard work cliches.  </p>

<p>Of course our GUI metaphors are more restrictive than the textyverse... We&#39;ve only been using them for a decade or three.  We should not stop research into fledging ideas like the guiverse... ...Merely  because  other paradigms are centuries older and have more productive tools  The Dizzy Heights of TextyverseWhat is true is that it is much harder to  program the guiverse than the textyverse.  </p>

<p>Sure, the textyverse learning curve can be shallow (takes a long time to reach a high level of expertise)  But the learning curve goes much higher in the textyverse than the guiverse  And don&#39;t give me no grief about  intensive visual environments being inherently more productive than the textyverse.  Bah! Humbug!  Yes, the guiverse is more motivating for beginers. But the guiverse isn&#39;t    necessarily more productive for power users. For example,  </p>

<p> The UNIX metaphors encourage the rapid construction of ensembles of tools not monolithic packages but large libraries of tiny tools that can be quickly wired together to perform novel tasks And those ensembles can create a different user environment that support a very different style of inter-action So the UNIX metaphors let you quickly define and deploy new metaphaors Something that is very hard to do given the strict rules and restrictions of the  guiverse&#39;s padded playground. For another example, </p>

<p>In the guiverse we can only see specific instances (e.g. a directory called &#39;home&#39;). But in the textyverse we can build abstractions (e.g. replace a specific concept like &#39;tim&#39; with &#39;x of type person&#39;). Then we can write functions that work for all &#39;person&#39;s, not just &#39;tim&#39;.  So in textyverse we can reason about abstractions,  and abstractions about abstractions  and abstractions about abstractions about... (Help! Blacking out! Not enough oxygen up here!)    </p>

<p>Its time for my pill now </p>

<p>Sure, the above is a little  close to the edge and OTT and but, heh, it was  fun to write.  </p>

<p>And what would have happened, I wonder, if Jobs and Gates had taken that wrong turn at Albuquerque, missed Xerox PARC, and ended up in Bell Labs in the 1990s. Would everyone be using Acme instead of the guiverse? </p>

<p>Anyway... </p>

<p>Getting CRUSTY   </p>

<p>Install  Get a gmail address; e.g. your.name@gmail.com mkdir $HOME/svns cd $HOME/svns svn checkout https://crusty.googlecode.com/svn/ crusty --username your.name cd crusty/trunk &amp;&amp; make &amp;&amp; make install . ~/.bash_profile . ~/.bashrc Enter screen and enjoy your travels to the textyverse. </p>

 title : The cryptanalysis-of-hitag2 Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>cryptanalysis-of-hitag2, </p>
 title : The crystalgisutilities Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>crystal gis utilities used by crystal gis incorporated., </p>
 title : The crystalsaf Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>About Crystal Crystal is a static analysis framework built as an Eclipse plugin. It&#39;s primary goals are to teach students about static analysis and to provide a way for researchers to prototype analyses. </p>

<p>You may create new analyses by extending Crystal with another Eclipse plugin. Crystal supports features such as branch-sensitivity, annotation extraction, exceptional control flow, and three address code. The classes used in Crystal are based on the abstractions of lattices and flow functions, thus making it easy to go from a formally defined analysis to a prototype. </p>

<p>DocumentationWe now have Javadocs of the Crystal APIs. </p>

<p>Tutorial at ECOOP 2009The tutorial &quot;Crystal–izing Sophisticated Code Analyses&quot; has been accepted to ECOOP 2009! If you&#39;d like a hands-on experience using Crystal, please meet us at ECOOP 2009 from July 6-10 in Genova, Italy. Our tutorial will be aimed at both educators who would like to use Crystal in the classroom and researchers who would like to write their own Crystal analyses. </p>

<p>Tutorial Presentation </p>

<p>Tutorial Notes </p>

 title : The cs-4750-group-project Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>DotNetNuke is an open source web application framework ideal for creating, deploying and managing interactive web, intranet and extranet sites. It is very well supported, just take a look at snowcovered.com. Unfortunately, VB and C# programmers don&#39;t cooperate as best they should, and take a mutually exclusive choice between the languages. This is unfortunate because DotNetNuke is a very well developed framework for ASP.NET that a lot of C# programmers do not want to look at. In an attempt to open it up to a wider audience, we have converted the VB code into C#. Today, Oct. 28, 2006 we have released the first successful build in C#. Please support the authors at DotNetNuke.com for their work, and report bugs in the C# code base to us. To avoid forking the code, we will only update the code when a new release of the VB code. </p>

<p>2007-0607: Here we grow again. Jule Bostick has been added as a member to the team. He brings with him 5+ years of professional ASP.NET development. Welcome aboard. Aside from that, I will be updating a lot of fixed I&#39;ve made to the code over the past few months including javascript errors, client api, and adsi membership modules.  </p>

<p>2007-03-31: The project welcomes Jason Thomas, who has picked up my slack and was finally able to get it to load and run for the most part. He&#39;s still getting am still getting null exceptions from many of the modules and invalid type errors in some some areas. But with his energy to the being brought to the team, I&#39;ll re-establish my interest and work with him and finish the conversion once and for all. Thanks to Jason everybody!  </p>

<p>2007-01-22: Updated to v4.4.0; now time to debug. </p>

<p>2007-01-12: updated to v4.3.7; next is 4.4.0 </p>

<p>2007-01-11: updated to v4.3.6 </p>

<p>2007-01-07: finished updating the trunk from v4.3.4 to v4.3.5. It has also been tagged under tags/v4.3.5. </p>

<p>2007-01-06: Just tagged v4.3.4 as a workable solution. Please report all issues with the project here. In the mean time I will be updating the code base up to 4.4.0 and then come back and fix all the issues you post here. </p>

<p>-- Andrew Cates -- catesandrew@gmail.com</p>

 title : The csed Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>csEXWB is a C# .NET 2.0 control that creates, hosts and sinks the events of the original Webbrowser control (Not .NET or any other wrapper). Advanced customization and total control over the Webbrowser control are achieved via implementation of a number of interfaces, along with the addition of many methods, properties, events and a COM library. </p>

<p>Here are some of the features of this control: </p>

<p>Can easily be extended by adding other interfaces and methods, unlike .NET or any other Webbrowser wrapper  All the basics expected from a Webbrowser wrapper are implemented Setting/getting UI, and DL control flags Handling of context menus, keyboard, registry, security manager, script errors, popups, authentication, security problems, font size, messageboxes, file downloads Monitor HTTP and HTTPS request and response headers for all resources, images, sounds, scripts, etc, with the opportunity to add your own headers When a resource has been fully downloaded and read by MSHTML engine Built in onload and onunload events for top level and any frames/iframes Frameset aware. All the relevant routines check for frames Full drag and drop support Perform automation tasks, click button, check radio, select list items,... Load HTML content specifying BaseURL Use the control as an MSHTML editor MSHTML as a UI-less HTML parser helper class Has no dependencies on MSHTML interop. All of the interfaces, enums and structs are defined within the project A comprehensive demo that demonstrates how to use most of the functionality offered by this control beyond the basics. </p>

<p>An HTTP and HTTPS request and response header viewer A complete DOM viewer. Multi tab simulation. Cookies and Cache viewer and remover, per site or all, File download status viewer. Retrieve information from document object. An HTML editor with edit, source, and preview panes. Many editing functionalities, internal and external drag drop, font, color, inserting items such as table, reading and setting properties such as table cell, underline text ... An UI_Less HTML parser How to use window.external function Popup handling HTMLDialogs handling Find and highlight Webbrowser automation Basic authentication</p>
 title : The csexwb2 Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>CSIsat is an interpolating decision procedure for the quantifier-free theory of rational linear arithmetic and equality with uninterpreted function symbols.  Our implementation combines the efficiency of linear programming for solving the arithmetic part with the efficiency of a SAT solver to reason about the boolean structure. </p>

<p>CSIsat Project Home PagePlease visit the CSIsat Project Home Page DocumentationTool paper at CAV 2008: CSIsat: A Tool for LA+EUF Interpolation Proc. CAV&#39;08, LNCS 5123, pages 304-308, Springer-Verlag, 2008. API and source code documentation Tutorial coming soon. Quick reference DownloadsThe download list provides archived source code and binaries for released versions Check out the latest version To build from source code, read the installation instructions Problem ReportsMail to: Dirk Beyer (first.last@sfu.ca) or Damien Zufferey (first.last@epfl.ch) AcknowledgementsWe thank many other people for their contributions.</p>

 title : The css-boilerplate Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>Boilerplate: noun standardized pieces of text for use as clauses in contracts or as part of a computer program. </p>

<p>As one of the original authors of Blueprint CSS I&#39;ve decided to re-factor my ideas into a stripped down framework which provides the bare essentials to begin any project. This framework will be lite and strive not to suggest un-semantic naming conventions. You&#39;re the designer and your craft is important.  </p>

<p>If you prefer: </p>

<p> { float: left; width: 240px; margin-right: 110px; }over </p>

<p>class=&quot;column span-2 append-1&quot;then you&#39;re in the right place my friend. </p>

<p>Releases16 Dec 2007 Version 0.3 - Fixed IE centering but. Related ticket that explains the fix. Books you should read:Bulletproof Web Design CSS Mastery Designing with Web Standards Pro CSS Techniques</p>

 title : The css-palette Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>CSS Redundancy CheckerA simple script that, given a CSS stylesheet and either a .txt file listing URLs of HTML files, or a directory of HTML files, will iterate over them all and list the CSS statements in the stylesheet which are never called in the HTML. </p>

<p>Basically, it helps you keep your CSS files relevant and compact. And it&#39;s reasonably accurate. </p>

<p>Usagecss-redundancy-checker.rb [cssfile] [directory of html files OR .txt file listing urls to use]Requirementsyou&#39;ll need Rubygems and Hpricot, plus a reasonably up-to-date version of Ruby (built on 1.8.5; should be fine on at least 1.8.4). </p>

<p>More detailed instructions (if the above wasn&#39;t clear enough)First, you&#39;ll need Ruby and Rubygems installed. That&#39;s left as an exercise for the reader. </p>

<p>Next, you&#39;ll need the Hpricot gem: </p>

<p>sudo gem install hpricot	 Pick the most recent version for your OS (mswin32 for Windows, ruby for anything else) </p>

<p>Once you&#39;ve got all that, you should be set. Now, get the redundancy checker script (or update it to the latest version): </p>

<p>svn checkout http://css-redundancy-checker.googlecode.com/svn/trunk/ css-redundancy-checker	 Navigate to the directory you&#39;ve checked the code out to. Then, it&#39;s just a case of doing this: </p>

<p>ruby css-redundancy-checker.rb [cssfile] [directory of html files OR .txt file listing urls to use]	 The first argument should be a CSS file. The second argument should EITHER be a directory, containing HTML files, or a .txt file with one URL per line for an HTML file. The script will process all the relevant files, and at the end, list any CSS statements which are not relevant to ANY of the HTML files. </p>

<p>NotesThe script will NOT work with incomplete HTML files (eg: template components, partial fragments, etc). You should only use it on complete HTML, either in the form of flat files, or rendered output from your web application. </p>

<p>Bugs and correspondance...should be addressed to tom@infovore.org </p>

<p>--- Released under the MIT License.</p>

 title : The cssgenerator Open Source Project on Open Hub
 title : The cssmin Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>cssmin reduces the size of stylesheet definitions by removing all unneeded whitespaces and comments.  </p>

<p>Nothing special but has the same syntax as jsmin. </p>

<p>Requirements:PHP 5.x Syntax:string cssmin::minify(string $css, mixed [$options])$css = stylesheet definitions as string. $options = array or comma separated list of options. Optionsremove-last-semicolon: Removes the last semicolon in the style definition of an element (activated by default). preserve-urls: Preserves every url defined in an url()-expression. This option is only required if you have defined really uncommon urls with multiple spaces or combination of colon, semi-colon, braces with leading or following spaces. Example:include(&quot;cssmin.php&quot;);</p>

<p>// without options
<br/>file_put_contents(&quot;path/to/target.css&quot;, cssmin::minify(file_get_contents(&quot;path/to/source.css&quot;)));</p>

<p>// with the options remove-last-semicolon and preserve-urls
<br/>file_put_contents(&quot;path/to/target.css&quot;, cssmin::minify(file_get_contents(&quot;path/to/source.css&quot;), &quot;remove-last-semicolon,preserve-urls&quot;));</p>
 title : The cssutils Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>cssutilsA Python package to parse and build CSS Cascading Style Sheets.  </p>

<p>Actually querying a parsed stylesheet on a given document or element is planned for probably 0.9.7, for now see the example examples/style.py. </p>

<p>example# -*- coding: utf-8 -*-
<br/>import cssutils</p>

<p>css = u&#39;&#39;&#39;/* a comment with umlaut ä */ 
<br/>     @namespace html &quot;http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml&quot;;
<br/>     html|a { color:red; }&#39;&#39;&#39;
<br/>sheet = cssutils.parseString(css)</p>

<p>for rule in sheet:
<br/>    if rule.type == rule.STYLE_RULE:
<br/>        for property in rule.style:
<br/>            property.value = &#39;green&#39; 
<br/>            property.priority = &#39;IMPORTANT&#39;
<br/>        rule.style[&#39;margin&#39;] = &#39;01.0eM&#39; # or: (&#39;1em&#39;, &#39;important&#39;)</p>

<p>sheet.encoding = &#39;ascii&#39;
<br/>sheet.namespaces[&#39;xhtml&#39;] = &#39;http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml&#39;
<br/>sheet.namespaces[&#39;atom&#39;] = &#39;http://www.w3.org/2005/Atom&#39;
<br/>sheet.add(&#39;atom|title {color: #000000 !important}&#39;)
<br/>sheet.add(&#39;@import &quot;sheets/import.css&quot;;&#39;)results in  </p>

<p>@charset &quot;ascii&quot;;
<br/>@import &quot;sheets/import.css&quot;;
<br/>/* a comment with umlaut \E4  */
<br/>@namespace xhtml &quot;http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml&quot;;
<br/>@namespace atom &quot;http://www.w3.org/2005/Atom&quot;;
<br/>xhtml|a {
<br/>    color: green !important;
<br/>    margin: 1em
<br/>    }
<br/>atom|title {
<br/>    color: #000 !important
<br/>    }development version0.9.7 is in alpha status. Planned is an implementation of CSS Variables, see the docs in trunk for more info. </p>

<p>0.9.7a4 improves implementation of CSSVariables a bit more 0.9.7a4 improves compatibility to the new CSSOM spec including some bugfixes 0.9.7a3 CHANGES CSSRule constanst value due to a spec change! 0.9.7a3 improves parsing of FUNCTION values (e.g. for PrinceXML properties) 0.9.7a2 fixes &amp;nbsp;Issue #32&amp;nbsp; and &amp;nbsp;Issue #33&amp;nbsp; (Imports from different folders work now) 0.9.7a2 improves parsing of unknown @rules like @bottom which use function values like content: attr(href) 0.9.7 improves parsing speed by quite a bit  current versionRelease 0.9.6final 091007. A few non-backwards compatible changes have been made, please see the online docs help to migrate to 0.9.6. See the docs for full detailsMore info on the pages or downloads referred to on the sitebar.</p>

 title : The ctxnotes Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>ConTeXt 学习笔记， Using MkIV这份文档仅仅是我个人学习 ConTeXt 过程中所获取的一些我认为比较重要的知识的汇总，它也许有些凌乱，不是面面俱到，有些知识讲述地过于浅薄甚至出现了认识错误，这都是因为我还在学习中。 </p>

<p>由于自知能力有限，我没有将这份文档写成一部 ConTeXt 教程的欲望。官方的文档非常全面，如果想掌握 ConTeXt，我推荐你去阅读它们，当然，得具有一定的英语阅读能力。我写这份文档的出发点与你之所以读到它是一样的，都是出于对 ConTeXt 的喜爱。 </p>

<p>本文档有许多内容是只适于 Linux 环境，特别是 ConTeXt 环境搭建方面的内容。Windows 或 Mac OS 环境中的 ConTeXt 我从未尝试过。 </p>

<p>近期计划对已有内容进行大手术，让它看上去是真正的学习笔记，而不是一份教程，因为官方的教程已经足够详细； 添加制作演示文档的内容，这个是我最近比较喜欢学习的内容，因为不久要做一次报告； 添加 ConTeXt 文档项目管理的内容，写大文档，这个比较实用。</p>

 title : The cunitescore Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>The cUniteScore project provides simple Actionscript 2 and Actionscript 3 classes for your Flash games to implement the scores on major game portals, all in one. The game swf will detect which portal it is hosted on, and select the right score submission method. </p>

<p>AS3Validated game portalsbubblebox.com kongregate.com mochiads.com leaderboards pepere.org (issue on firefox with mochiads version control?)  nonoba.com games-garden.com jeuxgratuits.net (issue on firefox with mochiads version control?)  gamegarage.co.uk Invision Power Board (IPB) Forum running ibProArcade 3.40+ (issue with mochiads version control?) Invision Power Board (IPB) Forum running Arcade Enhanced 6.15+ (issue with mochiads version control?) Vbulletin (VB) Forum running ibProArcade v2.67+ Simple Machines Forum (SMF) E-Arcade 2.4.4+ mindjolt.com Implemented but not tested game portalsgamebrew.com gr8games.eu e-gierki.com (portal not yet compatible with AS3 games) AS2Be careful, using Mochiads version control for an AS2 game, will make the scores not working on many portals! </p>

<p>Validated game portalskongregate.com (won&#39;t work with mochiads version control) mochiads.com leaderboards pepere.org (issue on firefox with mochiads version control?) bubblebox.com nonoba.com games-garden.com jeuxgratuits.net (issue on firefox with mochiads version control?) gr8games.eu e-gierki.com gamegarage.co.uk Invision Power Board (IPB) Forum running ibProArcade 3.40+ (issue with mochiads version control?) Invision Power Board (IPB) Forum running Arcade Enhanced 6.15+ (issue with mochiads version control?) Vbulletin (VB) Forum running ibProArcade v2.67+ Simple Machines Forum (SMF) E-Arcade 2.4.4+ mindjolt.com Implemented but not tested game portalsxpogames.com surpassarcade.com hallpass.com (won&#39;t work with mochiads version control) z-fox.com gamebrew.com UseCodeHow do I get the sources ? How do I use the AS2 classes ? How do I use the AS3 classes ? SpecificitiesMochiads leaderboardsYou must create a leaderboard for your game on the mochiads site. You must call a specific method to inform the cUniteScore class of the leaderboard id you&#39;ve created. Mochiads leaderboards, is the default highscore system used when the game is not hosted on one of the implemented portals. NonobaYou must create a highscore for your game on the nonoba.com website. The key of your main highscore list must be &quot;totalscores&quot;. Then you can create as many highscore lists as you wish. </p>

<p>ibProArcadeThe cUniteScore system is compatible with latest ibProArcade systems. To detect that the swf is hosted on a compatible system, the game checks 2 conditions that are verified on the boards running an arcade module compatible with ibProArcade (VB ibProArcade, IPB ibProArcade, IPB Arcade Enhanced, SMF E-Arcade). </p>

<p>The game swf must be hosted in the /arcade/ (VB ibProArcade, IPB ibProArcade, IPB Arcade Enhanced) or /Games/ (SMF E-Arcade) folders. If, for example, the .swf is named myGame.swf, a text file must be present at this url : /arcade/gamedata/myGame/myGame.txt. </p>

<p>Portal ownersCould my portal be supported by the cUniteScore classes ? cUniteScore game list</p>

 title : The custom-context-menu Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>Current Version - 0.6.2Javascript and Actionscript 3 code to enable a custom made right-click events in Flash / Flex. </p>

<p>ReferencesThis solution is integrated into Adobe Captivate 4 as a default method for capturing right click events in Actionscript3 / Flex based movies. </p>

<p>More information: http://blogs.adobe.com/captivate/2009/01/adding_rightclick_in_captivate_1.html </p>

<p>About The ProjectThe idea is fairly simple: </p>

<p>1-Use Javascript in the HTML container page to disable the right-click on top of the SWF. </p>

<p>2-Capture the event and pass it to a function that communicates with Flash via the External Interface </p>

<p>3-In Actionscript the function called from Javascript does whatever you need to display your own custom context-menu. </p>

<p>Check out the download section for source code and working demo.</p>
 title : The custom-field-error Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>custom_field_error allows you to easily setup custom HTML to be displayed when there is a validation issue with a form. You can setup a different view for every model, or setup a view in one model and have that view be used as the default for all the other models. You can also explicitly override the default view you have chosen by defining another view within another model. Last but not least, you can choose to leave the Rails default view for whatever models you want. </p>

<p>It sounds like a lot, but it&#39;s actually very simple. Just put the following line in your model, in this case a User model: </p>

<p>custom_field_error &quot;?</p>

<p>Unknown end tag for </p>

<p>&quot; </p>

<p>Now, if there was an error on a field called &quot;name&quot; in a form, it would look like: </p>

<p> </p>

<p>However, this custom view would only be for the User view. To make this view the default view, simply set the second argument to &#39;default&#39;: </p>

<p>custom_field_error &quot;?</p>

<p>Unknown end tag for </p>

<p>&quot;, &#39;default&#39; </p>

<p>However, what if I now want to set a special view for my Project model? Simple. Just set custom_field_error like usual and it&#39;ll override the default view: </p>

<p>custom_field_error &quot;?&quot; </p>

<p>Voila! The plugin will automatically figure out what view it needs to display and display it. </p>

<p>Enjoy. If you have any questions, feel free to email me. </p>

<p>NOTE: Google Code doesn&#39;t like square brackets, but they&#39;re there!</p>
 title : The custom-xml-serialization Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>CustomXMLSerialization is a Ruby on Rails plug-in that allows you more freedom in how your model objects are serialized using the to_xml method in ActiveRecord::XmlSerialization.  Your ActiveRecord subclasses can specify a complete custom serialization, without having to override to_xml in each object. </p>

<p>You can specify exactly which fields to include in a serialization, apply custom tag names, enclose data in CDATA constructs, and unwrap superfluous second-level associations into more brief first-level fields. </p>

<p>For more information and examples of usage, visit the overview page at http://code.google.com/p/custom-xml-serialization/wiki/Overview</p>

 summary : <p>Search by CustromField-data. </p>

<p>Project homepage: </p>

 summary : <p>iPlus 2.0b is an iphone jailbreak software which can install packages while jailbreaking . This ruby script used for making  payload.zip with on-line customize source server like Touch Toolset:repo.sc. </p>

 title : The cwin Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>Cwin的全称为Core Window，适用与JDK1.5+。对于已有系统，Cwin是一个便捷实用的CRUD插件。可以嵌入在任何支持Servlet的Java Web应用中。对于中小型应用而言，Cwin可作为系统的基础架构。Cwin可以大大减少简单繁杂的劳动，从而将精力放在核心业务的开发上来。因为使用Cwin完成功能将不需要编写任何的代码(XML配置除外)。 Cwin的核心概念是Window。那么，什么是一个Window呢？比如一个User的查询与编辑功能就可以配置为一个Window。这个Window将可以完成User的CURD操作。包含查询、排序、分页展示、验证等等完备的功能。 </p>

<p>Cwin的目的，为了使Java的Web开发人员能从简单繁杂的劳动中解脱出来。比如单表操作、简单的基础数据维护操作、数据查询操作。我们都知道这些功能都很简单，但是麻雀虽小，五脏（CRUD四个操作、加上验证、分页、查询等等）俱全，这些工作是系统中是很让人头疼的部分，因为大部分代码都在COPY或者使用代码生成器生成。开发人员哼哧哼哧弄完之后还得对功能进行各种测试。而Cwin力图使这些操作完全地自动化。事实上，现在Cwin已经可以在不写入任何代码的情况下自动配置好这些功能。 </p>

<p>Cwin很便捷:集成Cwin所需要的代价仅仅是引入jar包与资源文件，配置好Servlet与数据源就可以使用了。 </p>

<p>为什么说Cwin是一个实用的CRUD插件呢？ 我知道现在的CRUD框架生成的代码大都比较简陋，比如说遇到长字段一个表格会被撑开，录入界面只是简单的输入框，验证功能较弱... Cwin允许长字段值隐藏在表格中，在需要时可pop或以其它方式出来。 Cwin也支持录入控件的配置，支持下拉列表、文本域、还集成了当前最流行的fckeditor... Cwin支持的指定字段的查询与排序。支持数据库透明的物理翻页。 Cwin支持主从表的常规维护操作。 Cwin有很好的灵活性。 Cwin的编辑页面与表格都可以作为一个单独的模块进行引用。 ...... </p>

<p>最重要的是，完成这些工作不需要写任何的代码。只需要配置一个XML的文件。 </p>

<p>Cwin有一些比较小但非常重要的功能。 </p>

<p>1.比如说我们的用户类型在数据库中存储为数字，但我们要在表格中显示用户类型的描述。对，Cwin自动就会这么干。当然必须要为我们的用户类型配置下拉列表。下拉列表可以是固定的也可以是一个SQL查询的结果。 </p>

<p>2.如果您经常在项目中把某个下拉列表或在线编辑器在各个要使用他的页面中来回COPY。Cwin可以把这些资源统一管理。使用时只需要定义一个属性(如</p>

<p>)即可。 </p>

<p>3.允许表格显示展示数据以外的列，并支持动态URL。这样我们通过URL可以把不同的Window串起来。因为Window的各页面都可以通过URL来到达。 </p>

<p>4.允许Window动态接收参数作为window的条件与默认值，这样大大地加大了Window的灵活性。 </p>

<p>5.Cwin支持系统变量的插入。比如记录的创建时间，修改时间。当然用户也可以自定义系统变量。 </p>

<p>6.如果您使用Cwin。那么Cwin的配置文件可以作为一份不错的数据库文档。因为修改的每一个字段都必须修改配置文件才能得到体现。这样，这份文档总是最新的！ </p>

<p>Cwin的缺陷： 由于界面是自动生成，对于生成界面的美化，可以通过CSS替换。但这也有一定的限制。 所以就目前而言，Cwin用于角落里的小应用或内部人员使用的后台。是非常有帮助的。 </p>

<p>Cwin包含的组件： </p>

<p>1.Cwin包含一个基于泛型的强大JDBC工具包。提供了基于注释的简洁的事务控制器。提供了一个通用的DAO，它拥有一系列实用的方法，并包含一个数据库无关的分页查询方案。 </p>

<p>2.Cwin包含一个通用的JavaScript验证API与表单自动验证API。（目前已提供下载） </p>

<p>最新版本是2008.10.14日发布的preview1版。</p>
 title : The cwpfsamples Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>In an attempt to help others use the Microsoft Patterns and Practices Composite WPF framework (formerly Prism) this project aims to provide samples relating to usage of the framweork. </p>

<p>All examples given within this project are not meant to be used as real world projects but server as an example of how to solve common and not so common problems within real world projects. </p>

<p>I&#39;ve now migrated source and history from subversion to mercurial, follow these instructions to obtain the source. </p>

<p>Late Night 0.4 Now AvailableWell folks it&#39;s the first build of Late Night that I&#39;ve made, and keeping with the samples name it&#39;s currently 4:50am while I write this. I hope you get a bit out of this application even it it&#39;s just a little. Please by all means let me know what you think. It&#39;s very similar to Product Prism, I wanted to rewrite Product Prism to remove references to the company I work for as you may already be aware of. </p>

<p>Some new features you will find that were not in Product Prism are </p>

<p>A new login screen that demonstrates how one might implement a login screen. Use admin for the username and pass for the password when the application starts up (this is written on the dialog itself). A new splash screen demonstrating how one might show a borderless window with a progress bar and message text while the application starts. I haven&#39;t perfected this yet as I need a way for modules to register messages as they are starting up, the problem I&#39;m facing is that modules must be started on the UI thread which is not practicle for sending messages to this dialog. An about screen that can be found from Help&gt;About which demonstrates presenting IModule data for modules found from the applications IModuleEnumerator. I&#39;d like to extend this further by getting some of the assembly information which could be useful in order to show the assembly version and an icon if it exists. Document model has been enhanced to provide feedback via events for opening/closing documents, a cancellable event can be used while closing a document which will abandon a close operation. Any System.Windows.FrameworkElement object can be used for a document view, it no longer needs to be a System.Windows.Controls.UserControl. Tabs now have a close button with functionality that reflects the IE7 tabbed browsing mechanism. A new use-case module has been used to replace the LinePlanModule from Product Prism. This new module represents a common &quot;Notes&quot; interface where notes can be created/deleted/edited. This module extends on the LinePlanModule by </p>

<p>Providing a better static service implementation Providing a &quot;New&quot; command to create new notes. Allowing a user to &quot;Delete&quot; a note. I will be extending this module at a later date to provide user feedback by preventing a close if the note has not been saved. I will also provide a mechanism for notes to be serialized by a pluggable persistence mechanism (DB/WS/File). </p>

<p> </p>

<p>NoticeI&#39;m working on a new project called LateNight, this project is a reiteration of ProductPrism but is a rewrite for several reasons, one being for the new Microsoft.Practices.Composite libraries for Composite WPF. </p>

<p>Late Night has a lot of new features that Product Prism doesn&#39;t, such as </p>

<p>An about box: that demonstrates how to present the user with currently loaded mosules A login screen: demonstrating how and where you could present the user with a dialog asking for credentials. A splash screen: Showing one possible way of handling a splash screen, this does not currently support feedback from other modules though I am looking at ways for this to be handled. </p>

<p>Check out the late night solution from the mercurial source repository. </p>

<p>Mercurial AccessIf you&#39;re new to mercurial and are wondering how to check-out the source-code take a look at Mercurial. </p>

<p>Looking for SupportI&#39;d love to hear what others are doing, please feel free to communicate with me on the issues section for any issues relating to the project or through the groups hosted at the Composite WPF site for general Composite WPF discussion. </p>

<p>Disclaimer I &quot;Brett Ryan&quot;, as the originator of this project am new to all areas of what this project is trying to acheive and hope that I can gather positive feedback and support on how I have solved some of the problems presented.</p>

 title : The d-phoenix Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>基于 D 2.0 + druntime，编译器推荐 DMD 2.0 最新版本(注意:目前 d-phoenix 仅兼容 Windows ，其他平台暂未列入计划中)。 </p>

<p>初始版本 0.5.1 推荐使用 DMD 2.019，因为这个版本还没有移植到 druntime 上。 如果想要体验 druntime ，请使用 DMD 2.021 或 DMD 2.0 最新版本并 Check out 最新版本。 </p>

<p>老实说，我也不知道这个项目会做到什么地步。 现在已经完成常见数据结构，并发布初始版本 0.5.1。 并行/并发这块设计还没想好，可能会对 Thread 有些增改。 已经有了些概念，而且也做了些封装。 </p>

<p>在做完数据结构这块，接下来会做一些国际化的准备。 因为线程是带有区域信息的，先做这些对以后的工作能提供莫大的便利。 </p>

<p>目前在线程提供支持方面，仅仅实现 Windows 平台，并且优先考虑支持 Windows 平台，不过同时也保留了其他平台实现的接口，且有些函数已经兼容 Linux平台。 </p>

<p>数据结构是平台独立的。 </p>

<p>关于性能：只举一例，当年 STL 出世的时候，着实嘲笑了 C 库的 qsort 一把。本人也很自豪的说，d-phoenix 项目的排序功能性能完全可以媲美 STL 的 sort 函数。不客气的说，只高不低，哇哈哈~ </p>

<p>Change Log: </p>

<p>2008-11-24 </p>

<p>增加 API 文档(简体中文)。 </p>

<p>2008-11-20 </p>

<p>释出初始版本 0.5.1。这个版本中完成了大部分常见数据结构，以及部分编解码( </p>

<p>全部几种在 Unicode 上)和线程操作 API。 </p>

<p>此外，还完成了 C Runtime 封装和基础函数功能。 </p>

<p>详情请参见 Release Note 。</p>

 title : The dailydev-resources Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>English text follows. </p>

<p>Daluang adalah sebuah program untuk membaca Wikipedia tanpa memerlukan koneksi Internet. Hal ini dilakukan dengan cara membaca database Wikipedia lokal yang telah diunduh sebelumnya. </p>

<p>Data yang dibaca Daluang bersumber dari XML Database Dump yang disediakan oleh Wikipedia. Daluang mengkonversinya menjadi format yang lebih efisien dalam hal penyimpanan dan waktu pembacaan. Daluang menyediakan data yang ada dengan bantuan aplikasi web kecil berbasiskan Django. Anda dapat membaca data yang ada dengan peramban favorit Anda maupun dengan peramban spesial yang juga datang bersama Daluang (berbasiskan Firefox). Daluang juga mendukung penggunaan Xapian dan akan menggunakannya untuk melakukan pencarian dalam data jika Anda memasang indeks data. </p>

<p>Harap diingat bahwa pada saat ini Daluang masih berada pada tahap awal pengembangan. Banyak fitur yang direncanakan yang belum ada pada implementasi yang ada saat ini. Pengembangan Daluang bersifat terbuka sehingga Anda juga dapat ikut serta di dalamnya. </p>

<p>Daluang is an application for reading Wikipedia without Internet connection. It is done by reading a local wikipedia database that has been downloaded already. </p>

<p>Data that is read by Daluang originates from XML Database Dump provided by Wikipedia. Daluang converts it to a more efficient format in terms of storage capacity and access time. Daluang serves the content using a small web application based on Django. You can read the available data using your favorite browser or a special browser that comes with Daluang (based on Firefox). Daluang supports Xapian and will use it for content searching if you install the data index. </p>

<p>Please keep in mind, at the moment, Daluang is still in early stage of development. Many planned features might not available yet in the current implementation. Daluang development is open so you can participate in it. </p>

<p>Debian&#39;s control files are maintained at http://daluang.googlecode.com/svn/debian-packages/ </p>

<p>Git repository is available at http://github.com/fajran/daluang/</p>

 title : The daqmxbase-swig Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>The National Instruments NI-DAQmx Base C API for data acquisition supports most National Instruments data acquisition hardware. This SWIG wrapper gives you access to the library from scripting languages. </p>

<p>The NI-DAQmx Base library is available for Windows, Mac OS X, and Linux, as well as certain PDAs. The initial focus of this project is support for the NI USB-6008/6009 devices using the Ruby programming language. So some of the API that doesn&#39;t apply to the USB-6009 isn&#39;t wrapped yet, and the support is Ruby-specific in places. </p>

<p>I&#39;d love to extend the support to other languages, but this is my first SWIG project and I don&#39;t know all the ins and outs of the language yet.</p>
 title : The daremusicfixer Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>AboutThe LG Dare&#39;s music player is very picky about ID3 tags on mp3s.  Complicated ID3 tags confuse the Dare and cause album art to not show up.  This program scans all mp3s in a folder and will properly format the ID3 tags so that album art is displayed on the Dare.  If album art isn&#39;t present, the program automatically attempts to retrieve it from amazon, seamless to the user.  Also, tracks of an album on the Dare are listed in alphabetical order which contradicts what most people are used to when listening to cds.  This program also fixes the names of the songs so they show up in the proper order. </p>

<p>DownloadWindows executable is available in the downloads section.  Requires the .NET 2.0 Framework - Download Here. </p>

<p>How to UseConnect your phone or sd card as a usb mass storage device. Copy your mp3&#39;s to my_music Run DareMusicFixer Click go, select your my_music folder Your music will be properly tagged for album track order, and album art will be downloaded from amazon if not already present.  If the art cannot be found, or a tag is missing, an edit tag dialog will appear, where you can modify the name of the album, artist, track, and track number. When the process completes, load up my music on your phone and enjoy a more organized music player! TroubleshootingIf you don&#39;t see any results, try accessing My Music from your phone without the sd card in first. </p>

<p>ContactIf you have any issues, don&#39;t hesitate to contact me, my information can be found on the right.</p>

 title : The darksigns Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>A collection of service/manager pairs, miscellaneous utilities and data structures shared by Project Darkstar developers. </p>

<p>Currently the project containsDarkstarIntegrationTest - An integration testing framework for running tests against a full-featured Darkstar Server DarkstarRPC - RPC API for simplified communication between Darkstar server and clients DataStructures - Currently only a linked list and a reference-reference. AdminClient - Provides a means of connecting with Darkstar and doing some &quot;server side&quot; manipulation of the data by means of actions written for specific needs. DataInspector (Service/Manager) - Provides basic data-browsing functionality to the AdminClient HotBackup (Service/Manager) - A very simple service that just executes db4.5_hotbackup at a given interval as long as the server is running (this should be done by an other process in a live environment - but as a snap-shot tool it works quite well) Identity (Service/Manager) - A very simple service that gives access to the Identity of a transaction Other projects for Project Darkstardarkstar-exp - Experimental changes to the Darkstar core. darkstar-examples - If you are looking for examples to copy-paste from. (would someone start and maintain this project) Participate in this project?If you have some general purpose code for Project Darkstar that you would like to share - of if you just want to help improve the contributions in this project please leave me a mail on &quot;greisen at gmail dot com&quot;</p>
 title : The darkstar-contrib Open Source Project on Open Hub
 title : The darkstar-exp Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>Darkstar EXP is a modified version of the official Project Darkstar Server distribution. It contains experimental new features which do not exist in the vanilla Darkstar. If experience shows that some of the features are useful, they may be included in the vanilla Darkstar by its developers. Individual features can be enabled and disabled by editing the darkstar-exp.properties file. </p>

<p>The project files are available in Maven format in a Maven repository (see MavenIntegration). </p>

<p>If you wish to contribute to Darkstar EXP, contact the project owner (username@gmail.com). You should provide a patch for your modifications and unit tests which verify the new functionality. You will then get write access to the source repository so that you can maintain your own features. </p>

<p>Current FeaturesTransparentReferences - Avoid manual management of ManagedReferences (by Esko Luontola, since 0.9.6_2) Decoupled AppContext from its implementation details to allow mocking the whole Darkstar (by Esko Luontola, since 0.9.6_1) Mocking support to help testing Darkstar applications (by Esko Luontola, since 0.9.6_1) Also have a look at related projects: mocksgs and darkstar-integration-test Interpret the application root in the application properties file as relative to the properties file, instead of the working directory (by Esko Luontola, since 0.9.6_0) In Progress(None) </p>

<p>Planned FeaturesData garbage collection Refactoring of serialized data Indexing ManagedObjects and their fields, similar to how RDBMSs index database table columns</p>
 title : The darkstar-mysql-service Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>This is a service written for Project Darkstar to interface with a MySQL database. It is for now a quite naive implementation that does not try to keep PD and MySQL completely in sync, but rather copy things lazily from PD to MySQL, and giving direct read access to MySQL from PD. </p>

<p>Get StartedInstallationInstructions : the name says it ExecutingQueries : Explains how to use the MySQLManager from your application.</p>

 title : The dase Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>What is DASe?DASe (Digital Archive Services) is a lightweight digital asset repository.  DASe provides a platform for users to store, catalog, aggregate, and share images, audio, video, and documents.  End-users can search or browse items in DASe, and can create &quot;sets&quot; to save, share or present in a simple slideshow format.  DASe also includes an administrative interface for creating new collections, uploading new items, and adding metadata to existing items. </p>

<p>In addition to the web interface, all of the DASe functionality is available through Atom/AtomPub web services.      </p>

<p>DASe was developed by Liberal Arts Instructional Technology Services at the University of Texas at Austin. The current installation at UT Austin includes over 4 million pieces of metadata about 300K+ audio, video, images, and document files. Public beta release      is scheduled for Dec 2008. </p>

<p>What technologies does DASe use?DASe is written in PHP and can use MySQL, PostgreSQL, or SQLite as a backend. The DASe code base also includes some client utilities written in Python (including a small GUI file uploader) written in Python.</p>

 title : The database-counters Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>MOVEDMoved to http://github.com/mikedemers/database-counters/tree/master </p>

<p>Database CountersAdds two database counters to the log for a request: </p>

<p>total number of requests that were made total number of rows that were returned ExampleEnabling in a Controller: </p>

<p>class ApplicationController &lt; ActionController::Base
<br/>  # ...</p>

<p>  database_counters :on</p>

<p>  # ...
<br/>endWill result in log output that ends like so: </p>

<p>Completed in 0.05835 (17 reqs/sec) | Rendering: 0.00007 (0%) | DB: 0.00265 (4%) Calls: 5 Rows: 6 | 200 OK [http://localhost/]Installationscript/plugin install http://database-counters.googlecode.com/svn/tags/current/database_counters</p>

 title : The dataturbine Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>Welcome to the Google Code home of the open source Data Turbine initiative. The Data Turbine is a java-based network ring buffer for streaming numeric, audio, video, text and binary data across a user-defined network topology. Data is streamed over TCP, primary access is via the Java API or Tomcat/WebDAV server. </p>

<p>NSF’s vision of large-scale sensor-based Observing Systems, to address the National Research Council’s “Grand Challenges” for environmental science, relies on robust cyberinfrastructure. Streaming data middleware is an essential component of this cyberinfrastructure, providing the foundation for reliable data acquisition and instrument management services. The environmental science and engineering communities are currently engaged in the early planning and development phases of the next generation of large-scale sensor-based observing systems. </p>

<p>Please see http://dataturbine.org/ or the sidebar links to learn more. </p>

<p>Please join rbnb-commits if you want email on Subversion commits. </p>

<p>For older versions, please see the neesforge site until the quota increase arrives. </p>

<p> </p>

<p>The Open Source Data Turbine Initiative is sponsored by NSF award #OCI-0722067</p>

 title : The datautils Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>UPDATE: Moved to GitHubhttp://github.com/adzap/date_time_text_field_helpers </p>

<p>No more updates will be submitted here. </p>

<p>DescriptionThis Ruby on Rails plugin provides a set of form helpers for dates and time that output text fields for each date/time component instead of the select dropdowns which the standard date helpers use. It can make for more efficient data entry using the keyboard. It uses the rails built-in multi-parameter handling the same as the date select helpers do. </p>

<p>It is best combined with a plugin like validates_date_time (http://svn.viney.net.nz/things/rails/plugins/validates_date_time/) to do the date and time validation for you. The standard rails date helpers rely on the limited options in the dropdowns to avoid the need for proper date validation. But see what happens when you enter 30th February and notice that it silently becomes a date in March. </p>

<p>It also allows you to add some javascript behaviours to handle  auto-tabbing between components when filled. There is a demo in the plugin which uses LowPro from Dan Webb. </p>

<p>ExampleThe helpers return the date parts as text fields i.e. </p>

<p>date_text_field :person, :date_of_birth, :order =&gt; [:day, :month, :year], :blank =&gt; truereturns this for a new person record </p>

<p>  
<br/>  -
<br/>  
<br/>  -
<br/>  
<br/>InstallUnix$ ./script/plugin install http://date-time-text-field-helpers.googlecode.com/svn/trunk/
<br/>  
<br/>$ mv vendor/plugins/svn vendor/plugins/date_time_text_field_helpersWindows&gt; ruby script\plugin install http://date-time-text-field-helpers.googlecode.com/svn/trunk/ </p>

<p>&gt; move vendor\plugins\svn vendor\plugins\date_time_text_field_helpersPiston (http://piston.rubyforge.org/)$ piston import http://date-time-text-field-helpers.googlecode.com/svn/trunk/ vendor/plugins/date_time_text_field_helpersCopyright/LicenseCopyright (c) 2008 Adam Meehan, released under the MIT license</p>

 title : datte_deleted : datte_deleted - Open Hub
 summary : <p>Active ObjectThis is a simple example of the Active Object concurrency pattern.  Example code is provided in both Ruby and Java. </p>

<p>See http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Active_Object </p>

<p>This is intended to be used in my talk on Active Object at the Melbourne Patterns group http://melbournepatterns.org/ </p>

<p>The example is a contrived one of a domain name reseller selling .com, .com.au, and .co.nz domain names with the restriction that the respective domain name registries (or registrars) only allowing one connection at a time from the reseller. </p>

<p>Note that I assume a really simple FIFO scheduler and so do not supply a queue iterator on the Activation Queue, instead I just supply a dequeue method to take the first item off the queue, blocking if the queue is empty. </p>

<p>Directory structure:   </p>

<p>- examples: contains example usage  in ruby of the classes defined in the other directories. 
<br/>  - classic: contains ruby classes needed for a classic implementation of Active Object where each &quot;active object&quot; consists 
<br/>of a proxy (ActiveDomainNameRegistry) that has a reference to a single servant (DomainNameRegistry), 
<br/>and a single scheduler (Scheduler), and the scheduler contains a single activation queue (ActivationQueue). 
<br/>   - variation: contains a variation (in ruby) of the pattern that allows multiple servants per activation queue 
<br/>and is avoids being tied to a single type of servant by using method_missing. 
<br/>   - java: contains the sample example code in java</p>
 title : The davidbkemp-activeobject Open Source Project on Open Hub

 summary : <p>Dawn of Hubris: </p>

<p>This project is still under development, but no fear? From this date forward I will try to make weekly uploads and commits! That means, you can download and play my weekly demo&#39;s until the completion of Dawn of Hubris. I am currently revamping the project as it did lie dead for quite some time, as I had issues in real life (Yes, there is such a thing my dear WoW players) to attend to. I now welcome you all back to this project, and hope to see some downloads soon! </p>

<p>Note: This project is ran using the RGSS engine, most often associated with RPGXP. I will compile weekly bin&#39;s and allow you to play them to your hearts content! </p>

<p>This project has been delayed for an unseen period of time, but fear not! I shall continue it eventually. For now all bins have been taken down, and all downloads as well, as I am thinking of using another engine entirely.</p>

 title : The dazzle Open Source Project on Open Hub
 title : The db-dump Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>DescriptionThis tool is used for dump and restore database of Django. And it can also support some simple situations for Model changes, so it can also be used in importing data after the migration of Model. </p>

<p>It includes: dump and restore. </p>

<p>DumpCommand Line: </p>

<p>    python db_dump.py [-svdh] [--settings] dump [applist]If applist is ignored，then it means that all app will be dumped. applist can be one or more app name. </p>

<p>Description of options: </p>

<p>-s Output will displayed in console, default is writing into file -v Display execution infomation, default is does not display -d Directory of output, default is datadir in current directory. If the path is not existed, it&#39;ll be created automatically. -h Display help information. --settings settings model, default is settings.py in current directory.  It can only support Python format for now. It&#39;ll create a standard python source file, for example: </p>

<p>    dump = {&#39;table&#39;: &#39;tablename&#39;, &#39;records&#39;: [[...]], &#39;fields&#39;: [...]} table&#39; is table name in database, records is all records of the table, it&#39;s a list of list, that is each record is a list. fields` is the fields name of the table. </p>

<p>Load(Restore)Command Line: </p>

<p>    python db_dump.py [-svdrh] [--settings] load [applist]You can refer to the above description for same option. Others is: </p>

<p>-r Does not empty the table as loading the data, default is empty the table first then load the data  Using this tool, you can not only restore the database, but also can deal with the simple changes of database. It can select the suitable field from the backup data file according to the changed Model automatically, and it can also deal with the default value define in Model, such as default parameter and auto_now and auto_now_add parameter for Date-like field. And you can even edit the backup data file manually, and add a default key for specify the default value for some fields, the basic format is: </p>

<p>    &#39;default&#39;:{&#39;fieldname&#39;:(&#39;type&#39;, &#39;value&#39;)}default is a dict, the key will be the field name of the table, the value will be a two element tuple, and the first element of this tuple is type field, the second element is its value. Below is a description of type field: </p>

<p>Type  Value  Description   &#39;value&#39;  real value  using the value field directly   &#39;reference&#39;  referred field name  the value of this filed will use the value of referred field. It&#39;ll be used when the field name is changed   &#39;date&#39;  &#39;now&#39;|&#39;yyyy-mm-dd&#39;  It&#39;s a date date type, if the value field is &#39;now&#39;, then the value be current time. Otherwise, it&#39;ll be a string, it&#39;s format is &#39;yyyy-mm-dd&#39;   &#39;datetime&#39;  &#39;now&#39;|&#39;yyyy-mm-dd hh:mm:ss&#39;  The same as above   &#39;time&#39;  &#39;now&#39;|&#39;hh:mm:ss&#39;  The same as above  </p>

<p>The strategy of selection of default value of a field is: first, create a default value dict according the Model, then update it according the default key of backup data file. So you can see if there is a same definition of a field in both Model and backup data file, it&#39;ll use the one in backup data file. </p>

<p>According the process of default value, this tool will suport these changes, such as: change of field name, add or remove field name, etc. So you can use this tool to finish some simple update work of database. </p>

<p>But I don&#39;t give it too much test, and my situation is in sqlite3. So download and test are welcome, and I hope you can give me some improve advices. </p>

<p>How to use itdownload it and extract to your Django project directory and put it with settings.py together run it in the command line according to the above description Change LogVersion 2.1 2007-09-18 add Time type support Version 2.0 2007-09-11 refact, and add aoto reset postgres sequence Version 1.9 2007-09-02 (Merge from RichardH) Adds try-except to catch the changes in db.backend refactoring in svn version. So db_dump.py can support old version except trunk. Version 1.8 2007-08-30 Fix backend.quote_name to backend.DatabaseOperations().quote_name Thanks to richardh Version 1.7 2007-05-28 keep up with the change of GenericRel, so you can use db_dump.py in trunk and version before 0.97 Version 1.6 2007-04-09 Add float support Version 1.5 2007-02-08 If the filename is not exists, then skip it Version 1.4 2007-01-21 support mysql Version 1.3 2007-01-20 change the output format of data file, and improve the process effective of dumpping and loading Version 1.2 2007-01-20 change dumpdb to use model info but not cursor.description, because some database backend does not support cursor.description Version 1.1 2007-01-19 if no arguments after db_dump.py, then it&#39;ll show help infomation Version 1.0 2007-01-18</p>
 summary : <p>DB Explorer is an easy-to-use application that lets you manage any JDBC (Java Database Connectivity) compliant database. It provides connectivity to wide-range of SQL databases through their JDBC drivers. This makes it completely different from other single database centric applications. Features like simple tabbed-interface to run SQLs query, Schema-Browser, multiple database connections in a session and powerful CSV export/import makes it perfect tool to manage any database. </p>

<p>FeaturesSupport multiple queries per tab. Use Separator token to separate multiple SQLs. Limit number of rows in query result. Default is 50 rows. Support comments in SQL. Use /&quot;&quot; &quot;&quot;/ to comment any part of SQL. Powerful Database Schema Explorer. Just enter  to execute simple SELECT query. View previously Executed SQLs in History Dialog. Tray hide/unhide support. Export query result to CSV file. Import CSV file. Manage connections to multiple database in single session. UsageSupport any Database with JDBC driver. For non-executable(EXE) version, Add JDBC driver file to CLASSPATH or edit run.bat. </p>

<p>In Settings Window, </p>

<p>Select JDBC driver (com.mysql.jdbc.Driver). Enter Database URL (for example, jdbc:mysql://localhost:3306/test) Enter Database User and Password (if required). Hit Ok button and you are ready to go. You can change connection anytime by using Settings Window. Each Connection information(same or different database) will be maintained, so you can switch to any connection in active tab. DB Explorer does not need any JDBC driver file to connect to ODBC connection.  </p>

<p>The latest release version is 1.2.</p>

 title : The db-populate Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>db-schema2omnigraffle is an applescript for creating schemas from mysql databases in OmniGraffle automatically. </p>

<p>Requirements: </p>

<p>Omnigraffle mysql command line client Example </p>

<p> </p>

<p>There are no files released yet, but you can check out the latest version from the Subversion repository. </p>

<p>At the moment the script draws the selected tables, the primary is drawn in bold, other key are drawn in italic and the script tries to connect foreign keys to their table. At the end, when all tables have been drawn, the script uses the auto-layout feature of Omnigraffle to arrange all tables on the canvas. This is not an optimal solution, but you are in most cases going to modify the drawing anyway.</p>

 title : The dbmapper Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>Point this tool at your database to map from your relations to JPA and JAXB classes.  However, it is designed specifically to work well with databases where a certain number of best practices are adhered to: </p>

<p>Every table should have a primary key named &#39;id&#39; that auto-increments on insert Foreign key columns must be named tablename_id Many to Many join tables must be named tablename1_tablename2 All foreign keys should be declared in the database If you can live by these rules you will never have to write JPA classes again.  Here is the usage message: </p>

<p>Usage: com.moonspider.dbmap.GenerateConfig
<br/>  -type (-t) [String] The type to generate, either &#39;jpa&#39; or &#39;gorm&#39; (experimental) (jpa)
<br/>  -destinationDirectory (-d) [String] Destination directory
<br/>  -url [String] The url of the database
<br/>  -pkg (-package) [String] The target package ()
<br/>  -user (-u) [String] Database user (sa)
<br/>  -password (-p) [String] Database password ()
<br/>  -globalExtends (-extends) [String] Class for all Java classes to extend
<br/>  -globalImplements (-implements) [String] Class for all Java classes to implement
<br/>  -driver [String] Database drive class
<br/>  -extension (-ext) [String] File extension for the generated code (java)
<br/>  -hibernate [String] Generate hibernate.cfg.xml to this directory
<br/>  -jaxb [flag] Enable xml binding generation
<br/>  -schema [String] Specify the non-default schema to useThe Grails GORM support is very experimental and doesn&#39;t work well for complex relationships yet.  The JPA support is very solid and has been used in commercial products.  There are lots of things that you can override using a special XML configuration file that will allow you to break some of the rules above, but I don&#39;t recommend it, you can find an example in the tests.</p>
 title : The dbmigrate Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>DescriptionSimilar to &#39;rake migrate&#39; for Ruby on Rails this library lets you manage database upgrades for your Java applications. </p>

<p>SetupChoose a version table name for your database.  The default is db_version. Choose a package within which you will store all your classes and scripts for migrations. Create a directory within that package named after your database (in lowercase, e.g. mysql). Create a script in that directory named migrate0.sql and in that script create the version table and insert version 1, e.g: CREATE TABLE db_version (version integer not null) ENGINE=InnoDB;
<br/>INSERT INTO db_version VALUES (1);RuntimeBefore accessing your database in your programs you need to create a Migrate instance with the appropriate database configuration. Make sure the version is set to the version of the program accessing the database. Call migrate() on your Migrate instance to ensure that your client version matches the database version.  If you have enabled &#39;auto&#39; and don&#39;t specify a client version it will look at the database version it will scan for more recent migrations.  You have a few options for defining migrations.  As far as code they can be either Java, Groovy or SQL.  As far as version transition they can define either &#39;to&#39; or &#39;from&#39; flavors. The &#39;from&#39; flavor is used when you may want to skip versions while the &#39;to&#39; flavor is for when you want the target database version to be the same as the version number in script and don&#39;t mind the reduced flexibility.   Attempt to use a migration class: packageName + databaseName + &quot;.Migrate(To/From)&quot; + dbVersion If class in 1 not found, use a migration script: pacakge dir + &quot;/&quot; + databaseName + &quot;/migrate(to/from)&quot; + dbVersion + &quot;.sql&quot; If script in 2 not found, attempt to use a generic migration class: packageName + &quot;.Migrate(To/From)&quot; + dbVersion If class in 3 not found, use a generic migration script: pacakge dir + &quot;/migrate(to/from)&quot; + dbVersion + &quot;.sql&quot; It will return once the client version and database version are equal.  It will throw an exception if anything happens that stops that from being true. It is safe to run the migration from many different programs at the same time due to the locking that it does (in most databases).  It is also safe to run it multiple times. ImplementationAlways migrate before the first access to your database in a program Never upgrade a database in use without a strategy for discovering that its been upgraded Try to use generic DDL whenever you can if you expect to use more than one type of database with your application FutureDDL layer that understands different databases Integration with JPA and other data access frameworks LOC</p>

 title : The dbsgeo Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>A collection of scripts, models, and tools written in python, sql, or javascript using open source geospatial software (FOSS4G). </p>

<p>SVN Trunk is organized by software and then by project or type. </p>

<p>For example a recent project primarily using postgis and sql for hydrological analysis and modeling can be found in a &#39;hydro_project&#39; folder within the &#39;postgis&#39; directory: http://code.google.com/p/dbsgeo/source/browse/trunk/postgis/hydro_model </p>

<p>Note: All code written on Mac OS 10.5 and not tested on other systems unless noted, so if you attempt to run any scripts on linux or windows you&#39;ll find slight modifications necessary. Other great repos on google code for foss4g related scripts include: </p>

<p>http://code.google.com/p/perrygeo/ http://code.google.com/p/bpgeo/ http://code.google.com/p/spatialguru/ http://code.google.com/p/maphew/ http://code.google.com/p/flatlandmaps/ </p>

<p>Other google code sites with python, sql, and openlayers examples: </p>

<p>http://code.google.com/p/mapnik-utils/ http://code.google.com/p/geodjango-basic-apps/ http://code.google.com/p/rcoos/ http://code.google.com/p/postexperiments/ http://code.google.com/p/postoolbox/ http://code.google.com/p/webprocessingserver/ </p>

<p>Further examples of python for geospatial: </p>

<p>http://www.gis.usu.edu/~chrisg/python/ http://crschmidt.net/python/ http://www.ftools.ca/ https://www.msu.edu/~ashton/classes/825/ https://www.msu.edu/~ashton/classes/825/weekly.html http://trac.reprojected.com/qgislite/ http://os.umbrellaconsulting.com/ http://trac.osgeo.org/gdal/browser/trunk/gdal/swig/python/samples http://trac.osgeo.org/gdal/browser/trunk/gdal/swig/python/scripts http://trac.gispython.org/lab/browser/PCL/trunk/examples http://trac.osgeo.org/grass/browser/grass/trunk/swig/python/examples http://code.djangoproject.com/browser/django/trunk/django/contrib/gis http://scm.wald.intevation.org/svn/thuban/trunk/thuban/ http://trac.osgeo.org/mapserver/browser/trunk/mapserver/mapscript/python/examples </p>

 title : The dbsprockets Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>DBSprocketsThe goal of DBSprockets is to give the developer the power to simply generate web content from available database definitions.  Because DBSprockets relies heavily on Toscawidgets, it is framework-independent.  It is easy to implement forms on TG, TG2, Pylons, Zope, and Grok using DBSprockets&#39; primitives.  </p>

<p>DBSprockets is mainly supporting SQLAlchemy, so any application you have that uses  SQLAlchemy will be well supported.  Support for other ORMs will be available in the future. </p>

<p>Every component of DBSprockets is extensible so that the developer can override a form or a set of forms to his or her liking. </p>

<p>One of the important implementations using DBSprockets is DBMechanic, which acts as a control board for your database crud. </p>

<p>Current Version0.2.2, 0.5dev </p>

<p>Dependent ongenshi&gt;=0.5 sqlalchemy &gt;=0.5 toscawidgets &gt;=0.9.2 Supported FrameworksTurbogears 1.0 Turbogears 2.0 Grok InstallationIf you don&#39;t already have easy_install setup download ez_setup here. And execute it. </p>

<p>With easy_install: </p>

<p>easy_install dbsprockets </p>

<p>more details. </p>

<p>DeclarativesDeclaratives are the easiest way to get going with DBSprockets. </p>

<p>FormBaseTake a look a the simplest example, a login form: </p>

<p>from dbsprockets.declaratives import FormBase
<br/>from myProject.myModel import User</p>

<p>class LoginForm(FormBase):
<br/>    __model__ = User
<br/>    __limit_fields__ = &#39;username&#39;, &#39;password&#39;</p>

<p>login_form = LoginForm()In your template, you would render the form like this: </p>

<p>${login_form()}Here is what the form looks like: </p>

<p> </p>

<p>More information about the model that created this form. </p>

<p>TableBaseAnd here is an example showing what it looks like to display a list of users: </p>

<p>from dbsprockets.declaratives import TableBase
<br/>from dbsprockets.primitives import get_table_value
<br/>from myProject import User
<br/>     
<br/>class UserTable(TableBase):
<br/>    __model__ = User</p>

<p>user_table = UserTable()
<br/>value = get_table_value(User)</p>

<p>user_table(value=value)Which when rendered through a web framework looks something like this: </p>

<p> </p>

<p>Notice that the town name (Arvada) has been automatically added. </p>

<p>Extensible APIThe power of DBSprockets is that every part of it is extensible so customizing forms, widget templates and other portions of your database view is made easier.  Simply override the fields you want to change by name or type with what you want.  Want a whole set of sprockets that have the same modification?  No problem, create a Sprockets cache with your new defaults. </p>

<p>more on DBSprocketsAPI </p>

<p>DBMechanic </p>

<p>Started as a replacement for Catwalk that works with Sqlalchemy. </p>

<p>DBMechanic is a stand-alone TG2 controller for database viewing. </p>

<p>UsageDBMechanic is easy to use!  Here is an example of how to use it in TG 1.0: </p>

<p>from myproject.model import metadata
<br/>from dbsprockets.dbmechanic.frameworks.tg import DBMechanic
<br/>from dbsprockets.saprovider import SAProvider</p>

<p>dbmechanic = DBMechanic(SAProvider(metadata), &#39;/dbmechanic&#39;)more on DBMechanic</p>

 summary : <p>A build service that creates .deb files from source using Checkinstall. </p>

<p>It is run with Camping on a &quot;server&quot; machine, or a regular machine, and accepts uploaded source from another (usually slower, with no way to compile software due to speed or limited system resources) machine and gives back a downloadable .deb file for the &quot;slower&quot; computer to install easily.</p>
 title : The deb-buildservice Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>Easily customisable robust Debian boot CD scripts.  </p>

<p>Uses pbuilder (a standard tool) for creating the base system allows you to edit the base system (install more packages using apt-get, edit files...) creates an iso image (you can test it in qemu) after booting, it drops you into the busybox, with instructions how to proceed - you need to mount the cdrom (usb stick, whatever) manually (so that you can always boot it) boots the rest of the system automatically Why another Debian boot CD?There are other similar projects (see the links), however this project&#39;s motivation is: </p>

<p>simplicity: just a simple short bash script, doing things you would do by hand, if you wanted to create the boot CD (thus you can do it automatically but also you can modify it to suit your needs perfectly) robustness: you do all the vulnerable steps that can fail by hand (creating the base system, adding extra packages, locating the base.tar.bz2 after booting), so that you can always easily fix it and you can boot from all kinds of CDs and USB sticks, as long as you are able to mount the drive in the shell from the kernel, that you installed on the image See for yourself, browse the code from svn here. </p>

<p>Installation and usageSee the README file in the repository: </p>

<p>svn co http://debianiso.googlecode.com/svn/trunk/ debianiso
<br/>cd debianiso
<br/>vim READMETipsInstall manually those packages, that you need (xfs utils, debootstrap, ...), boot from the CD, connect to the internet, install anything you might need on the live system, use debootstrap to install debian (see DebootstrapInstructions) on the disk.</p>

 title : The decide Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>The solution for decision apathy! </p>

<p>Decide For Me was inspired by a common lunch scenario -- a bunch of software developers decide to go out for lunch, we all pile into the car, and then as we&#39;re driving out of the parking lot, someone says, &#39;where are we going?&quot;  And no one wants to make the decision between Chinese, Subway or Wendy&#39;s.  Been there?  I thought so. </p>

<p>So like any good software developer I realized we could solve our problems with code.  Enter decide-for-me.  This web app will decide any of your life&#39;s problems by providing a random answer. </p>

<p>But it gets better... </p>

<p>Since I couldn&#39;t decide what webapp framework to write it in, I decided to write a version in every web framework.  Well, not really.  But I&#39;m trying. </p>

<p>The real goal of Decide For Me is to provide a simple, yet not quite trivial web application which can be used for training and education purposes.  The hope is to implement the same simple website in as many web frameworks and languages as catch our fancy.  The code should be small enough to understand easily, but showcase enough as to let a developer get a decent feel for how a language or framework operates.  Ideally, one should be able to code-up a new version of Decide For Me within a day or maybe a weekend, even if trying out a completely new technology. </p>

<p>At the moment, the project starts with a Google App Engine version (the hosted version on decide-for-me.com) and a slightly dated Rails version.  Please feel free to use the code, comment on it, and provide improvements to make it more idomatic.  If you&#39;re interested in implementing a version of the site in your own favorite framework, that&#39;s great!  Check out the specification and how to help.</p>
 title : The decostage Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>DecoStage for OS X (10.5 Leopard or later) strives to be the complete open source solution for SCUBA divers wanting to plan their dives -- and dive their plans! </p>

<p>The intial release will enable users to model mixed-gas dives on open as well as on closed circuit, using Baker&#39;s VPM-B algorithm and a Buhlmann-derived gradient factor algorithm. </p>

<p>DecoStage is developed using Apple&#39;s excellent native framework, Cocoa and the garbage-collected languages like Objective-C 2 and Python. Plugins implementing other decompression algorithms can be written in any of the &#39;first-class citizen&#39; languages available on OS X 10.5 Leopard: Objective-C, Ruby, Python.</p>
