 title : The demonine Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>DemoNine will be an open-source library, eventually with an IDE, for developing web-applications. These applications will require a server running Ruby 1.8, and clients with browsers supporting JavaScript 1.6 or later. Actually, the framework will also seamlessly render sites that work without Javascript, but there will be limited functionality where client side events are concerned. Namely, the only client-side events that will work without Javascript are onSubmit and onClick events. The good part is that DemoNine will handle Javascript-less clients automatically. We may figure out a work around for more events, like onFocus, but for the moment we are at a loss as to how to do this without Javascript. </p>

<p>The important thing to remember is that the DemoNine framework will provide a high level of abstraction that will allow rapid software development similar to that of Java or C#--both with a plethora of built-in libraries. However, DemoNine&#39;s power is that it will unify all the common system layers in a web application--HTML, server-side scripting language, Javascript, MySQL, XML, etc. By &quot;unify&quot;, we mean eliminate all but a single language. </p>

<p>Best of all, elegance will be a driving force in the layout and implementation of the DemoNine framework. Frameworks that require excessive or repetitive coding in order to make new modules compliant with the framework&#39;s standards are not nearly as useful. Also, they make for clumbsy code that looks terrible. DemoNine will accomplish this elegance and simplicity by abstracting and exploiting some of the amazing core features available in Ruby. For example, think of the trace functions&#39; power. In this sense, think of DemoNine as an extension to the Ruby compiler--an extension to the Ruby language itself rather than simply a bunch of functions that you can call. </p>

<p>What does all this mean? Imagine being able to build a web application with Ruby in the exact same way you would build say a Qt application with Ruby. Programmers will be able to develop applications delivered through a web page in the exact same way they develop applications for Windows or Gnome Desktop. This is something many web applications already do, such as Amazon.com, GMail, Facebook, etc. But, the production frameworks used by those systems are not entirely available to the public, if at all, and they still do not eliminate the need for writing HTML, Javascript and annoying SQL statements. We know what you are thinking--&quot;That&#39;s witch craft!&quot;, or &quot;Hey, there is already a project that does that!&quot; If your thinking the latter, please send a link via e-mail so we can review the project. But we warn you, if it is not written in Ruby, it probably can&#39;t do what DemoNine can, and it certainly can&#39;t do it as elegantly. If it is Ruby or Ruby on Rails based, then it probably comes close to DemoNine, but still falls just a bit short. Nevertheless, send us the links. Our contact info is at the bottom of this page. </p>

<p>The first pre-alpha release of this framework (palpha 1.0) is slated to be released in the second quarter of 2008. The framework will contain support for the at least the following: </p>

<p>Event systems which will trigger system wide events which can call code via Javascript on the client side, in Ruby on the server side, or both. For example, an onClick event can trigger both Javascript functions and Ruby functions on the server-side. A function in Ruby can trigger functions in Ruby on the server or in Javascript on the client. Enough library tools to build a generic website with forms, tabbed forms, drop down menus, vertical menus, basic content management, etc. Ajax forms and UI controls that can be used and extended without ANY knowledge of Javascript or HTML at all! Ajax controls which can trigger events in the browser and on the server, such as deleting a record from list or changing the site theme, or even simply triggering a word count box to update it&#39;s display. Ajax data tables which can show generic data in rows and columns, similar to Ruby on Rails. Database abstraction layer which internally handles normalization and de-normalization of data automatically. Extendable libraries to customize and expand built in functionality, while maintaining the built in support for existing Ajax and event systems. User log in and account management, with group level permissions. The ability to nest groups within other groups, and put users in multiple groups in order to create an abstract ACL hierarchy. And, expect anything else we can get implemented by May of 2008.</p>

 title : The derby-scores Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>To design, build, and test a database engine for reporting, tracking, and analyzing roller derby bout scores.  It&#39;s good to see this longtime goal of finally nearing fruition, and it&#39;s a great first step on the lengthy road to the real holy grail of derby data mangling:  skater-by-skater, jam-by-jam records of scoring, penalties, and assists.  You have to crawl before you walk, but it&#39;s good to finally be crawling.  ~Hurt Reynolds </p>

<p>Test out a theory of web development.  A simple observation that CS always thinks about encapsulation, and web development so often screws this up.  I think every single piece of this project should be a &quot;self&quot; rendering encapsulated component.  Every major table, every display, should be in a well behaved div that you can cram into anything with a reasonable set of parameters.  They should be generated and styled dynamically so that somebody can call components that return functional namespace &quot;objects.&quot;  You should be able to call a component and render it in a generic layout, or return HTML &amp; Javascript via ajax.  If you cannot, obviously you broke encapsulation.  Plus I think it will really help us not step on each others toes if you don&#39;t have to worry about somebody constantly screwing with the &quot;main&quot; layout page. ~Justin</p>
 summary : <p>When I post some article to my blog I&#39;ll put the code to this project, if I want to share it. </p>

 title : The derjanandhisblog Open Source Project on Open Hub
 title : The desarrollo-ubuntu Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>IntroducciónEste proyecto consiste en un texto libre y en español sobre el desarrollo y empaquetamiento de programas para sistemas basados en Debian GNU/Linux (en particular, Ubuntu). </p>

<p>La idea es documentar el proceso de desarrollo de aplicaciones de escritorio sencillas escritas en lenguajes como Python o Java, usando Glade; y además del trabajo que se requiere para tomar el código de la aplicación y convertirlo en un paquete de software instalable desde un repositorio. </p>

<p>Estas tareas adicionales al desarrollo permitirán que los usuarios de una aplicación puedar obtener de forma automática las ultimas actualizaciones de nuestra aplicación. </p>

<p>Cómo obtener el documentoEl documento PDF es generado regularmente y está disponible en la sección de descargas de este sitio web. Además, se puede descargar el código XML que sirve para generar la documentación en formatos HTML y PDF. </p>

<p>Cómo generar la documentación en formato HTML1.- Debes estar seguro de tener instalados los paquetes xsltproc, docbook-xsl y subversion </p>

<p> $ sudo apt-get install xsltproc docbook-xsl subversion2.- Obtener el código fuente XML del documento </p>

<p> $ svn checkout http://desarrollo-ubuntu.googlecode.com/svn/trunk/ desarrollo-ubuntu
<br/> $ cd desarrollo-ubuntu/libro3.- Generar el libro en formato HTML </p>

<p> $ xsltproc -o libro.html /usr/share/xml/docbook/stylesheet/nwalsh/xhtml/docbook.xsl libro.xmlEl documento libro.html recién generado es el libro en formato HTML. </p>

<p>Generación de la documentación en formato PDFAdemás de los paquetes anteriores, se requiere Java y Apache FOP. </p>

<p>1.- Instalar uno de los siguientes paquetes: </p>

<p>sun-java5-jre (para Java versión 5), sun-java6-jre (para Java versión 6), icedtea-java7-jre (para usar Java versión 7). </p>

<p> $ sudo apt-get install sun-java5-jre
<br/> $ sudo update-alternatives --config java2.- Descargar y descomprimir Apache FOP (unos 20 Megabytes) </p>

<p> $ wget -c http://www.apache.org/dist/xmlgraphics/fop/fop-current-bin-jdk1.4.zip
<br/> $ unzip fop-current-bin-jdk1.4.zip
<br/> $ chmod a+x fop-0.94/fop3.- Generar el PDF en el directorio donde se encuentran los archivos XML </p>

<p> $ xsltproc -o libro.fo /usr/share/xml/docbook/stylesheet/nwalsh/fo/docbook.xsl libro.xml
<br/> $ fop-0.94/fop libro.fo libro.pdf</p>

 summary : <p>Just me learning to use Ruby, </p>

 title : The detain Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>A modular network management tool with a web-frontend written in django.</p>
 summary : <p>Notice: This is the developers page for more details please go to Deuce Homepagehttp://www.deucestm.orgDeuce provides a runtime environment for Java Software Transactional Memory (STM). </p>

<p>Deuce is a powerful open source java support for software transactional memory.  Deuce lets you develop highly concurrent applications without worrying about concurrency.  Deuce allows you to write your application as if it was a single threaded application while in fact it runs many threads. Deuce is an extensible framework, which allows developers to develop/extend their own STM algorithms.</p>

 summary : <p>Development of Rails Knowledge, </p>

 title : The developstuff Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>A hodge podge of code that I&#39;ve written across the years... </p>

<p>Check out: </p>

<p>Topological Sort (C# implementation) Color Chart (C# Color Chart example) GAFramework (Early Java implementation of a GA framework) Infix (DLR implementation of infix notation) </p>

<p>Also check out EvolveStuff</p>
 summary : <p>Smart Debugger for Perl, Python, Ruby, FirebugIntroduction </p>

<p>Many programmers never touch the debugger. Because debugger is powerful 
<br/>but somewhat esoteric. It provides granular controls for the debugging, 
<br/>but failed on convenience. My goal for writing Smart Debugger is to 
<br/>provide convenience and usability features. </p>

<p>Debugger Usability </p>

<p>Many people are most comfortable with adding debugging variables and 
<br/>print statements to their code. These are fine techniques; I use them 
<br/>too, when they are appropriate. At other times, the debugger is more 
<br/>convenience to see what is going on right in front of your eyes and poke 
<br/>the code at the debugger prompt rather than having to modify the code 
<br/>and rerun it. </p>

<p>Debugger Dimensions </p>

<p>Dimension 1: Can somebody help me with this? The only time we reach for 
<br/>a debugger is when something goes wrong or breaks and our standard 
<br/>debugging techniques such as print statements (or better yet, log 
<br/>messages) do not reveal the root of the problem. The source code 
<br/>debugger runs code in a controlled manner. It allows stepping through a 
<br/>piece of code one line at a time, walking up and back down call trees, 
<br/>setting break points, and using the power of the Python shell for 
<br/>various levels of introspection and control. </p>

<p>Dimension 2: Hell is other people&#39;s code ? To mangle an old saying, with 
<br/>apologies to Sartre, &quot;Hell is other people&#39;s code.&quot; Other people think 
<br/>differently than I do; they use weird idioms, and sometimes their 
<br/>comments are incomprehensible. Invoking the debugger on someone&#39;s code 
<br/>is like having a conversation with the author. It opens the code to the 
<br/>questions I want answered, in real time--and there&#39;s another party in 
<br/>the conversation, the interpreter. The debugger makes it easy to try 
<br/>things out, even quicker than writing a one-liner, because the 
<br/>environment&#39;s already set up for the running program. 
<br/>Debugger vs Smart Debugger </p>

<p>Debugger offers the below controls. 
<br/>Smart Debugger offers the below convenience. </p>

<p>Data controls: setting watch expressions, commands to see the values in run time. convenience: data rendering to render only the variables in last exec line. Code window controls:see the execution line, commands to see the window around lines. convenience: always display the window around lines.   </p>

<p>Code markers controls: show the current execution line convenience: show the last/current execution line. </p>

<p>Stepping: controls: no default. decide step into/over. convenience: default is step into.</p>

 title : The devwisdom Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>Dex is a programming language that combines C-like syntax and semantics with LISP-like macros, so it ought to be universally loathed.</p>

<p>Dex is an imperative, statically typed, compiled language. Its design was influenced by C, Ada, Java, C# and modern scripting languages (Perl, PHP, Python, Ruby), and to a lesser extent by LISP and OCaml.</p>

<p>Dex macros take a Dex parse tree as input and can modify that tree as the macro writer desires. Dex macros are written in Dex; the Dex standard library contains modules and classes useful for manipulating a Dex parse tree.</p>

<p>The philosophy behind Dex is to keep the core language as simple as possible, but to allow the language to be extended using macros. Complicated features such as generic programming, operator overloading or aspect-oriented programming can be built with Dex macros. It may be possible to use Dex macros to model programming features that otherwise would be completely alien to an imperative language; continuations, for instance.</p>

<p>Dex macros are similar to LISP macros, except that LISP macros are generally more powerful. LISP macros can affect a program at runtime, for instance, where Dex macros cannot.</p>

<p>Dex is also a &#39;safe&#39; language, in that it does not allow the usual culprits: There&#39;s no pointer arithmetic in Dex, nor unchecked conversion, and bounds checking on array accesses is mandatory.</p>

<p>Dex programs can use a garbage collector, but like Ada, the garbage collector is not required. Unlike Ada, Dex programs compile with a garbage collector by default; unlike most Ada compilers, the Dex compiler comes with the garbage collection library pre-installed.</p>

<p>The safety enforcements and garbage collection (if present) will impact the performance of a compiled Dex program when compared against a C or assembler program. However, unlike &#39;managed&#39; environments like Java or C#, and unlike the popular scripting environments such as Python, the overhead imposed by the Dex language is minimal.</p>

<p>Status: Dex is currently pre-alpha.  The parser is mostly complete, so the next step is to implement semantic anlaysis.</p>
 title : The dexlanguage Open Source Project on Open Hub
 title : The dexter-cpan Open Source Project on Open Hub

 title : The dez Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>Dez is an asynchronous network stack for Python. Its sole dependency is Registered Event Listener, which enables dez to run without libevent (a C module). </p>

<p>The dez library includes an asynchronous server benchmarking toolset; advanced, inotify-based static caching; XML and JSON stream parsing; Stomp, OP, HTTP, and WebSocket servers; and WebSocketProxy, which enables web application deployment on existing, unmodified TCP servers without straying from the HTML5 spec. In addition, dez offers a highly sophisticated API for implementing custom protocols, as well as a controller class that simplifies the creation of applications that require multiple servers to run in the same process.</p>
 title : The dfa-to-regularexpression-converter Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>Written in Scheme, this converts DFAs to Regular Expressions. It will be either used in its current form as the backend for a site, or ported to javascript to run in a browser, or ported to some other language (F#, maybe?) to run as the backend for a site.</p>
 summary : <p>This project is for the JAVA version of DFBnc (Read below for delphi/pascal) </p>

<p>HistoryDFBnc was originally an IRC Bouncer written in Delphi. It compiled on Linux (FreePascal) and windows (using both Delphi and FreePascal). </p>

<p>DFBNC Was originally licensed under the ZLIB License, unfortunately this version had a number of bugs in it, and is no longer available. </p>

<p>NowDue to issues with the code and random other things, the decision was taken to completely rewrite DFBnc (for the 2nd time), and rather than relying on external librarys (lsocket and wsocket) and having to test on 3 compilers and work around the various differences in compilers/platforms by hand it was decided to be rewriten in Java, with the rock-solid IRC Parser from DMDirc] powering it. </p>

<p>CompatabilityConfig files between the 2 versions are not compatible with each other, due to the config-directory structure used by dfbnc-java. </p>

<p>External FilesDFBnc makes use of files from other projects, which are automatically downloaded when using svn. The projects used are: # DMDirc (irc parser) # DF Libs (cliparser and logger) </p>

<p>All 3 of the used parts are coded by me, but are part of other projects I am a developer for.</p>

 title : The dfgs Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>OverviewDFL designer is a collection-oriented scientific workflow (COSW) tool based on DFL notation which combines established formalisms from workflow modeling and databases, namely Petri nets and nested relational calculus (NRC). COSW tools are used in applied sciences like bioinformatics where large amounts of structured data are processed with the use of specialized services that are made available online by scientific institutions. They make such data processing experiments easier to conduct by the experimentators and easier to repeat by the reviewers. The notations, models and techniques used in construction of such tools are similar to the ones known from workflow modeling, but additional emphasis is put on the data manipulation aspects, e.g., processing of nested collections of data. DFL designer not only allows to design and enact complicated workflows with the use of a huge library of supported bioinformatics services, but also provides a set of features for testing and analyzing workflow specifications that is unique for COSW, including but not limited to token game, hierarchical analysis and translation of hierarchical side-effect free workflows to NRC. Thus, DFL designer can be used to study in a COSW setting the usefulness of ideas well-tried in workflow modeling and databases. </p>

<p>Instructions, directions, materials, ...Several wiki pages are available for the project. They contain useful information and materials including: </p>

<p>The installation instructions Several flash tutorials Examples and screen shots FAQ </p>

<p>CreditsDFL designer is developed at Faculty of Mathematics, Informatics and Mechanics of University of Warsaw by (in an alphabetic order): </p>

<p>Łukasz Krupa  Jacek Sroka Piotr &quot;Korba&quot; Tomczyk Piotr Włodarczyk</p>

 title : The di-as3 Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>Developed for use with ActionScript 3, Flash 9 and Flex 2 projects it provides an inversion of control container for components that support dependency injection.  </p>

<p>Feature summary: Support for constructor and setter injection, with setter injection available to public variables, setter accessors, and methods. </p>

<p>Dependency resolution can be performed automatically through reflection or by providing:  </p>

<p>a subclass as a type-hint, a key string that a component was registered with, a function reference to return the dependency, a literal value. </p>

<p>Component instances can be cached allowing emulation of singleton access to instances. </p>

<p>The DI library can also detect some forms of cyclic dependency between components. </p>

<p>Support is included for managing instances created outside of the container. Once registered they are available to any component that requests an instance. Additionally registered instances can be populated by setter injection once, every time or never when retrieved from the container. </p>

<p>Runtime container configuration by XML is available, with additional formats easily added.  </p>

<p>Components can be registered in any order as they are only resolved when requested from the container. This allows for the loading of multiple external defintions and RSLs to load classes as required.  </p>

<p>A Reflection API is included in the DI library to address issues with the flash.utils.describeType function, and provides an API that makes the common use-cases of the DI library quick and easy.</p>

 summary : <p>Diadems is an Action RPG game made with C++ and Stackless Python. You play a character who has decided to usurp the King of his nation.  title : The dieselblittingengine Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>Introduction </p>

<p>With the Bitmap classes in Flash Player 9, developers now have the ability to utilize blitting and double-buffering techniques to create resource efficient gaming engines in the Flash Player. Diesel is a set of ActionScript 3 classes that provide a conveinent display engine to take advantage of these new player features. </p>

<p>Why should I care? </p>

<p>Diesel uses 1 bitmap to draw to vs. hundreds of MovieClips / Sprites. This results in a more scaleable engine, allowing for more moving sprites, lower usage of RAM &amp; Processor, and better refresh rates.</p>

 title : The dirclaboratorios Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>DirectoryQueueA Python package providing an abstraction around a filesystem-based queue.  All queue operations are atomic as they rely on directory operations, so it is commonly used as a persistent queue between services. </p>

<p>Example: </p>

<p>  &gt;&gt;&gt; from directory_queue.directory_queue import DirectoryQueue
<br/>  &gt;&gt;&gt; from directory_queue.generic_queue_item import GenericQueueItem
<br/>  &gt;&gt;&gt; import os
<br/>  &gt;&gt;&gt; 
<br/>  &gt;&gt;&gt; qdir = &#39;/tmp/queue&#39;
<br/>  &gt;&gt;&gt; os.mkdir(qdir)
<br/>  &gt;&gt;&gt; dq = DirectoryQueue(qdir, GenericQueueItem)
<br/>  &gt;&gt;&gt; 
<br/>  &gt;&gt;&gt; item1 = dq.newQueueItem(&#39;item1&#39;)
<br/>  &gt;&gt;&gt; file(item1.dataFileName(), &#39;w&#39;).write(&#39;some data&#39;)
<br/>  &gt;&gt;&gt; item1.writeMetadata({&#39;what&#39;: &#39;anything&#39;, &#39;foo&#39;: &#39;bar&#39;})
<br/>  &gt;&gt;&gt; dq.itemReady(item1)
<br/>  &gt;&gt;&gt; 
<br/>  &gt;&gt;&gt; ready_item1 = dq.getNext()
<br/>  &gt;&gt;&gt; md = ready_item1.readMetadata()
<br/>  &gt;&gt;&gt; md
<br/>  {&#39;what&#39;: &#39;anything&#39;, &#39;foo&#39;: &#39;bar&#39;}
<br/>  &gt;&gt;&gt; data = file(ready_item1.dataFileName(), &#39;r&#39;).read()
<br/>  &gt;&gt;&gt; data
<br/>  &#39;some data&#39;
<br/>  &gt;&gt;&gt; dq.itemDone(ready_item1)DirectoryQueueServiceDirectoryQueueService is a Twisted IService that polls a DirectoryQueue and fires callbacks to process new queue items when they become available. </p>

<p>The DirectoryQueueService supports processing items concurrently, up to the concurrency level specified by the constructor parameter. </p>

<p>Note that the user-supplied callbacks must take care of the details of running asynchronously for actual concurrency to occur.  See itemReadyCallback method.</p>

 title : The diwi Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>Diwi: Brings django killer features to desktop development. It uses all meta data from django models to generate interfaces for the desktop.  </p>

<p>Diwi uses the Kiwi framework to represent widgets and forms for django models. </p>

<p>How to install itUse subversion to check out diwi. </p>

<p>svn checkout https://diwi.googlecode.com/svn/trunk/ diwiOr download http://diwi.googlecode.com/files/diwi-0.1.tar.gz file and uncompress it. </p>

<p>Inside diwi folder run:  </p>

<p>$ python setup.py installYou will need root access to install it. </p>

<p>How to use itUse your favorite editor to create a new python file, like this: </p>

<p>from yourapp import models
<br/>import diwi
<br/>import gtk</p>

<p>w = diwi.ApplicationForm(models)
<br/>w.maximize()
<br/>gtk.main()
<br/>On command line: </p>

<p>$ export DJANGO_SETTINGS_MODULE=settings
<br/>$ python yournewfile.pyThat&#39;s all, you&#39;ll get something similiar to django.admin interface over GTK+. Also you can use models or objectlist from diwi.framework.</p>

 title : The django-admin-skin Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>DjangoAdminSkin. An alternative look for the Django Admin-Interface (currently only available for Firefox). </p>

<p>Note (2008-08-22): DjangoAdminSkin is now Grappelli.</p>
 summary : <p>This code is no longer maintained and no longer works in current versions of Django. Forks of it live on in a few different places:  </p>

<p>http://bitbucket.org/carljm/django-adminfiles/ http://github.com/rizumu/django-admin-uploads/ </p>

<p>File/media browser for Django admin interface. Designed to insert images and files into textareas in the admin interface with a simple GUI interface. </p>

<p> </p>

<p>To install: </p>

<p>svn co http://django-admin-uploads.googlecode.com/svn/trunk/ django-admin-uploadsMove upload to your Python Path Move upload_media to your MEDIA_ROOT Create uploads folder in your MEDIA_ROOT Move the upload folder inside templates to your project template folder Add upload to your INSTALLED_APPS Add this to your urlpatterns: (r&#39;^uploads/&#39;, include(&#39;upload.urls&#39;)) Add the following line to the Admin class on any model you would like to have uploads available js = [&#39;/static/upload_media/jquery.js&#39;, &#39;/static/upload_media/model.js&#39;]or to add TinyMCE for WYSIWYG editing  </p>

<p>js = [&#39;/static/upload_media/jquery.js&#39;, &#39;/static/upload_media/tiny_mce/tiny_mce.js&#39;, &#39;/static/upload_media/model.js&#39;]where /static is your MEDIA_ROOT </p>

<p>Now manage.py syncdb and cross your fingers :) </p>

<p>External Services (Flickr, YouTube)To enable inserting your YouTube videos, add YOU_TUBE_USER to your settings file. To enable inserting your Flickr photos, add FLICKR_API_KEY and FLICKR_USER to your settings file (note: FLICKR_USER currently needs to be in old format which can be found in the id field of your Flickr RSS feed)</p>

 title : The django-announcements Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>django-announcements provides a reusable app for dealing with announcements on your site.</p>
 summary : <p>This project intent to provide an application that uses python-clamav library to integrate with ClamAV antivirus, and provide a template filter that check a a file for virus and saves this information, returning if that file can or not be downloaded. </p>

<p>Depends on pyClamAV and jQuery libraries to work. </p>

<p>How to use: </p>

<p>1. First you need to add the application to your INSTALLED_APPS setting; </p>

<p>2. Add the following node to your project urlpatterns: </p>

<p>(r&#39;^antivirus/&#39;, include(&#39;apps.antivirus.urls&#39;)),3. Considering you have an object called &quot;document&quot; that has a field &quot;file&quot; of FileField type, you shall follows this example: </p>

<p>{% load antivirus %}</p>

<p>{{ document|check_for_virus:&quot;file&quot; }}This will show a message like &quot;Wait for file checking...&quot; and make an Ajax request, returning the download link or message that found a virus depending on result. </p>

<p>The file scanning is made just once time, that is stored in database and used for next times.</p>

<p>ARCADE_STORAGE_MODULE = &#39;arcade.storage.file&#39; ARCADE_STORAGE_PATH = os.path.join(os.path.dirname(file), &#39;data&#39;, &#39;game_files&#39;) ARCADE_STATIC_URL = &quot;http://localhost:8000/games/&quot; </p>

<p>Autopost is still broken, I&#39;m working on it.</p>
 title : The django-arcade Open Source Project on Open Hub
 title : The django-assetpackager Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>When it comes time to deploy your new web application, instead of sending down a dozen javascript and css files full of formatting and comments, this Django Application makes it simple to merge and compress JavaScript and CSS down into one or more files, increasing speed and saving bandwidth. </p>

<p>When in development, it allows you to use your original versions and retain formatting and comments for readability and debugging. </p>

<p>Because not all browsers will dependably cache javascript and css files with query string parameters, AssetPackager writes a timestamp into the merged file names. Therefore files are correctly cached by the browser AND your users always get the latest version when you re-deploy. </p>

<p>This code is released under the MIT license. You’re free to rip it up, enhance it, etc. And if you make any enhancements, I’d like to know so I can add them back in. Thanks!</p>
 summary : <p>Attributes of several data types</p>

 title : The django-blogs Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>Welcome to Grappelli - a Django app that supports multiple blogs. It is currently compatible with Django 0.97 pre. </p>

<p>I&#39;m making some changes to the code for Django 1.0 compatibility. Stay tuned! </p>

<p>By the way, this app is currently being used by The Globe and Mail&#39;s new education website, GlobeCampus.ca -- http://www.globecampus.ca/blogs/freshman-life/. Check it out! </p>

<p>About This DocumentThis document includes instructions on installing the django-blogs app. The goal is to provide everything you need to know to get started on using django-blogs. </p>

<p>Note: This is an unfinished document. Holes are actively being filled. Please check back for regular updates. </p>

<p>DependenciesThe templates provided requires two Django apps to be loaded: django.contrib.humanize and django.contrib.markup. </p>

<p>Add the following to the INSTALLED_APPS variable in your project&#39;s settings.py module. </p>

<p>INSTALLED_APPS = (
<br/>    // ...
<br/>    &#39;django.contrib.humanize&#39;,
<br/>    &#39;django.contrib.markup&#39;,
<br/>)The markup module is to enable Markdown formatting syntax in the comments. In order for it to work you need to make sure the markdown module is available in your PYTHONPATH. If you don&#39;t have markdown already, please visit this website. </p>

<p>Of course, markdown is totally optional. If you don&#39;t want to include it feel free to leave it out of the INSTALL_APPS list. Just make sure you make corresponding changes to your templates or else you&#39;ll get exceptions. </p>

<p>JavaScript LibrariesThe JavaScript used by django-blogs relies on the jQuery library. You can download it from their website. The latest tested version is jQuery 1.2.6 -- newer version should work as well. </p>

<p>The dashboard interface uses tiny_mce for the advanced HTML editor. You can grab it from their website: http://tinymce.moxiecode.com/download.php. The latest version that has been tested to work is 3.0.4.1, but newer versions will most likely work as well. If something breaks please let me know! </p>

<p>Getting StartedThese are the steps to start using django-blogs in your project. </p>

<p>Grab The AppCurrently you can only obtain a copy of the code by checking out the trunk from SVN. I&#39;ll provide easier installation methods as this project matures. </p>

<p>To checkout from trunk, execute the following command: </p>

<p>svn checkout https://django-blogs.googlecode.com/svn/trunk/ django-blogsYou can change the folder name to your liking, it is named django-blogs here. Inside the checked-out folder will be a sub-folder called blogs. This folder contains the actual application. </p>

<p>Make sure the blogs application is located somewhere in your PYTHONPATH envrionment variable. Usually you&#39;ll just have it residing in your project path. The easiest way to do this is to create a symbolic link inside your . </p>

<p>ln -s /blogs /blogsAdd New SettingsYou need to define a few variables in your project&#39;s settings.py file. </p>

<p>BLOGS_MEDIA_PREFIX
<br/>JQUERY_PREFIX
<br/>TINY_MCE_PREFIX
<br/>BLOG_ADMIN_NUM_ITEMS
<br/>DEFAULT_CACHE_TIME
<br/>POST_EDITOR_MODE
<br/>BLOG_EDITOR_MODE
<br/>RECAPTCHA_SETTINGS 
<br/>RECAPTCHA_PUB_KEY
<br/>RECAPTCHA_PRIVATE_KEYThere&#39;s an example file here for reference. You can copy and paste the contents of that file in your settings.py. The five things that you really need to change are: BLOGS_MEDIA_PREFIX, JQUERY_PREFIX, TINY_MCE_PREFIX, RECAPTCHA_PUB_KEY, and RECAPTCHA_PRIVATE_KEY. </p>

<p>to be continued... </p>

<p>HelpAny questions or comments are welcome. E-mail me at .</p>
 title : The django-bloom Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>Bloom is set of open source pluggable applications for rapidly developing mobile websites in Django. </p>

<p>Bloom PetalsBloomDevice: pluggable application for device detection using Device Atlas BloomImage: scales images to fit mobile devices BloomSMS: component for sending and receiving SMS messages BloomAd: component for including mobile  BloomShare: pluggable app for sharing shortened urls BloomUser: extends user model to contain phone numbers BloomTrack: component for tracking page views / unique visitors Installing BloomDownload the latest stable version of Bloom: </p>

<p>$ wget http://django-bloom.googlecode.com/files/bloom-0.1.tar.gz
<br/>$ tar -tzvf archive.tar.gz bloom-0.1.tar.gz
<br/>$ cd django-bloom
<br/>$ python setup.py installOr if you&#39;re feeling lucky, the latest SVN release: </p>

<p>$ svn checkout http://django-bloom.googlecode.com/svn/trunk/ django-bloom
<br/>$ cd bloom
<br/>$ python setup.py installPetal Spotlight: BloomDeviceBloomDevice uses Device Atlas to detect the browsing device from request.META[&#39;HTTP_USER_AGENT&#39;]. BloomDevice modifies the request object, adding the dictionary request.device which contains information about the browsing device pulled from Device Atlas. </p>

<p>For example: </p>

<p>&gt;&gt;&gt; request.META[&#39;HTTP_USER_AGENT&#39;]</p>

<p>&#39;SonyEricssonW850i/R1GB Browser/NetFront/3.3 Profile/MIDP-2.0 Configuration/CLDC-1.1&#39;</p>

<p>&gt;&gt;&gt; request.device</p>

<p>{u&#39;mobileDevice&#39;: &#39;1&#39;, u&#39;displayWidth&#39;: &#39;240&#39;, u&#39;displayHeight&#39;: &#39;320&#39;, u&#39;vendor&#39;: &#39;Sony Ericsson&#39;,  u&#39;model&#39;: &#39;W850i&#39;, ...}Device detection can be used either on all requests through bloom.device.middleware.DeviceDetectMiddleware or applied to individual views with the decorator function bloom.device.decorators.detect_device.</p>

 title : The django-captchas Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>This project offers two different captcha approaches (completely automated public turing tests to tell computers and humans apart) with newforms-style fields. First, a pretty much configurable ImageCaptcha, as you see on various sites like Slashdot, Google or Yahoo. Second, a ReverseCaptcha field which is invisible for human users, but tempting for malicious scripts.</p>
 title : The django-cart Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>NOTE: django-cart is a different project starting on March 25th, 2009. Thanks a lot to Eric Woudenberg for letting us reuse this project </p>

<p>django-cart is a very simple application that just let you add and remove items from a session based cart. django-cart doesn&#39;t provide any product information, and you&#39;ve to define your own product models, and then use their instances on the cart. </p>

<p>A basic usage of django-cart could be: </p>

<p>views.py </p>

<p>from cart import Cart
<br/>from myproducts.models import Product</p>

<p>def add_to_cart(request, product_id, quantity):
<br/>    product = Product.objects.get(id=product_id)
<br/>    cart = Cart(request)
<br/>    cart.add(product, product.unit_price, quantity)</p>

<p>def remove_from_cart(request, product_id):
<br/>    product = Product.objects.get(id=product_id)
<br/>    cart = Cart(request)
<br/>    cart.remove(product)</p>

<p>def get_cart(request):
<br/>    return render_to_response(&#39;cart.html&#39;, dict(cart=Cart(request)))templates/cart.html </p>

<p>{% extends &#39;base.html&#39; %}</p>

<p>{% block body %}
<br/>    
<br/>        
<br/>            Product
<br/>            Quantity
<br/>            Total Price
<br/>        
<br/>        {% for item in cart %}
<br/>        
<br/>            {{ item.product.name }}
<br/>            {{ item.quantity }}
<br/>            {{ item.total_price }}
<br/>        
<br/>        {% endfor %}
<br/>    
<br/>{% endblock %}</p>

 title : The django-check-constraints Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>To implement check constraints on models for the Django Web framework.The various check constraints to be implemented: </p>

<p>Range Based Check Constraints Value Based Check Constraints </p>

<p>The development has moved to http://github.com/theju/django-check-constraints. Please feel free to fork the code. </p>

<p>Timetable</p>

<p>Date  Activity  May 28th, 2007Coding Starts June 1st, 2007Show Prototype to Mentor June 10th, 2007Complete Range Based Constraints June 20th, 2007Complete Cascaded Range Based Constraints with Documentation and test cases June 30th, 2007Complete Value Based Constraints July 10th, 2007Complete Cascaded Value Based Constraints with Documentation and test cases July 20th, 2007Invite bug reports and suggestions from community and make suitable changes and write tests July 30th, 2007Work towards integration into Django, this includes PEP-8 and i18n compliance upto August 20th, 2007Buffer Time</p>
 summary : <p>Cheetah template engine for DjangoUsage Use the render_cheetah_response shortcut just as you would use render_to_response  Use the CheetahTemplate class to render contexts in your views from text or file News - Now released a version which is the stand alone module django_cheetahtemplates and contains the application of the example below. See the source svn repository for the most up to date code. </p>

<p>ExamplePut this in your views  </p>

<p>from django_cheetahtemplates import render_cheetah_response,CheetahTemplate
<br/>from django.template import Context
<br/>from django.http import HttpResponse</p>

<p>def hello(request):
<br/>    # Use shortcut
<br/>    return render_cheetah_response(&#39;hello.tmpl&#39;, {&#39;myvar&#39;:&#39;hello world&#39;,&#39;range&#39;:range} )</p>

<p>def hello2(request):
<br/>    # Create and render context
<br/>    context = Context({&#39;myvar&#39;:&#39;hello&#39;})
<br/>    context[&#39;range&#39;] = range
<br/>    template = CheetahTemplate(filename=&#39;hello.tmpl&#39;)
<br/>    return HttpResponse(template.render(context))Then create hello.tmpl somewhere in your TEMPLATE_DIRS </p>

<p>$myvar
<br/>#for i in $range(10)
<br/>$i#slurp
<br/>#end forWhen you go to the url linked to either hello or hello2 you will see this </p>

<p>hello world 0123456789Capabilities: </p>

<p>Django context/template rendering compatibility with CheetahTemplate class.  Shortcut replacement for render_to_response =&gt; render_cheetah_response </p>

<p>TODO: </p>

<p>Cheetah template path search (always defaults to your project directory when trying to include files) Fix: find your template from there with relative links?  Transfer over filters to cheetah format Create URL shortcuts for generic cheetah template views (like &#39;direct_to_template&#39; in urls.py)</p>
 title : The django-cheetahtemplate Open Source Project on Open Hub
 title : The django-chunks Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>This project is now hosted at Github!, </p>
 title : The django-clevercss Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>Today I stumbled upon the CleverCSS project and decided I liked it and wanted to experiment with it.  In an effort to find a use for it, I decided to create this project that allows you to use CleverCSS in your Django templates. </p>

<p>What Does django-clevercss Do?This project allows you to create CleverCSS stylesheets using the classic Django administration utility.  The use of a template tag, get_clever_css, will allow you to use these stylesheets that are stored in your database.  The template tag retrieve the stylesheet by its title and spits out a file on the filesystem each time the stylesheet changes in the database.  This slightly reduces the amount of overhead because the CleverCSS stylesheet does not need to be parsed for each page request. </p>

<p>InstallationDownload django-clevercss using one of the following methods: </p>

<p>Checkout from Subversionsvn co http://django-clevercss.googlecode.com/svn/trunk/ django-clevercssPackage DownloadDownload the latest .tar.gz file from the downloads section and extract it somewhere you&#39;ll remember. </p>

<p>I&#39;m still working on a setup.py script to make this easier, so for the time being you need to put the dlevercss (clevercss with a d) application somewhere on your PYTHONPATH.  Usually, a safe bet is something like /usr/lib/python2.5/site-packages or C:\Python25\Lib\site-packages. </p>

<p>RequirementsThis application requires CleverCSS to be installed on your system.  An easy way to install this utility is to use easy_install: </p>

<p>sudo easy_install clevercssor </p>

<p>easy_install clevercssFor more information and syntax help for CleverCSS, see the project homepage. </p>

<p>Important note: I built this project on Django 1.0 alpha (rev. 8222), which uses the newforms-admin.  This means that the project is currently incompatible with any revision of Django (at least the administration utility) before July 18th, 2008.  If there is enough demand, I suppose I can insert a simple class Admin into the model to solve the problem.  However, since I am eagerly looking forward to the official release of Django 1.0 in the near future, I will leave the code as is (again, unless there is a demand for &quot;backward compatibility&quot;). </p>

<p>UsageFirst of all, you must add this project to your list of INSTALLED_APPS in settings.py: </p>

<p>INSTALLED_APPS = (
<br/>    &#39;django.contrib.admin&#39;,
<br/>    &#39;django.contrib.auth&#39;,
<br/>    &#39;django.contrib.contenttypes&#39;,
<br/>    &#39;django.contrib.sessions&#39;,
<br/>    &#39;django.contrib.sites&#39;,
<br/>    ...
<br/>    &#39;dlevercss&#39;,
<br/>    ...
<br/>)Run manage.py syncdb. </p>

<p>Create a new stylesheet in the Django administration utility (see the CleverCSS homepage for syntax guidance), and save it. </p>

<p>Then in your Django template, simply do something like this: </p>

<p>{% load dlevercss_tags %}</p>

<p>Django-CleverCSS</p>

<p>Header 1
<br/>Bla bla bla</p>

<p>Note the {% load dlevercss_tags %} at the top of the snippet.  Assuming your settings.MEDIA_URL is /media/ and the stylesheet you created in the administration utility was named Testing, you should end up with something like /media/clevercss/testing.css in the link tag&#39;s href attribute. </p>

<p>Behind the scenes, the project checks to see if the stylesheet in the database is newer than the stylesheet on the filesystem.  If it is, the CleverCSS stylesheet in the database will be parsed by clevercss and crammed into a real CSS file that your templates can access and use. </p>

<p>As of revision 4, the project includes a tag for inline CleverCSS: </p>

<p>{% load dlevercss_tags %}</p>

<p>Django-CleverCSS</p>

<p>{% clevercss %}
<br/>body:
<br/>    background-color: #333</p>

<p>    h1:
<br/>        color: #f00
<br/>        weight: normal
<br/>{% endclevercss %}</p>

<p>Header 1
<br/>Bla bla bla</p>

<p>Be sure to watch your indentation with this tag :) </p>

<p>Good luck!  Please contact me with any questions or concerns you have with the project!</p>
 title : The django-comics Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>Together with django-forumBR, django-comics is part of the Pigmalion Project.It&#39;s identification is Green-Pigmalion.  </p>

<p>Pigmalion ProjectsBlue Pigmalion As all Pigmalion projects, it uses MooTools as javascript framework and BluePrintCSS as css framework. </p>

<p>Current Version0.45 0.6 </p>

<p>Used FrameworksCSS Framework : blueprintcss (helps big time! I&#39;m no designer, folks ;) Javascript Framework : MooTools (prettier then jquery) </p>

<p>Version 1.0 goals ... </p>

<p>Well, let&#39;s say you need to create a page to an artist, like a virtual comic book. This app does just that! It makes it easy to create a colection of related comic books. Basically, my inspiration came from the lot of great online comic books out there.From marvelous Grim Tales(and company!) comics, fantastic Flaky Pastry, caustic Sexy Loosers, up to the clever XKCD comics. I hope this is usefull to someone and if suggestions are ALWAYS welcomed! </p>

<p>Right now, django-comics is in version 0.3, as it needs improved visual editing, needs beter coding, and solid access restrictions. Therefore, one can still use it for simples projects without problem.  </p>

<p>Django-comics is now in version 0.45. That means it kind of works, but is still kind of ugly. Let&#39;s see the features so far: Django-comics is now in version 0.6. That means it works fine, but there are a few funcionality missing yeat. Let&#39;s see the features so far: </p>

<p>You can have as many comic books within the app as you want(even one!) You can set access policies as &#39;who can comment&#39; Mature content filter(naughty things get asks for age) You can define the header image easely Comics accept commeting(i&#39;ll probaly change that to use django commenting contrib..) A viewer can browse through all the comic book strips in archive random strip view implemented you can add comic strips right from comics. No admin here Missing </p>

<p>Inline comic message sensoring Logging Finish CleverCSS template Maybe make it look prettier. </p>

<p>That&#39;s pretty much it! Check django-comics in action within this url : http://www.italomaia.com/comics/</p>
 title : The django-compress Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>django-compress provides an automated system for compressing CSS and JavaScript files. By default, it only outputs compressed files, while not in DEBUG-mode. That means you can still debug and edit your source files while coding, and when going to production, the compressed files will be automatically generated. </p>

<p>Support for jsmin and CSSTidy is included and enabled by default (but can easily be disabled). </p>

<p>django-compress includes template tags for outputting the URLs to the CSS/JavaScript-files and some other goodies to improve the performance of serving static media. </p>

<p>See the following wiki-pages for more information: </p>

<p>Introduction Features Installation Configuration Usage FarFutureExpires Customization </p>

<p>django-compress was written by Andreas Pelme . Feel free to contact me with questions, suggestions etc. </p>

<p>The Python-version of jsmin (http://www.crockford.com/javascript/jsmin.html) is included in django-compress. It was translated from to Python by Baruch Evan, from the original jsmin implementation by Douglas Crockford.</p>
 summary : <p>This is the first approach to give admins a nice interface for geographical data. With the included CoordinatesFormField it is possible to add and edit GPS coordinates using one of the popular map services from Google and Yahoo. </p>

<p>Since most of the work is done via Javascript it has a nice fallback with a default TextField. The javascript code is written with generalisation in mind to handle the differences between the map systems. </p>

<p>Example: </p>

<p>from django.db import models
<br/>from field import CoordinatesField</p>

<p>class Location (models.Model):
<br/>    name = models.CharField(maxlength=100)
<br/>    gps = CoordinatesField()Please watch the Subversion repository for changes</p>
 title : The django-coordinatesfield Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>Django CountriesNice little application for Django projects providing fixtures and models for a &quot;complete&quot; list of world countries and US states. Also throwing in a small template filter for getting country flags by ISO 3166-1 alpha-2 country code. </p>

<p>InstallationJust check out the latest source and copy countries into your django site directory: </p>

<p>svn checkout http://django-countries.googlecode.com/svn/trunk/ django-countriesadd countries to the list of installed apps and run syncdb and you&#39;re good to go. (Note: the models are fixed to the country and usstate tables, se models.py for details) </p>

<p>And for the flags hed over to famfamfam and download the ISO 3166-1 alpha-2 country code flag package. And add a flags director to your media root and copy the .gif flags there.  An alternative flag resource is ip2location </p>

<p>Optionally add: </p>

<p>COUNTRIES_FLAG_PATH = &#39;flags/%s.png&#39;to django settings if you want to have the flags in an alternative location or use .png instead of the default .gif ( .gif is just a tiny bit smaller ;) </p>

<p>Source of informationCountry listThe list of world countries is based on the list of ISO 3166 codes for countries in existence at the time of last update. The tricky part is getting the list complete with iso-2 code, iso-3 code, number and official printable name se models.py for more details. Therefore this country list is a merge from these two resources: </p>

<p>http://www.iso.ch/iso/en/prods-services/iso3166ma/02iso-3166-code-lists/index.html http://unstats.un.org/unsd/methods/m49/m49alpha.htm The official list is constantly receiving updates, so the list might not be 100% accurate. </p>

<p>Country list last updated: 2007-08-20 - 244 countries. </p>

<p>US States listDEPRECATED django.contrib.localflavor provides listings of states. This is still not implemented in the app and needs some modifications to work. US states list is a plain list of name and abbreviation. Making the list more complete are the additional six military &quot;states&quot; all according to the usps list at the time of last update: </p>

<p>http://www.usps.com/ncsc/lookups/usps_abbreviations.html US States list last updated: 2007-08-20 - 59+6=65 states </p>

<p>DisclaimerAs a disclaimer I&#39;ll cite the Unite Nations list of county names at http://unstats.un.org/unsd/methods/m49/m49alpha.htm  </p>

<p>&quot;The designations employed and the presentation of country or area 
<br/>names in this list do not imply the expression of any opinion whatsoever on 
<br/>the part of the Secretariat of the United Nations author concerning  
<br/>the legal status of any country, territory, city or area or of its  
<br/>authorities, or concerning the delimitation of its frontiers or boundaries.&quot;</p>

 title : The django-cron Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>The django app will allow the site to run code in a cron job like manor without needing to setup a real cron job (Usefull for people hosting on windows or with Hosting companies that do not give you access to setup cron jobs). </p>

<p>To create a Cron Job you create a file called cron.py in your application directory that will contain the jobs you wish to run. Once you have your jobs created you need add two lines to your primary urls.py (Similar to what you need to do for the admin site) </p>

<p>import django_cron
<br/>django_cron.autodiscover()That will go though all your installed apps and see if they have a cron job to register </p>

<p>Example Cron Job included in the applicationfrom django_cron import cronScheduler, Job</p>

<p># This is a function I wrote to check a feedback email address and add it to our database. Replace with your own imports
<br/>from MyMailFunctions import check_feedback_mailbox</p>

<p>class CheckMail(Job):
<br/>	&quot;&quot;&quot;
<br/>		Cron Job that checks the lgr users mailbox and adds any approved senders&#39; attachments to the db
<br/>	&quot;&quot;&quot;</p>

<p>	# run every 300 seconds (5 minutes)
<br/>	run_every = 300
<br/>		
<br/>	def job(self):
<br/>		# This will be executed every 5 minutes
<br/>		check_feedback_mailbox()</p>

<p>cronScheduler.register(CheckMail)</p>

 title : The django-discussion Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>A generic discussion application for Django projects, designed to make it easy to integrate simple, nested discussions by registered users about any content item in your projects. </p>

<p>Features: </p>

<p>registering comments against any Model instance. replying to specific comments for nested discussions. generic views which take care of adding, editing and deleting comments against specific Models. a template tag library for retrieving the number of comments made on any object or list of objects and comment trees themselves. </p>

<p>Based on an implementation of Modified Preorder Tree Traversal by Julio Nobrega, originally posted on the Django wiki. </p>

<p>NB: this application is being developed against the development version of Django (which is 0.97-pre at the time of writing), so you&#39;ll need a recent checkout of Django&#39;s SVN trunk to run it.</p>
 summary : <p>This project collects some of the most useful components for building community sites in Django.  The django apps and utilities were extracted from the code used to build our forum-hosting project: http://www.lefora.com/. </p>

<p>Notable apps include: </p>

<p>storage - A file storage module, configurable with many backends: Filesystem, MogileFS, S3, and more... </p>

<p>stash - A caching module, in conjunction with django.cache, provides namespace management and several convenience layers </p>

<p>modelmud - Enhancing Django&#39;s ORM, mostly motivated by performance.  </p>

<p>visitor, affiliation, permission - each app building on top of the previous to provide management of many sub-sites. </p>

<p>modular - components for django: scatter/gather blocks, viewlets, and withlets. </p>

<p>inquiry - form widgets specified via template, aggregate fields, and more...</p>

 title : The django-dynamic-media-serve Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>Django Dynamic Media ServeDjango Dynamic Media Serve is the good alternative of the default django.views.static.serve for serving the media files in Django. You can simply set just one line in urls.py. </p>

<p>At first, Django Dynamic Media Serve was developed for web album application, which handles enoumous image thumbnails and huge javascript files and each time when new files is added, creating thumbnail and compressing javascript files is so painful, so we wrote this Django Dynamic Media Serve to dynamically handle various media files in runtime without using any already-created file, especially image files. </p>

<p>FeatureVarious Media Serve thru DjangoSVG images(png, gif, jpeg, etc which can be supported by PIL). javascript any other files. External MediaIf you need to fetch the media from outside of your media repository, Django Dynamic Media Serve support the ourside media. It can be useful for Cross-Domain access in Ajax script. </p>

<p>Image Resizing and CropingUsing PIL(Imaging Python module), Django Dynamic Media Serve can create normal image thumbnail by image size ratio and can create the flicker style thumbnail. </p>

<p>~Javascript Compression~~Django Dynamic Media Serve can compress the javascript file using jsmin,.~ Django Media Server no longer does support javascript compression using jsmin because of the confirmed comment, &#39;/, /&#39; related problems. </p>

<p>Support If-Modified-Since, If-None-MatchTo respect the If-Modified-Since and Etag, Django Dynamic Media Serve can handle properly the If-Modified-Since and If-None-Match header variables. </p>

<p>CachingSupport the native Django caching system</p>

 summary : <p>django-emailthis is a simple email-to-a-friend application that generates an email form, handles its submission, persists the submission data to a database, and sends a templated email.  Both anonymous and registered users can send email. </p>

<p>This app started out as a quasi-fork of Jeff Croft&#39;s &quot;mailfriend&quot; app (http://code.google.com/p/django-mailfriend/), but the latter only supported registered users; this supports users of both the registered and unregistered varieties. </p>

<p>Form submission is here done solely via ajax; loading is intended to be handled similarly.</p>

 title : The django-evserver Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>django_evserver is simple http server for Django applications. It&#39;s based on libevent library. The main advantage of django_evserver is that it provides methods of preempting django views. You can render a site in several chunks, each of them can be handled by different django view. </p>

<p>Using this idea it&#39;s possible to use django_evserver as comet server for django applications. </p>

<p>Yes! Now you can write comet applications in django!</p>

 title : The django-farstyle Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>Farstyle simplifies the management and serving of CSS and JavaScript asset files. Required css or js files, conveniently defined and ordered in the database, are merged and compressed, then inserted into your HTML using a single templatetag. Unique file name used for merged asset files enable far-future caching, with a change in any file causing a new merged asset file to be generated and loaded by browsers. </p>

<p>The merging and optimization process is fully customizable, offering control over both the overall processing of merged assets, as well as the handling of each individual file. CSS and JavaScript files can be individualy exempted from merging or optimization, and custom conditions can be used to group and serve files as separate assets based on request parameters or optional templatetag variables. </p>

<p>Farstyle also helps with the creation of CSS and JavaScript files, by allowing them to be rendered from Django templates. Farstyle searches for files in both template provider locations and static filesystem directories, creating the opportunity to override static files with same-name templates. </p>

<p>For development, merging and optimization are disabled when DEBUG is set to True. In this case individual tags are created for each file, with an added query string parameter which ensures that changed files will always be reloaded by browsers. </p>

<p>A bonus feature enables far future caching of media files, such as large images that rarely change. </p>

<p>Main FeaturesDefine CSS and JavaScript files in the database. Control the files&#39; order, toggle merging/compression for each file, and write custom Python rules to determine when files are to be used. Create CSS and JavaScript files using django templates. Use constants in your template-based CSS, defined in an optional settings module. Override static CSS and JS files with template-based versions (especially useful when combined with django-dbtemplates). Write CSS in less or sass format. Include all defined CSS and JS files in your templates using a single templatetag (single tag for each asset type, with the provision for using multiple tags combined with conditional statements). Create far-future-caching friendly image tags for large images that rarely change. CSS and JS files are merged down to the smallest possible number of asset files to optimize loading, and are named using unique names which allow browsers to cache assets while immediately loading new versions when assets are changed. Merged and optimized asset files are re-generated on demand when any of the original CSS or JS files are modified. The Sites application is supported, using Many-to-Many relationships so that multiple sites can share common assets. CreditsFarstyle&#39;s database-based specification of CSS and JavaScript files was inspired by django-assetpackager. </p>

<p>The use of customizable filter chains to control optimization and compression of assets was inspired by django-compress, and much of the filtering code was taken from that project. </p>

<p>The Python version of jsmin insluded in Farstyle was translated to Python by Baruch Evan, from the original jsmin implementation by Douglas Crockford.</p>
 summary : <p>This app allows you to relate users with objects that are their favorites.  Its a generic relation with of an  object with a user. </p>

<p>It is not a working version, or even close.  If you would like to work on it send me an email.</p>

 title : The django-fckconnector Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>FCKeditor is a Javascript-based rich text editor for web applications. One of the enhanced features it offers is a web-based browser for media files stored on the server. The browser relies on a server-side connector to provide XML responses for commands. FCKeditor includes connectors for many server-side technologies, including a Python CGI implementation. However, when using FCKeditor in a Django application, it is desirable to implement the connector within the Django process. This project provides a Django-based implementation of the FCKeditor server side specification.</p>
 title : The django-filebrowser Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>The FileBrowser is an extension to the Django Admin-Interface in order to </p>

<p>browse directories on your server and upload/delete/edit/rename files. include images/documents to your models/database using the FileBrowseField. select images/documents for TinyMCE and CKEditor. For editors using the Admin-Interface, the FileBrowser replaces an FTP-Client. </p>

<p>Take a look at the Screenshots. </p>

<p>RequirementsDjango 1.0+ PIL (Python Imaging Library), see http://www.pythonware.com/products/pil/ Grappelli (Version 2.0+), see http://code.google.com/p/django-grappelli/ Discussion/QuestionsUse the FileBrowser Google-Group for asking questions, discuss development- and improvement-issues and stay informed about changes/updates: http://groups.google.com/group/djangofilebrowser. News &amp; Updates2010-02-06: The first alpha of MedMan is out. see http://code.google.com/p/django-medman/. Testing &amp; Feedback is very much appreciated. 2009-11-28: Added CSRF-workaround for either Django 1.1.1 or SVN. 2009-11-27: Added default sorting. New settings DEFAULT_SORTING_BY, DEFAULT_SORTING_ORDER. 2009-11-26: Added Pagination. New setting LIST_PER_PAGE. 2009-11-12: FileBrowser Version 3.0 has been merged to the trunk. Documentation is updated. Please Note that Grappelli 2.0 is a requirement. InstallationBasic Installation Using the FileBrowse-Field Using the FileBrowser with django-tinymce Using the FileBrowser with TinyMCE HelpAvailable Settings The FileObject  Using Image Versions Templatetags Signals   Translation/i18n FAQ FeaturesMultiple Upload using Uploadify. Define allowed file-extensions and max. Upload-Size. Automatic Thumbnails. Integration with TinyMCE (AdvImage &amp; AdvLink). Automatic filters for date and file-types. FileBrowse-Field to select Images/Documents. Includes Image-Preview (Thumbnail) with the ability to click the Thumbnail and see the original Image. Define individual select/upload directories, allowed extensions and selection formats for every FileBrowse-Field. Rename/Delete files/directories. Generate different Image versions on the fly. DEBUG-Mode in order to display FileObjects in the Admin-Interface. Signals for Upload, Rename and Delete.</p>

 title : The django-flag Open Source Project on Open Hub
 title : The django-flags Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>django-flagsThe django-flags helps writing internationalized applications based on &quot;verbose&quot; templates: </p>

<p>In this situation, it is more efficient to maintain a set of templates per language than writing one set of templates with many trans tags. </p>

<p>Last languages added: romanian </p>

<p>What django-flags doesdjango-flags provides: </p>

<p>a template tag displaying country flags in a form two template loaders searching (LANGUAGE_CODE)/(template_name) Here&#39;s an example of a flags form: </p>

<p> </p>

<p>Test itdownload or check it out, then launch the project test with: </p>

<p>  python manage.py testserverThat&#39;s all ! </p>

<p>A screenshot of test page: </p>

<p> </p>

<p>Using django-flags in your django projectsettings.pyadd the following template loaders first: </p>

<p>TEMPLATE_LOADERS = (
<br/>    &#39;yourproject.flags.loaders.filesystem.load_template_source&#39;,
<br/>    &#39;yourproject.flags.loaders.app_directories.load_template_source&#39;,
<br/>    ...
<br/>)add the local middleware after the session middleware: </p>

<p>MIDDLEWARE_CLASSES = (
<br/>    ...
<br/>    &#39;django.contrib.sessions.middleware.SessionMiddleware&#39;,
<br/>    &#39;django.middleware.locale.LocaleMiddleware&#39;,
<br/>    ...
<br/>)add the flags application: </p>

<p>INSTALLED_APPS = (
<br/>    ...
<br/>    &#39;yourproject.flags&#39;,
<br/>)add flags application parameters; you can choose flags icons server: </p>

<p># see urls.py
<br/>FLAGS_I18N_PREFIX = &#39;/lang/i18n/&#39;
<br/># flags served by local server
<br/>#FLAGS_URL = MEDIA_URL
<br/># flags served by net server
<br/>FLAGS_URL = &#39;http://djangodev.free.fr/flags/&#39;</p>

<p># languages
<br/>ugettext = lambda s: s
<br/>LANGUAGES = (
<br/>    (&#39;ar&#39;, ugettext(&#39;Arabic&#39;)),
<br/>    (&#39;fr&#39;, ugettext(&#39;French&#39;)),
<br/>    (&#39;en&#39;, ugettext(&#39;English&#39;)),
<br/>    (&#39;es&#39;, ugettext(&#39;Spanish&#39;)),
<br/>    (&#39;de&#39;, ugettext(&#39;German&#39;)),
<br/>    (&#39;pl&#39;, ugettext(&#39;Polish&#39;)),
<br/>)urls.pyinclude flags.urls (the prefix must match settings.FLAGS_I18N_PREFIX): </p>

<p>urlpatterns = patterns(&#39;&#39;,
<br/>    # django-flags for internationalization
<br/>    (r&#39;^lang/&#39;, include(&#39;yourproject.flags.urls&#39;)),
<br/>    ...
<br/>)templatesInsert the following code to generate the flags form: </p>

<p>{% load flags_lib %}{% flags_form %}copy templates/.html to templates/LANG/.html translate templates/LANG/.html That&#39;s all. </p>

<p>Help neededYou can help me this way: </p>

<p>generate a 10x15 flag of your country named flag_CC.jpg translate this template send me these items Thanks for your participation :-)</p>
 title : The django-forum Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>This is a basic forum component that can plug into any existing Django installation and use it&#39;s existing templates, users, and admin interface. Perfect for adding forum functionality to an existing website. </p>

<p>Current StatusUses Django Admin for maintenance / moderation - no in-line admin features as yet Uses existing django Auth and assumes you already have that up and running. I use and recommend django-registration Roll your own site with little work: Install Django, install django-registration, flatpages, django-forum, setup your templates and you have an instant website :) Code is as pulled out of my other projects - changes will be made as I go to make sure it&#39;s as standalone as possible, right now should be pretty good. Getting StartedCheckout code via SVN: svn co http://django-forum.googlecode.com/svn/trunk/ forum Add forum to your INSTALLED_APPS in settings.py ./manage.py syncdb Add FORUM_BASE = &#39;/forum&#39; to your settings.py (no trailing slash) Update urls.py:  (r&#39;^forum/&#39;, include(&#39;forum.urls&#39;)), Go to your site admin, add a forum Browse to yoursite.com/forum/</p>

EASY INSTALL!!!!!! (there are harder ones ; ) </p>

 title : The django-gae2django Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>gae2django is a Django helper application that provides an implementation of Google&#39;s App Engine API based on pure Django. </p>

<p>The helper makes it easier to re-use applications originally designed for Google&#39;s App Engine environment in a Django environment. </p>

<p>(If you want to run existing Django applications in Google&#39;s App Engine environment, then Google App Engine Helper for Django is the right choice for you...) </p>

<p>Implemented APIsDatastore API Memcache API URL fetch API Users API Mail API XMPP API (as a stub implementation that does nothing) How to Use the Helperadd gae2django to INSTALLED_APPS add gae2django.middleware.FixRequestUserMiddleware to MIDDLEWARE_CLASSES below AuthenticationMiddleware at the top of manage.py add      import gae2django
<br/>     gae2django.install()This installs a drop-in replacement for the google.appengine module. </p>

<p>A practical example: The code review tool Rietveld on native Djangogae2django comes with a practical example and proof of concept: In the examples directory you&#39;ll find instruction on how to set up Rietveld, the code review tool available at http://codereview.appspot.com, to run with gae2django on native Django. Refer to the README or detailed instructions. </p>

<p>For known issues and limitations of the ported APIs see KnownIssues. </p>

<p>Please join the mailing list for gae2django related questions. </p>

<p>This project is in a very early stage of development. So don&#39;t expect that things always work as expected. Feel free to contribute!</p>

 title : The django-gcal Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>A Django application allowing developers to synchronise instances of their models with Google Calendar. Using Django&#39;s signals mechanism and generic relations, no changes to the model being synchronised are required, and synchronisation occurs without user intervention over the models lifecycle. </p>

<p>InstallationCheckout the contents of http://django-gcal.googlecode.com/svn/trunk/ to somewhere on your PYTHONPATH. </p>

<p>UsageIn a typical scenario, the following steps are required to use django-gcal: </p>

<p>Add djangogcal to the list of installed applications in your settings.py. Define a djangogcal.adapter.CalendarAdapter for each model you want synchronised. Instantiate a djangogcal.observer.CalendarObserver for each Google Calendar feed. Call the CalendarObserver.observe(model, adapter) method to link models with the Google Calendar feed. See GettingStarted for more information, and RelatedModels for information about sending updates when related objects are changed. </p>

<p>ExampleThe code in this example is sufficient to bind a model to Google Calendar. </p>

<p>from django.conf import settings</p>

<p>from djangogcal.adapter import CalendarAdapter, CalendarEventData
<br/>from djangogcal.observer import CalendarObserver</p>

<p>from models import Showing</p>

<p>class ShowingCalendarAdapter(CalendarAdapter):
<br/>    &quot;&quot;&quot;
<br/>    A calendar adapter for the Showing model.
<br/>    &quot;&quot;&quot;
<br/>    
<br/>    def get_event_data(self, instance):
<br/>        &quot;&quot;&quot;
<br/>        Returns a CalendarEventData object filled with data from the adaptee.
<br/>        &quot;&quot;&quot;
<br/>        return CalendarEventData(
<br/>            start=instance.start_time,
<br/>            end=instance.end_time,
<br/>            title=instance.title
<br/>        )</p>

<p>observer = CalendarObserver(email=settings.CALENDAR_EMAIL,
<br/>                            password=settings.CALENDAR_PASSWORD)
<br/>observer.observe(Showing, ShowingCalendarAdapter())</p>
 summary : <p>This project aims to be a drop-in solution for calendaring for any django app. I use this code, so it is living and breathing. If you have questions or suggestions for edge cases, I&#39;ll entertain them, but I can&#39;t guarantee that I&#39;ll implement them. For more information on gencal, you can visit my blog (which contains information on using gencal as well as any possible decisions being considered in reference to it) at http://justinlilly.com/</p>

 summary : <p>Overviewdjango-geo-kit is built on top to GeoDjango, the GIS branch of the Django Framework.  GeoDjango wraps three powerful libraries into one intuitive package: PostGIS, GEOS, and Proj.4. DGT complements this functionality with tools that work with you at the application level.  With DGT, you can easily relate GIS information to your models and the API is designed to return data in formats that work well with both maps and user interface controls. 
<br/> </p>

<p>GoalsThe goal of django-geo-tools (DGT) is to provide a well-rounded and easy to use suite of tools for adding basic geospatial features to your Django apps.  The project will include utilities for adding location attributes to your models as well as client side tools for mapping the data. </p>

<p> </p>

<p>DGT will help you spruce up your web applications with features like: </p>

<p>GeoTagging Find within city, state, zip code  Proximity searches based on a street address or (latitude,longitude) point Interactive maps - let users label locations on a map </p>

<p> NOTE this project is in very early stages of development     For the early phases of development, the client side mapping capabilities will be based on the Google Maps API.</p>
 title : The django-geo-kit Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>I manage a lot of Django projects that present slightly-different forms to users depending on the site/domain they&#39;re visiting.  There&#39;s also a bunch of custom submission code that differs from form to form, but that&#39;s neither here nor there. </p>

<p>I need different Google Analytics codes depending on the sites and after sticking these tags into every single template, I thought it would be cool to be able to manage these Google analytics accounts from the Django admin page. I also added a mode of operation that excludes the admin interface altogether (you can just use the template tag) </p>

<p>Aren&#39;t there other solutions already?In my searches I ran across two methods that have been around for a while but which I didn&#39;t find to be adequate.  The first is a Google Analytics middleware by Will Larson.  This method inspects each request, searches it for a  tag and dynamically insert the google analytics code.   </p>

<p>The bad thing is that the template for the tags are hard coded into the middleware, and as far as I know, this kind of defeats the purpose of caching, as a regular expression and some other code must be called for every request.  You&#39;ve also got to purposefully exclude the admin interface, which most people are never going to want to track anyway.   </p>

<p>Finally, you can&#39;t tie GA codes to sites (you can specify them in different settings files, though) and have them inserted properly.  I like the ability to administer as much as possible from the admin (when ideal). </p>

<p>The second method I found was a snippet that defined a simple template tag which replicates the second mode of operation you see below.  It&#39;s a little raw, but it works.  The main downside with this is that, again, you cannot edit the codes from the admin interface and you can&#39;t tie them to specific sites. </p>

<p>Two modes of operationAdministering and associating codes with Django sites Add the google_analytics application to your INSTALLED_APPS section of your settings.py.  This mode requires that you be using the Django sites framework too, so make sure you have that set up as well.  Add GOOGLE_ANALYTICS_MODEL = True to your settings.py  Run a ./manage.py syncdb to add the database tables  Go to your project&#39;s admin page (usually /admin/) and click into a site objects  You&#39;ll now see a new field under the normal site information called &quot;Analytics Code&quot;. In this box you put your unique analytics code for your project&#39;s domain.  It looks like UA-xxxxxx-x and save the site.  In your base template (usually a base.html) insert this tag at the very top: {% load analytics %}  In the same template, insert the following code right before the closing body tag: {% analytics %} Just using the template tag Add the google_analytics application to your INSTALLED_APPS section of your settings.py.  In your base template, usually a base.html, insert this tag at the very top: {% load analytics %}  In the same template, insert the following code right before the closing body tag: {% analytics &quot;UA-xxxxxx-x&quot; %} the UA-xxxxxx-x is a unique Google Analytics code for you domain when you sign up for a new account.</p>
 title : The django-google-analytics Open Source Project on Open Hub
 title : The django-googleanalytics Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>Simple solution for a simple task. This app helps you including google analyitics tracking codes to your site templates. </p>

<p>DocumentationInstallationCheckout the app from the svn repo:  svn co http://django-googleanalytics.googlecode.com/svn/trunk/google_analyticsMake sure the app is in your python path and add it to your INSTALLED_APPS settings Add the templatetag {% googleanalytics %} where you want the google analitics code to be inserted in your templates, don&#39;t forget to load it first in each template: {% load googleanalytics_tags %}. You can use as many tags as you need and you can (optionally) specify diferent codes for each, see bellow if you want some examples: Using the googleanalytics tagSyntax: </p>

<p>{% googleanalytics [account-code] %}The simplest and tipical usage of this tag: </p>

<p>{% googleanalytics %}This just inserts in place the google analitics tracking code (this is just a cuple of html script tags) using the account code (the code that idenifies your account) specified in the GOOGLE_ANALYTICS_ACCOUNT_CODE setting. If you don&#39;t set this or set it to False the tag will be ignored and no code will be inserted (this is useful in some cases... for example I prefer to set it to False in my development local settings insted of using {% if not debug %}). </p>

<p>You can also explicitly pass the account code as a tag param: </p>

<p>{% googleanalytics &quot;UA-xxxxxx-x&quot; %}This is specially usefull if you want to track to different accounts depending on the view/template, you can use this tag as many times as you need. </p>

<p>About the tracking code templateThe tracking code is the html code that google ask you to put on the pages to be tracked, in this app the code lives in a template (google_analitics/tracking_code.html) so you can override it if you want. </p>

<p>Using the legacy tracking code (urchin.js)If you use the default template you can use the legacy tracking code. </p>

<p>By default the current recomended tracking code by google is used (ga.js) but if you have good reasons you can use the legacy tracking code (the old urchin.js) by setting GOOGLE_ANALYTICS_LEGACY_CODE = True, in your settings, but keep in mind that this is not recomended by google: &quot;Please note that urchin.js will not receive feature updates and is not compatible with new features.&quot;.</p>
