 title : The django-googlemap Open Source Project on Open Hub
 title : The django-granular-permissions Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>Django Granular Permissions allow you to setup per-row permissions. </p>

<p>ver 0.2 adds NewForms-Admin support. </p>

<p>This project is injecting new methods into Django&#39;s auth.User and auth.Group in a non-invasive way (doesn&#39;t require modifying Django&#39;s code). </p>

<p>Simple permission checks within views and templates with templatetags. </p>

<p>You just simply have to install django-granular-permissions somewhere on your PYTHONPATH and add &#39;django_granular_permissions&#39; to your installed apps and invoke </p>

<p>python manage.py syncdbNote: superusers will always have True returned on has_row_perm(), also not active users will always get False </p>

<p>Example: </p>

<p># adding permission &#39;edit&#39; to a user &#39;Bart&#39; on an instance of a MyObject from myapp.models
<br/>&gt;&gt;&gt; from django.contrib.auth.models import User, Group
<br/>&gt;&gt;&gt; from myapp.models import MyObject
<br/>&gt;&gt;&gt; user = User.objects.get(username=&#39;Bart&#39;)
<br/>&gt;&gt;&gt; obj = MyObject()
<br/>&gt;&gt;&gt; obj.save()
<br/>&gt;&gt;&gt; user.add_row_perm(obj, &#39;edit&#39;)
<br/>&gt;&gt;&gt; user.has_row_perm(obj, &#39;edit&#39;)
<br/>True
<br/>&gt;&gt;&gt; user.has_row_perm(obj, &#39;delete&#39;)
<br/>False </p>

<p># similar for groups
<br/>&gt;&gt;&gt; group = Group.objects.get(pk=1) # get first group in the db
<br/>&gt;&gt;&gt; group.add_row_perm(obj, &#39;read&#39;)</p>

<p># now we&#39;ll add the user to the group and he will inherit the &#39;read&#39; permission
<br/>&gt;&gt;&gt; user.groups.add(group)
<br/>&gt;&gt;&gt; user.has_row_perm(obj, &#39;read&#39;)
<br/>True</p>

<p># now to remove permission
<br/>&gt;&gt;&gt; user.del_row_perm(obj, &#39;edit&#39;)
<br/>&gt;&gt;&gt; user.has_row_perm(obj, &#39;edit&#39;)
<br/>False</p>

<p># note that when you try to remove a permission from a user that is granted to him through group nothing changes
<br/>&gt;&gt;&gt; user.del_row_perm(obj, &#39;read&#39;)
<br/>&gt;&gt;&gt; user.has_row_perm(obj, &#39;read&#39;)
<br/>True</p>

<p># get all rows for a MyObject table that given user has &#39;read&#39; permission
<br/>&gt;&gt;&gt; user.get_rows_with_permission(MyObject(), &#39;read&#39;)
<br/># same method exists for groups</p>
 title : Page Not Found - Open Hub

 title : The django-issues Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>Django JITS (Just In Time Scheduler)A scheduling system for django.  </p>

<p>Instead of a traditional scheduler which has a main loop, usually in a thread, which polls for scheduled tasks this scheduler&#39;s polls are triggered by each new request. This way scheduled events are fired as often as needed to retrieve new data that may be needed for local content adjustment without the overhead of another thread and polling loop. </p>

<p>If you already have setuptools installed you can very simply: </p>

<p>sudo easy_install jitsFor more in depth information on installing setuptools and jits and configuring jits for your Django project refer to InstallAndConfig. </p>

<p>To checkout the source: </p>

<p>svn checkout http://django-jits.googlecode.com/svn/trunk/ django-jits</p>
 title : The django-jits Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>The Django Komodo Kit intends to various utilities and plugins to enhance productivity while implementing Django-based projects using Komodo Edit or Komodo IDE. The baseline for the feature set will be the freely available Komodo Edit application.   </p>

<p>The ActiveState Komodo editor/IDE is built on Mozilla technology and it provides a lot of easy to use hooks for customizing your environment. With a focus on Django development, this project will provide and collect:  </p>

<p>snippets   macros  commands  toolbars  templates extensions  Since a user of Komodo Edit will have individual preferences for which aspects of the application they are most comfortable with, features will be available via as many editor-specific hooks as makes sense.  For example, a feature to create stub code for a new Model could appear as a toolbar button, a context menu item in various places, or a snippet. </p>

<p>One auxiliary goal of the project is to implement as much as possible in Python.  Some combination of interfacing with XPCOM or possibly experimenting with Django apps that output XUL will be investigated. </p>

 summary : <p>lifefeed is a simple Django life stream app that lets you pull in your life stream from FriendFeed. </p>

<p>&#39;lifefeed&#39;If you wish to used the default html template be sure your TEMPLATE_LOADERS has the following </p>

<p>&#39;django.template.loaders.app_directories.load_template_source&#39;Template TagIn any template where you would like your FriendFeed lifestream to show </p>

<p>{% load lifefeed %}{% load cache %}
<br/>{% cache 900 friendfeed %}
<br/>    {% lifefeed &quot;YOUR FRIEND FEED USERNAME&quot; 10 %}
<br/>{% endcache %}TemplateIf you would like to use your own template to render the items create a friendfeed.html template in the root of your templates directory.  Or you can render any sources items differntley by dropping a template named after a friendfeed source id.  For example netflix.html </p>

 title : The django-math-captcha Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>django-math-captcha is a simple app for generating math-based captchas for your Django apps.</p>
 title : The django-menu Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>menu, </p>
 summary : <p>Documentación en español de django-menuse. </p>

<p>menuseThis app lets you create and administer menus from flatpages in 5 easy steps: </p>

<p>Create your flatpages. Create a menu. Generate links based on a flatpage or URI. Select the links corresponding to that menu. Place the menu in your HTML. </p>

<p>FeaturesNo need to create new flatpages or modify it&#39;s code. Can link to existing flatpages. Can link to a flatpage or URI. Menus and/or links can be restricted to staff users only. Menus and/or links can be restricted to (not) authenticated users. Possibility of having multiple menus. Menus can share links. Include your menu with just one simple template tag. Support for keywords. A separator between links can be defined from the template. (Only in svn) URL names can be used instead of the full URL. (Only in svn) KeywordsKeywords are a way to set links dynamically. </p>

<p>{{ SELF }} It&#39;s replaced with the URI that is being visited. {{ GET }} It&#39;s replaced with all the parameters received by the GET method. {{ URL }} It&#39;s replaced with the URI of the site. {{ LOGIN }} It&#39;s replaced with settings.LOGIN_URL {{ LOGOUT }} It&#39;s replaced with settings.LOGOUT_URL {{ SIGNUP }} It&#39;s replaced with settings.SIGNUP_URL (Only in svn) Be careful with the last one, remember that SIGNUP_URL is not a standard setting, so it will raise an exception if it&#39;s not found, but the templatetag will fail silently. This means that if all your links point to the URL you are viewing and rebooting your web server doesn&#39;t fix it, check this. </p>

<p>The keyword SELF is useful when combined with, for example, LOGIN: </p>

<p>{{ LOGIN }}?next={{ SELF }}Would result in something like: </p>

<p>/accounts/login/?next=/product/view/007/ReverseWhen the keyword &#39;reverse:&#39; appears in a URL, menuse will know that it has to resolve the given name to a URL. Suppose you have the following: </p>

<p>urls.py </p>

<p>urlpatterns = patterns(&#39;&#39;,
<br/>    (r&#39;accounts/^$&#39;, index, name=&#39;user-home&#39;),
<br/>    (r&#39;accounts/profile/^$&#39;, profile, name=&#39;user-profile&#39;),
<br/>    (r&#39;accounts/url/^$&#39;, url, name=&#39;user-url&#39;))This would be the link&#39;s URL: </p>

<p>reverse:user-profile?next=reverse:user-home&amp;url=reverse:user-urlWhich would output: </p>

<p>/accounts/profile/?next=/accounts/&amp;url=/accounts/url/This could also be combined with keywords! Like this: </p>

<p>{{ SIGNUP }}?next=reverse:user-homeLimitationsReversing names has still some limitations: </p>

<p>Can&#39;t reverse two consecutive URLs, needs at least one ? or &amp; character in between them. I see no real problem in this, but if you need a different behavior let me know. Check utils.py for more information. Passing arguments to the URL is not implemented yet. </p>

<p>TODOsAllow subitems. Allow multiple coma separated urls. Allow linking by url name. SourceCheckout a copy from the SVN: svn checkout http://django-menuse.googlecode.com/svn/trunk/ menuseDownload the source compressed. This could be a little out of date with respect to the svn. And a little buggy too. InstallationGet the source and copy the files to a directory in your project (i.e. &quot;menuse&quot;.) Add the app to your INSTALLED_APPS. Run syncdb. UsageCreate the flatpages you will link to (if you don&#39;t have them already.) Create links that will be included in your menus and link them to a flatpage, URI or keyword. Create the menus you need and select which links to display. In your template: Load the template tag: {% load render_menu %} Place the menu in the HTML: {% render_menu MenuName %} Every menu is displayed as an unordered list (</p>

<p>) and every link as a list item () Both have a class attribute, the menu&#39;s class is it&#39;s name in lowercase and the link&#39;s class is the same as the menu&#39;s plus &quot;_item&quot;. </p>

<p>Example: </p>

<p>    Home
<br/>    Contact
<br/>In action!http://www.icub.edu.uy/ http://django-bigua.googlecode.com/ http://www.profesores.edu.uy/ http://www.ifreewallpapers.com/ If you use it let me know and I&#39;ll add your site to the list. </p>

<p>NoteIf you downloaded the file django-menuse_x.xx-multilingual.tar.gz you will need the app django-multilingual installed in your project also.</p>
 title : The django-menuse Open Source Project on Open Hub
 title : The django-messaging Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>A messaging system with users last activity indicator for the django framework. Good for community sites so people can see who is active, and communicate via quick pms. </p>

<p>The version 0.3 contains a few bugfixes, but it is still a beta. </p>

<p>FeaturesSend personal messages to users that are in your contact list Users see their contacts&#39;s last activity on the site in minutes/hours/days Contact list management Full ajax interface  </p>

<p>InstallThis software works with django 0.97 svn </p>

<p>Put the folder django_messaging in your python path </p>

<p>SettingsRegister the app: add this line in your INSTALLED_APPS </p>

<p>&#39;django_messaging&#39;,Register the middleware: add this line in your MIDDLEWARE_CLASSES </p>

<p>&#39;django_messaging.middleware.DjangoMessagingMiddleware&#39;,Configure the profile class: </p>

<p>AUTH_PROFILE_MODULE=&#39;django_messaging.DmUser&#39;Note: you have to use django_messaging.DmUser class for the moment. The ability to use his own AUTH_PROFILE_MODULE class may be added later. </p>

<p>Be sure to have your MEDIA_URL and MEDIA_ROOT settings configured. </p>

<p>TemplatesCopy the templates/messaging folder to your templates directory. </p>

<p>Put this line in your template wherever you want the messaging interface to appear: </p>

<p>load_index()</p>

<p>Media filesCopy the media directory to the location setup in MEDIA_ROOT and rename this directory to messaging </p>

<p>JavascriptAdd these lines to your main template to call the javascript libs (replace my_media_url with your media path): </p>

<p>SetupIf you plug this module in a site that has existing users, you have to run a script before start using it, or adding users to contacts wont work until the users connect to the site: </p>

<p>Be sure to have your project in the python path Export your settings environement variable (replace my_project with your project name) </p>

<p>$ export DJANGO_SETTINGS_MODULE=my_project.settingsRun the setup script: $ cd django_messaging/tests/
<br/>$ python setup.pyNotesThe application is not yet internationalized: all the application messages are in french. Help welcome. </p>

<p>Contribute and feedbackPlease report any bugs </p>

<p>Feel free to improve the code or to come talk about the module: syntax_error in #django-fr on irc.freenode.net - Site: http://www.patrainet.com</p>
 title : The django-microformats Open Source Project on Open Hub

 title : The django-modelhistory Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>Revision Support for Django ModelsMotivationThe &#39;fullhistory&#39; branch has been lying dormant for a few months it seems (at least no commits to the django hosted branch) - so I&#39;ve recently updated and implemented leftover functionality in a modified version of the branch. </p>

<p>DisclaimersThis code has been tested and should work with django trunk (last tested r5546) and is likely to have some backwards-incompatibility (I haven&#39;t tested it) with 0.96 or earlier, though feedback on this issue is welcome. This code will be experiencing some potentially significant functional changes as some leftover features are integrated - this is your fair warning :-D It is undoubtedly imperfect, but it should work in common use cases that are checked by the included tests. The embedded docs should shed light on any differences. The current code also provides for determining the calling user (the django.contrib.auth.models.User who initiated the model change). This method works (tilts head) but is meant more as a placeholder until a better implementation is discussed/implemented. API</p>

<p>Method Name                                Return Value       get_version(obj,rev)                       Model/None       get_version_by_date(obj,date)              QuerySet/list()     get_history(obj,offset=0)                  QuerySet/list()     set_version(obj,rev)                       Model/None       restore_version(content_type,obj_id,rev)    Model/None     </p>

<p>Future WorkModelhistory should probably provide some means (if end user-desired) of providing distinct tables for each revisioned object. With regard to (1), we have syncdb hooks and  could be autogenerated; however, (1) might be best served when coupled with a distinct subsystem that manages backend-specific logic - i.e., django/ multi-db allowing for a separate archival database, in which case this discussion would require a much broader consensus/design points. Consider implementing delta-only change log entries (full object serialized in first version, deltas only to follow - (space v. execution time (specifically,reverts))</p>

 summary : <p>messaging between objects in Django</p>

Everyone else who has reported bugs against this project. Thanks to the django-pyodbc team for cross-pollination.</p>

 summary : <p>This is a GSoC 2007 project aimed at integrating Django&#39;s existing caching functionality into new cache() methods on QuerySet ORM lookups. </p>

<p>Getting the source codeYou can check out the code with something like the following command: </p>

<p>svn co http://django-object-level-caching.googlecode.com/svn/trunk/ dolcDependenciesFor now, I&#39;m going to be working against the latest svn version of Django, updated daily; until QuerySetRefactoring rolls around, the QuerySet code will be quite stable. Django&#39;s caching framework supports any backend you&#39;d like to use easily, but I&#39;ll be most likely testing with memcached and simple. </p>

 title : The django-offline Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>With the recent release of Google Gears, there is a real possibility of making Django applications available offline. </p>

In the end, a Django application will be available to automate part of this process, as well as a framework for tying in custom JavaScript code to fill in the gaps that can&#39;t be automated.</p>
 title : The django-on-twisted Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>This is DOT(Django On Twisted)Normally, django runs on Apache web server as production server or runserver feature in django for development, but under Apache, it takes too much time to (re)start and is difficult to combine other python-based network applications, like pydirector for load-balancing, so I use this script for running django on Twisted.web2 framework. </p>

<p>The DOT is the derived work of jnoetzelman&#39;s work in Django development trac. </p>

<p>RequirementPython 2.5(or later) twisted framework 2.5(or later or svn) twisted.web2 0.2.0(or later or svn) InstallationDownload the DOT(Django On Twisted) and uncompress the tarball. </p>

<p>spike@bebop:/bebop/work/django_test$ pwd
<br/>/bebop/work/django_test
<br/>spike@bebop:/bebop/work/django_test$ v
<br/>total 0
<br/>drwxr-xr-x 6 spike spike  54 2008-01-24 12:48 .
<br/>drwxr-xr-x 7 spike spike 143 2008-01-24 12:45 ..
<br/>drwxr-xr-x 3 spike spike  49 2008-01-24 12:45 db
<br/>drwxr-xr-x 5 spike spike 110 2008-01-24 12:48 django_testdjango_test was created by django-admin.py startproject django_test, yeah, it&#39;s django project home directory. </p>

<p>And we download the source from SVN and copy it in current directory. </p>

<p>spike@bebop:/bebop/work/django_test$ /usr/bin/svn checkout http://django-on-twisted.googlecode.com/svn/trunk/ 
<br/>A    trunk/init.py
<br/>A    trunk/run.py
<br/>A    trunk/conf.py
<br/>A    trunk/init.sh
<br/>Checked out revision 9.
<br/>spike@bebop:/bebop/work/django_test$ cp trunk/*.* .
<br/>spike@bebop:/bebop/work/django_test$ ls -al
<br/>total 20
<br/>drwxr-xr-x 7 spike spike  121 Jan 24 12:51 .
<br/>drwxr-xr-x 7 spike spike  143 Jan 24 12:45 ..
<br/>-rw-r--r-- 1 spike spike 1043 Jan 24 12:51 conf.py
<br/>drwxr-xr-x 3 spike spike   49 Jan 24 12:45 db
<br/>drwxr-xr-x 5 spike spike  110 Jan 24 12:48 django_test
<br/>-rw-r--r-- 1 spike spike 2041 Jan 24 12:51 init.py
<br/>-rw-r--r-- 1 spike spike  961 Jan 24 12:51 init.sh
<br/>drwxr-xr-x 2 spike spike   27 Jan 24 12:47 log
<br/>-rw-r--r-- 1 spike spike 4692 Jan 24 12:51 run.py
<br/>drwxr-xr-x 3 spike spike   72 Jan 24 12:51 trunkAll thing done. </p>

<p>ConfigurationIn the DOT&#39;s default configuration file, conf.py, you can edit the default configuration. This is default conf.py. </p>

<p># ports to be run.
<br/>PORTS = (9000, )</p>

<p># private key path
<br/>SSL_PRIVATE_KEY_PATH = None</p>

<p># logging style, &#39;apache&#39; or None
<br/>LOG_STYLE = NonePORTSThe DOT supports the multiple instance of your django project, that is you can run the sam e project in the many instance, which runs with another port. PORTS is the tuple datatype of python, so you append the other ports inside tuple like this, </p>

<p>PORTS = (9000, 9001, 9002, 9003, 9004, )SSL_PRIVATE_KEY_PATHThe DOT supports SSL, it rely on the Twisted SSL feature(twisted.internet.ssl). If you set the pem file path in the SSL_PRIVATE_KEY_PATH, if SSL_PRIVATE_KEY_PATH is set, DOT automatically runs your django project in SSL. </p>

<p>LOG_STYLEThe Twisted.web2 print out the apache-style log, but for the purpose of debuggin, DOT support the managed-style log. If you set the apache in LOG_STYLE, you can have the apache-style log. </p>

<p>All the log will be stored in log/ directory and log name is .log. </p>

<p>Run Your Django ProjectAfter the configuration, you are ready to run the DOT, just simply type like this, </p>

<p>spike@bebop:/bebop/work/django_test$ sh init.sh django_test startAs I alreay mentioned, the django_test is your django project name. init.sh support 4 actions like the init script of UNIX. </p>

<p>Actions of init.sh </p>

<p>start  start your django project  stop  stop it  restart  restart it  stand  don&#39;t fork it as sub-process, so all the log can monitor in there  </p>

<p>spike@bebop:/bebop/work/django_test$ sh init.sh django_test stand
<br/>Standing
<br/>Removing stale pidfile /home/bebop/work/django_test/log/9000.pid
<br/>2008/01/24 13:07 +0900 [-] Log opened.
<br/>2008/01/24 13:07 +0900 [-] twistd 2.5.0 (/usr/bin/python 2.5.1) starting up
<br/>2008/01/24 13:07 +0900 [-] reactor class: 
<br/>2008/01/24 13:07 +0900 [-] Loading run.py...
<br/>2008/01/24 13:07 +0900 [-] Loaded.
<br/>2008/01/24 13:07 +0900 [-] twisted.web2.channel.http.HTTPFactory starting on 9000
<br/>2008/01/24 13:07 +0900 [-] Starting factory If you don&#39;t have any errors, open up your django project in your web browser.</p>

 title : The django-pagination Open Source Project on Open Hub
 title : The django-pennypress Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>A Penny Press newspaper was a cheap paper in the 19th century that brought the news to the masses because it was affordable for the working class. </p>

<p>Penny Press is an open source content management system geared towards local online news sites.   </p>

<p>Building an online news site is expensive.  Penny Press hopes to lower the cost needed to enter the online news world.  As the big newspapers companies lose more and more money, local news will be produced by fewer and fewer companies and in turn, there will be fewer voices in the press.  The lower cost of entrance will help keep the diversity of those voices in tact. </p>

<p>Penny Press will follow standards found both in the web world and the news world. Standards such as NITF/NewsML import and export from the news world.  Standards such as RSS/Atom from the web world. </p>

<p>Penny Press has been migrated to launchpad.net, http://launchpad.net/django-pennypress</p>

 summary : <p>A thin layer around Django&#39;s MySQL DB driver that supports per-process or per-thread persistent connections.</p>

 title : The django-photologue Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>Photologue is a reusable Django application that provides powerful image management and manipulation functionality as well as a complete photo gallery solution. The 2.0 release adds more effects, including reflections and transparent watermarks. It also introduces the ImageModel abstract base class allowing developers to easily integrated the Photologue core functionality into their own models. Photologue embraces the Django admin and smoothly integrates with photo thumbnails and effect previews.</p>
 summary : <p>I wanted an easy way to get any random image from my Picasa Web public gallery onto my Web page, so I built this.  It uses the RSS feeds provided by Google to first find all of the public albums.  Then it finds all photos within the albums it finds.  Basic information about each photo and album is then stored in the local database to make retrieval a bit faster.  The local database can easily be refreshed when needed from the Django administration utility. </p>

<p>InstallationI don&#39;t have a packaged release for django-picasa yet, so you&#39;ll have to stick with an SVN version. </p>

<p>svn co http://django-picasa.googlecode.com/svn/trunk/picasaPut the contents of that directory somewhere on your PYTHONPATH, and you should be good to go.  To verify your installation, try the following command: </p>

<p>python -c &quot;import picasa&quot;If that doesn&#39;t display any errors (or output at all), then your installation worked.  If it spits out an ImportError, something went wrong. </p>

<p>Next, in your settings.py file, just add &#39;picasa&#39; to your INSTALLED_APPS list, specify the gallery (or galleries) to use by specifying something like PICASA_USERS = [&#39;mypicasausername&#39;] in settings.py, and run ./manage.py syncdb to install the required tables.  As soon as that is done, log into your site&#39;s administration panel and enter either the Picasa Albums or Picasa Photos section and click the &quot;Refresh database&quot; button/link.  If this link is not available (you might need to install JQuery in a special place...), try going to /admin/picasa/update/. </p>

<p>UsageIn the template that you would like the random image to be displayed in, make sure you have {% load picasa_tags %} somewhere (most likely near the top of your template).  Then you may use the {% random_picasa_photo %} template tag to insert your image. </p>

<p>If you&#39;re looking for some &quot;fancy&quot; effects, you can use the random_picasa_photo.js file that comes with django-picasa.  You may find it at picasa/templates/picasa/random_picasa_photo.js.  In it, I employ JQuery to change the random image every so often, fading images in and out in the process.  All of the images are displayed using CSS.</p>

 summary : <p>django-pipes offers a nice API to access remote JSON resources from within your Django applications. The API is intentionally kept as close as possible to the Django DB-API. So accessing data from a remote JSON API should feel just like an attempt to fetch the data from a database. It is inspired by Ruby on Rails&#39; ActiveResource library. </p>

<p>TutorialCheck out the tutorial at GitHub.</p>

 title : The django-plus Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>This is a functional work in progress for a private message system for Django projects. </p>

<p>The folders are accessed through the user&#39;s related manager: </p>

<p>user.inbox for received messages user.outbox for sent messages user.drafts for saved messages </p>

<p>Features:Contact list Black list User filter in the message lists Undelete Message history Check out the urls and the models to have a better idea: </p>

<p>http://django-pm.googlecode.com/svn/trunk/myproject/pm/urls.py http://django-pm.googlecode.com/svn/trunk/myproject/pm/models.py </p>

<p>TODO:clean some logic fixtures and css for the project example templates internationalization French locale ( because i can :P ) cron script to remove messages flagged for deletion unit tests ( yeah, i know, i should have done them before ! :P ) Project example:In the trunk you will find a test project, download it and run </p>

<p>manage.py runserverGo to the admin url http://127.0.0.1:8000/admin/ and log in with &quot;Admin&quot; / &quot;test&quot; ( case sensitive ) </p>

<p>Then go to your inbox : http://127.0.0.1:8000/pm/inbox/ </p>

<p>You can only send messages to yourself in this project </p>

<p>Notification:The private messaging system gives a feedback to the user through a custom system using the sessions framework. </p>

<p>You can either use it for your whole project, or replace it in the code with </p>

<p>request.user.messages_set.create(message=message)There is a special caveat with the messages containing undo links when you delete a message. </p>

<p>This notification system is explained here : http://django-pm.googlecode.com/svn/trunk/myproject/notification/__init__.py </p>

<p>User input filtering:User input is not filtered but the hooks are there, feel free to add your recipies there: http://django-pm.googlecode.com/svn/trunk/myproject/pm/formatters.py </p>

<p>Trunk:http://django-pm.googlecode.com/svn/trunk/</p>

 title : The django-profile Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>IntroductionThis is a Django pluggable user profile zone which can be used and customized easily in your social application web platform developed in django.  </p>

<p>It&#39;s developed with Django for the backend framework and uses Jquery as the javascript library for the client UI. It avoids big amounts of development time process in such a generic thing as the User Profile and account utilities. </p>

<p>News2008-09-24 Version 0.6 published. These are the most important changes: </p>

<p>Version 0.6.0 </p>

<p>Compatible with Django 1.0. Lot of simplifications. Removed the public/private user selection. It was confusing. Model abstraction with django model inheritance. Now the Profile class has been renamed BaseProfile. Thanks to Rob Yates and Alvaro Mouriño. Better management of avatars. New templatetag to generate thumbs on the fly. Thanks to Alvaro Mouriño. Password managament modified to use the new django password management utilities. Added internacionalization of the urls. Credits to Alvaro Stevens. </p>

<p>2008-07-21 The actual version on the SVN trunk is only compatible with the SVN version of Django. That&#39;s because newforms-admin has been merged into Django, newforms is the official forms library now, and this has a lot of implications that has been solved to make django-profile compatible with the new version of Django. </p>

<p>2008-07-21 Django-profile 0.5 was the last version compatible with django 0.96. The next version will only be compatible with Django 1.0. </p>

Now there&#39;s no gratuit javascript code, the application usability has been increased, lot of improvements, etc. You&#39;re invited to try the demo and test it for yourself: http://profile.coredump.es </p>

Lot of this work made as team with jonas.esp (http://code.google.com/u/jonas.esp/). </p>

 summary : <p>This project allows a fluxbb/punbb and django applications working together. Features are provided in 3 applications: </p>

<p>punbb.authent punbb.forum punbb.avatar </p>

<p>The punbb.authent application is a dependencie for the 2 others applications. </p>

<p>Featurespunbb.authentIt provides </p>

<p>the punbb&#39;s user and group models a backend for authentication based on punbb users a middleware providing a kind of sso with a punbb application a command to import punbb users and groups into django.auth models  </p>

<p>punbb.forumIt provides </p>

<p>the others punbb&#39;s models a command to import punbb forums into tribes (pinax) models </p>

<p>punbb.avatarIt is based on the gravatar (pinax) application </p>

<p>both punbb and gravatar avatars management </p>

<p>UsageAdd the PunBBSessionMiddleware middleware after session and authentication middlewares: MIDDLEWARE_CLASSES = (
<br/>    ...,
<br/>    &#39;django.contrib.sessions.middleware.SessionMiddleware&#39;,
<br/>    &#39;django.contrib.auth.middleware.AuthenticationMiddleware&#39;,
<br/>    &#39;punbb.authent.middleware.PunBBSessionMiddleware&#39;,
<br/>    ...,
<br/>)Add this in the settings.py file: AUTHENTICATION_BACKENDS = (
<br/> &#39;punbb.authent.authentication.PunBBShaBackend&#39;,
<br/>)
<br/>COOKIE_SEED = &#39;SAME VALUE AS $COOKIE_SEED IN CONFIG.PHP&#39;
<br/>PUNBB_COOKIE_NAME = &#39;punbb_cookie&#39;
<br/>EXTERN_USER_IS_STAFF = False         # if True, PunBB users are django staff users
<br/>PUNBB_TABLES_PREFIX = &#39;punbb_&#39;       # you should edit thisCommandsusage: python manage.py [command]import_punbb_usersimports punbb users/groups  into django authentication tables. </p>

<p>import_punbb2tribesThis command  should work in the context of django project that support forums features, like pinax. </p>

<p>It imports forums, categories, posts into django (pinax tribes) tables. The mapping is as follows: </p>

<p>punbb  pinax tribes   category    tribe  forum       tag   topics      topic   posts       threadedcomment  </p>

<p>Attention: the import_punbb_users command should be runned before. </p>

<p>SSO use casethe user loggs in with a username/password from punBB database the user opens a session from django: a punBB session is also opened. the user opens a session from punBB: a django session is also opened. example of a sso integration with 2 php applications: </p>

<p>dokuwiki (support authentication based on a punBB db) punBB forum (user/group data) django site (with django-punbb inside)</p>
 title : The django-punbb Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>DescriptionA Django external database backend for MS SQL Server that uses ODBC by employing the pyodbc library, supports SQL Server 2000 and 2005.  </p>

<p>Pyodbc seems to be a mature, viable way to access SQL Server from Python in multiple platforms and is actively maintained. It&#39;s also used by SQLAlchemy for SQL Server connections. </p>

<p>ImportantIf you are following Django trunk development and have revision 10026 or newer, the minimal development revision of django-pyodbc trunk you need to use is r157. </p>

<p>Also, the DATABASE_ODBC_DRIVER, DATABASE_ODBC_DSN and DATABASE_ODBC_EXTRA_PARAMS settings were migrated to the DATABASE_OPTIONS dictionary setting in this revision. </p>

<p>This is a backward-incompatible change for setups that were using at least one of these three settings. The equivalent DATABASE_OPTIONS keys are &#39;driver, &#39;dsn&#39; and &#39;extra_params&#39; respectively.  </p>

<p>SVN trunk development follows closely Django development, so it needs a recent checkout of Django SVN trunk. On Jan 24, 2009 (r138) a django-1.0.x SVN branch was created, its main purpose is to remain compatible with the Django 1.0.x maintenance branch. </p>

<p>See our News page. </p>

<p>FeaturesWorks on Windows and Linux (using FreeTDS) Native Unicode support. Every string that goes in is stored as Unicode, and every string that goes out of the database is returned as Unicode. No conversion to/from intermediate encodings takes place, so things like max_length in CharField works just like expected. Limit/offset emulation supported in SQL Server 2005 and SQL Server 2000. Offset without limit emulation supported in SQL Server 2005. Both Windows Authentication (Integrated Security) and SQL Server Authentication supported. Passes most of the Django test suite. InstallationInstall pyodbc. Download django-pyodbc. Add the top directory of your django-pyodbc checkout to your PYTHONPATH. In your settings file set the DB engine to sql_server.pyodbc. ConfigurationSee Settings. Examples: </p>

<p>On Windows, accessing SQL Server 2005: </p>

<p>DATABASE_ENGINE = &#39;sql_server.pyodbc&#39;
<br/>DATABASE_NAME = &#39;db_name&#39;
<br/>DATABASE_USER = &#39;webapp&#39;
<br/>DATABASE_PASSWORD = &#39;sikrit&#39;
<br/>DATABASE_HOST = r&#39;test_server\SQLEXPRESS&#39;
<br/>DATABASE_OPTIONS= {
<br/>    &#39;driver&#39;: &#39;SQL Native Client&#39;,
<br/>    &#39;MARS_Connection&#39;: True,
<br/>}Using FreeTDS plus unixODBC on Linux/Unix, accessing SQL Server 2000: </p>

<p>DATABASE_ENGINE = &#39;sql_server.pyodbc&#39;
<br/>DATABASE_NAME = &#39;the_database&#39;
<br/>DATABASE_USER = &#39;django_access&#39;
<br/>DATABASE_PASSWORD = &#39;guessme&#39;
<br/>DATABASE_OPTIONS = {
<br/>    &#39;driver&#39;: &#39;FreeTDS&#39;,
<br/>    &#39;dsn&#39;: &#39;MyDSN&#39;, # ODBC DSN name defined in your odbc.ini
<br/>}Testing environmentsTested on: </p>

<p>SQL Server 2005 Express SP2 and SQL Server 2000 SP4, Python 2.5 and Windows XP.  SQL Server 2005, Python 2.5 and Ubuntu 8.04.  Open issuesCurrently, the following parts of the Django test suite don&#39;t pass: </p>

<p>lookup: Regular expressions are not supported out of the box by SQL Server. Only simple wildcard matching with %, _ and [] character classes. serializers: Forward references cause foreign key constraint violation. ThanksFilip Wasilewski. For his pioneering work, proving this was possible and profusely documenting the code with links to relevant vendor technical articles (Django ticket #5246). mamcxi (http://www.elmalabarista.com). For the first implementation using pymssql (Django ticket #5062). Adam Vandenber (from the django-mssql project). For code to distinguish between different Query classes when sub-classing them. All the Django core developers, especially Malcolm Tredinnick. For being an example of technical excellence and for building such an impressive community. The Oracle Django team (Matt Boersma, Ian Kelly) for some excellent ideas when it comes to implement a custom Django DB backend.</p>
 title : The django-pyodbc Open Source Project on Open Hub
 title : The django-qmanager Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>QManager is an abstracted Django manager which filters via custom queries. </p>

<p>The QManager class is a subclass of django.db.models.Manager which can remove some of the boilerplate in manager definitions. Managers may be used to define &#39;table-level&#39; operations on your models, and one of their most common uses is to provide a pre-defined QuerySet for model data. The typical programming idiom goes something like this:      </p>

<p>  Define your custom manager as a subclass of django.db.models.Manager, overriding the get_query_set method to return a filtered query set. For example: </p>

<p>            class MyManager(models.Manager):
<br/>                def get_query_set(self):
<br/>                    return super(MyManager, self).get_query_set().filter(
<br/>                        field1=&#39;x&#39;, field2=&#39;y&#39;)  On your model, instantiate the manager. Following from the previous example:             class MyModel(models.Model):
<br/>                field1 = models.CharField(...)
<br/>                field2 = models.CharField(...)
<br/>                ...
<br/>                objects = models.Manager() # Default manager instance.
<br/>                my_mgr = MyManager() # Custom manager instance.The problem with this pattern is that it ends up being repeated several times for each model as you try to define several useful custom managers for each type of data. The QManager class abstracts this idiom by providing a simple way of defining managers to return query sets. Now, what originally involved two parts is now down to one: </p>

<p>    class MyModel(models.Model):
<br/>        field1 = models.CharField(...)
<br/>        field2 = models.CharField(...)
<br/>        ...
<br/>        objects = models.Manager()
<br/>        my_mgr = QManager(Q(field1=&#39;x&#39;, field2=&#39;y&#39;))As you can see, a custom manager is defined by passing QManager&#39;s __init__ method a Q object. Q objects are used in Django to specify queries of arbitrary complexity, and by using QManager you don&#39;t need to write all the boilerplate of the first example: all it takes is a simple Q object. </p>

<p>Another feature of Q instances is that they can be combined using the &amp; (and) and | (or) logical operators. These must not be the Python literal and and or operators, as these behave differently to the symbols. Let&#39;s say, for example, that you have two query sets defined by Q instances whose intersection (logical and) you want to find. Each of these query sets would be defined by an instance of Q, like so: </p>

<p>    query1 = Q(public=True)
<br/>    query2 = Q(confirmed=True)Each of these return query sets which contain those records which are public and confirmed, respectively. Such query sets would be obtained by calling the filter method on one of the model&#39;s managers (i.e. objects). Suppose you now want to find all the records which are both public and confirmed, in one query set. Typically, you would define a Q instance such as Q(public=True, confirmed=True), but this violates the DRY principle, as the same information is repeated. Instead, one may simply do this: </p>

<p>    query3 = query1 &amp; query2This is a shortcut which allows you to cut down the amount of extra code you write, and maintain DRY in your code. The QManager class provides a wrapper which lets you do the same thing in your manager definitions. An example might be: </p>

<p>    class MyModel(models.Model):
<br/>        public = models.BooleanField()
<br/>        confirmed = models.BooleanField()
<br/>        ...
<br/>        public_objects = QManager(Q(public=True))
<br/>        confirmed_objects = QManager(Q(confirmed=True))
<br/>        public_confirmed = public_objects &amp; confirmed_objectsThis use of &amp; and | is not restricted to just QManager instances; Q objects, QuerySet instances and regular managers may all be combined with QManager instances via the logical operators. A caveat, however: in these statements, the QManager instance must come before anything else. It is valid, for example, to do this: </p>

<p>    public_confirmed = public_objects &amp; Q(confirmed=True)It is an error, however, to do the following: </p>

<p>    public_confirmed = Q(confirmed=True) &amp; public_objectsIt is advisable to ensure that errors like these do not happen, as they will be difficult to debug if they do: an error will most likely be raised somewhere in Django&#39;s codebase, rather than for QManager. </p>

<p>Another feature of query set manipulation is exclusion. QuerySet and Manager instances have exclude methods which, when called with a Q object, will return the set of all data not matching the conditions given in the query. This is called finding the complement of a set of data, and QManager instances support this through the negation operator (-). For example: </p>

<p>    class MyModel(models.Model):
<br/>        ...
<br/>        public_objects = QManager(Q(public=True))
<br/>        non_public_objects = -public_objectsIf a reference to a QManager instance, whether through their definition (i.e. -QManager(...)) or a variable (i.e. -public_objects), is prepended with a - symbol, then it&#39;s __neg__ magic method will be called. In the case of QManager instances, this will return a new instance whose query is defined as the complement of the old query (Note on implementation: this is done via django.db.models.query.QNot). This may be used in conjunction with the other operators, for example: </p>

<p>    class MyModel(models.Model):
<br/>        ...
<br/>        public_objects = QManager(Q(public=True))
<br/>        non_public_confirmed = confirmed_objects &amp; -public_objects
<br/>        non_confirmed_public = -confirmed_objects &amp; public_objectsA common design pattern which emerges when using QManager is the definition of queries which apply to several similar models. For example, if several of your models have public fields which are boolean flags telling whether or not a record is public, then you may want a manager to get only public records. Because, however, you are defining managers across several models, the query Q(public=True) will be repeated several times. If, one day, you decide to change the field to being called is_public, then each query will have to be edited individually. A typical set-up might look something like this: </p>

<p>    class A(models.Model):
<br/>        public = models.BooleanField()
<br/>        ...
<br/>        public_objects = QManager(Q(public=True))
<br/>    
<br/>    class B(models.Model):
<br/>        public = models.BooleanField()
<br/>        ...
<br/>        public_objects = QManager(Q(public=True))As you can see, because the managers are defined on different models they may not be reused. A simple way around this is to use the QManagerFactory function in this module. At the top of your models file (or a separate file for managers, if you wish), place the following line: </p>

<p>    PublicManager = QManagerFactory(Q(public=True), name=&#39;PublicManager&#39;)PublicManager will now be a class, with the name &#39;PublicManager&#39; (due to the name keyword), which is a subclass of QManager, and has the query attribute pre-defined as Q(public=True). On each model, you now only need to place the following: </p>

<p>    class A(models.Model):
<br/>        public = models.BooleanField()
<br/>        ...
<br/>        public_objects = PublicManager()And likewise for B. For more information on the QManagerFactory function, you are advised to consult its docstring and source code. </p>

<p>For more information, esp. implementation details, consult the source code. It may also be useful to look at the official Django documentation for the Q class and database API.</p>
 title : The django-ratings Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>This project has been moved http://github.com/dcramer/django-ratings/tree/master, </p>
 title : The django-rdf Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>Django-RDF is an RDF engine implemented in a generic, reusable Django app, providing complete RDF support to Django projects without requiring any modifications to existing framework or app source code, or incurring any performance penalty on existing control flow paths.  </p>

<p>The philosophy is simple: Do your web development using Django just like you&#39;re used to, then turn the knob and - with no additional effort - expose your project on the semantic web.  </p>

<p>The project home is at Google Code and there is also a Google Group to help coordinate.  </p>

<p>http://code.google.com/p/django-rdf http://groups.google.com/group/django-rdf  Features  </p>

<p>Django-RDF can expose models from any other app as RDF data. This makes it easy to write new views that return RDF/XML data, and/or query existing models in terms of RDFS or OWL classes and properties using (a variant of) the SPARQL query language. SPARQL in, RDF/XML out - two basic semantic web necessities. </p>

<p>Django-RDF also implements an RDF store using its internal models such as Concept, Predicate, Resource, Statement, Literal, Ontology, Namespace, etc. The SPARQL query engine returns query sets that can freely mix data in the RDF store with data from existing Django models.  </p>

<p> Internals  </p>

<p>During configuration, the syncvb command inspects the database schema created by running syncdb and generates OWL ontologies for other apps in INSTALLED_APPS. The ontologies are serialized to RDF/XML files in the django-rdf/ontology/ directory, and subsequenty deserialized to create a combined vocabulary in the form of RDF model instances.  </p>

<p>The RDFS/OWL classes and properties in the vocabulary are associated with elements of the database schema that are then used by the SPARQL compiler to generate SQL code. A SPARQLQuerySet implementation wraps the compiler and provides access to model instances or values using the familiar Django query set interface - filter, count, iteration with slices, etc.  </p>

<p>A set of APIs gives convenient access to resources. Here is a toy example of a view that uses django.contrib.auth, resets the first name of a user and then renders everything known about that user in the RDF/XML format:   </p>

<p>def reset_first_name(request, username, first_name):
<br/>    AUTH = Namespace.objects.get(code=&#39;auth&#39;) 
<br/>    # Returns a django.contrib.auth.models.User object: 
<br/>    user = AUTH[&#39;user#%s&#39; % username]
<br/>    # Resets the first name of the user:
<br/>    Statement.objects.create(user, AUTH[&#39;User__first_name&#39;], first_name)
<br/>    # Renders everything known about the user in RDF/XML format:
<br/>    return render_as_rdf({resources: (user,)})A small set of shortcuts, templates and template tags simplifies RDF/XML output. An RDF/XML serializer/deserializer is also included. </p>

<p> Plan  </p>

<p>Django-RDF was initially implemented in March 2008. Current status as of April 25 2008 is as follows: </p>

<p>RDF store, basic SPARQL compiler and query set, render_as_rdf shortcut, RDF/XML deserializer, syncvb command are functional. URI synthesis for instances of existing models needs a rewrite. SPARQL implementation is missing features. SPARQL syntax is not compatible with the W3C Recommendation. No access control yet. No internationalization yet. No samples yet. ... and there are many other rough edges here and there.  The plan is to have a fairly polished &quot;ready-for-release&quot; version sometime in summer 2008. A fairly extensive set of unit tests already exists but there is still a lot of churn in various parts of the API, and the immediate goal is to extend the test coverage until the API reaches a more stable state. Feedback from the first intrepid users will be greatly appreciated! (And much of it will likely sound something like, hey, that&#39;s not working quite as advertised! :) </p>

<p>Enjoy, </p>

<p>Stefán</p>
 title : The django-recaptcha Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>This is a little module that helps users to use Recatpcha with some easings, like a Form class you can inherit to use Recaptcha  with no adds.</p>
 title : The django-recipes Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>My mom was writing a family cookbook using Microsoft Word and I thought this was a bad idea for several reasons. At first I thought about using LaTeX to separate the style from the content a bit, then I thought about using XML, then I settled on a database as being the most generic to store recipe data. I quickly decided on using Django to create this cookbook framework because Python is probably my strongest language and it makes creating custom websites really easy. </p>

<p>So far it includes: </p>

<p>Most important models, Recipe, Ingredient, Direction, Category, and a few more. Very nice admin interface for creating recipes with inline ingredients and directions. Front-end: only a recipe_list and recipe_detail so far, but the recipe_detail has an experimental method of displaying recipes that is based on this LaTeX style: http://www.ctan.org/tex-archive/macros/latex/contrib/cooking/ (apparently based on style in a famous German cookbook by Dr. Oetker (Gromzik, J.; Reich, C.; Sander, C. (ed.): Dr. Oetker Schulkochbuch – Das Original. Ceres, Bielefeld, 1996.) </p>

<p>Competitors/related projects: </p>

<p>KRecipes - KDE-based desktop recipes software. Ben Collins-Sussman&#39;s effrecipes - Simple, but it works. Not under active development. Recipes on Rails - Ruby on Rails recipes site. Not open source as far as I know. Embeds &quot;Source: Recipes on Rails&quot; on all photos and has google ads. Great site though. One thing it has that my site lacks is per-direction photos. This would be easy to do. I already have per-direction ingredients. </p>

<p>If you are aware of any other similar projects please let me know. I am especially interested in any other web-based and open-source cookbook projects.</p>
 summary : <p>django-recommenderAboutdjango-recommender is a pluggable that provides methods to work with collective user intelligence. It is a set of methods for getting recommendations using the opinion (votes) of the users compared with the other users&#39; one. So instead of getting only the most popular items on the system, the user can also discover the items that can interest him more. It also may use tags for content based recommendation, i.e., direct matching. </p>

<p>Most of the algorithms are based on Toby Segaran&#39;s book &quot;Programming Collective Intelligence&quot;. </p>

<p>Before you startREQUIRED: This pluggable uses django-voting as basic system for user voting, and django-tagging for content-based recommendation, so they are required for its work. </p>

<p>WARNING: Don&#39;t use this plugable as it is with a huge amount of data, because it is really expensive in CPU and RAM. Instead, use caching or data clustering techniques for managing a limited set of data. </p>

<p>InstallationJust add &#39;recommender&#39; to your INSTALLED_APPS in the settings.py project file. Run &quot;./manage.py syncdb&quot; and &quot;./manage.py test recommender&quot; to check the always interesting unit testing results. </p>

<p>Functionsget_best_items_for_user: This function will return a sorted list of pairs (value, item) containing the recommended items for a given user, based on the votes of the users.  get_similar_users: This function will tell us which are the most similar users, based on the historical votes for similar items. get_best_users_for_item: This function will return the best candidates that may like a given item, based on votes. get_similar_items: The closest items, based on the votes of the users. get_content_based_recs: Get recommendations using a Content Based distance calculation, using tags for items and users. cluster_users: Clustering function to get groups of similar users cluster_items: Clustering function to get groups of similar events How to use itIt&#39;s required to use it with django-voting and django-tagging pluggables. To use the functions, just invoke them through the manager of the Recommender class: Recommender.objects.get_best_items_for_user(user, users, movies) </p>

<p>The recommendable models must have been voted, using django-voting. And the user and the items should be tagged with django-tagging. </p>

<p>All these functions have as arguments the user or item to evaluate, a user list and an item list. This is because is can be useful to pass just a limited list of users or items, in order to have a better performance, or better results, focusing the recommendation only on a controlled set of data. </p>

<p>The result of the functions is a list of pairs (value, recommendation), where the value is a float indicating how close the recommendation is (1 is closest), and the recommendation will be the asked user or item. </p>

<p>In case of clustering functions, what it returns is a list containing other lists with the ids of the elements to cluster, i.e, if you want to have 3 clusters of users, the list will contain 3 sublists with the user ids of each cluster. </p>

<p>Have a look at the unit testing file tests.py to know more about the functions. </p>

<p>Roadmap0.1. Create the Recommender, based on user votes. DONE 0.2. Add content based recommendations, using django-tagging pluggable DONE 0.3. Clustering techniques DONE 0.x. Add cache support</p>
 title : The django-recommender Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>IntroductionThis Django app provides a set of inclusion tags for various pieces of form rendering.  These inclusion tags are  designed to replace the default rendering methods on Form instances.  The included templates are flexible enough for most common form designs, but even complex designs may benefit by simply overriding the templates. </p>

<p>renderform&#39;s primary template tags are {% show_form %}, {% show_field %}, {% show_label %}, {% show_errors %}, and {% show_help_text %}.  See the GettingStarted page for instructions and examples. </p>

<p>Use CasesAdding a required class to the appropriate label tags Rendering fields in tr, p, li, div, or other tags Updating form markup for your whole site in one place</p>
 title : The django-renderform Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>Rendertext is a Django app for using custom fonts on a web page for headings and the like without the use of Photoshop or Flash. </p>

<p>It does so by dynamically creating images out of text snippets. Both PNG and GIF output is currently supported. </p>

<p>Usage is simple. Rendertext provides the template filter rendertext which can be used like this: {{ myvar|rendertext:&quot;grunge&quot; }} to show myvar rendered with the font &quot;grunge&quot;. </p>

<p>You can easily configure size, color and rotations. For instance, {{ myvar|rendertext:&quot;grunge,16,#ff0000,45&quot; }} would show the text in size 16 with color red rotated 45 degrees counter-clockwise. </p>

<p>Behind the scenes, django-rendertext checks if the image already has been rendered. If not, the font is loaded, a new image is generated and saved to disk. Then an  tag is returned with the URL to the image, alt text and width and height set. </p>

<p>You can take a look at the documentation. Or the news to see what&#39;s changed. </p>

<p>Rendertext is originally based on a snippet from djangosnippets.org. </p>

<p>ExamplesThere&#39;s a simple example project you can download and play around with. </p>

<p>Sites using rendertextHere are some sites using rendertext (please contact olau@iola.dk to be added): </p>

<p>Talent Nord - Danish student consultancy bureau Rachel&#39;s and Jason&#39;s wedding site Who&#39;s behind this?The development so far has mostly been done by iola, a small Danish web-development house focusing on Django and jQuery.</p>
 title : The django-rendertext Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>A django application to build flexible, extensible reports through the web or as part of your views. </p>

<p>This project has been started due to interest on the django-users mailing list and very much subscribes to the &quot;release early and often&quot; philosophy. It is definitely not production ready, but this is an app that I think that users of django could benefit from, especially for those who are interfacing with legacy databases or in some sort of enterprise setting. </p>

<p>The idea is a central register which can easily tell you which fields are available for reports, and allows you to add to define your own reports in a sub-directory of your apps (much like the existing templatetags works). Here&#39;s an example from one of my app&#39;s report.py: </p>

<p>from nokia.reporting.helpers import FieldRegister
<br/>from datetime import timedelta
<br/>reg = FieldRegister()</p>

<p>@reg.register(&#39;Adjusted MTTR&#39;,&#39;Ticket&#39;,&#39;mttr&#39;)
<br/>def adjusted_mttr(ticket):
<br/>    &quot;&quot;&quot;The mean time to repair of the ticket&quot;&quot;&quot;
<br/>... rest of code body hereIn addition to the register, there are also a couple of Models (one for holding information on all the available fields, and one for your persistent Report objects) and these between them generate Reporter objects, which can produce CSV. </p>

<p>I&#39;m not convinced that I&#39;ve taken the right approach in all areas of the application, and I&#39;d very much like feedback and ideas, specifically: </p>

<p>The right way to persist the report objects, their construction is not really consistent and perhaps a relational database structure isn&#39;t the best means of storage. I&#39;m thinking that RDF or something similar (XML of some other sort) might be better? Testing... I&#39;m not really familiar with how to go about TDD, but i&#39;d like to learn! User interface, I&#39;m designing this to be brain dead (think dilbert manager ;-) ) simple to use. Presently this UI is dependant on Prototye, and I think this might hinder integrating it into admin views in the future. </p>

<p>Example code: </p>

<p>&gt;&gt;&gt; fld_reg = FieldRegister()
<br/>&gt;&gt;&gt; usr = fld_reg.User
<br/>&gt;&gt;&gt; #usr now has a representation of all of the fields the auth.User has, uncluding a
<br/>&gt;&gt;&gt; #count field for all of the FK and M2M relations and reverse relations:
<br/>&gt;&gt;&gt; usr
<br/>&gt;
<br/>&gt;&gt;&gt; usr._fields #This is all of the User._meta.fields
<br/>[,
<br/>........
<br/>]
<br/>&gt;&gt;&gt; usr.message_set</p>

<p>&gt;&gt;&gt; usr.message_set.title
<br/>&#39;Count of Message Set&#39;The best way to get to know the app is probably to install it, run syncdb, run generate_fields() (which is in helpers.py), and then have a play using ./manage.py shell. If you&#39;re using IPython you&#39;ll be up and running in no time.</p>
 title : The django-reports Open Source Project on Open Hub
 title : The django-representations Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>This presents a convention that allows models to be displayed in certain ways </p>

<p>For instance, for a list of blog entries: diario/entry_archive_day.html ... {% represent entry as &quot;summary.html&quot; %} </p>

<p>diario/entry_archive.html ... {% represent entry as &quot;summary.html&quot; %} </p>

<p>diario/entry_detail.html ... {% represent entry as &quot;detail.html&quot; %} </p>

<p>Each template is placed in  representations/diario.entry/ </p>

<p>The power of this convention is revealed when you do something like a search engine that may be a list of different content types: </p>

<p>{% for object in search_result_list %} </p>

<p>{% represent object as &quot;search_result.html&quot; %} 
<br/>{% endfor %}</p>
 title : The django-rest-interface Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>SummaryThe Django REST interface makes it easy to offer private and public APIs for existing Django models. New generic views simplify data retrieval and modification in a resource-centric architecture and provide model data in formats such as XML, JSON and YAML with very little custom code. </p>

<p>RESTify your Django apps! </p>

<p>Join the mailing list! </p>

<p>Installation &amp; SetupStep 1: Checkout from Subversion: </p>

<p>svn checkout http://django-rest-interface.googlecode.com/svn/trunk/ django-rest-interface Step 2: Add the django-rest-interface directory to your PYTHONPATH. </p>

<p>Step 3: Add these lines to your urls.py: </p>

<p>from django_restapi.model_resource import Collection
<br/>from django_restapi.responder import XMLResponderStep 4: For every model you want to be part of the API, create a Collection instance in urls.py (see more elaborate examples): </p>

<p>mymodel_resource = Collection(
<br/>    queryset = MyModel.objects.all(),
<br/>    responder = XMLResponder()
<br/>)Step 5: Add the resource to your URL patterns: </p>

<p>urlpatterns = patterns(&#39;&#39;,
<br/>   # ...
<br/>   url(r&#39;^xml/mymodel/(.*?)/?$&#39;, mymodel_resource)
<br/>)Voilà! Your XML API is ready at http://yourhost/xml/mymodel/. </p>

<p>ContactAndreas Stuhlmüller</p>
 title : The django-restful-model-views Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>UpdateAs I explained in this blog post, I am suspending work on this project to support the work of Andreas Stuhlmueller who is going to be implementing a more comprehensive RESTful API for Django as part of the Google Summer of Code. As his work looks like the most promising implementation, and many of his ideas are compatible with mine, I would prefer to spend my time supporting him by providing feedback, testing releases, possibly contributing documentation, etc. rather than developing partially overlapping code. </p>

<p>If you are interested, here are some relevant links to Andreas&#39; proposal: </p>

<p>http://www.aiplayground.org/artikel/improving-django/ http://code.google.com/soc/django/appinfo.html?csaid=63138DE89788093 http://groups.google.com/group/django-developers/browse_thread/thread/bbdacc7a5ddb8f6e   </p>

<p>BackgroundAs someone who has been away from Python for a little while and is new to Django and to the REST philosophy, I only set out to better familiarize myself with Django and to better understand REST, not to create this contribution. However, this is where my exploration of Django and REST have taken me. The following blog posts chronicle this exploration and should provide insight into the approach taken here: </p>

<p>Toward a RESTful Approach to Django Applications Django REST Redux Test Driving a RESTful Django Contribution New contribution announcement: RESTful model views. Evolving a RESTful Django Contribution At this stage, I offer this contribution only as an attempted proof of concept, and leave it for more experienced Django developers to judge if this approach is sound. I have attempted to follow best practices for implementing pure REST--as much as pure REST can be implemented--and to do so in a way that is compatible with Django. However, at this point, the implemenation is incomplete, and hasn&#39;t been tested in a real application environment. </p>

<p>Installation and SetupStep 1: Checkout from Subversion: </p>

<p>  svn checkout http://django-restful-model-views.googlecode.com/svn/trunk/ restful_model_views   Step 2: Copy or link this directory under django/contrib . </p>

<p>Step 3: In settings.py, separate the applications that should be RESTful: </p>

<p>  RESTFUL_APPS = (
<br/>    &#39;mysite.myrestfulapp&#39;,
<br/>  )</p>

<p>  INSTALLED_APPS = RESTFUL_APPS + (
<br/>    &#39;django.contrib.auth&#39;,
<br/>    &#39;django.contrib.contenttypes&#39;,
<br/>    &#39;django.contrib.sessions&#39;,
<br/>    &#39;django.contrib.sites&#39;,
<br/>    &#39;django.contrib.admin&#39;,
<br/>  )   Step 4: In urls.py, add RESTful URL patterns: </p>

<p>  from django.contrib.restful_model_views.restful_urls import get_restful_patterns
<br/>  urlpatterns += get_restful_patterns()Step 5: Instead of a single views.py, create a directory called &#39;views&#39; in your RESTful application, and don&#39;t forget to add an empty __init__.py file under it, so Python knows it&#39;s a module. Now, for each model class that should have RESTful views, create a new module and class under views based on the name of the model. A minimal implementation for a model class called &#39;Items&#39; would contain this code in views/Items.py: </p>

<p>from mysite.myrestfulapp.models import Items
<br/>from django.contrib.restful_model_views.ModelResources import ModelResources, edit, create, dispatch</p>

<p>class Items(ModelResources):
<br/>  pass</p>

<p>  class Items_Member (ModelResources.ModelResources_Member):
<br/>    pass
<br/>This minimal implementation makes the underlying view methods in Resources available to Django for the model. You can refer to the django.contrib.restful_model_views.Resources module to see a full implemenation, otherwise, the basic structure of a RESTful model view looks like this: </p>

<p>  class Resources
<br/>    def GET(request):
<br/>      pass
<br/>    
<br/>    def POST(request):
<br/>      pass
<br/>    
<br/>    class Creator:
<br/>    
<br/>      def GET(self, request):
<br/>        pass
<br/>    
<br/>    class Resources_Member:
<br/>    
<br/>      def GET(self, request):
<br/>        pass
<br/>    
<br/>      def PUT(self, request):
<br/>        pass
<br/>    
<br/>      def DELETE(self, request):
<br/>        pass
<br/>    
<br/>      class Editor:
<br/>    
<br/>        def GET(self, request):
<br/>          passmap these methods to form actions Override any methods you need to customize. Otherwise, the default implemenations are designed to use generic views, so the appropriate templates need to be in the usual places. (Consult the Django generic views documentation if you don&#39;t know where these are.) Also note that to overload POST for PUT and DELETE operations, you will have to add a form element called &#39;_method&#39; with the appropriate values &#39;PUT&#39; or &#39;DELETE&#39;. </p>

<p>Development RoadmapThis contribution is currently in a &#39;proof of concept&#39; stage, although there are unit tests distributed with it, so what is there should at least work. Immediate/obvious work to do includes: </p>

<p>Implement appropriate default generic views for all methods in Resources and Resources_Member classes. Allow this approach to work with a standard views.py module, to accomodate the case in which perhaps only a few RESTful methods will be overridden. Simplify deployment so that even minimal view classes like the Items.py module mentioned above won&#39;t be necessary if only the default functionality of the Resources module is needed. (Maybe this can be done by dynamically adding the Resources module to views at runtime?) I may also try to find a way to add the RESTful urlpatterns automatically without having to add code to urls.py. The answer may be to make this a full-fledged middleware component within Django, but currently, I am not sure that is the correct route to take. The following are discussed in more detail in Evolving a RESTful Django Contribution: Refactor to decouple resource view class structure (with default raise Http404 implementations) from ORM/generic view code. This will allow for more flexible definition of resources when they don&#39;t directly map to models. Along with the above refactoring, add more specifications options, such as specifying a list of resource names or a dictionary of resource names mapped optionally to model classes. Consider looking for this in urls.py as well as keeping the current RESTFUL_APPS approach in settings.py. Implement direct dispatching to PUT and DELETE methods instead of just relying on overloading post. Implement something like respond_to in Rails. Implement something similar to link_to, form_tag and form_for in Rails. Change &#39;_action&#39; to &#39;_method&#39;. Add service discovery views/templates. Look into ATOM Publishing Protocol, WADL, etc. </p>

<p>Background ResourcesThe following are some of the resources that have shaped my thinking and approach to this contribution: </p>

<p>Resource-oriented vs. activity-oriented Web services REST Controller for RAILS on Charlie Savage’s Blog (Another) Rest Controller for Rails by Peter Williams RESTful Rails Development by Ralf Wirdemann and Thomas Baustert. RESTful and User-Friendly URLS by Bill Venners RESTed and Confused on Don Park’s Daily Habit </p>

<p>add introductory REST links, relevant Django links? </p>

<p>   </p>

<p>AcknowledgementsThank you to those who have taken the time to give valuable feedback so far: </p>

<p>Malcolm Tredinnick  David Larlet from biologeek.com Samus (sorry, I don&#39;t have more information) </p>

<p>Alternate approaches: </p>

<p>Improving Django: Generic views for RESTful web services Django Collection contribution Django CRUD API </p>

<p>Contactadam smith</p>
 summary : <p>Flexible Version ControlReversion is an extension to the Django web framework that provides comprehensive version control facilities. </p>

<p>FeaturesRoll back to any point in a model&#39;s history - an unlimited undo facility! Recover deleted models - never lose data again! Admin integration for maximum usability. Group related changes into revisions that can be rolled back in a single transaction. Automatically save a new version whenever your model changes using Django&#39;s flexible signalling framework. Automate your revision management with easy-to-use middleware. Reversion can be easily added to your existing Django project with an absolute minimum of code changes. </p>

 title : The django-search-lucene Open Source Project on Open Hub
 title : The django-seasonal-stylesheets Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>django-seasonal-stylesheets is a goofy little project that I started as a result of a discussion I had with some co-workers.  We were talking about making our organization&#39;s website change the way it looked depending on what time of year it was.  That night I couldn&#39;t sleep because of my allergies, so I decided to see what I could do in a short amount of time to make our discussion a possibility (though it will never become a reality). </p>

<p>By the morning I had a pretty functional application that would change the color of various elements on the page based on the date.  It does this using CSS.  I&#39;m not sure that this application will ever become overly popular, but I&#39;m hoping that someone a little more creative than me will figure out a way to make it useful. </p>

<p>Basically, all you do is create a stylesheet that can have any number of seasons associated with it.  Each season can have an unlimited number of variable colors associated with it, but you should have the same variables defined in each season for a particular stylesheet.  Depending on the day of the year, the application selects the most recently past season and the soonest to come season.  It then determines how to transition each variable color from the past season to the coming season.  Sometimes you can get some pretty funky color combinations, but you can always add a new season in between to mitigate the funkiness. </p>

<p>RequirementsThis project was built with and requires at least Django 1.0 (though you could probably get away with any of the SVN versions since mid-July 2008). </p>

<p>InstallationDownload django-seasonal-stylesheets using one of the following methods: </p>

<p>Checkout from Subversionsvn co http://django-seasonal-stylesheets.googlecode.com/svn/trunk/ django-seasonal-stylesheetsPackage DownloadDownload the latest .tar.gz file from the downloads section and extract it somewhere you&#39;ll remember.  After extraction, execute the following command: </p>

<p>python setup.py installConfigurationFirst of all, you must add this project to your list of INSTALLED_APPS in settings.py: </p>

<p>INSTALLED_APPS = (
<br/>    &#39;django.contrib.admin&#39;,
<br/>    &#39;django.contrib.auth&#39;,
<br/>    &#39;django.contrib.contenttypes&#39;,
<br/>    &#39;django.contrib.sessions&#39;,
<br/>    &#39;django.contrib.sites&#39;,
<br/>    ...
<br/>    &#39;dsss&#39;,
<br/>    ...
<br/>)Run manage.py syncdb.  This creates a few tables in your database that are necessary for operation. </p>

<p>Currently, the only option for this application is DSSS_SAVE.  This setting allows you to specify whether or not you want the stylesheets to be saved to the filesystem for faster retrieval in the future.  Default: True </p>

<p>Next, you must include the URLconf for this project somewhere.  You can put a line like the following in your root urls.py: </p>

<p>    (r&#39;^seasonal/&#39;, include(&#39;dsss.urls&#39;)),UsageAll you really need to do is modify your templates to include a link to the special stylesheet.  Assuming I have a stylesheet with the slug sample, I could do this: </p>

<p>By default, the application looks in [template directory]/dsss/[slug].css for the template of a particular stylesheet.  You may override the template location if you so desire, but it should be somewhere in your template directories (as defined in your settings.py file). </p>

<p>A sample template follows: </p>

<p>body {
<br/>    background-color: {{ background }};
<br/>}</p>

<p>h1 {
<br/>    color: {{ header1 }};
<br/>}</p>

<p>h2 {
<br/>    color: {{ header2 }};
<br/>}This template assumes that my stylesheet has 3 variables: background, header1, and header2.  These are the names of the variables setup in the admin interface. </p>

<p>Good luck!  Please contact me with any questions or concerns you have with the project!</p>
 summary : <p>secureurlA Django application that protects content from unauthorized access. </p>

<p>What secureurl doesThis application makes it easy to add security tokens to the end of URLs. Tokens are simply hashes of session key and/or timestamps. These tokens can be checked by a view decorator. It also contains a mod_python access handler to check security tokens. Access without the correct session cookie will result in a 403 Forbidden error. </p>

<p>Security token can tie URLs to sessions and/or timestamps. </p>

<p>Situations is which secureurl could be used: </p>

<p>Authorization information is present only at the time of rendering the URL. The client accesses a URL many times and the authorization overhead is large. DocumentationComing...</p>
 title : The django-secureurl Open Source Project on Open Hub
 title : The django-seeker Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>Getting StartedOut of the box, django-seeker supports building a filter-based search interface driven from a django model. To get started, we&#39;ll walk through adding a search interface for a model to an existing project. Keep in mind that the backend is pluggable, allowing you to write code to search on any data model. </p>

<p>PrerequisitesjQuery json2.js jQuery UI Datepicker jQuery Form Plugin (for AJAX file imports) URLsIncluding the seeker application is easy: </p>

<p>from seeker.plugins.model import ModelSearchPlugin</p>

<p>params = {
<br/>    &#39;plugin&#39;: ModelSearchPlugin(MyModel),
<br/>    &#39;base_template&#39;: &#39;search.html&#39;,
<br/>}</p>

<p>urlpatterns = patterns(&#39;&#39;,
<br/>    ( r&#39;^search/&#39;, include(&#39;seeker.urls&#39;), params ),
<br/>    ...
<br/>)The base_template parameter is the name of a template that the seeker template will derive from. By default, it looks for a template named search.html. This allows you to embed the search interface into your site using your own base template. The base template can also take care of including the required CSS and javascript files. </p>

<p>There is also a media_url parameter to specify the location of the images that seeker needs to load. By default, media_url defaults to settings.MEDIA_URL + &#39;/images/seeker/&#39;, so if your MEDIA_URL was set to http://media.mysite.com, media_url would be http://media.mysite.com/images/seeker/. We&#39;ll get into media more below. </p>

<p>MediaSeeker relies on some external javascript libraries, as well as it&#39;s own javascript code. As mentioned before, including these files in a base template makes things very easy. Your base template (search.html in the example above) may look something like this: </p>

<p>{% extends &quot;site_base.html&quot; %}</p>

<p>{% block extra_head %}</p>

<p>{% endblock %}</p>

<p>{% block content %}</p>

<p>{% block seeker %}
<br/>{% endblock %}</p>

<p>{% endblock %}In this template, jquery.js was not included, since it was already included as part of the site_base.html template. You&#39;ll notice that we override the content block, and set up a seeker block -- this is where the interface will be rendered. This template also assumes that you have either copied or symlinked the necessary files into the appropriate MEDIA_ROOT directories. Basically, as long as all the required files are included, seeker doesn&#39;t care how you get them there. </p>

<p>CustomizationThe interface is fully customizable using CSS. You can also customize the HTML by using your own template, and passing template_name as a parameter when you include the URL configuration. </p>

<p>As of r7, you can create an inner Search class (much like Meta) to define excluded fields, initially displayed fields, and follow relationships. For example: </p>

<p>class OtherModel (models.Model):
<br/>    data1 = models.CharField( max_length=100 )
<br/>    data2 = models.CharField( max_length=100 )</p>

<p>class MyModel (models.Model):
<br/>    label = models.CharField( max_length=100 )
<br/>    status = models.ForeignKey( Status )
<br/>    active = models.BooleanField()
<br/>    other_info = models.ForeignKey( OtherModel )</p>

<p>    class Search:
<br/>        exclude = (&#39;active&#39;,&#39;other_info__data2&#39;)
<br/>        initial = (&#39;label&#39;,&#39;status&#39;,&#39;other_info__data1&#39;)
<br/>        follow = (&#39;other_info&#39;,)Note that you can exclude related fields from being searched/displayed, as well as specifying related fields to be initially displayed. The follow argument tells ModelSearchPlugin that fields from the related model should also be included for search/display. If the followed model has a Search inner class, those rules as respected as well. </p>

<p>Caching and PerformanceBy default, the ModelSearchPlugin uses Django&#39;s cache system to cache result sets. This is controllable by the cache_results and cache_time properties on the plugin object. </p>

<p>As of r7, the ModelSearchPlugin takes an optional select_depth argument, which defaults to 1. This is passed as the depth argument to select_related(). Ideally, it should be set to the maximum depth of any related fields that are available as display fields. This will greatly improve performance when rendering and sorting result sets.</p>

 summary : <p>Selenium IDE application for Django., </p>
