 title : The django-simplepages Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>Simple pages is an application for building out pages on a site through the Django admin interface. If you are familiar with the django.contrib.flatpages app simple pages uses the same concept(and some of the same code) and builds out from there. </p>

<p>FeaturesCreate edit and delete pages within the Django Admin interface using the YUI Rich Text Editor. Create site sections for the primary navigation and have it dynamically generate the site navigation for you. With the ability to specify what sections and pages show in the navigation. Direct link to edit the pages as you are browsing the site to for quicker and easier editing. Ability to easily include page content on dynamic pages, such as a generic view listing page that you want to have some intro text and an image on. Easily extensible as it&#39;s a normal django app you can easily customize to fit your needs. Absolutely no restrictions on the site design. Easily integrates with other django apps. RequirementsA relatively recent version django-svn. </p>

<p>DocumentationAdditional documentation </p>

<p>Quick InstallView more indepth installation instructions here </p>

<p>Currently to get the code you&#39;ll have to check it out from the repository here. Checkout the above code and place &quot;simplepages&quot; on you python path. Add &#39;simplepages&#39; to your projects settings.py file Add this &quot;simplepages.middleware.PageFallbackMiddleware&quot; as the last item in your settings.py MIDDLEWARE_CLASSES config Run the manage.py syncdb to create the necessary database tables You should now be able to go into your Sites admin and create Site Sections and pages for within those site sections. To view the page just browse to the url you entered when creating the page. </p>

<p>At this point the basic system should be working but a little more configuration has to be done to get the html editor, the edit this page, and the prepopulating the url with the section url to work. </p>

<p>Copy the three javascript files in simplepages/media/admin/js to either your admin_media folder. Two of these files are new js files, but the &quot;CollapsedFieldsets.js&quot; will overwrite the existing one to fix this bug. In your projects urls.py file add in the following url:  (r&#39;^simplepages/&#39;, include(&#39;simplepages.urls&#39;)),  At this point the html editor and the prepopulating for the urls should be working. One more step is required for the edit this page functionality to appear on the site. Paste the below (also included in the sample_base.html template) into the bottom of your base.html template. </p>

<p>{% if user.is_staff %}
<br/>    {# Determining if we should load the javascript for displaying admin links #}
<br/>    
<br/>{% endif %}Make sure to update the location to point to your admin media folder if it&#39;s not the &#39;admin&#39; subdirectory of your media_url. </p>

<p>Everything should be setup and working now. If the rich text editor, the edit page or the prepopulate aren&#39;t working it&#39;s most likely due to incorrect paths to the javascript files so they aren&#39;t being loaded. </p>

<p>What Simple pages doesn&#39;t doIt is not a full featured cms it only manages pages and it does that at a fairly simple level. The menu hierarchy is only one level, site section to pages. This can be extended to allow additional levels of links or even unlimited levels, but you&#39;d have to code up that capability.</p>
 title : The django-simplestats Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>A simple statistics and analytics application for Django-based web applications, allowing people with low-to-mid scaled sites to easily see their website usage statistics. </p>

<p>STATUS: Work in Progress, Unworking, UnsupportedRequirementsDjango (Trunk)</p>
 summary : <p>django-slots allows arbitrary Django models to be scheduled against one another, with time as a feature of that relationship.  The relationship can either start at a particular time, until the next change occurs: this is called a transition; or the relationship can occur explicitly between a start and end time: this is called a slot.  Think of them both as time-based foreign keys. </p>

<p>Some documentationNone of the documentation mentions transitions, which is a pain in the arse because they are actually more fully featured (eg, you can use them in the admin).  It&#39;s possible the code is simple and well documented/commented enough that its usage can be figured out without documentation. </p>

<p>This documentation, therefore, is related to slots.  Note that the patterns used when writing transitions has lead me to think that the slots approach is daft and can be simplified.  In particular the GenericIntermediaries stuff is properly overkill, as well as being the number one reason why an admin interface never sprang into life.  Nonetheless this stuff might be useful anyway: </p>

<p>Introducing django-slots is, as the name suggests, an introduction to what this project is about. There is a very terse guide to getting django-slots up and running.  Slots and schedules are also explained in a little more depth. Generic intermediaries, the mechanism which underlies the implementation of slots, is documented too. django-slots was started by Darren Foreman. The code is released under a BSD license, and is © Darren Foreman 2008.</p>
 title : The django-slots Open Source Project on Open Hub
 title : The django-sms Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>django-smsdjango-sms is a Django application designed to make sending SMS text messages as simple as sending an email.  </p>

<p>version 0.1 was released 2008-11-12. </p>

<p>QuickstartAdd sms to your INSTALLED_APPS in settings.py: </p>

<p>    INSTALLED_APPS = (
<br/>        # apps
<br/>        &#39;sms&#39;,
<br/>    )  Get in sync to update the database and install the provided Carrier fixtures: </p>

<p>    python manage.py syncdb  And play with some code: </p>

<p>    from django.contrib.auth.models import User
<br/>    from django.contrib.contenttypes.models import ContentType
<br/>    from sms.models import Carrier, ContentTypePhoneNumber, OutboundMessage
<br/>    from sms.util import send_sms</p>

<p>    # get a user
<br/>    matt = User.objects.get(username=&quot;matt&quot;)</p>

<p>    # get matt&#39;s cell phone carrier (at&amp;t)
<br/>    att = Carrier.objects.get(pk=7)</p>

<p>    # attach a phone number to matt
<br/>    matts_phone_number, created = ContentTypePhoneNumber.objects.get_or_create(
<br/>        content_type = ContentType.objects.get_for_model(User),
<br/>        object_id = matt.pk,
<br/>        carrier = att,
<br/>        phone_number = &quot;123-123-1234&quot;
<br/>    )</p>

<p>    # do stuff (probably very important!!!!) ...</p>

<p>    # send matt an sms
<br/>    send_sms(
<br/>        msg = &quot;omg im texting from python!&quot;,
<br/>        from_address = &quot;mattdennewitz@gmail.com&quot;,
<br/>        recipient_list = [matts_phone_number],
<br/>        fail_silently = False
<br/>    )     </p>

<p>How Do I Make This Work?SMS messages are sent with the sms.util.send_sms function, which is nearly identical to django.core.mail.send_mail. The key differences are that message subjects are not accepted and the recipient_list argument should be a list of ContentTypePhoneNumber objects. </p>

<p>django-sms provides two three models for users to work with: </p>

<p> Carrier, which represents the email-to-sms gateway provided by service providers. 61 carriers are provided for you in the fixtures, which should cover most everyone&#39;s needs. 
<br/>2. ContentTypePhoneNumber, which provides: 
<br/>     </p>

<p>phone number storage description of phone number - optional, meant for &#39;home&#39; or &#39;work&#39; &#39;primary phone number&#39; definition - optional, useful if you use this for contact storage      ContentTypePhoneNumber also has a custom manager, PhoneNumberManager, which allows 
<br/>for User lookups via ContentTypePhoneNumber.objects.get_for_user(user_obj). This manager 
<br/>will probably be fleshed out later, but thats it for now. </p>

<p>3. OutboundMessage, which acts as a message log. When a message is sent with sms.util.send_sms, 
<br/>the Carrier, ContentTypePhoneNumber and dispatch time are logged. This is for pulling usage 
<br/>information for both Carriers and ContentTypePhoneNumbers.  
<br/>      </p>

<p>To pull data from the OutboundMessage logs, check out OutboundMessageManager. It has two helpers 
<br/>now, but will also probably be expanded in the future: 
<br/>      most_popular_carriers, which pulls the most popular carriers in a given (optional) date range most_contacted_numbers, which pulls the most popular phone numbers is a given (optional) date range       See their documentation for more. </p>

<p>What&#39;s ComingSignals. Maybe. Forms, if people request such. Seems like a ModelForm for the Carriers should suffice for now. Requests?       </p>

<p>Words of Advice The data used in the fixtures was culled from Wikipedia. I didn&#39;t ask first, so I&#39;m sorry for any toes I may have stepped on. Also, keep in mind that phone service providers are liable to shut off these services or make changes to format, rate limit, etc. on a whim and without notice. If you encounter any trouble, report them and we&#39;ll see what can happen.</p>
 title : The django-social-economics Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>The economic relationships are based on the REA (Resources, Events and Agents) model: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Resources_Events_Agents </p>

<p>REA has the virtue of supporting any economic relationships, not limited to formal companies or money.  For example, whuffie accounting for open-source software projects (see obols below) or barter among friends (see swaps below). </p>

<p>(But of course it will also support the usual economic relationships within a company but also across companies or among members of an LLC or joint venture.  In other words, it&#39;s very flexible.) </p>

<p>While the code will eventually be usable for any Django project, at first it is targeted at Pinax and the Django Hotclub: http://code.google.com/p/django-hotclub/ </p>

<p>Current appsSwapsSwaps was incubated here, but has moved to its own Google project. </p>

<p>ObolsImaginary currency given between project members for project contributions. </p>

<p>Current state: once worked with pinax, probably doesn&#39;t any more with all the recent changes both to pinax and django trunk. </p>

<p>Has been neglected recently in favor of Swaps.  </p>

<p>If you want to work with it, you could add obols to django-hotclub/apps  </p>

<p>Then add this to projects/urls.py: </p>

<p>url(r&#39;^(?P\w+)/obols/&#39;, include(&#39;obols.urls&#39;), kwargs=wiki_args),And this somewhere in templates/projects/project.html: </p>

<p>ObolsNote: obols depends on pinax.  Neither tests nor views will run without it.</p>
 summary : <p>A reusable multi-user blogging platform for django social applications.   This blog was written for the Pinax project.  Now that it is maturing it is being broken out into it&#39;s own project. </p>

<p>DependenciesDjango-Atompub Django-Tagging Django-ThreadedComments NOTE:  We are in the process of breaking Django-Socialblog out of Pinax and making it a pluggable app.  It will work in your applications but may need some minor modifications. </p>

<p>Direct any questions to the issue tracker or email greg at 20seven dot org.</p>
 title : The django-socialblog Open Source Project on Open Hub
 title : The django-spambayes Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>Django-SpamBayes includes a few utility apps for Django that offer an easy to use interface to the SpamBayes statistical anti-spam filter allowing filtering and moderation (with training) of comments, contact forms and other publicly submitted data. </p>

<p>Note: These apps do not depend on any of the e-mail client plugins (i.e.: Outlook plugin) available from the SpamBayes project. However, the core spambayes python package needs to be installed on your PYTHONPATH. It is recommended that you download and install a recent &quot;source release&quot; of SpamBayes appropriate for your platform. </p>

<p>Apps:djangobayesThe &quot;djangobayes&quot; app is the workhorse that gets Django and SpamBayes to talk to each other. It contains a Django model for SpamBayes to store its &#39;learned&#39; data in and a SpamBayes Classifier subclass that wraps the Django model. This is all wrapped up in a SpamBayes Hammie instance (djangobayes.filter.filter) which contains the public API accessed by other apps.  </p>

<p>Basic Usage: </p>

<p>&gt;&gt;&gt; from djangobayes.filter import filter
<br/>&gt;&gt;&gt; score = filter.score(&#39;some text&#39;)
<br/>&gt;&gt;&gt; if score &lt; 0.3:
<br/>...     # do something with spam
<br/>... elif score &gt; 0.8:
<br/>...     # do something with ham
<br/>... else:
<br/>...     # unsure - do something elseOf course, this will only work if SpamBayes has been trained. To train do: </p>

<p>&gt;&gt;&gt; filter.train(&#39;some spam&#39;, True)
<br/>&gt;&gt;&gt; filter.store()
<br/>&gt;&gt;&gt; filter.train(&#39;some ham&#39;, False)
<br/>&gt;&gt;&gt; filter.store()In some situations you may want to filter based on more than a single body of text. For example, an author&#39;s name, e-mail address, IP address, etc. As SpamBayes is intended for filtering e-mail, you can pass in a message object rather than a plain string. djangobayes provides a handy shortcut, build_msg which excepts a body and any keywords you provide to build a message. For example: </p>

<p>&gt;&gt;&gt; from djangobayes.filter import build_msg
<br/>&gt;&gt;&gt; msg = build_msg(&#39;some text&#39;, author=&#39;Bob&#39;, email=&#39;bob@example.com&#39;)
<br/>&gt;&gt;&gt; score = filter.score(msg)
<br/>&gt;&gt;&gt; # or ...
<br/>&gt;&gt;&gt; msg = build_msg(&#39;body text&#39;, **{&#39;name&#39; : &#39;Sue&#39;, &#39;ip&#39; : &#39;127.0.0.1&#39;})
<br/>&gt;&gt;&gt; filter.train(msg)
<br/>&gt;&gt;&gt; filter.store()As far as I can tell, SpamBayes doesn&#39;t really care what the names of the keywords are as long as they are consistent throughout your app. It simply sees them as e-mail headers and doesn&#39;t give any particular headers more weight than others. That&#39;s why the primary text must be passed in separately. </p>

<p>As this is a SpamBayes API, see the SpamBayes documentation (and read the code) for more information. </p>

<p>commentbayesAn add-on to the django.contrib.comments app that adds SpamBayes filtering. Requires &quot;djangobayes&quot; to be installed in the project. commentbayes simply uses signals to add scoring and training to django.contrib.comments moderation. </p>

<p>commentbayes supports two optional settings to indicate the ham and spam thresholds. Each should be a floating point number between 0 and 1: </p>

<p>HAM_LEVEL (default is 0.3) SPAM_LEVEL (default is 0.8) </p>

<p>Assuming you have already installed django.contrib.comments, add commentbayes and djangobayes to INSTALLED_APPS in your settings.py file, run manage.py syncdb (to add the djangobayes table) and your all set. All future comments will be run through the SpamBayes filter. Any comment with a score greater than SPAM_LEVEL will be marked for deletion (comment.is_removed = True), any comment with a score equal to or between HAM_LEVEL and SPAM_LEVEL will be marked for moderation (comment.is_public = False), and any comment with a score less than HAM_LEVEL will be marked as ham. </p>

<p>To train SpamBayes, point your browser at http://yourdomain.com/comments/moderate/ (an undocumented part of django.contrib.comments) and either &#39;approve&#39; or &#39;remove&#39; the comments awaiting moderation. In a short time and with good training, you will be enjoying spam-free comments! </p>

<p>You may want to set up a cron job to remove comments marked for deletion (comment.is_removed = True) on occasion. </p>

<p>sb_demoThe &quot;sb_demo&quot; app is a very simple demonstration that provides a single page of comments with feedback on the SpamBayes scoring. This app does not use Django&#39;s forms or various other mechanisms that would make is useful for others. It&#39;s simply a demonstration that filtering works - mostly. </p>

<p>It also adds a very basic template for flatpages with comments enabled which provides a demo of commentbayes. </p>

<p>GAE BranchThe gae branch in the repo is an early semi-working version of the code for Google App Engine and BigTable. The file sb.py is essentially the same as the sbayes app above, but for BigTable. I&#39;m not currently using or maintaining this branch, but it&#39;s available for anyone who wants it.</p>

 summary : <p>Project moved to http://github.com/dcramer/django-sphinx/tree/master, </p>
 summary : <p>this project is outdated and no longer maintained!I recommend you take a look at the apps at http://github.com/sproutcoreisyournewbicycle instead. </p>

<p>--- </p>

<p>django-sproutcore provides an easy to use interface between django and SproutCore. </p>

<p>check out the wiki for more information: Wiki Index Page </p>

<p>Thanks to Pascal Gubler and Reto Wolf who coded and documented django-sproutcore as part of their thesis at the &quot;Zurich University of Applied Sciences&quot;. It is a vital building block of the overall application they developed for my company. --Stefan Foulis</p>

 title : The django-sqlgen Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>During production of http://playeraware.com we required a lot of database operations that were too intensive for django ORM to handle. It required writing lots of custom SQL queries. Raw SQL queries violate DRY principle and are hard to maintain, hence this project was born. </p>

<p>Quick example </p>

<p>Models: </p>

<p>class Customer(models.Model):
<br/>    TYPE_CHOICES = (
<br/>        (&#39;A&#39;, &#39;Admin&#39;),
<br/>        (&#39;N&#39;, &#39;Normal&#39;),
<br/>    )
<br/>    type = models.CharField(max_length=1, choices=TYPE_CHOICES, default=&#39;N&#39;)
<br/>    friends = models.ManyToManyField(&#39;self&#39;)
<br/>    
<br/>    moneySpent = models.PositiveIntegerField(default=0)</p>

<p>class AdditionalCustomerData(models.Model):
<br/>    customer = models.ForeignKey(Customer, null=True)
<br/>    name = models.CharField(max_length=100, unique=True)</p>

<p>class CustomerGroup(models.Model):
<br/>    &#39;&#39;&#39;Group of players.&#39;&#39;&#39;
<br/>    name = models.CharField(max_length=100, unique=True)
<br/>    customers = models.ManyToManyField(Customer, related_name = &#39;groups&#39;)</p>

<p>class Product(models.Model):
<br/>    name = models.CharField(max_length=100, unique=True)
<br/>    num_available = models.PositiveIntegerField(default=0)</p>

<p>class ProductInstance(models.Model):
<br/>    buyer = models.ForeignKey(Customer)
<br/>    product = models.ForeignKey(Product)
<br/>    date = models.DateTimeField()
<br/>    quantity = models.PositiveIntegerField(default=0)Example Queries: </p>

<p>SELECT(3).query() == [3, ]
<br/>SELECT(3/3).query() == [1, ]
<br/>SELECT(now).query() == [now, ]</p>

<p>#Automatic Foreign Key Join
<br/>acd = ModelSource(AdditionalCustomerData)
<br/>customer = acd.customer
<br/>SELECT([customer, acd.name]).query()</p>

<p>#Select with related name
<br/>customer = ModelSource(Customer)
<br/>SELECT([customer, customer.additionalcustomerdata_set.name]).query()</p>

<p>SELECT([(customer.type), (&#39;pid&#39;, customer.id)], limit = 3)</p>

<p>group = ModelSource(CustomerGroup)
<br/>SELECT(group.customers, where = (group == self.g1), order_by = group.customers.id),For more information on what those actually do and other queries check http://code.google.com/p/django-sqlgen/source/browse/trunk/django_sqlgen/test/tests.py</p>
 title : The django-stdimage Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>Django Standarized Image FieldDjango Field that implement those features: </p>

<p>Rename files to a standardized name (using object id) Resize images for that field Automatically creates a thumbnail (resizing it) Allow image deletion </p>

<p>InstallationDownload using subversion to any directory included in PYTHON_PATH (for example /usr/lib/python2.5/site-package) </p>

<p>svn checkout http://django-stdimage.googlecode.com/svn/trunk/ stdimageUsageIt&#39;s not necessary to include in INSTALLED_APPLICATIONS. </p>

<p>Import it in your project, and use in your models. Example: </p>

<p>[...]
<br/>from stdimage import StdImageField</p>

<p>class MyClass(models.Model):
<br/>    image1 = StdImageField(upload_to=&#39;path/to/img&#39;) # works as ImageField
<br/>    image2 = StdImageField(upload_to=&#39;path/to/img&#39;, blank=True) # can be deleted throwgh admin
<br/>    image3 = StdImageField(upload_to=&#39;path/to/img&#39;, size=(640, 480)) # resizes image to maximum size to fit a 640x480 area
<br/>    image4 = StdImageField(upload_to=&#39;path/to/img&#39;, size=(640, 480, True)) # resizes image to 640x480 croping if necessary
<br/>    image5 = StdImageField(upload_to=&#39;path/to/img&#39;, thumbnail_size=(100, 75)) # creates a thumbnail resized to maximum size to fit a 100x75 area
<br/>    image6 = StdImageField(upload_to=&#39;path/to/img&#39;, thumbnail_size=(100, 100, True)) # creates a thumbnail resized to 100x100 croping if necessary</p>

<p>    image_all = StdImageField(upload_to=&#39;path/to/img&#39;, blank=True, size=(640, 480), thumbnail_size=(100, 100, True)) # all previous features in one declarationFor using generated thumbnail in templates use &quot;myimagefield.thumbnail&quot;. Example: </p>

<p>[...]</p>

<p>[...]Previous template syntax is new in release 7, because of the file storage refactoring, that changed the way that FileField attributes are accessed. For previous versions the syntax {{ object.myimage }} and {{ object.myimage_thumbnail }} should be used. </p>

<p>About image namesStdImageField stores images in filesystem modifying its name. Renamed name is set using field name, and object primary key. Also it changes old windows &quot;jpg&quot; extesions to standard &quot;jpeg&quot;. </p>

<p>Using image5 field previously defined (that creates a thumbnail), if an image called myimage.jpg is uploaded, then resulting images on filesystem would be (supose that this image belongs to a model with pk 14): </p>

<p>image5_14.jpeg image5_14.thumbnail.jpeg</p>
 title : The django-survey Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>Create simple surveys with public or private results in seconds. Question types can be added externally, and the system is extensible. </p>

<p>The current native answer types are: </p>

<p>Text Input Text Area Select One Choice Radio List Radio Image List Checkbox List </p>

<p>More will be coming shortly. </p>

<p>There is also a django-survey google group.</p>
 title : The django-syncr Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>django-syncrSynchronize Django with the webThis project supplies everything needed to sync a Django project with several web APIs. It currently supports 8 services: </p>

<p>Flickr (http://flickr.com) Youtube (http://youtube.com) del.icio.us (http://del.icio.us) Twitter (http://twitter.com) ma.gnolia (http://ma.gnolia.com) Picasaweb (http://picasaweb.google.com) Readernaut (http://readernaut.com) Brightkite (http://brightkite.com)   Additional web services can be added easily. Suggestions for more services and/or patches welcome. </p>

<p>For an excellent example of django-syncr in action, check out Martin Geber&#39;s custom memory stream on his homepage. </p>

<p>Latest version: r47UPDATE 12/14/2008 Merged in a ton of Flickr patches and repackaged r47 into download archive labeled version 0.41. There&#39;s a ton of great changes (thanks Martin Geber). For a list of new features, examine the change log. This WILL be backwards incompatible because the models contain a richer set of data fields, so watch out.   </p>

<p>Previous UpdatesUPDATE 12/12/2008 Have packaged the lastest svn code into a downloadable archive labeled v0.40. It includes all the apps listed above and works on Django 1.0. Not sure what the status of the previous archive was, but it was certainly far out of date. </p>

<p>UPDATE 10/28/2008 Just checked in several bug fixes and flagged some feature requests for addition to the app. </p>

<p>Also, if you have ideas for django-syncr modules you&#39;d like to see added or want to implement, leave comments on the SyncrRequest wiki page. </p>

<p>UPDATE 9/20/2008 Have merged in support for ma.gnolia bookmarking service and picasaweb photo sharing (thanks yashh and v.oostveen!) Also fixed a few bugs related to the 1.0 update. These are in subversion release... please test and let us know how things are working for you. </p>

<p>UPDATE 8/5/2008 Django syncr&#39;s SVN version now supports ma.gnolia thanks to yash and new forms admin is now supported thanks to jblount. Several other bug fixes are implemented (see issues tab). Thanks to everyone who sent in patches! </p>

<p>UPDATE 4/17/2008 New version available in svn and in archive file format (0.35). This should fix, hopefully, all of the problems people have been having with Flickr. Please test and let me know and thanks for the feedback! Also note that you should be running Beej&#39;s flickrapi version 1.1 for flickr support. </p>

<p>UPDATE 4/15/2008: Sorry for the lack of updates. I have made several fixes from issues people reported and update the subversion repository. I suggest using the svn checkout instead of the packaged zip files for now. Thanks for the feedback, feel free to email me or look me up on twitter with suggestions. </p>

<p> </p>

<p>DEPENDENCIESEach syncr app has different dependencies, but generally you need Element Tree. ET is included in Python 2.5, but for older versions you need to download it from http://effbot.org/zone/element-index.htm. You also need to have django-tagging installed in your INSTALLED_APPS and on PYTHONPATH. See http://code.google.com/p/django-tagging/ </p>

<p>The twitter app depends on python-twitter, available at: http://code.google.com/p/python-twitter/ </p>

<p>The flickr app depends on Beej&#39;s Python flickrapi v1.1, available at: http://flickrapi.sourceforge.net/ </p>

<p>INSTALLATION / USAGEDownload the most recent tar file or check out the code:  svn checkout http://django-syncr.googlecode.com/svn/trunk/ syncr  
<br/>Add the syncr app to your PYTHONPATH. Modify your Django settings file by adding the appropriate modules to your INSTALLED_APPS. Available Django apps are: &#39;syncr.flickr&#39; &#39;syncr.youtube&#39; &#39;syncr.twitter&#39; &#39;syncr.delicious&#39; Use the interfaces provided in syncr.app to write scripts for synchronizing your web service data with the Django backend. For example: 
<br/>    from syncr.app.flickr import FlickrSyncr
<br/>    f = FlickrSyncr(API_KEY, API_SECRET)
<br/>    
<br/>    # sync all my photos from the past week...
<br/>    f.syncRecentPhotos(&#39;username&#39;, days=7)
<br/>    
<br/>    # sync my favorite photos list
<br/>    f.syncPublicFavorites(&#39;username&#39;)Pydocs of the methods available in these interfaces are here. 
<br/>Explore the results in the Django admin interface. CHANGELOGv0.40 (Dec 11, 2008) </p>

<p>First packaged (non-SVN) release in a while Support for readernaut, brightkite, picasa, and ma.gnolia added at various points Some bug fixes </p>

<p>v0.35 (Apr 17, 2008) </p>

<p>Major bug fixes with flickr module </p>

<p>v0.31 (Mar 18, 2008) </p>

<p>Bug fixes; now works with Python 2.3 Changed User models for Twitter and Youtube, now users TwitterUser and YoutubeUser </p>

<p>v0.30 (March 18, 2008) </p>

<p>Added support for Flickr EXIF data (Thanks Yash!) Added Flickr Geo data (latitutde, longitude and accuracy) These two changes will break your Flickr Photo models (ie. syncr reset flickr or use SQL to ALTER TABLE) Changed Twitter User model to allow Followers and Friends to be null Added syncPhoto method to FlickrSyncr to sync an individual photo Added ability to refresh individual photos by passing refresh=True to the new syncPhoto method </p>

<p>v0.21 (Feb 20, 2008) </p>

<p>Bug fixes with FlickrSyncr and YoutubeSyncr </p>

<p>v0.20 (Feb 19, 2008) </p>

<p>Initial release </p>

<p>More details and contact info on my blog announcement</p>

 title : The django-threadedforum Open Source Project on Open Hub
 title : The django-todo Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>django-todo 1.1 is a multi-user, multi-group task management and assignment system for the Django web application framework. Includes drag and drop task prioritization (via jquery) and email task notification. Can be used for something as simple as personal GTD tracking or as complex as an organizational ticketing/tracking system. </p>

<p>The assumption is that your organization/publication/company has multiple groups of employees, each with multiple users. Users may belong to multiple groups, and each group can have multiple todo lists. </p>

<p>Users can view and modify all to-do lists belonging to their group(s).  Only users with is_staff() can delete lists.  </p>

<p>You must have at least one Group set up in Django admin, and that group must have at least one User as a member. This is true even if you&#39;re the sole user of django-todo.  </p>

<p>Identical list names can exist in different groups, but not in the same group. </p>

<p>Emails are generated to the assigned-to person when new tasks are created.  </p>

<p>Comment threads can be added to tasks. Each participant in a thread receives email when new comments are added. </p>

<p> </p>

<p>See Wiki for more screenshots.</p>
 title : The django-trackback Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>Welcome to django-trackbackCurrently every django blog app has it&#39;s own trackback implementation (if it has one). This app is a generic, reusable trackback app, which lets your django project receive and send trackbacks and pingbacks according to the specs. </p>

<p>Trackback Spec http://www.sixapart.com/pronet/docs/trackback_spec Pingback Spec http://www.hixie.ch/specs/pingback/pingback StatusDjango-trackback may be usable, please see the docs for usage instructions: </p>

<p>INSTALL pingbacks settings Update 2008-01-19: I think django-trackback might now - for the first time - be usable out of the box. Please report bugs.</p>

 title : The django-treebeard Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>django-treebeard is a library that implements efficient tree implementations for the Django Web Framework 1.0+, written by Gustavo Picón and licensed under the Apache License 2.0.</p>

<p>django-treebeard is:</p>

<p> - Flexible: Includes 3 different tree implementations 
<br/> - with the same API:
<br/>    1. Adjacency List
<br/>    2. Materialized Path
<br/>    3. Nested Sets
<br/> - Fast: Optimized non-naive tree operations (see
<br/>    Benchmarks).
<br/> - Easy: Uses Django Model Inheritance with abstract
<br/>   classes to define your own models.
<br/> - Clean: Testable and well tested code base.
<br/>    Code/branch test coverage is above 96%</p>
 title : The django-treemenus Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>Django Tree Menus </p>

<p>This is a simple and generic tree-structured menuing system for Django with an easy-to-use admin interface. It covers all the essentials for building tree-structured menus and should be enough for a lot of projects. However it is easily extendable if you need to add some special behaviour. </p>

<p>Please note: django-treemenus requires Django 1.0 or a recent Subversion checkout of Django. It will not work on Django 0.96. </p>

<p>Full documentation is included in the package or directly accessible: here. Some sample templates are also provided in the package to get you started. </p>

<p>Change logv0.8.6 - 23/01/2010: Small update to make it compatible with Django 1.2. Also fixed some packaging issues from 0.8.5 </p>

<p>v0.8.5 - 21/01/2010: Minor updates (tests and doc fixes, and updated some locales) </p>

<p>v0.8 - 14/03/2009: Few small fixes. There are no backward incompatibilities in this release, but it is recommended to upgrade especially if you use recent development versions of Django. </p>

<p>v0.7.2 - 01/10/2008: Fixed a small edge-case bug and slightly improved the admin interface . </p>

<p>v0.7.1 - 29/09/2008: Fixed a small bug when deleting menu items. </p>

<p>v0.7 - 16/09/2008: A few small bugs fixed. This release generally brings a lot of robustness. Even if your data (ranks, levels, etc.) were corrupted, they should automatically be repaired after saving the faulty menu items. Please also note a few deprecated methods here. </p>

<p>v0.6 - 08/08/2008: Major refactor of the codebase to better fit New-Forms-Admin&#39;s API. Few and easily manageable backward incompatible changes are described here. </p>

<p>v0.5 - 22/07/2008: Upgraded code so it works after the merge of the Newforms-Admin branch (Keep using version 0.4 if you haven&#39;t upgraded your own code to newforms-admin). Also added German locale kindly provided by Thomas Kerpe. </p>

<p>v0.4 - 26/05/2008: New languages added: Russian (thanks maxim.oransky), dutch (thanks v.oostveen), and French. You can send me your translations and I&#39;ll include them in future releases. </p>

<p>v0.3 - 05/03/2008: Added a new section in the documentation &quot;Tips and tricks&quot;, and fixed a small bug as described in this issue. </p>

<p>v0.2.2 - 15/02/2008: Fixed another small bug as in previous release. </p>

<p>v0.2.1 - 15/02/2008: Fixed a bug as described in this issue. </p>

<p>v0.2 - 14/02/2008: Added a clean and generic way to extend and customize menu items. Have a look at the manual to see how it works. </p>

<p>v0.1 - 01/02/2008: First release </p>

 title : The django-urls Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>Experimental replacement for Django&#39;s get_absolute_url method, as described on ReplacingGetAbsoluteUrl. </p>

<p>For the moment I&#39;ve implemented it as a mixin class. Here&#39;s how you use it: </p>

<p>from django.db import models
<br/>from django_urls.base import UrlMixin</p>

<p>class ArticleWithPathDefined(models.Model, UrlMixin):
<br/>    slug = models.SlugField()
<br/>    
<br/>    def get_url_path(self):
<br/>        return &#39;/articles/%s/&#39; % self.slug</p>

<p>class AssetWithUrlDefined(models.Model, UrlMixin):
<br/>    domain = models.CharField(max_length=30)
<br/>    filename = models.CharField(max_length = 30)
<br/>    
<br/>    def get_url(self):
<br/>        return &#39;http://%s/assets/%s&#39; % (self.domain, self.filename)You need to define either get_url_path or get_url on a model - there&#39;s no need to define both. If you define one, the other will magically start working. Here&#39;s an example session using the above models: </p>

<p>&gt;&gt;&gt; article = ArticleWithPathDefined.objects.create(slug = &#39;my-article&#39;)
<br/>&gt;&gt;&gt; article.get_url()
<br/>&#39;http://localhost/articles/my-article/&#39;
<br/>&gt;&gt;&gt; article.get_url_path()
<br/>&#39;/articles/my-article/&#39;
<br/>&gt;&gt;&gt; asset = AssetWithUrlDefined.objects.create(domain=&#39;example.com&#39;, filename=&#39;logo.png&#39;)
<br/>&gt;&gt;&gt; asset.get_url()
<br/>&#39;http://example.com/assets/logo.png&#39;
<br/>&gt;&gt;&gt; asset.get_url_path()
<br/>&#39;/assets/logo.png&#39;</p>
 title : The django-userprofile Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>A User Profile app for Django Projects</p>

 summary : <p>django-weatherProject StatusIf any one would like to take over the project please let me know. </p>

 title : The django-webapp Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>This project is unmaintained; there are better ways of doing this, like django-piston. This project will be removed in January 2010. </p>

<p>Like Django itself, this code came up out of necessity: I was writing a quick single-page AJAXy app and came up with a few techniques and patterns to make that easy. After refining them some, I&#39;ve decided to release them to the world. Hopefully they&#39;ll make your web development fast and easy. </p>

<p>The design was inspired by the simplicity of CherryPy coupled with the explicit expressiveness and extensibility of Django itself. You can use this code as-is, but you&#39;ll get the most benefit from reading it carefully and subclassing it to get the results you want. </p>

<p>A core idea is using class methods as views. The type dispatch allows for flexible subclassing. </p>

<p>Includes: </p>

<p>extensible REST-ish Resource class, simpler than django-rest-interface (but lacking some of its features) class-based HTTP method dispatching easy AJAXy APIs transparent JSON serialization AJAX-friendly error handling </p>

<p>I am working on a blog mini-series that uses this code to make a small app. </p>

<p>Code is now available; documentation coming soon.</p>

 title : The django-widget-framework Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>Django is a great web framework to develop web application rapidly. But in a large web application, that develop with widgets is necessary to speed up. </p>

<p>We provide a simple framework to make this easier. You can create your own widgets easily, or can use the widgets we made. In this time, we support widgets written with ExtJS. </p>

<p>A glance of widget usage: </p>

<p>{% load Widget %}
<br/>  {% formWidget %}
<br/>  {
<br/>   &#39;strategy&#39;: &#39;wforms&#39;,
<br/>   &#39;action&#39;: &#39;/view/&#39;,
<br/>   &#39;method&#39;: &#39;POST&#39;,
<br/>   &#39;form&#39;:  form,
<br/>  }
<br/>  {% endformWidget %}
<br/>Please see wiki pages for more details. </p>

<p> The first version of this project is almost finished, but not yet committed to google code subversion. This is because we are refactoring it to separate it from our original project. please wait, coming soon...</p>
 summary : <p>django-wikiThis project has moved to GitHub: http://github.com/sneeu/django-wiki/ </p>

 title : The django-yui-layout-templates Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>Django layout templates using the Yahoo UI libraryThis project provides a set of default Django template layouts using the Yahoo UI library CSS tools (Grids, Font, Reset, Base).  Just svn export to help you get you along your way with using the Django framework and/or Google App Engine. </p>

<p>Supported Yahoo UI versions: </p>

<p>2.4.1 2.5.2 2.6.0 Also included are the following 8 layouts: </p>

<p>1 column - full page width 2 column - narrow left column (size of column can be changed) 2 column - narrow right column (size of column can be changed) 2 column - equal width columns 3 column - equal width columns 3 column - varying width columns (size of columns can be changed) 3 column - 1/4 - 1/2 - 1/4 4 column - equal width columns There is also a base layout included in the layouts directory that contains all the defaults.   </p>

<p>Feel free to add your comments or suggest a better (or another) layout! </p>

<p>Installation Django Google App Engine Usage Overriding Tips Links Installation(If you&#39;re using anything &lt; the latest Yahoo UI, check out the branches directory - this is where all the template layouts will be maintained.  I&#39;ll try to match trunk to the latest Yahoo UI library.) </p>

<p>DjangoExport the layouts and install them in a directory where the Django templating system can find them.  (I typically install them in project_name/templates/main_site/layouts/). </p>

<p>The source code can be accessed by performing a Subversion export. For example, the following command will export the application&#39;s source code out to a templates directory: </p>

<p>svn export http://django-yui-layout-templates.googlecode.com/svn/trunk/ templatesBe sure to check the branches directory for any version &lt; the latest Yahoo UI trunk </p>

<p>Google App EngineExport the layouts and install them in a directory named templates inside of your project directory. </p>

<p>The source code can be accessed by performing a Subversion export. For example, the following command will export the application&#39;s source code out to a templates directory: </p>

<p>svn export http://django-yui-layout-templates.googlecode.com/svn/branches/VERSION_HERE templatesThe Google App Engine versions will only live in the branches directory. </p>

<p>UsageTo use the layouts, you&#39;ll have to do 3 things.   </p>

<p>If you&#39;ve exported the the files from svn, there should be a file called  &#39;layout_overrides.html&#39;.  If not, create one in your main template directory. The base layout expects a file called &#39;header.html&#39; and &#39;footer.html&#39; in a directory called shared somewhere in your template path.  If you don&#39;t have this directory, either create one or keep reading to learn how to override the &#39;base_layout.html&#39; settings. (Thanks akaihola!)   Extend one of the provided Django template layouts in your template.  {% extends &#39;layouts/layout_2_equal_columns.html&#39; %}To add content to these layouts, there is a standardization on the block name you need to override in your templates.  The name of the block to add content to will be the column number (from left to right).  Using the example above, to add content to a layout, you&#39;ll have to put the following in one of your templates: </p>

<p>{% extends &#39;layouts/layout_2_equal_columns.html&#39; %}</p>

<p>{% block 1 %}
<br/>Left Column
<br/>{% endblock 1 %}</p>

<p>{% block 2 %}
<br/>Right Column
<br/>{% endblock 2 %}
<br/>As you can see, block 1 is the left column, block 2 is the right column.  For a 3 column layout, block 1 would be the left column, block 2 would be the center column, and block 3 would be the right column. (Not too hard. :P). </p>

<p>OverridesTo override any of the layout defaults, just place them in the layout_overrides.html file.  To see what you can override, take a look at layout_base.html.  As an example, you might want to override where the Yahoo UI css files are loaded from.  Currently, they&#39;re loaded from the Yahoo servers, but you might want to load it from your own CDN.  Taking a look at layout_base.html, you&#39;ll see the following: </p>

<p>{% block css.shared %}
<br/>     
<br/>     
<br/>{% endblock css.shared %}To override this default, just put the following in the layout_overrides.html file. </p>

<p>{% block css.shared %}
<br/>     
<br/>     
<br/>{% endblock css.shared %}Of course, this will override this default for all your layouts.  To override them in specific templates, just place the above code in your own template file. </p>

<p>TipsTo remove spaces from your templates, inside one of your templates, you&#39;ll want to do something like the following: </p>

<p>{% block layout.base %}{% spaceless %}{{block.super}}{% endspaceless %}{% endblock layout.base %}External LinksTo read more about how to configure the templates for Django, see the Django Project documentation.  To read more about how to tweak these layouts, see the section on template inheritance. ({{block.super}} is your friend!). </p>

<p> Voila! (Enjoy)  </p>

<p>If you have any suggestions, think there should be more layouts, or just want to talk story, feel free to contact us!</p>
 title : The django-zodb Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>Using Django and ZODB together., </p>
 title : The djangobile Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>Djangobile, Django Mobile ExtensionAbstractDjangobile is a django mobile extension for rendering web pages according to device capabilities. Therefore djangobile offers an implementation for W3C Working Draft IDEAL (Interface DEscription Authoring Language). Note: This software is under hard development. </p>

<p>DependenciesRequiredPyWURFL (pywurfl-6.4.0b). A Python language package that makes dealing with the WURFL in Python a little easier. Special thanks for Armand Lynch for his patience. OptionalLevenshtein Module (python-Levenshtein-0.10.1). Required if you want to use the Levenshtein distance or Jaro-Winkler algorithms for user agent similarity. lxml (lxml-2.1beta3.tar.gz). Required in order to validate IDEAL XML templates against MyMobileWeb&#39;s IDEAL DTD scheme for presentations. pyparsing (pyparsing-1.5.1.tar.gz). Required if you want to use the PyWURFL query language for create devices families. InstalationSimply check out djangobile in a django project root. </p>

<p>svn checkout http://djangobile.googlecode.com/svn/trunk/djangobile djangobileAnd set a new context processor in your project settings.py </p>

<p>TEMPLATE_CONTEXT_PROCESSORS = (
<br/>    &#39;django.core.context_processors.auth&#39;,
<br/>    &#39;django.core.context_processors.debug&#39;,
<br/>    &#39;django.core.context_processors.i18n&#39;,
<br/>    &#39;django.core.context_processors.media&#39;,
<br/>    # This context processor is required to djangobile works properly.
<br/>    &#39;djangobile.context_processors.mobile&#39;,</p>

<p>)OptionsMiddlewareYou can get device attribute in request object through a middleware. </p>

<p>MIDDLEWARE_CLASSES = (
<br/>    &#39;django.middleware.common.CommonMiddleware&#39;,
<br/>    &#39;django.contrib.sessions.middleware.SessionMiddleware&#39;,
<br/>    &#39;django.contrib.auth.middleware.AuthenticationMiddleware&#39;,
<br/>    &#39;django.middleware.doc.XViewMiddleware&#39;,
<br/>    # In order to use request.device in views.
<br/>    &#39;djangobile.middleware.DjangoMobileMiddleware&#39;,
<br/>)ApplicationDjangobile provides override_media_url and device_media_url in order to make easier to get media path according to device capabilities. </p>

<p>INSTALLED_APPS = (
<br/>    &#39;django.contrib.auth&#39;,
<br/>    &#39;django.contrib.contenttypes&#39;,
<br/>    &#39;django.contrib.sessions&#39;,
<br/>    &#39;django.contrib.sites&#39;,
<br/>    &#39;django.contrib.admin&#39;,
<br/>    # In order to use override_media_url and device_media_url templatetag
<br/>    # in templates.
<br/>    &#39;djangobile&#39;,
<br/>)PyWURFL classIn order to provide your own WURFL class to djangobile, you must set WURFL_CLASS variable. </p>

<p># Python WURFL class generated by wurfl2python.py script from pywurfl.
<br/>WURFL_CLASS = &#39;djangobile.wurfl&#39;User agent search algorithmDjangobile can use three distinct search algorithm: Tokenizer (by default), Jaro Winkler or Levenshtein distance. </p>

<p># Possible values are Tokenizer (default), JaroWinkler and LevenshteinDistance.
<br/># JaroWinkler and LevenshteinDistance require Levenshtein Module &gt;= 0.10.1.
<br/>USER_AGENT_SEARCH_ALGORITHM = &#39;Tokenizer&#39;For JaroWinkler search algorithm JARO_WINKLER_ACCURACY can be a value between 0 and 1. With values close to 1 you get a slower search. </p>

<p># Accuracy value for JaroWinkler search algorithm (0 to 1).
<br/># Default: 0.9
<br/>JARO_WINKLER_ACCURACY = 0.9Capabilities searchIn order to choose a template, djangobile uses a capabilities set to get the right template. </p>

<p># List of device capabilities to order template search.
<br/># Default: (id, user_agent, fall_back, preferred_markup, model_name, brand_name,
<br/>#           family)
<br/>DEVICE_SEARCH_ORDER = (
<br/>    &#39;user_agent&#39;,
<br/>    &#39;brand_name&#39;,
<br/>)Devices definitionIn order to define new devices, a file extra_devices.py can be created in the project root. The device definition uses PyWURFL syntax. </p>

<p>from djangobile import devices</p>

<p>devices.add(parent=&#39;generic&#39;,
<br/>            devid=&#39;fennec&#39;,
<br/>            devua=&#39;Mozilla/5.0 (X11; U; Linux i686; en-US; rv:1.9.1b2pre) Gecko/20081015 Fennec/1.0a1&#39;,
<br/>            actual_device_root=True)Devices families definitionOne definition of family is a set of capabilities that aims to provide designated fine-grained control over the identification devices. In order to define new families, a file extra_families.py can be created in the project root. The device definition uses PyWURFL QueryLanguage (setting  QUERY_LANGUAGE_SUPPORT   to  True  in settings.py) or native Python (over Device object) syntax. </p>

<p>from djangobile import families</p>

<p>@families.add
<br/>def xhtml_mp_device(device):
<br/>    return (device.preferred_markup == &#39;html_wi_oma_xhtmlmp_1_0&#39; or
<br/>            (device.preferred_markup == &#39;html_wi_w3_xhtmlbasic&#39; and 
<br/>             device.html_wi_oma_xhtmlmp_1_0 == True))</p>

<p># This syntax requires pyparsing module
<br/>families[&#39;morethan15columns_device&#39;] = &quot;&quot;&quot;columns &gt;= 15&quot;&quot;&quot;Obviously, the Python syntax is incredibly faster. </p>

<p>Prefix of loader tagsDjangobile provides two loader tags which are automatically added in order to make easier to write templates: those are &quot;extends&quot; and &quot;include&quot; templatetags device aware. This settings allows to define the prefix for them. By default its value is &#39;device&#39;, being the templatetags &quot;device_extends&quot; and &quot;device_include&quot;. But if it&#39;s  None , the native templatetags will be overwritten with those where suitable. </p>

<p># Prefix for &quot;extends&quot; and &quot;includes&quot; templatetags device aware.
<br/># If None, the native templatetags will be overwritten with
<br/># those where suitable.
<br/># Default: device.
<br/># And its use in templates is such as {% device_extends &quot;template.hmtl&quot; %}
<br/>DEVICE_LOADER_TAGS_PREFIX = &#39;device&#39;Prefix of device_media_url tagBy default its value is &#39;device&#39;, being the templatetag &quot;device_media_url&quot;. # Prefix for media_url templatetag device aware. # If None, the templatetags is named media_url # Default: device. # And its use in templates is such as {% device_media_url &quot;css/style.css&quot; %} </p>

<p>DEVICE_MEDIA_URL_TAG_PREFIX = NoneShow device logIn order to show detected device information in standard ouput, you can use this setting. </p>

<p># If you set this to True, djangobile will print information about device in
<br/># each request through standard output. Useful to debug issues.
<br/># Default: True
<br/>DEVICE_SHOW_LOG = True</p>

 title : The djangotaskscheduler Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>DjangoTaskSchedulerThis Django project provides an extension to the excellent Django Admin interface from which a system administrator can start and manage scheduled tasks. </p>

<p>Tasks are defined as Python programs that can utilize the Django models for the main application. The tasks need to interact with the task scheduler to report its status and request file locations for its output files. Example task programs are provided with the source code. </p>

<p>Non python programs can be kicked of from a python wrapper that follows the task scheduler conventions.  </p>

<p> </p>

<p>The codeThe code that you can obtain through the source tab contains a full Django application. The application consists of two Django apps: </p>

<p>demo scheduler </p>

<p>the demo app is empty and does nothing.  After installing and starting the webserver, pointing your webbrowser to http://localhost:8000 will not show anything. This starts the demo app which is empty. </p>

<p>The scheduler has another url: point the browser to http://localhost:8000/scheduler and you end up in the main scheduler page. From here you can schedule a new task, refresh the page or go into details on the scheduled or completed tasks.  </p>

<p>Each task can have one of many statuses (queued, processing, completed or failed). As each task is run the status is shown in the main scheduler page. Each task can provide custom status messages (in example a progress message) that shows on the main page.  </p>

<p>Each task can create output files. These are created and kept in a predefined place. If you spend some extra time setting up a secure webserver, an administrator can download the outputfiles right from the task details page.  </p>

<p>A poller program is provided that  </p>

<p>The statusThe status of this project is that it is under development. The main functionality is available in the current code. However, some additional code has to be completed. SOme outstanding tasks on the todo list are: </p>

<p>Include security for the scheduler. Typically normal visitors to the website have no reason to view/manage the scheduler.   Include instructions for setting up a file server to serve the output files in a secure manor. Include a more robust way of tracking whether the task program is still running or failed.  Switch from old-style admin to newforms admin for new task definitions and recurrences</p>
 title : The djapian Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>If you are using Djapian please tell us about your project in reply to this post </p>

<p>Use this package to allow full-text search in your Django project. </p>

<p>Versions compatibility matrix: </p>

<p>Djapian  Django  Xapian and python bindings  = 2.31.11.0.7 </p>

<p>Notice: there is an old issue with Xapian (&lt; 1.0.13) in mod_python environment. So be careful. </p>

<p>Notice: with 2.2.2 release has been introduced database schema backward-incompatible bug fix - Change model has switched its object_id field type from integer to string. </p>

<p>FeaturesMost of this features provided by Xapian itself and Djapian in this case plays role only as Django-compatible adaptation. </p>

<p>High-level DSL for indexer declaration Result filtering with Django ORM like API Result set compatible with standard Django Paginator Indexing of field, method results and related model attributes Entry filtering before indexing (by trigger function) Results filtering with boolean lookups support Term tagging Spelling corrections Stemming Result ordering by fields Indexers auto discovery Index shell Model changes auto tracking Support for different index spaces Usage exampleAssume that we have this models in our imaginary application: </p>

<p>class Person(models.Model):
<br/>    name = models.CharField(max_length=150)</p>

<p>    def __unicode__(self):
<br/>        return self.name</p>

<p>class Entry(models.Model):
<br/>    author = models.ForeignKey(Person, related_name=&quot;entries&quot;)
<br/>    title = models.CharField(max_length=250)
<br/>    created_on = models.DateTimeField(default=datetime.now)</p>

<p>    is_active = models.BooleanField(default=True)</p>

<p>    text = models.TextField()</p>

<p>    editors = models.ManyToManyField(Person, related_name=&quot;edited_entries&quot;)</p>

<p>    def headline(self):
<br/>        return &quot;%s - %s&quot; % (self.author, self.title)</p>

<p>    def __unicode__(self):
<br/>        return self.titleAnd we want to apply indexing functionality for model Entry. The next step is to create Indexer instance with proper settings. Indexer may look like this: </p>

<p>import djapian</p>

<p>class EntryIndexer(djapian.Indexer):
<br/>    fields=[&quot;text&quot;]
<br/>    tags=[
<br/>        (&quot;author&quot;,  &quot;author.name&quot; ),
<br/>        (&quot;title&quot;,   &quot;title&quot;,     3),
<br/>        (&quot;date&quot;,    &quot;created_on&quot;  ),
<br/>        (&quot;active&quot;,  &quot;is_active&quot;   ),
<br/>        (&quot;editors&quot;, &quot;editors&quot;     )
<br/>    ]
<br/>    trigger=lambda indexer, obj: obj.is_active</p>

<p>djapian.space.add_index(Entry, EntryIndexer, attach_as=&quot;indexer&quot;)In the django shell create some instances of models: </p>

<p>&gt;&gt;&gt; p = Person.objects.create(name=&quot;Alex&quot;)
<br/>&gt;&gt;&gt; Entry.objects.create(author=p, title=&quot;Test entry&quot;, text=&quot;Not large text field&quot;)
<br/>&gt;&gt;&gt; Entry.objects.create(author=p, title=&quot;Another test entry&quot;, is_active=False)
<br/>&gt;&gt;&gt; Entry.objects.create(author=p, title=&quot;Third small entry&quot;, text=&quot;Some another text&quot;)</p>

<p>&gt;&gt;&gt; Entry.indexer.update()Thats all! Each Entry instance has been indexed and now ready for search. Let&#39;s try: </p>

<p>&gt;&gt;&gt; result = Entry.indexer.search(&#39;title:entry&#39;)
<br/>&gt;&gt;&gt; len(result), result.count()
<br/>2, 2
<br/>&gt;&gt;&gt; for row in result:
<br/>...   row.percent, row.instance.headline()
<br/>... 
<br/>99 Alex - Test entry
<br/>98 Alex - Third small entryYou can follow complete Tutorial for study Djapian basics.</p>

<p>easy call views method DJS(Django JavaScript) </p>

<br/>    var id = 2;
<br/>    var callback = function(msg){
<br/>      alert(msg)
<br/>    };
<br/>    xxx.sample.views.index(request, id, callback);This code is called &quot;xxx.sample.views.index&quot; methods used Ajax. </p>

<p>page.replace_html(&quot;test&quot;, &quot;AJAX&quot;)
<br/>str = &quot;call id. %s&quot; % id
<br/>page.insert_html(&quot;bottom&quot;, &quot;test&quot;, str)
<br/>page.visual_effect(&quot;highlight&quot;, &quot;test&quot;, dict(duration=1))This sample is &quot;test.djs&quot;.  &quot;djs&quot; file is DJSTemplate File. DJSTemplate File is write &quot;pure python&quot;. h</p>

 title : The dmigrations Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>dmigrations - a simple migrations tool for DjangoCurrent version: 0.3.1 </p>

<p>dmigrations offers a simple but flexible way of managing changes to the database in your Django projects. It is a replacement for Django&#39;s built in syncdb command. </p>

<p>With dmigrations, every change to your database (including the creation of your initial tables) is bundled up in a migration. Migrations are Python files that live in a migrations directory. They can be applied and un-applied (reverted) in sequence. </p>

<p>The dmigrations app provides two sets of management commands: </p>

<p>./manage.py dmigrate </p>

<p>  </p>

<p>Commands for listing, applying and un-applying migrations to your database. 
<br/>./manage.py dmigration </p>

<p>  </p>

<p>Add a new migration to your migrations directory, ready to be executed using ./manage.py dmigrate 
<br/>For a full introduction, see the dmigrations tutorial. Read understanding migrations for more details on how migrations work and how they are managed. Check out dmigrations settings for information on additional settings. </p>

<p>dmigrations was presented at DjangoCon as part of the Schema Evolution panel. You can watch the video of the session, which includes a demo of dmigrations in action, here: http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=VSq8m00p1FM </p>

<p>Limitationsdmigrations requires Django 1.0 - it will not work with versions prior to the database creation refactoring in 8296 dmigrations currently only works with MySQL. It uses InnoDB tables by default, but can be configured to use MyISAM using the DMIGRATIONS_MYSQL_ENGINE setting dmigrations uses decorators, so requires Python 2.4 or later. Django&#39;s default test framework will still use syncdb, so it won&#39;t run your tests using your migrations to create the tables. A major refactoring took place to prepare the code for release. If you find any bugs, please report them in the bug tracker. It should go without saying, but it&#39;s an extremely good idea to back up your production database before running any migrations against it. dmigrations was written by Simon Willison and Tomasz Wegrzanowski. The code is released under a BSD license, and is © Global Radio 2008.</p>
 title : The dnastudy-rails Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>DNA Ruby on Rails study</p>

 title : The dnstun Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>dnstun provides a client and server for tunneling UDP traffic over DNS - perfectly suited to tunneling openvpn or similar traffic over DNS queries. </p>

<p>The client has two threads - one receives UDP packets on a socket and encapsulates them in DNS queries, while the other polls the DNS server for data and sends the data as UDP packets to the client accessing its socket. </p>

<p>The server also has two threads - one receives UDP packets on a socket and adds them to a queue, and the other receives DNS requests from the client and sends the data as UDP packets to a destination server, and receives polls from the client and responds with data from the queue. </p>

<p>Currently it is mostly complete but ENTIRELY UNTESTED.</p>

 title : The docbkx-tools Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>Docbkx Tools(Latest version: 2.0.10) </p>

<p> </p>

<p>What is it?The Docbkx Tools project provides a number of tools supporting DocBook in a Maven environment. This may seem odd to you, since 1) Maven 2 is supposed to support DocBook natively, relying on Doxia, and 2) there is already another DocBook plugin at mojo.codehaus.org. </p>

<p>The thruth however is that DocBook support in Doxia is fairly limited, mainly because Doxia as a framework supports only a small fraction of the concepts found in DocBook. The subset of DocBook supported by Doxia is not even close to simplified DocBook. </p>

<p>The DocBook plugin at mojo.codehaus.org is supporting a wider range of DocBook markup, and is in fact more similar to the DocBook tools provided with this project. There are however some significant differences. </p>

<p>Differences with other Maven pluginsThe focus is on ease of use. You should not be required to install additional stuff to your hard disk in order to generate content from your DocBook sources. Simply adding a reference to the plugin in your POM should be sufficient. This project focuses on providing dedicated support for particular DocBook XSL stylesheet distributions. That means you can rely on the dedicated parameterization mechanism of Maven Plugins to pass in the XSLT parameters defined for a particular version and type of XSLT stylesheet. In the DocBook Plugin found at mojo.codehaus.org, you will be required to download a specific version of the DocBook XSL stylesheets manually. The plugins packaged contain the stylesheets as well. (In this project, a particular version of the stylesheets is closely tied to a particular version of the plugin. That you means you can always rely on the plugin&#39;s documentation to know which parameters you could pass in.) The DocBook plugin found at mojo.codehaus.org requires you to have access to the Internet in order allow the plugin to resolve URI&#39;s. The plugins provided in this project act differently: if your DocBook sources are referening to a DTD, then you can simply add a dependency to a jar file containing the DTD and related entities, and the plugin will make sure that all references will be resolved correctly. How does this compare the DocBook Tools at SourceForge?This project builds on these tools; the main purpose is to provide something that integrates easily with Maven based builds. </p>

<p>I want to know moreFind the User Guide of the Maven Docbkx Plugin http://docbkx-tools.sourceforge.net/docbkx-maven-plugin/plugin-info.html.</p>

 title : Page Not Found - Open Hub
 summary : <p>What is dojangoDojango is a reusable django application that helps you to use the client-side framework dojo within your django project.   </p>

<p>It provides capabilites to easily switch between several dojo versions and sources (e.g. aol, google, local)  Delivers helping utilities, that makes the development of rich internet applications in combination with dojo more comfortable.  It makes the building of your own packed dojo release easier.  </p>

<p>Another goal of this project is, that you can learn how you have to structure your html to use dojo within your projects. </p>

<p>Dojango 0.3.0 is just running with Django versions &gt;= 1.0. </p>

<p>Dojango 0.3.1 is compatible with Django &gt;= 0.96. This is because dojango is now able to run on Google AppEngine and that platform uses Django 0.96. UPDATE: Not needed anymore, because AppEngine now supports Django 1.0 </p>

<p>Dojango 0.4: the FormIntegration just works with Django &gt;= 1.0.2 </p>

<p>Dojango 0.4.6: Dojo/Django ModelStore (Thanks to Ben Wilber, Documentation: http://sites.google.com/site/djangomodelstore/), easy dojo media file handling (dojo-media) and several bug fixes. Also available within PyPI (&quot;easy_install dojango&quot;). </p>

<p>Documentation and HelpSee a sample usage of dojango: </p>

<p>http://github.com/klipstein/dojango-sample </p>

<p>For tutorials and screencasts visit http://blog.uxebu.com </p>

<p>Find us hanging out in the IRC channel on freenode.net #dojango. </p>

<p>Ask questions, suggest new features or read other peoples thoughts in the Dojango Google Group at http://groups.google.com/group/dojango-users </p>

<p>Find more info in the wiki: </p>

<p>GettingStarted - How to install, setup and get the dojango test page running - in only two steps! (french version by Gilles Paul Dubois) Dojo Build - How to pack, build, optimize the JS source code by easily making a dojo build. Configuration - How to configure dojango. Dojo within Django example - An example django page using dojo. Django and templates - Describes how dojango can load its context into your template. Add dojo source - How to add your own dojo source version and to enable custom builds. Dojango on AppEngine - How to deploy your dojango powered app to Google&#39;s AppEngine  Using Dojo form elements - How to enable Dojo&#39;s form functionality in dojango.  Road map - What is the plan for the future, what is coming up next. </p>

<p>Or out in the wild internet: </p>

<p>AJAX with dojango - You got dojango and you want to write an AJAX app, read this blog article on how to make client server communication easy including JSON encoding and all that is needed. Dojo namespacing with dojango - If you want to know something about how dojo is using namespaces and how you incorporate it into your own reuseable django application, you should read this post.</p>

 title : The dokan Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>Dokan : user-mode file system library for WindowsWhen you want to create a new file system on Windows, for example to improve FAT or NTFS, you need to develop a file system driver. Developing a device driver that works in kernel mode on windows is extremely difficult. By using Dokan library, you can create your own file systems very easily without writing device driver. Dokan Library is similar to FUSE(Linux user mode file system) but works on Windows. </p>

<p>http://dokan-dev.net/en</p>

 summary : <p>Browser DOM CheckerA simple utility to thoroughly validate DOM, XMLHttpRequest, and cookie security restriction handling in modern web browsers.  title : The doodle-ad-stub Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>This plugin let you use stub images instead of real Google AdSense ads while running web project in development mode. </p>

<p>InstallationTo checkout the latest version of the plugin to your Rails project run the following command in the root directory of the project: </p>

<p>$ svn co http://doodle-ad-stub.googlecode.com/svn/trunk/ vendor/plugins/doodle-ad-stubor if you use piston then run </p>

<p>$ piston import http://doodle-ad-stub.googlecode.com/svn/trunk/ vendor/plugins/doodle-ad-stubOpen terminal and run following command in the root directory of the plugin (vendor/plugins/doodle_ad_stub) </p>

<p>$ ruby ./install.rbThis will create google_adsense/ subdirectory in public/images/ directory of your project, and copy sample images of most available Google AdSense ad formats there. </p>

<p>Configuration file ppds_doodle_ad_stub.rb will be placed to config/initializers/ directory of your project, don&#39;t forget to review it and correct settings. </p>

<p>Ppds::DoogleAdStub.client_id = &quot;pub-0557047985484196&quot;
<br/>Ppds::DoogleAdStub.color_border = &quot;666666&quot;
<br/>Ppds::DoogleAdStub.color_bg = &quot;DDDDDD&quot;
<br/>Ppds::DoogleAdStub.color_link = &quot;0000FF&quot;
<br/>Ppds::DoogleAdStub.color_text = &quot;000000&quot;
<br/>Ppds::DoogleAdStub.color_url = &quot;008800&quot;
<br/>Ppds::DoogleAdStub.ui_features = &quot;rc:6&quot;
<br/>Ppds::DoogleAdStub.language = &quot;en&quot;
<br/>Ppds::DoogleAdStub.cpa_choice = nil
<br/>Ppds::DoogleAdStub.ad_channel = nilYou will definitely want to change at least Ppds::DoogleAdStub.tracker_id parameter to match your own ID. The rest settings used to customize the appearance of the ads and are optional. </p>

<p>Usagewhere width and height defines size of the ad and type if not explicitly defined defaults to &quot;text&quot;. </p>

<p>Sample</p>
 summary : <p>Dope - A portable C implementation of a HashHash / Linked ListsAlmost everything I write requires some form of linked list, or more flexible array than C provides, perhaps because I&#39;m too used to using PHP or HashMaps in Java, or perhaps it&#39;s the same for everyone. It&#39;s such a small amount of code that you write it over and over without thinking about it. Dope can change that, while it&#39;s only a little bit of code it&#39;s incredibly useful, save yourself those 30 minutes every time you start a new project and go with a Hash that works and is thoroughly tested for leeks.</p>

 title : The dotmac Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>Robsworking branch merged to trunk, and robsworking and ilife branches deprecatedFor any users currently using trunk, you will receive a large update the next time you sync. We suggest that you back up your current install before trying the &quot;new&quot; trunk.  If you are currently using the robsworking branch, you will need to switch to trunk to get any future updates. </p>

<p>Snow Leopard SupportThere is preliminary support for Snow Leopard in the iLife branch. If you are using Snow Leopard please give it a try. If you have any issues with it, please post them here </p>

<p>Project Name Change !!!!At the request of Apple, we will be changing the name of our project. We have decided on  dotMobile.us Please bookmark that URL. We will be transitioning to a new project space and that URL will follow us where ever we go.   </p>

<p>What if...?you don’t think a few lousy gig’s of disk space on .Mac is enough you think .Mac is a bit slow you’d like backup.app to work without paying an annual fee   </p>

<p>Well... build your own dotMac  The following features should be expected to work on both 10.4 and 10.5: </p>

<p>Data synchronization for any application that supports .Mac (iCal, Address Book, notes, etc...) Note: Data synchronization between 10.4 and 10.5 isn&#39;t  (and probably won&#39;t be) implemented 
<br/>iDisk iDisk sync Note: If you are using multiple clients, please stick to either using idisk sync on all, or just straight idisk on all. This will be fixed in the second release 
<br/>Backup Please give the code a try, and let us know if you run into any problems here </p>

<p>Security issue foundPlease go here for detais http://code.google.com/p/dotmac/issues/detail?id=44 </p>

<p>Tools that we use and recommendThere are two very important pieces of software that we use to help decode the protocols for use in dotMobile.us. Without them, we probably would have given up long ago. They are: DAV Explorer - Open Source Java Application Charles Web Proxy - Shareware application that the author graciously donated to us for use with this project. Anyone that has to do any HTTP/HTTPS programming or debugging should pick up a copy of this. </p>

<p>the iLife branchnot for the fainted heartedWe&#39;re trying to push the iLife branch towards stable. We&#39;re looking for people willing to install from the iLife branch;  basic features like in trunk will still work - others might update regularly over time. iLife introduced a .db user backend which&#39;ll break your current setup;  We&#39;ve set up a special issue page on iLife here We need people both documenting and reporting errors.</p>
 title : The dotnet-membership-provider Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>This project takes the C# port of janrain&#39;s OpenID library, maintained here: </p>

<p>http://code.google.com/p/dotnetopenid/ http://groups.google.com/group/dotnetopenid/ and wraps it in a developer-friendly ASP.NET membership provider, allowing as close to an out-of-the-box developer experience as possible. </p>

<p>As an ASP.NET developer, you can plug in OpenID to your application and use it as you use any other standard authentication plug-in. The starter kit gives you a quick-start sample to show how it all works. </p>

<p>Our goals for this project are to make OpenID for .NET developers: </p>

<p>Simple to use: Make OpenID simple for developers to plug in to any ASP.NET project Familiar: Leverage the Membership Provider infrastructure in ASP.NET </p>

<p>RELEASE NOTES(12/10/2007) The current .vsi file &#39;OpenID Membership Provider Starter kit for Visual Studio 2005 Beta 0.4&#39; corrects &quot;No Session State Found&quot; error after login. This build corrects all known issues to date.  </p>

<p>(12/09/2007) &#39;OpenID Membership Provider Starter kit for Visual Studio 2005 Beta 0.3&#39; protects password data for OpenID users by creating unusable passwords and salts for users having OpenID logins (OpenID users are authenticated via their Identity Provider and therefore have no need for local passwords). This will allow applications to use the same Membership database for one application that uses both OpenID and Forms authentication. </p>

<p>(12/03/2007) &#39;OpenID Membership Provider Starter kit for Visual Studio 2005 Beta 0.2&#39; corrects the janrain.openid.dll incompatibility error that was found in the first release. </p>

<p>About The OpenID Membership ProviderUsing the ASP.NET Membership Provider model, the OpenID Membership Provider allows you to leverage declarative authorization and other ASP.NET providers (such as Roles Providers) with OpenID authentication. </p>

<p>To learn more about OpenID, visit OpenID.net. OpenID authentication is made possible through third party Identity Providers. This Starter Kit assumes your users will make use of existing OpenID Identity Providers (IDPs).</p>

 title : The doubler Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>Doubler is a code generator (C# and VB.NET) that makes unit testing easier. It is especially useful when working with legacy code. It is a Reflector add-in, a tool already woven into your workflow. It will help you cleave dependencies apart, create test doubles, and write unit tests with little effort and less coding. </p>

<p>Some of the features are: </p>

<p>Recording Generator – Use against an abstract type. It will create a Recording Test Stub. Recorders generated have the following features for each method on the subject type: o Property named Called of type Boolean that records if the method was called. 
<br/>o Properties for each parameter passed named in the following format Passed of the same type as the parameter. 
<br/>o Property named ReturnValue of the same type as return type of the subject method. If subject method is void this property is not created. When the method is called the this value is returned. 
<br/>o Property named ExceptionToThrow of type Exception. When the method is called if this property is not null the property value is thrown. 
<br/>Wrapper/Interface Generator – Use against a concrete type. It will create a mirror interface of the subject type and an implementation of the interface that passes all calls to a private instance of the subject type. This can be used to help control dependencies, allowing unit tests to insert a test double in place of the subject (run the Recording Generator on the mirror interface). Fake Generator - Use against an abstract type. It will create a Fake Object. Test Generator – Use against a concrete type. It will generate a unit test fixture and test methods for each public method on the test subject. The test methods will contain a start on the unit test.</p>

 summary : <p>A ruby library</p>

 summary : <p>dpUInt - digital primates Unit and IntegrationdpUInt has reached its 1.0 release and is now known as Fluint. It is currently an early beta release. Based loosely on the concepts of FlexUnit and its ancestor JUnit, it provides enhanced asynchronous support, a graphical test runner, integration with continuous build systems and an optional Adobe AIR client for directory watching. </p>

 title : The drarch Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>OverviewArchitecture Reconstruction is a process in which the &quot;as-built&quot; architecture of an implemented system is obtained from an existing system. This is done through a detailed analysis of the system using tool support. The tool (DRArch) extract information about the system and aid in building and aggregating successive levels of abstraction. The end result is an architectural representation. </p>

<p>The result of architectural reconstruction can be used in several ways. If no documentation exists or if it is out of date, the recovered architectural representation can be used as a basis for re-documenting the architecture. The results of a reconstruction can also be used  to recover the as built architecture to check conformance against an &quot;as-designed&quot; architecture. This assures us that the developers have followed the architectural edicts. The reconstruction can also be used as the basis for analyzing the architecture or as a starting point for re-engineering the system to a new desired architecture. Finally, the representation can be used to identify elements for re-use or to establish an architecture-based software product line. </p>

<p>DRArch define a process of Software Architecture Reconstruction. Consists of a collection of tools that can be used to extract information from an implemented system, build abstractions of that information, through the use of a query language and generate architecture views of that information.  </p>

<p>The following diagram show the main concept of DRArch:</p>

 title : The drics Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>Project OverviewIn the Orthopedic Biomechanics Laboratory here at the University of Florida, we are developing programs and systems to better understand and study human movement. One of these projects is a novel, robotically actuated X-ray imaging platform whose purpose will be to photograph (with X-rays) peoples joints or implants during normal movement. </p>

<p> </p>

<p>Graphical illustration of the system in operation </p>

<p>Producing a robust robotic system, which integrates robots, sensors, computer platforms, and programming languages, is a daunting task. Therefore this project focuses on the development and testing of the control software for this system. Named DRICS, Dynamic Radiographic Imaging Control Software, this effort will build an open source control framework. Highlights include </p>

<p>Distributed real-time control framework based on the Orca/Ice libraries Off and on-line measurement planning tools and algorithms Project roadmapGetting startedFirst check out a copy of the code from our subversion repository. This can be done in both Windows and Linux. However, 99% of our code base is meant to be compiled in Linux - in other words, use Windows at your own risk. </p>

<p>In Linux, to checkout the code type: </p>

<p>svn checkout https://drics.googlecode.com/svn/trunk/ drics --username your_user_name </p>

<p>You will then be prompted for your password. Once you have a copy of the code, hack away! When you feel you have added something useful to the code, commit your changes to share with everyone else: </p>

<p>svn commit -m &quot;Some message for the log books stating what you did&quot; </p>

<p>If you are writing a component for the first time, check out the Empty Component in the component directory.</p>
