 title : The dsmts Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>NEWS26/3/09: SBML L2v4 version of the DSMTS is released </p>

<p>MotivationStochastic simulation is a very important tool for Systems Biology modelling. However, it is difficult to check the correctness of a stochastic simulator, since any two realizations from a single model will typically be different. </p>

<p>AboutThis is a test suite of stochastic models encoded in the Systems Biology Markup Language (SBML) that have been solved either analytically or using numerical methods. This allows the accuracy of stochastic simulators to be tested against known results. The test suite is already being used by a number of stochastic simulator developers.</p>
 title : The dsnp Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>Simple and customizable script that automatically creates and configures a new django project with user&#39;s own preferences. Designed for developers that create many django projects with the same structure. </p>

<p>It is also good for Django newbies, because after execution there is a working Django project. </p>

<p>Created projects are configured for working with newforms-admin branch. </p>

<p>Installation and usage: </p>

<p>cd [INSTALLATION_PATH]
<br/>svn co https://dsnp.googlecode.com/svn/trunk/ dsnp
<br/>cd [DJANGO_PROJECTS_ROOT]
<br/>python [INSTALLATION_PATH]/dsnp.py [NEW_PROJECT_NAME]Customization of the script: </p>

<p>Edit dsnp.py and modify any of following variables: </p>

<p>APP_NAME: Name for your (first or only) django application (inside the project) ADMIN_NAME: Path for the django admin application SETTINGS_TEMPLATE: Your default settings.py file BASE_TEMPLATE: Your base.html file </p>

<p>Moving your project to a production environment </p>

<p>For moving your project to a production environment, as well as copying your project tree, you should do next steps: </p>

<p>Edit env_settings.py and modify necessary values (probably all values, specially set DEBUG to False, and set up your production database) Set up your production web server. Here it is an apache + mod_python virtual host sample file: </p>

<p>        ServerAdmin me@mydomain
<br/>        DocumentRoot /var/www/myproject
<br/>        ServerName mydomain
<br/>        ErrorLog /var/log/apache2/mydomain_error_log
<br/>        CustomLog /var/log/apache2/mydomain_access_log combined
<br/>        
<br/>                SetHandler python-program
<br/>                PythonPath &quot;[&#39;/opt/django/newforms-admin&#39;] + [&#39;/var/www&#39;] + sys.path&quot;
<br/>                PythonHandler django.core.handlers.modpython
<br/>                SetEnv DJANGO_SETTINGS_MODULE myproject.settings
<br/>                PythonDebug Off
<br/>        
<br/>        
<br/>                SetHandler None</p>
 title : The dsolve Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>This project seeks to firstly provide the most user friendly way for those with diabetes to track key information.  This information includes intraday blood sugars, meals (with their nutrional values), doctor visits, lab results (like A1c), and much more.  Lastly, since many meters on the market now allow you to save your blood sugar results to a file via a computer interface this application will also allow a user to upload files from various meters.</p>

<p>The second core feature will be that of both simple and complex data analysis for the individual user of their own diabetes information via datawarehousing techniques as well as visually through charts and graphs.</p>

<p>The last feature of this application will be for medical community researchers.  It is our hope that with enough specific information about those with diabetes, their nutrition, and lab results we will have built a solid basis for the medical community to conduct innumerable studies all in a manner that provides only the basic personnel information such as age, sex, and years with diabetes.  In this way both the individual diabetic is benefited from this very useful application but the diabetic community is also benefited from entering as much data as possible and created this research information library for analysis today and into the future.</p>

 title : The ducks-on-rails Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>For my master thesis research on duck migration I created a set of scripts to process and visualize the data. Ducks are captured, given a ring and then released. Days or years later the duck is found again and reported. Information such as age, cause of death, geographical location is added.  </p>

<p>Note: I moved the source code to Github, but other information will remain here. </p>

<p>Many countries keep a database with many different bird species that were ringed in their country. My research focussed on ducks ringed in the Netherlands. Because the data is stored according to the international EURING standard, this software can - with some modifications - in principle be used for all bird species in all countries that use the EURING standard or something similar. </p>

<p>The original EURING data is imported from a fixed-width text format into a MySQL database. Several Ruby on Rails migrations (some executing other SQL &amp; PHP scripts) convert this data into a relational database, perform consistency checks and mix it with some other data. Finally, the Rails program visualizes the data.  </p>

<p>I deviate from the EURING standard in several ways which I believe are necessary. For example I strictly adhere to the ISO 3166 standard of country (subdivision) codes (using e.g. geonames.org for the conversion) and use decimal coordinates of latitude and longitude.  </p>

<p>More information is available on the Wiki. You can download the source code and visit a demonstration website. The data is not (always) freely available, but there is a small example dataset and I will provide information on how to obtain more. The wiki also provides several MySQL queries that I used for my research. </p>

<p>After I graduate I may not have a lot of time for further development, but I will be available to answer questions and suggest ideas.</p>
 summary : <p>None, </p>
 title : The ductile Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>&quot;duetopia&quot; is a lightweight metadata management and search system intended for use with geographic information. duetopia is supported and made available by Terradue SRL  </p>

<p>Getting StartedQuick install package of duetopia  Checking the latest working version out of subversion Check out just the documentation (svn/trunk/docs)  FeaturesLibraries provide import of metadata from common standard formats into a shared model (ISO19115, ISO19139, FGDC, THREDDS) stored using RDF.  </p>

<p>A GeoDjango-based basic user interface allows for collaborative editing of metadata records in the repository, and a search interface that is designed to comply with the INSPIRE Implementing Rules for Discovery Services in the EU in a minimal way. </p>

<p>An OpenSearch interface using the OpenSearch Geo extensions provides search feeds in JSON, KML and XHTML.</p>

 title : The dunitlite Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>DUnitLite is an attempt to improve upon the DUnit unit-testing framework for Delphi. It&#39;s currently an add-on library for DUnit (though, as the name suggests, it may someday grow to be a full lightweight testing library in its own right). </p>

<p>Right now, DUnitLite offers three major features over the base DUnit library: </p>

<p>Readable assertionsMost xUnit test frameworks have backwards assertion methods. They make you put the expected value first, followed by the actual value: </p>

<p>CheckEquals(4, Add(2, 2));How do you read that? &quot;Check that 4 is what you get when you add 2 and 2&quot;? You shouldn&#39;t have to think this hard to understand what the test is doing. What if you could write it the way you would speak: &quot;Check that 2 plus 2 is 4&quot;? </p>

<p>Enter DUnitLite. </p>

<p>Specify.That(Add(2, 2), Should.Equal(4));
<br/>Specify.That(Control.Caption, Should.Equal(&#39;Close&#39;).IgnoringCase);
<br/>Specify.That(ElapsedTime, Should.Be.AtMost(500));See SupportedSyntax for a list of all the different things you can do. </p>

<p>More data typesDUnit&#39;s CheckEquals() methods support a limited number of data types. The only way you can compare two enums (or two records, or...) is to write your own CheckEquals overload -- which isn&#39;t that hard, but then you need to write more code if you want CheckNotEquals, CheckGreater, CheckGreaterOrEqual... </p>

<p>DUnitLite has built-in support for data types DUnit doesn&#39;t (e.g. TPoint). And when you want to add more, you only have to write the code once to get the benefit everywhere. </p>

<p>See SupportedTypes for more details. </p>

<p>String contextWhen comparing really long strings, it can be hard to see where they&#39;re actually different. DUnitLite makes it easier by showing only a portion of the strings, centered around the first character that&#39;s actually different. </p>

<p>Specify.That(Query.Sql.Text, Should.Equal(ExpectedSql));</p>

<p>Expected: ...&#39;.TicketID = Tickets.ID&#39;#13#10&#39;WHERE Component = 42 AND Status = 1 A&#39;...
<br/> but was: ...&#39;.TicketID = Tickets.ID&#39;#13#10&#39;WHERE Tickets.Component = 42 AND Tick&#39;...</p>

 summary : <p>打屁屁, </p>

 title : The dwarvis Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>This project is meant as a collection of 3rd party utilities for the game Dwarf Fortress. It concentrates on utilities that have the purpose of providing a 3-dimensual visualization of the ingame world. It contains two applications at the current time. </p>

<p>ApplicationsLifevisThis is the main program, a life viewer of a DF game. It shows a 3d representation centered on the current view, which constantly updates. It currently displays landscape, creatures, buildings and items, although the latter three aren&#39;t yet at full detail representation. Additionally it forwards all input to DF, so it can act as a remote control. </p>

<p>Please click the Feedback link to the right if you have questions about lifevis, want to make suggestions or provide general feedback. </p>

<p> </p>

<p>map_extractThis script accesses the memory of a running (and hopefully paused) Dwarf Fortress game. It extracts the landscape data and exports the tile types and other parts into a gzipped text file. More... </p>

<p>Latest Updates(Changes are listed chronologically from the bottom up.) </p>

<p>Lifevis v0.254 - Date: 03:05:45, Freitag, 14. November 2008 </p>

<p>All items are now stored in a hash again, due to unpredictably high id values exceeding the memory bounds when applied to an array. Removed &quot;item_present&quot; array in favor of visible flag on items, need to think about how to handle items vanishing from DF&#39;s memory list IF it happens. All update loops and the render loop now set times at which they wish to be run again; these times are calculated by adding the configurable delay to the current time and subtracting the time it took for the loop to run the last time. All update loops now run for a minimum configurable time slice before returning control to the dispatcher. All update loops and the render loop now have functions for time measuring. Item data is grabbed in buckets with each one spanning multiple item data sets. Unit data is now grabbed as one string and dissected in Perl. Speed-up of landscape updates when cell didn&#39;t change by comparing data extract in one step before cycling through the tiles in the cell. Lifevis v0.249 - Date: 13:33:29, Dienstag, 11. November 2008 This effectively improves performance by skipping invisible cells. Model drawing is now split into 1. drawing of landscape, 2. drawing of visibility masks and selecting cells based on visibility level, 3. drawing buildings, items, creatures in selected cells.  Landscape display list generation now generates crude visibility mask display lists.  Base lighting made brighter.  Lighting variances still not optimal.  Added glDeleteQueries call to OpenGL module. Notes about OpenGL module changes added to documents. All models are now drawn by z-layer in preparation for occlusion checks. Creature, building and item lists in cell structure are now divided by z-layer.  Display list storage in caches changed to enable easier access and extension.  Documents and internals files updated to correspond with that.  Calculation of light variances changed.  Recompiled OpenGL module to include occlusion check calls. Added QuadTree class to deal with creating occlusion check shapes. Implemented zoom-by-fov in order to reduce z-clipping. (inactive) Reduced z-buffer accuracy problems by clamping clipping planes to outer bounds of map. Made landscape display lists be drawn in one call. Fixed warning from threads when loading OpenGL twice by loading secondary modules later on.  Reactivated culling of invisible faces. ModelGen now generates vertex array draw commands. Adapted buildings, creatures, items to new generic method and phased out old specific methods. Made model generation sub routines return display list ids.  Building drawing adapted to general model display lists. Landscape drawing sketchily adapted to new parts subroutines.  General model-&gt;display list conversion routine created.  Model code generation switched to generating separate subroutines for faces in the cardinal directions and one for the main body.  Basis for parts-based display list generation laid. Made the model generator code decidedly less retarded and easier to transition over to generate individual subroutines for the normals. Added comments to model generator code. Refactoring to prepare for switch to vertex arrays.  Improved handling of z-based lighting of buildings. Added dedicated default building model.  Lifevis v0.227 - Date: 16:00:09, Samstag, 18. Oktober 2008 Input sent to DF is now immediate and doesn&#39;t follow Windows&#39; repeat rules anymore. Improved mouse interaction. New cursor model. Fixed Stairs-Down model to simply be a hole in the floor. Added vtable export converter. Made update loops for buildings and items assign vtable names and offsets to items. Added basic models for doors and workshops. Added basic building model distinction system. Made range change buttons dim when range limits reached. Made view range changes also change the clipping range to reduce z-fighting. A lot of code refactoring. Lifevis v0.215 - Date: 20:29:24, Dienstag, 14. Oktober 2008 Bugfix to make the view update when the drawing range is changed even then the cursor isn&#39;t moved. Far clipping plane moved closer to reduce z-errors. All Perl modules updated to most current versions, especially OpenGL, which is now at 0.57 and includes freeglut. Lifevis v0.213 - Date: 16:38:01, Dienstag, 14. Oktober 2008 New self-compiled executables. Items that are in bins now get ignored. Interface cleaned up a bit. Item data now stored in array and indexed by DF-internal item id, instead of in a hash indexed by memory address. Items are now only stored when they are lying on the ground and not hidden. Lifevis v0.209 Mostly performance improvements, as follows: Memory loop now sleeps until needed. Memory loop becomes less aggressive when all current cells are protected. Idle tasks routine converted to &quot;while&quot;-loop with a central loop scheduler to cut number of routine calls. Added higher priority for drawing-loop, tweaked fps limiter to be more exact. Unnecessary cloning of arrays converted to much faster iteration over them. Lifevis v0.204 Added display of item placeholders. Tweaked settings to speed graphics up a bit. Added export of data of items/buildings/creatures in current square. Fixed bug in rendering loop that prevented buildings from rendering in cells without creatures. Lifevis v0.200 - Date: 10:25:14, Mittwoch, 8. Oktober 2008 Buildings now get displayed as bright red blocks. Doesn&#39;t work 100% yet. Added readme file. Reduced creature update slowdown to 0. Made some small optimizations to creature updates. Lifevis v0.198 - Date: 01:12:00, Mittwoch, 8. Oktober 2008 Calls to Win32::Process::Memory converted to direct calls, resulting in a speed-up of the update routines of roughly 200%.</p>

 title : The dynamic-file-store Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>This plugin no longer works with Rails 2.1 and has subsequently been discontinued. </p>

<p>As an alternative, try placing this in application.rb: </p>

<p>  helper_method :read_fragment_or_cache
<br/>  def read_fragment_or_cache(opts)
<br/>    #puts &quot;read_fragment_or_cahce called. opts = #{opts.inspect}&quot;
<br/>    # Check to see if key has expired
<br/>    return nil unless opts[:key]
<br/>    key = opts[:key]
<br/>    expire_at = opts[:expire_at] || Time.now
<br/>    fragment = Rails.cache.read(key, :raw =&gt; true)
<br/>    #fragment = read_fragment(key, {:expire_at =&gt; expire_at})
<br/>    if fragment.nil?
<br/>      puts &quot;\n\n Fragment NOT FOUND for key:  #{key}\n&quot;
<br/>      # Render whatever should be rendered by the render options to a string for caching.
<br/>      fragment = render_to_string(opts[:render])
<br/>      Rails.cache.write(key, fragment, :raw =&gt; true)
<br/>      #result = write_fragment(opts[:key], fragment)
<br/>    else
<br/>      puts &quot;\n\n Fragment WAS INDEED found for key: #{key}\n&quot;
<br/>    end
<br/>    return fragment
<br/>  endThen you can define cache helper methods (in application.rb, for example) like: </p>

<p>  helper_method :cached_popular_this_week
<br/>  def cached_popular_this_week
<br/>    fragment = read_fragment_or_cache :key =&gt; &quot;home/popular_this_week&quot;,
<br/>                                      :expire_at =&gt; 1.hour.ago,
<br/>                                      :render =&gt; {:partial =&gt; &quot;shared/popular_this_week&quot;}
<br/>    return fragment
<br/>  endAnd simply call them in your views with: </p>

<p>&lt;%= cached_popular_this_week %&gt;
<br/>There might be better ways to do all this.  Hopefully this is of some help though if you are migrating to Rails 2.1 and beyond.</p>
 summary : <p>NO LONGER MAINTAINED: Superceded by http://code.google.com/p/restcontroller/ </p>

<p>A plugin for Rails to duplicate the generated scaffold_resource (a RESTful Controller and Views for a given model/resource), but do it dynamically, like the &#39;scaffold :model&#39; call available in Rails, currently. Also allows for running all the standard scaffold_resource tests by &#39;include DynamicScaffoldResourceTestHelper&#39; and then specifying the @singular_name for the resource in your test setup funtion. </p>

<p>See README link or the included docs, for more details.</p>

 title : The eapmlib Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>Description </p>

<p>Object oriented C++ library to develop Evolutionary Algorithms based on Probabilistic Models.  This library allows the use of predefined state-of-the-art methods, and contains the basic structures to easily create new methods. </p>

<p>Dependencies </p>

<p>This library uses the OpenCV library. This is an open source library for computer vision, and it is available at: http://sourceforge.net/projects/opencvlibrary/ </p>

<p>Platform </p>

<p>The source code has been tested under Windows (Microsoft Visual Studio 6.0 and 2005), under Linux (Eclipse &amp; Automake). </p>

<p>Acknowledgements </p>

<p>This library also contains the Naïve Bayes models Estimation (NBE) algorithm, developed by Daniel Lowd and published in: </p>

<p>Daniel Lowd and Pedro Domingos. &#39;Naive Bayes Models for Probability Estimation&#39;. Proceedings of the Twenty-Second International Conference on Machine Learning (ICML), 2005. Bonn, Germany: ACM Press. </p>

<p>The original source code can be accessed at: http://www.cs.washington.edu/ai/nbe/ </p>

<p>Support More information can be found at http://www.cvc.uab.cat/~xbaro/eanbe/ or http://www.cvc.uab.cat/~xbaro/</p>
 title : The easier-indexes Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>A simple plugin to make adding indexes in Rails migrations easier: </p>

<p>create_table :authors do |t|
<br/>  t.string :name, :index =&gt; true
<br/>  t.string :email, :index =&gt; true
<br/>  t.integer :company_id, :index =&gt; { :unique =&gt; true }
<br/>  t.text :bio
<br/>endInstall like this: </p>

<p>./script/plugin install http://easier-indexes.googlecode.com/svn/easier-indexes</p>
 title : The easyalm Open Source Project on Open Hub

 title : The easyb Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>easyb is a BDD framework (like RSpec &amp; JBehave) that provides a domain specific language which makes application verification simple, fun, and easy. easyb provides support for two types of specifications, Behaviors and Stories. Behaviors are created with before and it. Stories are created with scenario, given, when and then. </p>

<p>easyb in actioneasyb enables you to verify behavior of normal Java objects, work-flows, etc (basically, anything you write in Java) in a more natural way-- for instance, imagine having a conversation with a customer who wants you to write something to validate zip codes. </p>

<p>&quot;Could you please write something that lets my customers know when they&#39;ve provided an invalid zip code?&quot;  
<br/>&quot;Sure! So, given an invalid zip code, this validation service should notify someone that</p>
 title : The easybuy Open Source Project on Open Hub

 title : The easycache Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>Easycache lets you easily cache arbitrary data in your Ruby on Rails applications. The plugin makes use of Rails&#39; built-in fragment caching mechanism to store and retrieve any serializable data. This is especially useful when you want to store data from slow/external sources like LDAP, Web Services, or REXML functions, for which Rails does not currently offer an integrated caching mechanism. </p>

<p>INSTALLATIONFrom the command line, cd into your Rails application&#39;s root directory and run: </p>

<p>ruby script/plugin install git://github.com/zuk/rails-easycache.git </p>

<p>EXAMPLESOnce you&#39;ve installed the plugin, you should be able to do something like this anywhere in your application (in controllers, helpers, etc.): </p>

<p>foo = [&#39;alpha&#39;, &#39;beta&#39;, &#39;delta&#39;, &#39;gamma&#39;]</p>

<p># store foo in the cache under the keyname &#39;greek&#39;
<br/>Easycache.write(&#39;greek&#39;, foo)</p>

<p># retrieve the data stored under keyname &#39;greek&#39;
<br/>foo = Easycache.read(&#39;greek&#39;)</p>

<p># delete the data stored under keyname &#39;greek&#39;
<br/>Easycache.delete(&#39;greek&#39;)In practice, you will probably want to use caching transparently, so that data is pulled from the cache if available, or from the original source otherwise. For example, say you have a function ldap_query() that does a slow LDAP query to retrieve some data. Just wrap this function call inside an Easycache.cache block, like this: </p>

<p>my_data = Easycache.cache(&#39;ldap_data&#39;) do
<br/>  ldap_query()
<br/>endThe first time the block runs, it will execute ldap_query(), store its return value in the cache under the key &#39;ldap_data&#39;, and return it for assignment into your my_data variable. The next time it&#39;s run, the return value will come from the cache, so the block won&#39;t need to be executed. </p>

<p>TIME-BASED EXPIRYThe write() and cache() methods both take an optional options hash. Currently the only supported option is :expiry, which will force the cached value to expire after the given number of seconds. For example: </p>

<p>Easycache.write(&#39;greek&#39;, [&#39;alpha&#39;, &#39;beta&#39;], :expiry =&gt; 60)or </p>

<p>greek = Easycache.cache(&#39;greek&#39;, :expiry =&gt; 60) do
<br/>  [&#39;alpha&#39;, &#39;beta&#39;]
<br/>endThe above will expire the &#39;greek&#39; value after 60 seconds. In Rails applications you can use active_support&#39;s time extensions to specify the expiry period. For example: </p>

<p>Easycache.write(&#39;greek&#39;, [&#39;alpha&#39;, &#39;beta&#39;], :expiry =&gt; 24.hours)</p>
 title : The easygui Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>Send email to this group: egui_dev@googlegroups.com for any question.   </p>

<p>How to Use the eGUI in you mfc application.By Yang XiaoWang 
<br/>1. Create a CContainerWidget as a root container of other widgets.   CContainerWidget* m_pRootContainer = new CContainerWidget();2. Create a CDisplayManager to hold your mfc window&#39;s draw context.   CDisplayManager* m_pDisplayManage=new CDisplayManage(m_hWnd,wrc.Width(),wrc.Height());3. Set the rootContainer&#39;s Display Manager as the above displayManager   m_pDisplayManage-&gt;RegisterRootContainer(m_pRootContainer);
<br/>   m_pRootContainer-&gt;SetDisplayManage(m_pDisplayManage);4. Change app&#39;s OnPaint() or OnDraw() as below to draw the widget.   this-&gt;m_pRootContainer-&gt;InvalidateContent(0);5. Hook the windows event ( such as key, mouse,...)   BOOL CYouWnd::PreTra</p>

 title : The ebi-pride Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>The PRIDE PRoteomics IDEntifications database: A centralized, standards compliant, public data repository for proteomics data. </p>

<p>Index | How to Obtain, Build and Configure a Local PRIDE Web Application: Prerequisites -&gt; </p>

<p>IntroductionThe PRIDE PRoteomics IDEntifications database is a centralized, standards compliant, public data repository for proteomics data. It has been developed to provide the proteomics community with a public repository for protein and peptide identifications together with the evidence supporting these identifications. PRIDE has been developed through a collaboration of the EMBL-EBI and Ghent University in Belgium. The original motivation behind its development was to provide a common data exchange format and repository to support proteomics literature publications. This remit has grown with PRIDE, with the hope that PRIDE will provide a reference set of tissue-based identifications for use by the community. The future development of PRIDE has become closely linked to HUPO PSI. In addition to identifications, PRIDE is able to capture details of post-translational modifications coordinated relative to the peptides in which they have been found. LinksBuilding_A_PRIDE_Based_Application </p>

<p>Copyright 2007 EMBL-European Bioinformatics Institute Licensed under the Apache License, Version 2.0 (the &quot;License&quot;); you may not use this file except in compliance with the License. You may obtain a copy of the License at http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0 Unless required by applicable law or agreed to in writing, software distributed under the License is distributed on an &quot;AS IS&quot; BASIS, WITHOUT WARRANTIES OR CONDITIONS OF ANY KIND, either express or implied.  See the License for the specific language governing permissions and limitations under the License.</p>

 title : The ecataloger Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>The eCataloger application provides cataloging utilities to create an eLibrary for an individual or small organization. </p>

<p>An eLibrary is a collection of electronic records used to organize and manage born digital resources (websites, ebooks, mp3) and as a meta-data proxy for books, magazines, physical video and audio, and other physical objects. The 1.1 release of the eCataloger, currently in an development beta, uses the FRBR (Functional Requirements for Bibliographic Records) framework to model the records using data elements and concepts from the MODS (Metadata Object Description Schema), MARC, and other current and developing cataloging and metadata standards. By using FRBR as the descriptive framework, an overarching goal of the eCataloger is realized by being able to produce valid and well-formed MODS and MARC xml documents for interchange with existing and legacy library electronic systems. Because of the richness of the underlying FRBR data model, the eCataloger can be valid component in a larger semantic web ecology.</p>

 title : The echo-nest-remix Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>The Echo Nest Remix API is the Internet Synthesizer that lets you make things with music and video. </p>

<p>We&#39;ve done the following: rearranged the syllables of a vocal line, walkenized and cowbellized hundreds of thousands of songs in a week, mixed up the hits of a drum beat and synced it to another loop, beat matched two songs, split apart DJ mixes by their individual tracks, made new kinds of video mashups, corrected sloppy drumming,  synced a video to a song, transitioned between two covers of the same song, made a cat play piano, put a donk on it. </p>

<p>We&#39;re making this available as an open source SDK for Python (other languages forthcoming!) that can be easily installed for Mac OS X, Windows and Linux. It accesses the Echo Nest Analyze API at http://developer.echonest.com via the pyechonest wrapper and plays with the results to make new concoctions of audio and video. You&#39;ll need an Echo Nest API key to use this SDK, instructions are found on the following install pages. </p>

<p>What to doStep 1: Download the native installer for your platform</p>

<p>  </p>

<p>  </p>

<p>    OS X 10.5 or  OS X 10.6</p>

<p>  Windows</p>

<p>(Please first read WindowsInstallNotes.)</p>

<p>  Linux / Source</p>

<p>   </p>

<p>Step 2: Set up your Echo Nest API KeyYou need an API key from The Developer Nest to use Remix. Get your key and set it up on your computer or in your code.  </p>

<p>Read this key install tutorial for Windows, Mac or Linux. </p>

<p>For the experts in the room, just set the environment variable you need.  </p>

<p>export ECHO_NEST_API_KEY=&quot;the key you got from the Echo Nest Developer Site&quot;Step 3: Make something beautifulPlay with the many community contributed examples that make awesome things with audio and video. The installers put them on your computer along with some sample audio.  </p>

<p>On Windows they are in your Python folder (probably C:\Python26\echo-nest-remix-examples\.) </p>

<p>On the Mac they are in /usr/local/share/echo-nest-remix-examples. </p>

<p>cd one
<br/>python one.py ../music/CryMeARiver.mp3 output.mp3output.mp3 will sound like Cry Me A River, but only the first beat of every measure. </p>

<p>You should now start writing your own remix programs! </p>

<p>Join the discussion list for questions and comments.  </p>

<p>Read Adam Lindsay&#39;s excellent tutorial. </p>

<p>Bookmark the API Documentation. </p>

<p>&quot;&quot;&quot;Reverse a song by playing its beats forward starting from the end of the song&quot;&quot;&quot;
<br/>import echonest.audio as audio</p>

<p># Easy wrapper around mp3 decoding and Echo Nest analysis
<br/>audio_file = audio.LocalAudioFile(&quot;NeverGonnaTellIt.mp3&quot;)</p>

<p># You can manipulate the beats in a song as a native python list
<br/>beats = audio_file.analysis.beats
<br/>beats.reverse()</p>

<p># And render the list as a new audio file!
<br/>audio.getpieces(audio_file, beats).encode(&quot;NeverGonnaTellItBackwardsByBeat.mp3&quot;)Which creates something like this: NeverGonnaTellItBackwardsByBeat.mp3 </p>

<p>Lots more examples at ExampleAudioAndVideo</p>

 title : The ecko Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>{{Infobox bot | screenshot = [[Image:EckoSplash.jpg|250px]] | name = Ecko | developer = {{deviant|AzimuthDragon}} | language = [Ruby] | development_state = 0.1 Alpha (Rewrite 1) | source_model = Open source | last_release_s = None | license = software] (General Public License|GPL]) }} </p>

<p>Ecko is a WIP bot written by {{deviant|AzimuthDragon}}. Ecko was written in Azimuth&#39;s spare time as a fun project to occupy him when bored, and to provide a challenge and the next step in working with the Ruby programming language. </p>

<p>Notice Due to the large volume of schoolwork I am attempting to balance with my full-time job, I cannot give anyone a specific date at which Ecko will be available to the private alpha testers. &#39;&#39;&#39;I am still looking for alpha testers, but please be patient if you do want to try Ecko, as it may be a while before there is a functional program to download and test.&#39;&#39;&#39; </p>

<p>DownloadsEcko is not currently publicly available, however, a private alpha will be available hopefully within the coming weeks. To join the alpha, please note {{deviant|AzimuthDragon}} via dAmn in #Botdom or the regular dA notes system and he will add you to the list. </p>

<p>TasksOverall Tasks Finish &amp; debug GUI  Write core functions (connection class, plugin system, etc.)  Connect to dAmn and work out further flaws in code. </p>

<p>Current Tasks Continue writing core classes in individual files. </p>

<p>To Do Write core classes.  Reenable logging to file.  Write a class to log any errors to file, or prevent Ecko from exiting on error, instead disconnecting from dAmn and printing the error to the chat feed.  Enable users to change colors.  Enable dAmnColors-type logging in the chat feed.  Debug connection class.  Enable connection to my server for Update class.  Enable autoscrolling in the main log window.  Enable tabs for channels.  Create plugin system, and write an API for the user to create plugins with.  Write a debugger to run plugins through a dry run, disconnected from dAmn if the user wishes to enable it. </p>

<p> Take over the world. &#39;&#39;In Progress&#39;&#39; </p>

<p>Features GUI  Main Window:  Chat window (Tab for each channel Ecko is connected to)  Control bot functions (Start, Stop, Restart)  Options Window:  Enable/Disable program colors  Enable/Disable Welcome message  Enable/Disable Plugins  Manage User Lists  Enable/Disable Automatic Login  Enable/Disable Automatic Reconnect  Enable/Disable Logs  Select Log Path  Exclude specific channels  Settings Window:  Change Username/Password  Change Trigger  Change Owner  Specify Default Chatroom </p>

<p>ChangelogMay 2nd, 2008 Added a basic Updater class. </p>

<p>May 1st, 2008 Separated core classes into individual files.  Rewrote classes to load core files. </p>

<p>April 29th, 2008 Altered code to compare symbols instead of strings.   Started commenting on the code to enable RDoc documentation for classes, methods, and other functions.  Began writing code in separate files, according to class types. </p>

<p>April 23rd, 2008 Reformatted system and configuration variable storage, isolated into two variables. </p>

<p>April 17th, 2008 Added a Comparison class and reformatted the Save Options function to be compatible with the comparison class and new options window interface. </p>

<p>April 15th, 2008 Logging Class:  Enabled logging to a file, and the ability to enable/disable chat logging </p>

<p>April 14th, 2008 Dynamic saving class:  Changed output format slightly. </p>

<p> Options Dialogue:  Rearranged and reformatted controls. Grouped together controls according to what they do, ex, GUI change, or a System change.  Switched from buttons to radio selection buttons, and added the ability to select where to save log files if logging is on. </p>

<p>Credits {{deviant|ManjyomeThunder}} - Thanks for the time and patience in helping me learn Ruby, and for [Sapphire], which I used to learn even more of Ruby. </p>

<p>Disclaimer I, {{deviant|AzimuthDragon}}, am not responsible for anything that using this bot may cause on your computer.   Ecko has been developed and tested under Microsoft Windows XP, Service Pack 2, and I cannot guarantee that this program will run correctly on other operating systems. This includes, but is not limited to:  Mac OS X  Linux  Microsoft Windows Vista  I am also NOT responsible for improper use of this bot. If you cannot use the bot or set it up yourself, then you shouldn&#39;t be messing with it. I suggest you learn how to use, operate, and maintain a bot before you try to use Ecko or any other bot available for dAmn or other networks. If you can&#39;t figure out how to install Ruby or download Ecko, that is your problem. I will assist you IF you have honestly tried setting up the bot and failed no matter what you do. Of course, if you get an error, please inform me immediately. </p>

 title : The ecouch Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>DescriptioneCouch is an Erlang application that provides access to CouchDb servers. </p>

<p>CharacteristicseCouch is an application that provides an API to a CouchDb server It uses the rfc4627 module from LShift eCouch design was inspired by the article Building a Non-blocking TCP server using OTP principles It assumes that inets application is running FeaturesFollows all the OTP design principles Can run stand-alone with its own supervision tree or be included inside an existing supervision tree Guarantees synchronism between calls and their responses DocumentationAPIDocumentation CopyrightCopyright © 2008 Vitor Rodrigues</p>
 title : The ecs235a-project Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>OverviewA project for ECS235a, a UC Davis graduate course in the Computer Science department.  Extends the work presented in Web-Based Inference Detection by addressing some of the weaknesses in that paper. </p>

<p>AbstractSensitive information is redacted from a document before the document is released to protect that information from being exposed. Existing research proposed a web-based inference detection system but suffered from three weaknesses:  </p>

<p>Leaking Information Performance Problems Limited Strategy for Redacting.   Our work shows that the weaknesses in the existing proposed system can be overcome without sacrificing the quality of the inference detection.  iDetect, our prototype inference detection system, leverages a large offline knowledge base for detection, a synonym system for recommending word replacements, and an entity extraction system for identifying entities to remove to defeat inferences. </p>

<p>TechnologiesiDetect uses a suite of Java and open source technologies to implement its functionality.  Brief descriptions of each technology and how they were utilized are provided below: </p>

<p>Technology  Utilization   Java API for XML Binding (JAXB).  JAXB provides object to xml mappings by compiling XSDs into objects and then marshalling/unmarshalling between XML and objects.  The Wikipedia data dumps are provided in XML format.  By using JAXB, we were able to convert the exported data into Java objects, which we then could manipulate and store in a database and/or search index.   Java Persistance API (JPA).  JPA provides a lightweight object relational mapping (ORM) scheme through the use of annotations.  Java objects are annotated with various descriptors that indicate how to map the fields into relational storage.  JPA also provides service classes to manage the persistence of objects, including handling transactional concerns.  Our data is mapped and retrieved from its object form into a database through JPA.   Spring is used as a lightweight inversion of control (IoC) container that does dependency injection, serving to wire together components in a declarative fashion.  Our subsystems and services are wired together using Spring, to facilitate loose coupling between the components.   Hibernate provides a robust ORM implementation and support for mapping objects into a search index.  Hibernate is our JPA provider, meaning that it implements the functionality to make JPA work in our system.  We also use the Hibernate Search offering to map the article full text into a search index.   Lucene is a Java-based full text search engine.  We used Lucene to be the full text search engine that we utilized to search for the “similar documents”.   LingPipe is a natural language processing toolkit that includes a named entity recognizer (NER) and a trained model, for that NER, built from news sources.  LingPipe is our named entity recognizer for Persons, Organizations, and Locations.   Java Server Faces (JSF) is a recent component based model for web design.  The entire web-based UI was developed using JSF components.   Jetty is a light-weight servlet container that makes it easy to start up a web application without requiring the user to install a servlet container like Tomcat.  We use Jetty to host the iDetect web application when it is running on a local host.</p>

Please contact ecug.core@gmail.com News2009-11-07: China Erlounge IV今年 Erlang 中国社区人气有了明显的提高，也陆陆续续有互联网公司使用 Erlang 到他们的产品中。也有很多人开始用 Erlang 风格的并发模型（Erlang Style Concurrency）在自己熟悉的语言（如 C/C++、Java 等）中做事情，一些语言更号称自己已经实现 Erlang Style Concurrency 模型。另外，也踊跃出一批基于 Erlang Style Concurrency 模型的新语言（比如Scala）。在我们看来，Erlang是否会最终非常成功，目前言之过早，但是 Erlang 风格的并发模型（Erlang Style Concurrency）的成功，却是已经不容置疑的事实。  </p>

<p>今年将于11月7~8日举行的 Erlang 开发者大会属于第四次 Erlang 开发者大会，简称 CN Erlounge IV。 </p>

<p>时间：2009-11-7 ~ 2009-11-8，为期2天 地点：杭州（详细地址待确定） 议题：研究、探讨、关注Erlang风格的并发模型（Erlang Style Concurrency）的技术及最新进展（不局限于Erlang语言） 面向人群：对Erlang风格的并发模型有一定了解并有兴趣应用于实际工程的人。 会议主持：ECUG 会务组 会议形式多数时间由交流会讲师针对某个 Topic 进行论述，其他人提问（Q&amp;A）方式交流。 留出一小段时间，安排沙龙式的对等交流机会。  会议规则会议的讲师报销来回路费和住宿（投稿并申请成为讲师）。点击这里可以查看已经确定的讲师名单。 任何人可报名免费参与听讲（注册并申请参加本会议）。  注：由于场地限制，我们可能没法接受所有的与会申请，请谅解。如果名额已满，我们会回信说明。 </p>

<p>2008-12-20: China Erlounge III时间：2008-12-20 ~ 2008-12-21，为期2天 地点：上海 人物：面向 Erlang 中国社区，但不排斥其他任何对 Erlang、分布式、多核等话题感兴趣的人。 议题： Erlang 语言相关技术、Erlang 应用、Erlang 与其他语言协作、分布式、多核等等。 会议主持：ECUG 会务组 会议形式多数时间由交流会讲师针对某个 Topic 进行论述，其他人提问（Q&amp;A）方式交流。 留出一小段时间，安排沙龙式的对等交流机会。  会议规则会议的讲师报销来回路费和住宿（投稿并申请成为讲师）。点击这里可以查看已经确定的讲师名单。 任何人可报名免费参与听讲（注册并申请参加本会议）。  注：由于场地限制，我们可能没法接受所有的与会申请，请谅解。如果名额已满，我们会回信说明。 </p>

 title : The eee-ubuntu-support Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>This project is not maintained anymore (I sold my eeepc). Please drop me a message (benoit.favre@gmail.com) if you want to be a maintainer.   </p>

<p>EEE-PC Support in Ubuntu/Gutsy:small fonts, no compiz, fullscreen apps... wifi (based on madwifi) hotkeys overclocking to 900Mhz (using the eee module) webcam suspend-to-ram (WARNING: some users reported that the eee may wake-up if you unplug the power cord while suspended, and even wake up for no reason, and then it may cause heat damage: you should shutdown instead of suspending for long periods) sound other fixes new in v0.7the mute key is fixed closing the lid now suspends your eee. suspend/sleep timeout (see preferences/power management) brightness hotkeys now works as expected. no more screen dimming or weird brightness setup. video driver to get skype to show the video of both conversation participants (from xandros) new in v0.6compiz still activated, but allow windows to cross the top of the screen delete old madwifi drivers to ensure they do not show up OSD fixes add software sources new in v0.5OSD for wifi and overclocking nearly working OSD for brightness disabled overclocking on startup -&gt; press Fn-F6 to reenable new in v0.4shifted key codes by 128 in asus_acpi module to prevent hotkey conflict updated acpi/hotkey scripts to reflect the key code shift Fn+F6 now toggle overclocking (no feedback yet. if /proc/eee/fsb exist, then you are overclocked)</p>
 title : The eeedora Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>OverviewThe Asus Eee 701 PC comes with a nice-and-easy UI, on top of a Xandros (debian-based) core.  </p>

<p>However, for &#39;power users&#39; familiar with RedHat distributions, it&#39;s far more comfortable to use a version of Fedora, customized for the Eee machine. </p>

<p>This project includes the files necessary to build a custom spin of Fedora (using their excellent tools), put it onto a CD (or USB key) as a Live version to test it out, and then install it as a replacement for the Asus default. </p>

<p>GoalsThis project&#39;s goal is to have a Live (and installable) distribution that : </p>

<p>Is Fedora (currently Fedora 8) Runs XFCE as a windowing environment Takes as little space on the Eee&#39;s Flash drive as possible Gives the user the option of installing bigger packages (like openoffice, media players, etc) Understands each piece of hardware on the Eee (wireless, webcam, speakers, etc) ... and generally gives everyone a sense of satisfaction. </p>

<p>DocumentationThere are a few more Wiki pages over at http://wiki.eeeuser.com/howto:eeedora , and there&#39;s a downloadable ISO available at http://eeedora.complexvalues.com/ . </p>

<p>The current State of Play The Basic Approach taken with getting this spin working Notes on getting the wired internet to work Notes on creating a Live USB install AdvertWith this EeeDora loaded, the Asus Eee makes a perfect carry-around for techies everywhere. </p>

<p>If you&#39;d like to join in development (with SVN commit rights, for instance), please contact : EeeDora (at) PLATFORMedia.com</p>

 title : The Egg Clock Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>Egg Clock is a simple timer for Symbian Series60 3rd/5th edition devices. The timer value can be up to 100 minutes. </p>

<p>When the timer countdown reaches zero, the audio file selected by the user is played and the screen starts flashing, showing the indication of the extra time. </p>

<p>All the actions can be executed from the menu of the application, but here&#39;s a short list of shortcuts: </p>

<p>Press central key to start or stop the timer.
<br/>Press &quot;c&quot; key to reset the timer press Up/down/left/right to increase or decrease the volume of the notification. </p>

<p>On touchscreen devices (5th edition phones such as Nokia 5800XM): </p>

<p>Tap the screen once quickly to start or stop the timer tap and hold the screen for about 1 second to reset the timer. Use volume keys to adjust the volume.</p>

 title : The ehci Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>ehci can also be used as an open source head tracking library </p>

<p>    </p>

<p> </p>

<p>Potential ApplicationsIdeAs - Please Contribute </p>

<p>News12/18/09 - We are on Linux Magazine </p>

<p>Alessandro Faria has published a cool article about EHCI on December issue of Linux Magazine. Check it here! </p>

<p>03/28/09 - Planning </p>

<p>Reading the survey from Erik Murphy-Chutorian http://cvrr.ucsd.edu/publications/2008/MurphyChutorian_Trivedi_PAMI08.pdf and planning new directions for EHCI. </p>

<p>02/28/09 - New release EHCI 0.6 New features </p>

<p>RANSAC - RANdom SAmple Consensus algorithm filters outliers yielding more stable results. Configure file - the config.ini file makes room for selecting the camera as well as using input from files Better model positioning </p>

<p>02/12/08 - Some research </p>

<p>After reading lots of papers, here is the conclusion for NextSteps </p>

<p>02/11/08 - Next steps </p>

<p>Refactor code Use RANSAC for good in keyframes </p>

<p>12/26/08 - Some milestones reached! </p>

<p>RANSAC is now done, thanks to God (check not calibrated video here), but still needs to: </p>

<p>Adjust sinusoidal model to glue to face in the reference point Delete RANSAC outliers Adjust RANSAC paramters Use a config file (for the camera and other parameters) Decouple the head model used (make room to use other models) Optimize some code Use headmodel instead of sinusoidal Use keyframes to zero error accumulation Capture features Create a blender plug-in X-Server integration (XGl) Integrate with compiled OpenCV 1.1 version Test vinjn.z binaries and check windows binaries Work with videos for functional testing </p>

<p>09/20/08 - PyCon Brasil 2008 </p>

<p>Queria deixar o meu grande agradecimento a todos da PyCon Brasil 2008, pelas excelentes palestras, pela organização e pelas grandes pessoas que pude conhecer lá. Meus sinceros agradecimentos a vocês!  Slides da PyCon 2008 </p>

<p>09/17/08 - New Release: </p>

<p>EHCI 0.5 with Python bindings has been released. Check out Panda3D integration sample. </p>

<p>09/13/08 - Next milestones: </p>

<p>Python bindings RANSAC algorithm </p>

<p>DocumentationInstallationInstallingOnLinux </p>

<p>CompilingOnWindows </p>

<p>ConfigIni </p>

<p>DiagramsActivityDiagram </p>

<p>Project research and reportsPython Interface </p>

<p>6 Degrees Of Freedom HeadTracking </p>

<p>HeadTracking </p>

<p>HandTracking </p>

<p>ChromaKeying </p>

<p>TutorialsGetting head position, width, and height </p>

<p>Obtaining head X, Y, and Z coordinates </p>

<p>Python interface tutorial </p>

<p>Project descriptionThis application is a webcam image processing library on top of OpenCV intended to generate events from user&#39;s head, hand and body movements. This library is also intended to track objects so that augmented reality can be made. In order to enhance human computer interaction, the application is going to use a single webcam, without the needs to use FTIR or Diffused Illumination techniques. Besides tracking positions, this library will also be able to provide higher level events and gestures like get 3d user position, and open hand gestures. Collision with virtual objects is also considered in augmented reality. </p>

<p>Features:2d/3d head tracking, hand/finger tracking, body tracking, gesture recognition, fiducial marks, motion velocity, augmented reality object tracking. </p>

<p>Aligned with Natural User Interface idea of benefiting artistic and educational applications, this library&#39;s use could range from helping people severely paralyzed or afflicted with diseases such as ALS (Lou Gehrig’s disease) to revolutionary user interface paradigms. 3d head-tracking can create an environment so that Internet browser contents could be zoomed in and out as well as visualize 3d models from user perspective of view. Hand and finger tracking can be used in eye-toy like games as well as scrolling book pages or photos from distance, as when showing photos to friends or in Slideshow  presentations. Similar functionalities like Touchlib&#39;s could also be used. Augmented reality can bring a brand new revolutionary paradigm of user interface through an unexplored mix of virtual and real objects for never seen interaction mechanisms. Library demo applications like these should be included. An interesting trait of this library is that users won&#39;t need to wear any equipment! </p>

<p>Brief list of deliverables:1st Month: </p>

<p>Hand tracking and hand gesture recognition classes. Zoom and rotation features. Documentation of classes through tutorials, code documentation and demos. </p>

<p>2nd Month: </p>

<p>Head and body tracking facade classes. 3D head tracking class. Documentation and small OpenGL demos. </p>

<p>3rd Month: </p>

<p>Motion flow and 3d model wireframe tracking classes. Documentation. Project packaging through Google Summer of Code and Natural User Interface sites. </p>

<p>Pdf describing the application: http://gpuwire.googlecode.com/files/SoCProposal.pdf </p>

<p>ReportsFirstMonth </p>

<p>Final Report</p>

 title : The eipp Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>eipp is a C++ library that offers a simple and safe interface to Erlang External Term format.  Example: </p>

<p>using namespace eipp;
<br/>using namespace std;</p>

<p>int main()
<br/>{
<br/>	while(1)
<br/>	{
<br/>		atom_t cmd; // atom type... think std::string
<br/>		et data;    // generic &quot;erlang term&quot; type</p>

<p>		// expect tuple of the form {CmdAtom, Data}
<br/>		untuple(cmd,data)=binary_to_term(receive4(cin));
<br/>		
<br/>		// Only one command supported for now...
<br/>		if(cmd==&quot;times2&quot;)
<br/>		{
<br/>			int num=data; // &quot;et&quot; can cast itself to many types
<br/>			num*=2;
<br/>			send4(cout,term_to_binary(tuple(&quot;ok&quot;,num)));
<br/>		}
<br/>	}
<br/>}The library only supports ETF encoding/decoding and port compatible packet encoding, but this will grow in the future.</p>
 summary : <p>something or other.</p>
 title : The ekanem Open Source Project on Open Hub
 title : The ektos Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>projeto ruby</p>
 title : The elbautizadordetelefonos Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>El Bautizador de Teléfonos </p>

<p>Herramienta de utilidad para generar combinaciones que te ayuden a memorizar números de teléfono. </p>

<p>http://elbautizadordetelefonos.com/ </p>

<p>Autor </p>

<p>http://fernandoguillen.info  Links del proyecto </p>

<p>http://elbautizadordetelefonos.com/ http://open.movilforum.com/node/374 http://open.movilforum.com/node/375  Intenciones </p>

<p>El Bautizador de Teléfonos intenta ser una herramienta sencilla pero útil. editar Instrucciones </p>

<p>Inserta tu teléfono o el de un amigo, selecciona un diccionario y te mostraremos una selección de maneras de teclear ese mismo teléfono pero acordándote de letras y palabras en vez de números. </p>

<p>El teclado de cualquier teléfono comparte las teclas tanto para escribir números como para escribir letras. Cuando estamos escribiendo un número para marcarlo el teléfono sabe que lo que tiene que coger es el número de la tecla y no la letra. Pero eso no quita que en lo que tú te fijes sea la letra. </p>

<p>Por ejemplo: intentemos pulsar las teclas del teléfono para escribir &#39;abaco&#39; (atención: una pulsación por tecla, no varias como en los SMS). Si escribimos &#39;abaco&#39; vemos que el teléfono nos marca el: &#39;22226&#39;. </p>

<p>Y si intentamos escribir &#39;cachorros&#39; nos marca el &#39;222467767&#39;. </p>

<p>Esta aplicación hace la operación inversa. Dale un teléfono y veremos que cosas raras podemos escribir con esa combinación.  </p>

<p>El Bautizo </p>

<p>Al proceso de convertir el número de teléfono en una secuencia de caracteres y números lo llamamos &#39;El Bautizo&#39;. </p>

<p>Disclaimer </p>

<p>No hay que esperar que dé la casualidad de que tu teléfono tenga una combinación de letras chula rollo &#39;elreyguay&#39;, es bastante difícil, lo más normal es que aparezcan propuestas como &#39;aba5tio45&#39;. </p>

<p>APIs de Movistar </p>

<p>Si estás dado de alta en el servicio copiagenda (copiagenda) de Movistar España podrás descargar todos tus contactos y elegir uno de los teléfonos a bautizar. </p>

<p>Si estás dado de alta en el servicio interface HTTP de envío de SMS (Interfaz HTTP de envío de SMS) de Movistar España podrás enviar el número de teléfono bautizado a tu contacto vía SMS. </p>

<p>Código </p>

<p>http://code.google.com/p/elbautizadordetelefonos/  Ejemplos </p>

<p> 666567890 </p>

<p> mmolor8y0 2. nonkm7890 
<br/>3. 6molopu90

<br/>5. 6mojo7890 
<br/>6. non5678y0 
<br/>7. 6molopu90 
<br/>8. 6mol67u90 
<br/>9. 66ojopu90

<p>Mejoraremos el algoritmo para generar mejores resultados: más recordables. </p>

<p>Introducir más diccionarios.</p>

 title : The embeddedjavascript Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>EJS cleans the HTML out of your JavaScript with client side templates. After EJS gets its rubber gloves on dirty code, you&#39;ll feel organized and uncluttered. </p>

<p>Home   Getting Started Guide  NBA Demo   How-to Screencast   </p>

<p>DescriptionEJS is essentially a port of Masatoshi Seki&#39;s erb.rb in the Ruby Core. It operates in the same way that PHP, ERB, or any of the other embedded language interpreters work, except where all existing preprocessing engines execute on the server-side, EJS is intended to run within the web browser. This allows client-side code to process JavaScript-based web templates for insertion into the current page without consulting the server. </p>

<p>EJS uses  or % as its magic tags.  Like most other frameworks of its type,  tags cause all code within them to be executed, and the addition of an equals sign () causes the enclosed code to be evaluated and the toString representation of the result appended to the document. </p>

<p>Typical UseEJS templates can be loaded within a page or a separate file.  Once the EJS template is loaded, it is passed data used to render template.  The result of the render is typically used to update HTML on the page. </p>

<p>ExampleWith this example, we will create and load a template that displays a list of cleaning supplies. </p>

<p>First, lets create a template file that iterates through a list of supplies: </p>

<p>Supplies</p>

<p>Next, we create an object to hold those supplies: </p>

<p>var my_supplies = {supplies: [&#39;mop&#39;, &#39;broom&#39;, &#39;duster&#39;]}Finally, we load the template, render it with the supply object, and update an HTML element with the results. </p>

<p>var result = new EJS({url: &#39;templates/supplies.ejs&#39;}).render(my_supplies);
<br/>document.getElementById(&#39;supply_list&#39;).innerHTML = resultView HelpersEJS includes view helpers to make building repetitive HTML snippets easier.  The view helpers are very similar to Ruby on Rails ActionView helpers. </p>

<p>ExampleThe following builds a form that adds cleaning supplies. </p>

<p>	
<br/>	
<br/>Error HandlingUsing a special version of JSLint, EJS can provide nice error handling when you are developing your templates. By including ejs_fulljslint similar to  </p>

<p>EJS will error with a line number if there is a syntax error.</p>

 title : The ememoa Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>Memory pool allocator that help to improve memory allocation speed and memory usage by improving memory locality during data manipulation. To do so it require a little bit more help from the developper to tell him what kind of usage pattern the allocator must expect.</p>

<p>It also include a static buffer allocator, thus avoiding any further syscall, but in that case the maximum available memory will only be 64MBytes.</p>

<p>To help the developper in optimizing and providing this information, it provide some pretty good statistic so that developers can learn a bit more how the application consume and use in real world the allocated data.</p>

<p>It also include, in debug mode, a lot of assertion and memory verification which stop as soon as detected the program. This will also help the developper by reducing the time between a memory corruption and it&#39;s detection.</p>

<p>The current SVN version is considered stable and optimized. The TODO is almost complete, but if you want another feature don&#39;t hesitate to ask it !</p>

 title : The enchanter Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>Enchanter is a small library that helps you script SSH sessions in a manner similar to Expect.  It comes in multiple flavors that support different scripting languages including Python, Ruby and BeanShell.  This tool requires Java 5 or greater. </p>

<p>Here is an example script, &#39;date.py&#39;, that connects to a remote SSH server and gets the output of the &#39;date&#39; command: </p>

<p>ssh.connect(&#39;myserver&#39;, &#39;myusername&#39;);
<br/>ssh.waitFor(&#39;:~&gt;&#39;);
<br/>ssh.sendLine(&#39;date&#39;);
<br/>print &#39;Server date is &#39;+ssh.getLine();
<br/>ssh.disconnect();To execute this script with the script and enchanter jar in the current directory, run </p>

<p>java -jar enchanter-python-VERSION.jar date.pyFeaturesDifferent builds to support Python, Ruby, and BeanShell scripts &#39;Learning Mode&#39; to automatically build scripts based on observing an interactive SSH session Supports public key (RSA and DSA), password, and password-interactive authentication API similar to the ZOC telnet/SSH client Latest release: 0.5.1Fixed missing RSA or DSA key not failing over properly to password-based authentication methods DocumentationCommon commands for the &#39;ssh&#39; variable include: </p>

<p>connect(server, username)Connects to the remote server disconnect()Disconnects from the remote server waitFor(prompt)Waits for the text and returns true if found waitForMux(promptList)Waits for multiple prompts and returns the index of the first match sleep(millis)Sleeps for the given number of milliseconds setTimeout(millis)Sets the timeout for all commands that wait for prompts send(text)Sends the text to the server sendLine(text)Sends the text to the server with the end of line markers </p>

<p>For a full list of commands, see the SSH interface </p>

<p>ExamplesEach scripting language build has its own examples: </p>

<p>Python Ruby BeanShell </p>

<p>Comments or suggestions?  Any feedback is appreciated.</p>

 title : The entitydescriber Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>The Entity Describer (E.D.) is a mechanism for intersecting the Semantic Web with the normal Web. It lets users tag resources on the Web with terms from structured knowledge representation and organization systems. In the first version, E.D. drew its semantic tags directly from the ontologies of the semantic web. In the present version, these special tags are gathered from the millions of topics in the Freebase database. In addition E.D. has been extended so that it is possible to use databases other than Freebase.  Currently E.D. may be used with Connotea.  This means the tags are stored in the Connotea bookmark management site in addition to being stored into ED&#39;s database. </p>

<p>What is Freebase?Freebase is a highly structured collaborative online database.  It contains data harvested from different sources (Wikipedia, MusicBrainz) and data that has been added by individuals.  You can add your own data to Freebase!   </p>

<p>   </p>

<p>In addition, The Entity Describer can also be used with other databases that conform to the API.  Download it and customize it </p>

<p>Please see this google doc for the API specifications: DataSource API  </p>

<p>What is Connotea?Connotea is a free online reference management system.  It is a social bookmarking tool similar to CiteULike and del.icio.us where users can save links to their favourite sites. </p>

<p>   </p>

<p>DownloadDownload the latest release: </p>

<p>entitydescriber.tar.gz </p>

<p>See alsoRequirements </p>

<p>Installation </p>

<p>Documentation</p>
 summary : <p>This is a little blog System on Google app Engine. base on Python., </p>
 title : The entprj Open Source Project on Open Hub
 title : The entropic Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>Entropic(ĕn-trō&#39;pĭk) - A timekeeping application that utilizes the concept of quick entries or &quot;traces&quot; of time will help keep things simple and make the downtime between &quot;switching gears&quot; less of a drag.  </p>

<p>The ideaThe idea began when I realized how much time was spent recording where I spent my time; project-wise, work-wise.  I started out with a piece of paper in a simple notepad and just kept logging things like, &quot;Work Order: 12431; 15 minutes; Updated documentation.&quot; </p>

<p>It took a larger effort at the end of the week to help aggregate those &quot;traces&quot; of time into a bigger note, to be placed into the corporate work-order / trouble-ticket database.   </p>

<p>Granted, I am a big subscriber to the &quot;Getting Things Done&quot; way of work-life, and I do recommend the other GTD products out there as well. (43, etc.)  What I needed was a way to just &quot;diary&quot; my time and where it was spent.  Sort of from &quot;the other direction.&quot; </p>

<p>Also, I figured if I could log my time in a quick manner, it would help to deter me from surfing around the web in that &quot;I just changed gears from project A to project B and need to focus&quot; mood.   </p>

<p>There are a few reports, some snazzy flash, thanks to pullmonkey.com&#39;s introduction to Open Flash Charts. </p>

<p>The statusPlease visit our discussion group located here: entropic-discuss </p>

<p>14JAN2009 The project is in a pretty stable state - I&#39;m using it on a daily basis at work, and the reports are what I need, in terms up reporting.  Time needs to be spent tweaking a few little visual bugs or quirks here and there, as well as writing complete tests. </p>

<p>Screenshot</p>
 title : The entuittss Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>A web based application written in Ruby on Rails to manage the technical services requirements of IT providers to the SMB market.</p>
 title : The enumgen Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>NOTE: This project is new.  The code generator is fully functional and feature rich, now fully unit tested.  The implementation of the generated interface is now complete as well.  Feel free to take a look by downloading the code from subversion (click the Source link) if you&#39;d like and giving it a try.  Feedback welcome. </p>

<p>It&#39;s easier to show examples than to write documentation (but it&#39;s coming).  Here&#39;s an example where Fruit.enum is the input, and Fruit.hpp, Fruit.ipp, and Fruit.cpp are generated as a result. http://code.google.com/p/enumgen/source/browse/#svn/trunk/demo </p>

<p>If you&#39;re a C++ programmer, I hope you find this useful, and recognize the amount of effort put into generating clean and efficient C++ code.   </p>

<p>Why enumgen? </p>

<p>C++ classes have desirable properties that regular enum types do not yet(*) have.  Some of the benefits class hold over raw enums are are: </p>

<p>classes are forward-declarable, enums are not. (yet) classes can prevent implicit conversions to ints classes can have member functions and are generally extensible, enums are not. Therefore I created a code-gen tool which reads a simple input file and generates a complete C++ class (header/implementation files) for you to include in your projects and use directly instead of regular enums. </p>

<p>Additional benefits: </p>

<p>user provided code can extend the generated class interface a fairly extensive introspection interface for the generated code to query the enumerator names, values, and aliases ability to create enum objects out of strings that spell their name or one of their aliases ability to ask an enum object for a string representation of its enum value The code generator itself is written in Common Lisp.  Currently I&#39;ve tested with CLISP, SBCL, and ECL, but it should be simple enough to get working elsewhere.  You&#39;ll need to install a CL implementation to generate C++ code, however, once you generate your C++ source files, they can be compiled into your C++ project without the need for a lisp environment whatsoever.  There is absolutely no dependency on lisp except to run the code generator itself.   </p>

<p>(*) I&#39;m aware of the future C++0x standard and new strongly-typed, forward-declarable enums.  However that will only help improve this generated code, and does not obviate it.  One reason is the ability to have MEMBER FUNCTIONS of an enum is still not on the table.  I plan to make heavy use of these new enum functions as the new standard implementations become available and widespread.</p>
 title : The enviao Open Source Project on Open Hub

 title : The epbp Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>EPBP </p>

<p>See the EPBP official website for more information: http://epbp.earlz.biz.tm  </p>

<p>EPBP is a portable bytecode project. It is designed to resemble an actual machine from the bytecode/assembler point of view. It is designed in this way so that real programming languages can be ported to compile to this bytecode format. </p>

<p>Emulated Machine Info: </p>

<p>The strangest feature of the emulated machine is that there are no true registers. There is a registers mechanism however. This is implemented by register banks. Register banks make it so an area of memory can be mapped so that this area of memory can be addressed by using only 1 byte. </p>

<p>For getting &quot;outside&quot; the emulation, there is a method of external callings of system functions. This is called &quot;xcall&quot;. This must be used for things such as printing to screen, or drawing graphics, or other external functions. </p>

<p>This Implementation: </p>

<p>EPBP is encouraged to be implemented by people other than me. I only wish to make a decent, but basic implementation demonstrating all of the opcodes and how xcall-able libraries can work.  </p>

<p>This Is The Concept Version: </p>

<p>This is only the concept version. This is done to prove the concept and to make it easy for current developers to develop on the EPBP platform. This version is 32bit and the FPU functions are elementary at best. The expected eventual version will be 64bit and the FPU functions will be very elegant including all the functions expected of an FPU. </p>

<p>Interested? </p>

<p>At this point, the code is no where near a working demo. If you find this project interesting though, please feel free to contact me at &quot;earlz?at?earlz.biz.tm&quot; by email for any questions. I am looking for some help with this project. You don&#39;t just have to add code, I am looking for someone just to bounce ideas off of that has some experience with bytecode. Of course, I am always looking for programmers, documenters, and testers to help me with the project.</p>

 title : The epub-tools Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>About epub-toolsepub-tools is a collection of open source (BSD) tools for generating and managing ePub documents, including conversions from: </p>

<p>Word RTF DocBook TEI FictionBook Developers are encouraged to try out the tools and implement them in their own projects.   Interested parties should contact liza@threepress.org. </p>

<p>epub-tools is part of the threepress project. </p>

<p>Last updated: April 28, 2009 </p>

<p>What is ePub?ePub is the name for the e-book standard documented by the International Digital Publishing Forum (IDPF).  It is a packaged set of XML documents, metadata and other media that make up a digital book. </p>

<p>Sub-projectsdocbook2epubdocbook2epub is a Python/XSLT application to convert a DocBook XML document to ePub.   </p>

<p>The current version is 1.0.1 </p>

<p>RequirementsPython 2.4 or greater The lxml Python library The DocBook XSLT (version including the epub module, &gt;= 1.74.2) setuptools DownloadPackaged zip versions are always available from the downloads page.  </p>

<p>You may also check out the latest version from source code via subversion. </p>

<p>EPUBGenContributed by Adobe </p>

<p>EPUBGen (rtf2epub, word2epub, fb2epub) </p>

<p>rtf2epub, word2epub and fb2epub are Java applications to convert their respective file types to ePub. </p>

<p>The current version is 0.1.0 </p>

<p>Requirements </p>

<p>JDK 1.5 or greater (fb2epub additional requirements) Apache Commons FileUpload Apache Commons IO log4j tei2epubtei2epub is a Python/XSLT application to convert a TEI XML document to ePub.   </p>

<p>The current version is 1.0b2 </p>

<p>As of version 1.0b, epubcheck is no longer included. </p>

<p>RequirementsPython 2.4 or greater The lxml Python library DownloadPackaged zip versions are always available from the downloads page.  </p>

<p>You may also check out the latest version from source code via subversion. </p>

<p>LimitationsImages, CSS and other media may work, but this has not been tested. Very large TEI documents may convert slowly. This issue is known but has not been completely addressed.</p>

 summary : <p>About EpyEpy was created to make client-end web scripting possible with Python. <p>Familiar reusable Pythonic design Easy class construction Easy iterables (including custom iterables) Namespaces! Best of all, less Javascript!  We will also be wrapping a number of quality Javascript libraries in an &quot;Epy-friendly&quot; way, as well as porting existing Python modules for use by Javascript (making the Javascript world better one module at a time).</p>

 title : The eregansu Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>Eregansu is an object-oriented web application framework. </p>

<p>Eregansu is split into four parts: </p>

<p>Pathfinder: a system for automatically loading scripts and instantiating objects (implemented both in PHP, and also a native PHP extension) Foundation: A high-level Model-View-Controller framework. Macaque: An ECMAscript-based language which includes the facilities of Pathfinder, Core and Foundation. Macaque is powered by the Mozilla SpiderMonkey engine. Application Server: A multithreaded modular application server which supports request pipelining.</p>
 title : The ergate Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>随着信息化进程的不断深入，各种信息管理系统在各个行业中发挥着重要作用。信息管理系统运作过程中，一个很重要的步骤就是信息的数字化。当前常用的做法是系统提供一个表单界面，由操作人员手工填写各个输入项，然后提交给系统存储到数据库中。 
<br/>这种模式简单可行，易于实现，却存在着不少的问题。对系统操作人员而言，当录入信息，十分繁琐，工作量大，效率低下，而且正确率难以保证。其次，录入的信息只能应用在系统内部，系统间却没有相应的共享机制。如果不同的系统录入的信息相似度很高，则会导致信息的重复录入，对人力物力造成极大的浪费。一个典型的例子是图书管理系统，不同的机构（出版社，图书馆，书店，网上书店，书评应用服务等）录入的书刊信息基本上是一致的，录入工作却要分别进行，导致了大量的重复工作。 
<br/>如果信息系统能通过统一通用的接口获取到相应的信息，即可实现表单的自动录入，免除了系统操作人员手工录入的繁琐操作，提高信息录入的速度和准确率。基于网络数据采集的智能表单录入系统(Ergate)的提出，为信息系统的自动录入提供了可能性。Ergate使用多种途径从网络获取数据，利用网络搜索技术和数据库技术，形成一个稳定准确的数据源，并以标准通用的Web服务协议对外发布。需要信息录入、而且信息具有重复性的应用均可通过使用Ergate 系统实现信息的自动录入，从而增强用户的使用体验。 
<br/>当前有大量信息系统录入的信息存在重复性，如图书馆、书店的图书信息录、商场超市的产品信息以及电子商务中商品信息。通过Ergate系统，上述系统可以免除用户重复输入的繁琐操作，提高用户的使用体验，提高了录入信息的准确率。 
<br/>Ergate具有以下特色：
<br/>网络搜索技术和数据库技术相结合。网络搜索技术保证信息来源的广泛性和实时性，保证了信息数据的完备性和及时性（与最新信息保持同步），同时避免了一般系统数据收集所需的启动时间；数据库技术作为本地缓冲，存储用户搜索的历史信息，提高系统的响应速度，同时为系统数据的自我完善打下基础。 数据整理智能化。系统接收到搜索引擎返回的相关数据时，通过指定规则将其排序，向用户返回最优数据。如果其中的最优信息出现信息缺失，系统可以实现信息的自动重组，组合多条信息以满足用户需求。 数据采集采用以网络数据自动采集为主，信息权威机构（如出版社，产品生产厂商等）参与为辅的策略。引入信息权威机构的参与可以提高信息的有效性和准确性，增强用户体验。 系统引入用户反馈系统和信息评价系统，实现系统的自我完善。 通过Web服务标准协议发布，做到平台无关，语言无关，模型无关（C/S或者B/S），适用范围广，使用简单。 可以实现数据的单个录入和批量录入，以满足不同的需要。</p>

 title : The erl-flush Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>An implementation of Hartmann pipelines in Erlang. In short, they are extensions of the usual Unix pipes that allow building graphs of programs and thus one can implement a full data-flow environment. </p>

<p>Code example with current API, counting the number of lines in a file containing &quot;=&quot; and the number of lines that don&#39;t contain it: </p>

<p>    P1 = pipes:pipe(cat, [FileName]),
<br/>    P2 = pipes:pipe(lines),
<br/>    P4 = pipes:pipe(grep, [&quot;=&quot;]),
<br/>    P3 = pipes:pipe(count),
<br/>    P5 = pipes:pipe(count),
<br/>    
<br/>    pipes:connect([P1, P2, P4, P3]),
<br/>    pipes:connect({P4, nomatch}, P5),
<br/>    
<br/>    {WithEquals, WithoutEquals} = {pipes:get_result(P3), pipes:get_result(P5)}.This will look in the future similar to the Unix-ish </p>

<p>    {WithEquals, WithoutEquals} = pipes:build(
<br/>      &quot; cat $FileName | 
<br/>        lines | 
<br/>        g: grep \&quot;=\&quot; |
<br/>        count &gt; $1
<br/>      &quot;,
<br/>      &quot; :g/nomatch |
<br/>        count &gt; $2
<br/>      &quot;
<br/>    ).Read more in the Overview.</p>
 title : The erl-pipes Open Source Project on Open Hub
 title : The erlang-dhcp-server Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>The Dynamic Host Configuration Protocol (DHCP) provides a framework for passing configuration information to hosts on a TCP/IP network. DHCP is based on the Bootstrap Protocol (BOOTP), adding the capability of automatic allocation of reusable network addresses and additional configuration options.  DHCP captures the behavior of BOOTP relay agents, and DHCP participants can interoperate with BOOTP participants. This program is a high performance multithreaded DHCP server written entirely in Erlang. It strives to be fully functional, and RFC compliant. The main advantages of erlang-dhcp-server compared to other DHCP servers are performance and elegance. The performance comes from the underlying Erlang system and its ability to handle concurrent processes in an efficent way. Its elegance comes from Erlang as well. Network servers don&#39;t have to be written in ugly adhoc languages.</p>

 summary : <p>This MySQL driver for Erlang is based on the Yxa driver obtained from Process One (at https://support.process-one.net/doc/display/CONTRIBS/Yxa). It includes several new features such as prepared statements, transactions, binary queries, type-converted query results, more efficient logging and a new connection pooling mechanism.</p>

 title : The erlawys Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>This is an implementation of the Amazon Web Services (AWS) API. </p>

<p>There are four modules: aws_ec2_xml, aws_ec2,  aws_fps_xml and aws_fps. </p>

<p>aws_ec2/fps_xml implements a straightforward marshaling of erlang parameters into a URL formatted for AWS, which is then sent to Amazon. It returns the result in XML, Amazon&#39;s current preferred format. </p>

<p>aws_ec2/fps uses aws_ec2/fps_xml to get the XML, which it then attempts to marshall into erlang records.</p>

 title : The erlfs Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>THIS PROJECT IS PRE-ALPHAIt is not ready for testing yet.We just switched to github and we have decided to use a DHT instead of a meshWhat is ErlFS?ErlFS is a system to store files in a highly redundant and highly available way across multiple machines. ErlFS scales linearly. </p>

<p>How does ErlFS work?GeneralErlFS uses distributed Erlang and the chord DHT algorithm. The more nodes you add to the cluster, the more capacity, throughput and redundancy you get. ErlFS is a write-once read-many system. </p>

<p>StorageWhen a file is put into the system, it is split up into chunks and each of those chunks are redundantly copied to the next log(N) nodes&#39; file systems. The meta-data includes the keys to each of the chunks for each particular file, content-type and other common attributes. </p>

<p>RetrievalWhen a file is retrieved, the client retrieves the meta-data from any node, potentially behind a load-balancer, and uses the list of all the nodes for all of the chunks of a file to retrieve each chunk and joins all of them together to recompose the file, resulting in higher throughput under high load.</p>
 title : The erlguten Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>Erlguten is a system for high-quality typesetting. It is written purely in Erlang and implements microtypographic techniques ( such as margin kerning, optical alignment of margins, merning and tracking adjustments to text). It also contains a PDF rendering library as well as a Docbook Light library. Although it is still in development, it is in production use.</p>

 summary : <p>My erlang programs, </p>

 summary : <p>erlrc is designed to make it easy to integrate your OS package manager with erlang&#39;s hot code loading mechanism.  It consists of an extensible boot procedure controlled by a directory, and hooks for upgrading and downgrading individual applications (with shell script interface).  Also includes an automatic appup file generation scheme which incorporates most of the cases from the appup cookbook. </p>
