 title : The ftr-gwt-library Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>An Demo version can be seen here: http://www.future-earth.eu/gwt/calendar/MainDemoApp.html </p>

<p>12 December We are happy with gwt release 2.0.0 Upgraded libraries are uploaded also including all minor fixes. Reporters of issues are strongly encouraged to check their issues. And resolve them if fixed. </p>

<p>Sebtember 9, We released version 1.1.0 It includes mainly improvements and support for gwt 1.7. The next release we will try to include multi day support. more on this later. </p>

<p>June 2, We will be processing the issue list this week. I hope that everyone is having patiance with us. Since we are quite busy. If you have any issues but not reported them please post them this week. </p>

<p>April 17, The code on svn is upgraded to 1.6. We switch to the maven plugin from codehouse. This is version 1.0.0. It will be released when we feel it&#39;s working nicely with 1.6 and the listeners have been removed </p>

<p>March 18, </p>

<p>A bit later than promised but this due to the happy fact that my second daughter was borm a bit sooner. She decided not to wait and join the family. Version 0.9.9 is on the download page. Things done for this release: </p>

<p>Removed flextables where possible Improved performance when navigating weeks Cleaned up code. Please note that the of the extra libary this will be the latest version. We feel that is does not add enough value to maintain as a seperate library. We have bugin developing a gwt application frmaework and everything will be moved there. This project will be internal for the foreseable future. The Calander and File widget will be kept seperate and actively maintained. </p>

<p>March already, We will release 0.9.9 this weekend. The release has some mayor improvements in performance and uses no flextable anymore. Futher things that are solved were reported by some of our users. The ow custom moven plugin has been removed from the demo project and now uses the one that can be found on google code. Futher, the ant scripts have been improved. </p>

<p>January 2009. Happy new year everybody. We just release 0.9.8. It also has the Calander now as emul so you can use the java.util.Calander class. </p>

<p>9 November We released the 0.9.7 release and uploaded the libraries. </p>

<p>23 Oktober At the moment we are unable to upload files. We are looking into it and as soon as it works we will upload 0.9.6 which is ready. </p>

<p>14 Sebtember Some changes in the panels for the event panel. Now it&#39;s based on the Rounded corner panel. Looks nice. We also made a first change on how custom sub panel could be implemented. The setup is better and now uses a setbody for building the structure and a repaintPanel for reseting the shown data on the panel. </p>

<p>(It is a different setup so do not update the svn tree unless you want to upgrade your code, It&#39;s not backwar compatible. but will allow for better customisation and also coloring in the future. We are aiming at allowing the stye to be set by the sub panel.)  </p>

<p>9 Sebtember Ant files updated. Thanks to Kami. People wo are using the source code please be aware that the maven setup requires a internal plugin. So please use the ant file. We will try to resolve this issue in the Future. Futher any tips on what documentation is required or wanted most is greatly apprieciated. And controbutions and insights are welcome ofcours. </p>

<p>20 August. Release 0.9.5 with thanks to Loic. This will be the last release for gwt 1.4. From now on all mayor development wil be done with 1.5 in mind. This wil be welcomed by most and not by others.  </p>

<p>22 Juni. </p>

<p>It has been a wile but we released version 0.9.4 and also added some exiting new things. Most important are: </p>

<p>File upload wicket to upload files without needing to use post directly. It works like the google file upload in gmail. It&#39;s real handy. Works with Apache file upload. Date Edit field with date picker. Date picker provided. Next release it will support event indication. Showing by rendered component that an event is present on day. Month select panel that you can embed in application Whole day event are now supported. and manageble Cleaned up css to be more consistent and less to conflict with other libraries. Removing the need for The Interface. The suggestion of Papick was taken to heart and we saw that it would improve usability more than the seperate interface. People now can use any object that is Serializable to use in the Renderer. We upgraded to the new dnd library. It improves some things a lot and we feel the need to keep used technologies up to date as reasonable possible. Further we fixes some bugs. </p>

<p>People who are willing to test we really like your feedback. </p>

<p>18 January. </p>

<p>We are released 0.9.2. </p>

<p>This release holds some changes like seperating the EventData into a seperate library so that ejb back end can be deployed without the complete library included. Futher point will be: </p>

<p>Delete an Event is not allowed (Added an example in the default dialog to show how this should work) Icon used for event timeslot creation (We did some work on the look and feel and hope you will be pleased.) Compile pre built jars with earliest possible JDK ( Source and Target will be set to 1.4) Ant scripts and some basic documentation. Wiki page </p>

<p>All release notes can be found on the wiki pages. </p>

<p>RoadmapAfter that we are open for suggestions. We need to determine a roadmap for future release. So be free to suggest features in the news group. </p>

<p>We had some questions about a commercial version of the library. We have discussed about this but are against it. We are willing to supply support on an hourly basis or maybe under a support contract setup. We want to know what the general opinion is about this. Would such a possiblety make the library more easy to use within your company. </p>

<p>Let us know at info@future-earth.eu </p>

<p>ContentsThe Library contains at the moment: </p>

<p>Google look a like Week calender Google look a like Day calender Google look a like Month calender DateBox A Formatted text box which allows users to enter dates. TimeBox A Formatted Text Box which allows users to enter times. </p>

<p>More will follow with each release. </p>

<p>Please do file issues. We are aware of several issues that people want resolved. Please check the list before entering new issues. One of our testers is The developer of the rounded corners. See http://code.google.com/p/cobogw/ </p>

<p>The use of the library is fairly simple. checkout the source code to see how the library can be used.</p>

 title : The fujisawa-oss Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>Fujisawa-OSS CakePHPをベースにWebアプリ開発実験プロジェクト「fujisawa-oss」では、開発経験ゼロのメンバーで、皆で楽しみ学びながらオープンソースのwebアプリケーションを作成していきます。 </p>

<p>何を開発するかも、これから話し合って決めていきます。 </p>

<p>決まっているのは、PHPとMySQLを使うこと。 </p>

<p>そして、PHPフレームワークとしてCakePHPを使用することです。 </p>

<p>リンクfujisawa-oss ブログ fujisawa-oss グループ 勉強会資料20071012 第1回 OSSを使おう 20071024 第2回 開発環境構築(XAMPP Lite,サクラエディタ) 20071114 第3回 XHTMLとCSSによるWEBサイトの作成 20071114 第3回 (おまけ)サクラエディタでUTF-8保存・参考図書 20071128 第4回 PHP入門前 20071212 第5回 猿でも分かる（･･･はずの）MySQL 20080130 第6回 オブジェクト指向って 20080312 第7回 CakePHPのススメ 開発環境を統一化メンバーで、開発の道具を統一することで、使い方に困っても皆で教えあっていきたいと考えています。 </p>

<p>また、使用するソフトもできるだけシンプルなものを選択していきたいと思います。もちろんフリーソフトで。 </p>

<p>種類  ソフトウェア  備考   サーバーソフト  XAMPP Lite  Apache,PHP,MySQL  エディタ  サクラエディタ  PHPのスクリプトをハイライト表示。マクロによりPHPDoc作成可能  Subversion本体  Subversion  バージョン管理システム。コマンドライン。   Subversion用GUI  TortoiseSVN  上記をGUIで操作する。日本語化する  フレームワーク  cakePHP1.1   </p>

<p>開発スタート環境cakePHPを展開して、直下に空のossディレクトリを作成する。 subversionによりチェックアウトする ソースコードの記述ルール開発文字コードはUTF-8 phpDoc形式 タブは使用しない。半角スペース4文字で代替。</p>

 title : The funcall Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>functionsboolean fc_add_pre(string function,string callback)Add a callback which will be called before the function call.The callback accept one parameter,which is array contain the args passed to function.See examples below for detail. </p>

<p>boolean fc_add_post(string function,string callback)Add a callback which will be called after the function call.The callback accept three parameters.First one is array contain the args passed to function, the second param is the result of that function and the third one is the processing time in ms of that function.See examples below for detail. </p>

<p>array fc_list()Return all callbacks like:  
<br/>    array(
<br/>        0=&gt;array(
<br/>            &#39;mysql_query&#39;=&gt;array(
<br/>                &#39;pre_callback1&#39;,&#39;pre_callback2&#39;
<br/>            )
<br/>        ),
<br/>        1=&gt;array(
<br/>            &#39;mysql_query&#39;=&gt;array(
<br/>                &#39;post_callback1&#39;,&#39;post_callback2&#39;
<br/>            )
<br/>        )
<br/>    );Examples</p>
 title : The funcl Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>FunCL: The Functor Clause LanguageFunCL is the Functor Clause Language, an interpreted functional programming language originally inspired in part by John Backus&#39;s Turing Award Lecture &quot;Can Programming Be Liberated From the von Neumann Style?&quot; </p>

<p>FunCL uses functors which are like functions, only more generalized. Functor syntax is unique, reminiscent of Forth and LISP--but not either. Functors are made up of clauses, each clause is a series of functors which manipulate the stacks and environment of the FunCL virtual machine (FVM). The FunCL VM is implemented in Java, with the internal functors implemented as Java class methods.</p>

 title : The functor Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>This is a dynamic stack language written in Python. It has PostScript like syntax, and will implement most of the functionality of Scheme. </p>

<p>It&#39;s purpose is to be used as a scripting language for AI programs. </p>

<p>It should also make for some killer turtle graphics. :)</p>

 summary : <p>HomeFunnel is a toolkit for physical computing. Funnel supports Arduino I/O boards, Gainer I/O modules, XBee wireless modems and FIO boards.  title : The fusecompress Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>What is FuseCompress?FuseCompress provides a mountable Linux filesystem which transparently compresses its content. </p>

<p>Files stored in this filesystem are compressed on the fly and FUSE allows to create a transparent interface between compressed files and user applications. </p>

<p>FuseCompress supports different compression methods: LZO, gzip, bzip2, and LZMA. </p>

<p>Isn&#39;t there a new version?This is the legacy C implementation of FuseCompress (0.9.x tree). It performs slightly less well than the current one implemented in C++ (1.99.x tree), but does not exhibit flaws such as data corruption or files growing larger and larger that make the current code (as of July 17 2008) unusable in a production environment. You can find the new version at Milan Svoboda&#39;s website. Because Milan is concentrating on the new version, I am now maintaining the old tree. </p>

<p>How well does it work?It works well enough that I have trusted it to handle the vast majority of my private data. I am also using it for my $HOME directory, source trees, and I have (with some really evil hacks) succeeded in installing an openSUSE 11.0 system with FuseCompress as its root filesystem. (That, however, is not something you should currently try at home. At least not on a real system.) </p>

<p>LZMA support is experimental. Both the implementation in FuseCompress and the library used by it are not stable yet. Versions 4.999.3 and 4.999.5 of the LZMA library create mutually incompatible streams, for instance. </p>

<p>I am still occasionally fixing slight deviations from the expected behavior of a Unix filesystem. These problems are all minor, but may still cause data loss, depending on how robust your applications are. </p>

<p>FuseCompress now has experimental support for Mac OS X and MacFUSE. </p>

<p>Where to get itPackages for openSUSE Source code can be found in the SVN repository. More informationBuild HOWTO How to use FuseCompress What compression method should I use?</p>
 summary : <p>Fusemetrics takes the .xml output from PMD, CPD, JUnit, JDepend, FindBugs, Clover, Cobertura and several other metrics/analysis tools, and creates a unified dashboard view of the top level metrics.  In addition, it &quot;remembers&quot; how these values change over time and creates sparkline graphs to see the ongoing evolution of the overall project metrics.  Lastly, where available, it analyzes the metrics across the complete set of classes and packages, and creates various histograms describing the overall class/package population, in terms of size, complexity, coverage, etc.  </p>

<p>Fusemetrics is written in Groovy, and uses Nu.Xom and JFreeChart to assist in processing the xml and generating the charts.</p>

 title : The fuzzyclock Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>OverviewA blatant rip-off of the KDE source code with tips picked up from here. This code injects a DLL (FuzzyHook.dll) into the WndProc of TrayClockWClass to replace the standard numeric text with fuzzy text. The code also places a clock icon (taken from Crystal SVG; thanks Everaldo!) in the system tray. Right-click on the icon to exit the program. </p>

<p>RequirementsMicrosoft Visual C++ 2005 SP1 Redistributable Package (x86) (for 32-bit platforms) Microsoft Visual C++ 2008 SP1 Redistributable Package (x64) (for 64-bit platforms) If a configuration error dialog is displayed when launching FuzzyClock, install the corresponding redistributable package. </p>

<p>InstallationExtract FuzzyClock.zip to a folder of your choosing (i.e. x:\Program Files\FuzzyClock). The default language is English. Additional languages can be found within Localizations.zip.  Drag and drop a localization file onto the icon representing FuzzyClock.exe and that localization will be used.  The localization file is stored in %APPDATA%\FuzzyClock as FuzzyClock.xml. In Windows 2000, XP, and Server 2003, %APPDATA% is located at x:\Documents and Settings\\Application Data In Windows Vista, %APPDATA% is located at x:\Users\\AppData\Roaming To start FuzzyClock with Windows, create a shortcut for FuzzyClock.exe and place it in %STARTMENU%\Programs\Startup. In Windows 2000, XP, and Server 2003, %STARTMENU% is located at x:\Documents and Settings\\Start Menu In Windows Vista, %STARTMENU% is located at x:\Users\\AppData\Roaming\Microsoft\Windows\Start Menu UseRight-click (or double-click) on FuzzyClock tray icon to exit program. Click on FuzzyClock tray icon to toggle between fuzzy and precise times. CreditsAlmost the entirety of the translations is from KDE source code. A few words were grabbed from Microsoft Terminology Translations. </p>

<p>DetailsBuilt using Visual Studio 2005 SP1 (x86 build) and Visual Studio 2008 SP1 (x64 build).  Tested on Windows XP and Windows Server 2003.  According to Softpedia, this should work on Win2K and Vista, too.</p>

 title : The fxadata Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>FxADataThis project contains a set of Actionscript 3 classes that are built upon the flash.data classes. These classes allow developers to easily access and communicate with the SQLite databases using MXML and AS3. </p>

<p>This library is currently in Pre-Alpha and has not been released for the general public.There are two separate libraries (that may be merged together in a future release); FxAQuery and FxAProc. </p>

<p>FxAQuery allows the developer to access and execute queries against a SQLite database using  MXML and/or AS3. </p>

<p>FxAProc allows the developer to write and execute a set of dependent SQL statements (like a stored procedure). Although the procedure must be written using AS3 the developer can trigger the execution of the procedure using MXML and/or AS3.</p>

<p>fxSpy allow you to inspect and dynamically change most properties and styles of the visual components in your Flex application. You can - for example - try out a specific width or a background color for your component before changing it in your code. </p>

 summary : <p>FxStruts is a free open source library with the taglib part licensed under the Apache License 2.0 and the serialization part under the LGPL 3.0 that provides replacements  for Struts (version 1.x.x) JSP tags  and  that outputs AMF or XML from any Java object with ActionErrors and transaction token support. FxStruts is present both on the Flex and Java side. </p>

<p>Note: Struts 2 is an entirely different beast and currently not supported by FxStruts. </p>

<p>FxStruts Taglib is licensed under the Apache Software License, 2.0. The serialization bit is licensed under LGPL. Therefore they are distributed as two different JARs due to the licensing. </p>

<p>The HTTPAMFService component, FxStrutsMailReader and HelloWorld Flex application is licensed under the MPL 1.1. </p>

<p>For more details, see this blog post.</p>
 title : The fxstruts Open Source Project on Open Hub
 title : The fxt Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>FXT implements client side templating using Model-View-Controller. FXT provides a simple, productive, and compatibile way to deliver rich websites using Adobe Flex.</p>

<p>Model == XML embedded into HTML
<br/>View/Controller == Flex SWF File</p>

<p>Benefits:</p>

<p>&amp;nbsp;- Model Driven – The data (Model) is in HTML as XML. It is browser and search engine compatible.</p>

<p>&amp;nbsp;- Restful URLS – The urls are simple, bookmarkable, and back button supported.</p>

<p>&amp;nbsp;- Classic MVC - Model is XML embedded in HTML, View and Controller are Flex-generated SWFs.</p>

<p>&amp;nbsp;- E4X is used to render data within the template SWF file.</p>

<p>&amp;nbsp;- Model driven use of Flex &#39;states&#39; are supported.</p>

<p>&amp;nbsp;- Rapid– Just open a project, edit the XML model, and edit the Flex template to create an interactive site. Layout is component based and easy with E4X.</p>

<p>&amp;nbsp;- Fast – Once the SWF file is cached, each page load time is 100% data loading and Flex instantiation.</p>

<p>Regards,</p>

<p>Ted Patrick</p>

 title : The gaeunit Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>GAEUnit 2.0 alpha for Django is released, please download and follow the instruction.GAEUnit is a unit test framework that helps to automate testing of your Google App Engine application. With a single configuration change (it can be completed within 30 seconds), your unit tests can be run in the real GAE app server environment using a web browser. </p>

<p>GAEUnit is simple. It contains only one file: gaeunit.py. Just copy that file into your application directory and add the test URL to app.yaml. </p>

<p>Usage </p>

<p>1. Configure the environment: </p>

<p>Copy gaeunit.py to the project directory. Add the following 2 lines to app.yaml: </p>

<p>- url: /test.*
<br/>  script: gaeunit.py2. Write your test case scripts in Python modules, each containing unittest.TestCase subclasses, in the &#39;test&#39; directory and launch dev_appserver.py </p>

<p>3. Browse to the following URL (change the port if necessary): </p>

<p>http://localhost:8080/testYour test results will be displayed in the browser: </p>

<p> </p>

<p>If you wish to run a single module, execute it like this: </p>

<p>http://localhost:8080/test?name=my_test_moduleYou can also specify a single test class, like name=my_test_module.MyTestCase or even a single test method, like name=my_test_module.MyTestCase.test_stuff </p>

<p>See FeatureCandidates for a list of potential upcoming features. </p>

<p>Please let us know if you have interesting ideas or specific requirements for GAEUnit.  Use the comments on the FeatureCandidates page, or use the Issues tab above.</p>

It will create thumbnails for you if you choose so, scaled or unscaled, centered and cropped inside a fixed thumbnail box defined by CSS.  </p>

 title : The game-core Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>GCore (for Game-Core) is my personal lib shared between my game projects (currently made on spare time). This is a C++ lib that gather classes useful to build the core organization of a game.  </p>

<p>Currently it is only tested on Windows XP but I&#39;d like it to be cross-platform (for at least Windows/Linux/Unix/MacOS and maybe Haiku too). It should be thread-safe too as there is no static data nor any singleton class. The user can use the singleton class provided to specify witch class should be a singleton. </p>

<p>This lib is useful when you want to build a game from scratch with other libs (like Ogre + RakNet + OIS + OPCode etc) as it provide some useful (and optional) basic systems often required in a game (like a console system, a log system etc). </p>

<p>The only dependency is boost (http://www.boost.org/) 1.42 at least. </p>

<p>IMPORTANT : THIS CODE IS CURRENTLY IN EXPERIMENTAL STATE! Some part of the code are in heavy refactoring and comments might not always be in sync.   </p>

<p>More details comming soon (or in the wiki).</p>
 title : The game-rts-framework Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>RTS FRAMEWORKWe want to build a framework for realtime strategy games. </p>

<p>Screenshot from Demo_061022</p>
 summary : <p>C++ ( gcc-4.3 / Visual C++ 2008 ). Created with Bullet 2.74, OpenGL, Cg, SDL, CEGUI, etc. </p>

<p>Required :  CPU with SSE2 instructions support (Pentium4 or newer) </p>

<p>Common : </p>

<p> Press ESC to enter options menu (pause simulation, release mouse).  Click &quot;Back&quot; button to return to simulation. Bullet&#39;s Vehicle Simulation TestUsed Lamborghini Miura SV Model (Teemu Haapoja) </p>

<p>(OpenGL 1.4 or newer required) </p>

<p> </p>

<p>Binary : vehicle_rXXX.7z.exe (self-extracting archive, click at vehicle.exe). BTW, windows binary runs without any problems/tweaks in Wine emulator on Linux (Debian &quot;lenny&quot;) - change into vehicle_rXXX folder (important for CEGUI files) and run &quot;wine vehicle.exe&quot;. </p>

<p>Source : vehicle_src_rXXX.7z.exe (self-extracting archive, all dependencies for Visual C++ 2008 build are included. Solution files are in &quot;build/vs9&quot;. Binary will be in &quot;release&quot; folder. Important : set Visual C++ &quot;working directory&quot; (Configuration Properties/Debugging) to &quot;..\..\release&quot; to run directly from Visual C++, otherwise there will be exceptions while CEGUI files will be unavailable. Debug build currently doesn&#39;t include CEGUI. </p>

<p>To build on Linux look into Makefiles in &quot;build/linux&quot;. There are NO dependencies for Linux build included. Download and compile Bullet 2.74 and CEGUI 0.6.2 and set paths in Makefiles. All other libraries should be available from distribution. Don&#39;t use CEGUI from distribution, it may be not compatible. Debian &quot;lenny&quot; (GeForce 6800 Ultra with NVIDIA driver) is main development platform. </p>

<p>Controls:Views </p>

<p>   F1   : camera : FREE mode      F2   : camera : VEHICLE mode (inside view) (DEFAULT)    F3   : camera : VEHICLE mode (rear view, fixed)     F4   : camera : VEHICLE mode (rear view, interpolated)     F5   : camera : VEHICLE mode (front view, fixed)  Vehicle control </p>

<p>move MOUSE left/right to rotate steering wheel. </p>

<p>Hold &quot;W&quot; or &quot;UP&quot; to increase power. </p>

<p>Hold &quot;S&quot; or &quot;DOWN&quot; to decrease power. </p>

<p>Hold &quot;SPACE&quot; to brake. </p>

<p>Hit &quot;BACKSPACE&quot; to change direction (forward, backward). </p>

<p>Free mode </p>

<p>   W, S to move forward/backward. Move mouse to turn.   &quot;Lamp&quot;(NVIDIA VP40/FP40 shader profiles - NV4x GPU (GeForce 6xxx) or newer is required) </p>

<p>Binary : lamp_rXXX.7z.exe (self-extracting archive, click at lamp.exe). BTW, windows binary runs without any problems/tweaks in Wine emulator on Linux (Debian &quot;lenny&quot;) - change into lamp_rXXX folder (important for CEGUI files) and run &quot;wine lamp.exe&quot;. </p>

<p>Used : Cg (VP40/FP40) shader, occlusion query, FBOs, depth textures, fullscreen shader, etc ... </p>

<p>Controls:Views </p>

<p>   F1   : camera : FREE mode      F5   : camera : CHARACTER MODE  Default mode is character. </p>

<p>Character control </p>

<p>  LMB click to shoot cube      A, S, D, W to move. Move mouse to turn and look up/down.  Free mode ( camera: F1) </p>

<p>  LMB click to shoot cube      W, S to move forward/backward. Move mouse to turn.</p>
 title : The game-ws Open Source Project on Open Hub
 title : The gamecatapult Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>GameCatapult is a library, middleware, framework for constructing game authoring environment.
<br/>It contains Lua wrapper for C++ and C++ class binding, easy to build game authoring environment with Lua scripting and extended open scene graph file(.x or COLLADA file). This project forcuses to design a smart and flexible &#39;Game Object&#39; model.
<br/>Currentry, this can render and animate skinned mesh with Direct3D API and blend multiple motion and these are all commanded from Lua script.</p>

<p>GameCatapultはオープンソース・フリーなゲーム開発環境構築ミドルウェアです。Luaスクリプトによるオーサリングを実現するC++ラッパーを備え、.xファイルまたはCOLLADAに独自の拡張を施してシーングラフを完全にデータとして表現する手段を提供します。</p>

<p>現在はDirectXに依存しています。（OpenGL/OpenAL/SDLも選択できるようにする予定です）
<br/>あるいは、グラフィックエンジンにはIrrlichtなどを採用して、自前で用意するのをやめるかもしれません。
<br/>物理エンジンにはODEを採用する予定です。</p>

 title : The gappproxy Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>什么是GAppProxy？一个开源的HTTP Proxy软件。 使用Python编写，运行于Google App Engine上。 GAppProxy的优势：是一个完整的Proxy解决方案：与常见的HTTP Proxy不同，GAppProxy运行在Google App Engine上，不需要专门的服务器，这是最大优势。 个人的Proxy：自己管理，自己使用。 依托于Google App Engine：Google的网络比较可靠。 GAppProxy的劣势:仅支持标准80端口的HTTP协议和443端口的HTTPS协议,其他端口均不支持. 需要安装客户端. GAppProxy的设想用户:教育网用户(不能直接访问国外网络者). 其他需代理的用户.</p>

 title : The garbagetruck Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>Welcome!Have you ever forget to take out the garbage? </p>

<p>IntroductionGarbageTruck is a c# library that works among other libraries (add-ins) to handle recurrent date/time events. </p>

<p>A temporal expression is the basic element to describe a recurrent event. The most common example of a recurrent event is the days the garbage truck come to pick the garbage up. In my case I have to take out the garbage every Wednesday night but that can be vary depending on holidays and so on.  </p>

<p>So what is the information that can be get from a temporal expression about a recurrent event? This project is focused on:  </p>

<p>to determinate if a single date/time is part of the event and  when will the event occur again from a given date/time. </p>

<p>There are infinite imaginable recurrent events and its importance depend on the application they are going to be applied, so try to build a complex library to describe them all is not a good idea. This project is based on that premise. </p>

<p>GarbageTruck allows to handle and persist single and related temporal expressions that are build separately in order to gain simplicity and flexibility. </p>

<p>For more information about recurrent events, temporal expressions and the patterns which this project is based on please read Martin Fowler, Recurring Events for Calendars article that can be found in the downloads section of this site. </p>

<p>Help usYour collaboration is very important to improve this project since it requires continuous improvement a test.  Performance and accuracy are the key of the successful since there are events that can occur even in nanoseconds. </p>

<p>You can help the way you want to this project but there three main aspects that need to be covered: </p>

<p>Development </p>

<p>There&#39;s no words wrote in stone here.  </p>

<p>Project structure needs to be reviewed to see if there are a better approach to handle temporal expressions. Current temporal expressions need to be reviewed to see if there&#39;s a way to improve their code. New temporal expressions need to be created to increase the scope of recurrent events. Demo applications needs to be created to help people to understand the use of the libraries. For more information about development procedures and tasks see the development page of the wiki. </p>

<p>Quality assurance </p>

<p>To ensure that a temporal expression works as it should is not a simple task, so... </p>

<p>Test cases need to be figured and implanted. Those test cases should be executed. For more information about development procedures and tasks see the Quality assurance page of the wiki. </p>

<p>Documentation </p>

<p>A library must be understandable for the people that needs to use it, code comments are not enough, library reference and tutorials need to be created as well. </p>

<p>For more information about development procedures and tasks see the documentation page of the wiki. </p>

<p>How to join?If you are interested in participate of the project just send an email to the any of the administrators telling how you can collaborate.  There&#39;s no mailing list at this point. </p>

<p>Issues are going to be created to solve specif needs of the project.  Once you be a member you can pick any of the open issues and start working on them. </p>

<p>GarbageTruck is in an initial stage and lots of things need to be done, be free to add issues you think must be covered and let us know any suggestion or comment about the project.</p>
 summary : <p>This plugin for the SportTracks software is meant to replace part of Garmin Training Center (GTC).  As such, this plugin allows you to create and edit the advanced workouts and profiles that can then be sent to fitness units.  Even though this is meant to replace GTC you will find a better integration with SportTracks via the usage of SportTracks categories.  This plugin also implements the latest units targets such as power and some user friendly features like drag &amp; droping, copy-pasting and more. </p>

<p>The latest version can be downloaded from here </p>

<p>Installation instructionsDownload the latest version on your hard drive. Once the download has completed, open the .st2plugin file If you have a version already installed in SportTracks you should uninstall the current version prior to installing a new one with the above method.  You can also simply update directly from the Plugins section of the SportTracks Settings page. </p>

<p>Important NotesThis version of the plugin requires the latest version of SportTracks, which is 2.1.3478 or later The Garmin Communicator Plugin must be installed and activated in Internet Explorer.  After it has installed, go to the test page in Internet Explorer and allow the ActiveX plugin. Once this is done, your unit should be detected on the test page. The &quot;export to device&quot; feature won&#39;t work on Vista x64 (and possibly XP x64, I need a confirmation on this)  Please consider donating if you like this plugin.For some help on how to use the plugin and the features it offers, please visit the wiki. </p>

<p>If you would like to report a bug, add a feature request or make a comment about the plugin, head to the issues page. </p>

<p>Feel like contributing?  There are some features that need programming and some translations are still missing.  Contact me via the official plugin&#39;s thread (http://www.zonefivesoftware.com/SportTracks/Forums/viewtopic.php?t=4702) or via a PM to PissedOffCil.</p>

 title : The gba Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>GBA é um framework para desenvolvimento no paradigma orientado a objetos escrito em PHP5. </p>

<p>O objetivo é organizar no framework as diferentes tecnologias e permitir que as mesmas desempenhem seus papeis, aplicando os princípios que são estudados no meio acadêmico. </p>

<p>HTML - responsável pela estrutura da informação; Bancos de Dados, XML e RDF - conteúdo e base de conhecimento; CSS - interface visual, interação homem-máquina. As classes do framework devem ser capazes de gerar todo o código que será utilizado pelas tecnologias acima, de modo que o desenvolvedor possa instanciar objetos e não perder tempo escrevendo tags HTML, por exemplo. </p>

<p>Pontos abordados e funcionando no frameworkAbstração para o banco de dados MySQL. As classes de persistência são capazes de mapear as tabelas do banco e dar tratamento adequado a cada tipo de dado. Classes de componentes de interface para HTML. Você não precisa digitar uma linha de código HTML para criar páginas, formulários, etc. Seguindo o padrão w3c, inclusive passando pelo validador deles. Suporte a importação de arquivos XML para os conteúdos.  Próximos pontos que serão tratadosIncorporar as classes para manipulação de RDF; Incorporar classes para utilização de Ajax; Desenvolver as páginas wiki das principais classes.</p>

 title : The gc4r Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>Google Charts 4 Rails (gr4r)Full featured ruby wrapper for Google Charts API. </p>

<p>Let&#39;s begin1. Hello World    @chart = GoogleChart.new </p>

<p>2. ok, make a line chart with size 300x200    @chart = GoogleLineChart.new :width =&gt; 300, :height =&gt; 200 </p>

<p>3. add some random data    dataset = GoogleChartDataset.new :data =&gt; [10,50,4,10,16]
<br/>    data = GoogleChartData.new :datasets =&gt; dataset
<br/>    @chart = GoogleLineChart.new :width =&gt; 300, :height =&gt; 200
<br/>    @chart.data = data </p>

<p>4. add a chart title    dataset = GoogleChartDataset.new :data =&gt; [10,50,4,10,16]
<br/>    data = GoogleChartData.new :datasets =&gt; dataset
<br/>    @chart = GoogleLineChart.new :width =&gt; 200, :height =&gt; 150, :title =&gt; &#39;Java vs. Ruby Montly Job Opportunities&#39;
<br/>    @chart.data = data
<br/> </p>

<p>5. wow, title is too big let&#39;s wrap it    dataset = GoogleChartDataset.new :data =&gt; [10,50,4,10,16]
<br/>    data = GoogleChartData.new :datasets =&gt; dataset
<br/>    @chart = GoogleLineChart.new :width =&gt; 200, :height =&gt; 150, :title =&gt; [&#39;Java vs. Ruby&#39;, &#39;Montly Job Opportunities&#39;]
<br/>    @chart.data = data Notice: title is now an array instead of string </p>

<p>6. ok now, let&#39;s add more data    dataset1 = GoogleChartDataset.new :data =&gt; [10,50,4,10,16]
<br/>    dataset2 = GoogleChartDataset.new :data =&gt; [99, 81, 25, 54, 80]
<br/>    data = GoogleChartData.new :datasets =&gt; [dataset1, dataset2]
<br/>    @chart = GoogleLineChart.new :width =&gt; 200, :height =&gt; 150, :title =&gt; [&#39;Java vs. Ruby&#39;, &#39;Montly Job Opportunities&#39;]
<br/>    @chart.data = data </p>

<p>7. hmmmm, let&#39;s put some colors    dataset1 = GoogleChartDataset.new :data =&gt; [10,50,4,10,16], :color =&gt; &#39;FF0000&#39;
<br/>    dataset2 = GoogleChartDataset.new :data =&gt; [99, 81, 25, 54, 80], :color =&gt; &#39;0000FF&#39;
<br/>    data = GoogleChartData.new :datasets =&gt; [dataset1, dataset2]
<br/>    @chart = GoogleLineChart.new :width =&gt; 200, :height =&gt; 150, :title =&gt; [&#39;Java vs. Ruby&#39;, &#39;Montly Job Opportunities&#39;]
<br/>    @chart.data = data </p>

<p>8. better but not good enough, which one is java which one is ruby, let&#39;s put the legend    dataset1 = GoogleChartDataset.new :data =&gt; [10,50,4,10,16], :color =&gt; &#39;FF0000&#39;, :title =&gt; &#39;Java&#39;
<br/>    dataset2 = GoogleChartDataset.new :data =&gt; [99, 81, 25, 54, 80], :color =&gt; &#39;0000FF&#39;, :title =&gt; &#39;Ruby&#39;
<br/>    data = GoogleChartData.new :datasets =&gt; [dataset1, dataset2]
<br/>    @chart = GoogleLineChart.new :width =&gt; 200, :height =&gt; 150, :title =&gt; [&#39;Java vs. Ruby&#39;, &#39;Montly Job Opportunities&#39;]
<br/>    @chart.data = data </p>

<p>9. now, it will be nice to have axis    dataset1 = GoogleChartDataset.new :data =&gt; [10,50,4,10,16], :color =&gt; &#39;FF0000&#39;, :title =&gt; &#39;Java&#39;
<br/>    dataset2 = GoogleChartDataset.new :data =&gt; [99, 81, 25, 54, 80], :color =&gt; &#39;0000FF&#39;, :title =&gt; &#39;Ruby&#39;
<br/>    data = GoogleChartData.new :datasets =&gt; [dataset1, dataset2]
<br/>    axis = GoogleChartAxis.new :axis  =&gt; [GoogleChartAxis::LEFT, GoogleChartAxis::BOTTOM]
<br/>    @chart = GoogleLineChart.new :width =&gt; 250, :height =&gt; 150, :title =&gt; [&#39;Java vs. Ruby&#39;, &#39;Montly Job Opportunities&#39;]
<br/>    @chart.data = data
<br/>    @chart.axis = axis </p>

<p>10. and two more, right and second x axis    dataset1 = GoogleChartDataset.new :data =&gt; [10,50,4,10,16], :color =&gt; &#39;FF0000&#39;, :title =&gt; &#39;Java&#39;
<br/>    dataset2 = GoogleChartDataset.new :data =&gt; [99, 81, 25, 54, 80], :color =&gt; &#39;0000FF&#39;, :title =&gt; &#39;Ruby&#39;
<br/>    data = GoogleChartData.new :datasets =&gt; [dataset1, dataset2]
<br/>    axis = GoogleChartAxis.new :axis  =&gt; [GoogleChartAxis::LEFT, GoogleChartAxis::BOTTOM,  GoogleChartAxis::RIGHT, GoogleChartAxis::BOTTOM]
<br/>    @chart = GoogleLineChart.new :width =&gt; 300, :height =&gt; 200, :title =&gt; [&#39;Java vs. Ruby&#39;, &#39;Montly Job Opportunities&#39;]
<br/>    @chart.data = data
<br/>    @chart.axis = axis </p>

<p>11. so far so good, now i want a bar chart    dataset1 = GoogleChartDataset.new :data =&gt; [10,50,4,10,16], :color =&gt; &#39;FF0000&#39;, :title =&gt; &#39;Java&#39;
<br/>    dataset2 = GoogleChartDataset.new :data =&gt; [99, 81, 25, 54, 80], :color =&gt; &#39;0000FF&#39;, :title =&gt; &#39;Ruby&#39;
<br/>    data = GoogleChartData.new :datasets =&gt; [dataset1, dataset2]
<br/>    axis = GoogleChartAxis.new :axis  =&gt; [GoogleChartAxis::LEFT, GoogleChartAxis::BOTTOM,  GoogleChartAxis::RIGHT, GoogleChartAxis::BOTTOM]
<br/>    @chart = GoogleBarChart.new :width =&gt; 300, :height =&gt; 200, :title =&gt; [&#39;Java vs. Ruby&#39;, &#39;Montly Job Opportunities&#39;]
<br/>    @chart.data = data
<br/>    @chart.axis = axis </p>

<p>12. or nice 3d pie chart    dataset1 = GoogleChartDataset.new :data =&gt; 50, :color =&gt; &#39;FF0000&#39;, :title =&gt; &#39;Java&#39;
<br/>    dataset2 = GoogleChartDataset.new :data =&gt; 90, :color =&gt; &#39;0000FF&#39;, :title =&gt; &#39;Ruby&#39;
<br/>    data = GoogleChartData.new :datasets =&gt; [dataset1, dataset2]
<br/>    @chart = GooglePieChart.new :width =&gt; 400, :height =&gt; 200, :title =&gt; [&#39;Java vs. Ruby&#39;, &#39;Montly Job Opportunities&#39;],
<br/>      :chart_type  =&gt; GooglePieChart::PIE_3D
<br/>    @chart.data = data </p>

<p>13. if you like it, theninstall plugin: </p>

<p>script/plugin install http://gc4r.googlecode.com/svn/trunk/in controller: </p>

 summary : <p>Gcal.app is a Google Calendar client for Mac OSX Tiger - a very minimalistic (WebKit-based) browser, that only displays Google Calendar. Nothing else. It’s meant to be as distraction-free as possible, allowing you to focus on tasks and events.</p>
 title : The gcalcli Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>(gcalcli) Google Calendar Command Line Interfacegcalcli is a Python application that allows you to access your Google Calendar from a command line.  It&#39;s easy to get your agenda, search for events, and quickly add new events.  Additionally gcalcli can be used as a reminder service to execute any application you want. </p>

<p>Author: Eric Davis - email - web </p>

<p>Download: gcalcli-1.4 </p>

<p>Check your OS Distribution for packages (gcalcli is starting to be noticed)... </p>

<p>Changelog </p>

<p>Screenshots: One - Two - Three - Four - Five </p>

<p>Requirements: </p>

<p>Python Google&#39;s GData Python module ElementTree Python module dateutil Python module A love for the command line! Features: </p>

<p>list your calendars show an agenda using a specified start/end time and date graphical calendar display (my paying homage to the  remind application) search for past and/or future calendar events &quot;quick add&quot; new calendar events to your default calendar run as a cron job and execute a command for reminders work against specific calendars (by calendar type or calendar name regex) config file support for specifying program defaults colored output and unicode character support easy integration within shell scripts, cron, screen, conky, etc Not (Yet) Supported: </p>

<p>import meeting.ics Outlook events add (non-quick) events with ability to set reminders, repeat, guests, etc configurable reminders (i.e. 30 mins before event every 5 mins) offline mode working from cached data</p>
 title : The gchart Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>Warning: Con artists have likely gained admin access to the Client-side GChart project. Consequently, John Curtis Gunther is no longer administering this Google code project, or using the johncurtisgunther Google account. </p>

<p>On two occasions, I have deleted the same inappropriate attachments posted on the GChart issue tracker only to find that these attachments were undeleted without any further action on my part.  </p>

<p>Since only johncurtisgunther (the GChart project admin) can undelete attachments, the simplest explanation for these events is that con artists have obtained the johncurtisgunther Google account password.  </p>

<p>Unfortunately, I have not been able to find a fool-proof way to assure, beyond reasonable doubt, that unknown, possibly bad-acting, persons will not have inappropriate access to the GChart project going forward (I did change passwords, but Google accounts are complex, and my knowledge of them limited, so I cannot be sure the intruders don&#39;t still have some sort of back door). </p>

<p>So I&#39;ve decided to just make a clean break: disavowing/abandoning my own project and Google account. Specifically, I no longer have any association with, and will make no updates, releases, posts or emails from, the GChart project located at http://gchart.googlecode.com, the google id johncurtisgunther@gmail.com, and the yahoo id johncurtisgunther@yahoo.com.  </p>

<p>In light of this experience, I&#39;d urge anyone releasing a project on Google Code to have a rock-solid plan for assuring that others cannot access your Google account password. And if that plan does not consider the scenario of a drive-by download triggered by visiting a link posted on your project&#39;s issue tracker, it still needs some work. </p>

<p>Sincerely, </p>

<p>John C. Gunther </p>

<p>Client-side GChart author</p>
 summary : <p>gchartjava IS NOW charts4jgchartjava ---&gt;  charts4jPlease update your bookmarks, </p>
 title : The gchartjava Open Source Project on Open Hub
 title : The gchartphp Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>This project is NOT actively maintained (and frankly, barely works...)The code may help you on your way, but it&#39;s not even close workable out of the box... sorry!PHP Object wrapper for the Google Chart APIA simple PHP Object wrapper for the Google Chart API. Should help anyone who needs to automate the building of the Google Chart url. Supports all types of charts.  </p>

<p>Get the code here: code link </p>

<p>Pie Chart Example </p>

<p>pie chart using the gPieChart class. </p>

<p>code: </p>

<p>$piChart = new gPieChart;
<br/>$piChart-&gt;addDataSet(array(112,315,66,40));
<br/>$piChart-&gt;valueLabels = array(&quot;first&quot;, &quot;second&quot;, &quot;third&quot;,&quot;fourth&quot;);
<br/>$piChart-&gt;dataColors = array(&quot;ff3344&quot;, &quot;11ff11&quot;, &quot;22aacc&quot;, &quot;3333aa&quot;);
<br/>Check out the Examples  </p>

<p>NotesLimitations as it currently sits: no support for lxy, or scatter-plots. lxy and scatter should be available soon…  scaling is in place, but kinda useless until I get axes marked correctly. That’s tops on my priority list for this. Some extras still need implementation (chart background, image background, data point markers, etc.) I am pleased with how the code is shaping up. I haven’t had much of an opportunity in the past to play with inheritence and polymorphism in PHP. </p>

<p>Currently I have it set up where like so (in terms of inheritence): </p>

<p>gChart (the base chart class)  gPieChart (has a simple set3D(bool) function) gLineChart gBarChart gStackedBarChart gGroupedBarChart I will probably refactor that sometime soon. But, I’m happy with how it works currently. </p>

<p>I was concerned for a bit about how I would be losing the ability to change the chart type with one line of code (as I could did with the first draft) by breaking chart types out into separate classes. The fact of the matter is that really, no one is very likely to be doing that anyway. So, better code at (perhaps) the sake of some usability…</p>
 title : The gchartrb Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>Introductiongchartrb is a Ruby wrapper around the Google chart API located at http://code.google.com/apis/chart/ </p>

<p>It provides a nice object oriented interface with friendly names, and methods to populate data. Then the data is automatically encoded and the URL can be generated. </p>

<p>Features in the new release of Google Charts API are pending and should be implemented soon. Check out TodoList for a complete list. </p>

<p>Download and InstallationThe simplest way to install gchartrb is via Rubygems </p>

<p>gem install gchartrbAlternatively you can download the latest packages from the Download Page. Run/View the lib/test.rb file to get started. </p>

<p>DocumentationA comprehensive README along with the API docs are located http://gchartrb.rubyforge.org </p>

<p>You can also look at the lib/test.rb (link) and lib/example.rb (link) in the package for a comprehensive set of examples. </p>

<p>Another source is the gchartrb entries on Deepak&#39;s blog </p>

<p>Changes May 21 2008  </p>

<p>latest commit on github contains a new test.rb file which gives an indication of how things are going to change in the next release, syntaxwise. Docs are still pending. </p>

<p> May 13 2008  </p>

<p>Massive rewrite ongoing. Follow at http://github.com/deepakjois/gchartrb/ </p>

<p> May 7 2008  </p>

<p>Moved primary development to github at http://github.com/deepakjois/gchartrb/tree . Watch out for implementation of new API features soon </p>

<p> Mar 20 2008  </p>

<p>Version 0.8 released Fixed Rakefile to process URL correctly (Thanks Aaron Blohowiak) Fixed Axis error due to typo in base.rb (Thanks Jack Nutting) </p>

<p> Feb 3 2008  </p>

<p>Version 0.7 released Added fill area feature (see fill_area) Added to_escaped_url method for encoding the URLs properly Fixed bug where wrong variable name was being used in method </p>

<p> Jan 27 2008  </p>

<p>Version 0.6 released Added a new lfi chart type. See FinancialLineChart. (EXPERIMENTAL) Added support for line styles, using line_style method Added support for customisable width and spacing for bar charts, using width_spacing_options method </p>

<p> Jan 23 2008  </p>

<p>Version 0.5.5 released Fixed a bug related to encoding of multiple datasets using extended encoding. </p>

<p> Jan 07 2008  </p>

<p>Version 0.5.4 released Fixed a bug related to data encoding in Stacked Charts Fixed a bug in which title font and title font size values were being ignored Fixed a bug where shape markers and range markers were overriding each other </p>

<p> Dec 19 2007  </p>

<p>Version 0.5.3 released Welcoming Aseem Tandon to the gchartrb team. Added idiomatic Ruby syntax using blocks (see updated examples below) Added support for shape markers. RDoc documentation  Dec 14 2007  Version 0.5.2 released Added support for title color via title_color attribute (read Rdoc Docs) Added support for vertical and horizontal range markers (read Rdoc docs) using the range_marker method Removed show_labels from base.rb and added it only for pie charts   </p>

<p>Dec 12 2007 (evening) </p>

<p>Version 0.5.1 released max_value method to allow setting of maximum values to encode against. See RDoc documentation or code sample for scatter chart below for example. Added an lib/example.rb to plot some graphs like at http://24ways.org/2007/tracking-christmas-cheer-with-google-charts </p>

<p>Dec 12 2007 </p>

<p>Version 0.5 released Scatter Charts support added Documentation Updated Sample UsageHere is some sample code </p>

<p>    require &#39;rubygems&#39;
<br/>    require &#39;google_chart&#39;</p>

<p>    # Pie Chart
<br/>    GoogleChart::PieChart.new(&#39;320x200&#39;, &quot;Pie Chart&quot;,false) do |pc|
<br/>      pc.data &quot;Apples&quot;, 40
<br/>      pc.data &quot;Banana&quot;, 20
<br/>      pc.data &quot;Peach&quot;, 30
<br/>      pc.data &quot;Orange&quot;, 60
<br/>      puts &quot;\nPie Chart&quot;
<br/>      puts pc.to_url</p>

<p>      # Pie Chart with no labels
<br/>      pc.show_labels = false
<br/>      puts &quot;\nPie Chart (with no labels)&quot;
<br/>      puts pc.to_url  
<br/>    end</p>

<p>    # Line Chart
<br/>    GoogleChart::LineChart.new(&#39;320x200&#39;, &quot;Line Chart&quot;, false) do |lc|
<br/>      lc.data &quot;Trend 1&quot;, [5,4,3,1,3,5,6], &#39;0000ff&#39;
<br/>      lc.show_legend = true
<br/>      lc.data &quot;Trend 2&quot;, [1,2,3,4,5,6], &#39;00ff00&#39;
<br/>      lc.data &quot;Trend 3&quot;, [6,5,4,3,2,1], &#39;ff0000&#39;
<br/>      lc.axis :y, :range =&gt; [0,6], :color =&gt; &#39;ff00ff&#39;, :font_size =&gt; 16, :alignment =&gt; :center
<br/>      lc.axis :x, :range =&gt; [0,6], :color =&gt; &#39;00ffff&#39;, :font_size =&gt; 16, :alignment =&gt; :center
<br/>      lc.grid :x_step =&gt; 100.0/6.0, :y_step =&gt; 100.0/6.0, :length_segment =&gt; 1, :length_blank =&gt; 0
<br/>      puts &quot;\nLine Chart&quot;
<br/>      puts lc.to_url
<br/>    end</p>

<p>    # Bar Chart
<br/>    GoogleChart::BarChart.new(&#39;800x200&#39;, &quot;Bar Chart&quot;, :vertical, false) do |bc|
<br/>      bc.data &quot;Trend 1&quot;, [5,4,3,1,3,5], &#39;0000ff&#39; 
<br/>      bc.data &quot;Trend 2&quot;, [1,2,3,4,5,6], &#39;ff0000&#39;
<br/>      bc.data &quot;Trend 3&quot;, [6,5,4,4,5,6], &#39;00ff00&#39;
<br/>      puts &quot;\nBar Chart&quot;
<br/>      puts bc.to_url
<br/>    end</p>

<p>    # Line XY Chart
<br/>    line_chart_xy = GoogleChart::LineChart.new(&#39;320x200&#39;, &quot;Line XY Chart&quot;, true) do |lcxy|
<br/>      lcxy.data &quot;Trend 1&quot;, [[1,1], [2,2], [3,3], [4,4]], &#39;0000ff&#39;
<br/>      lcxy.data &quot;Trend 2&quot;, [[4,5], [2,2], [1,1], [3,4]], &#39;00ff00&#39;
<br/>      puts &quot;\nLine XY Chart (inside a block)&quot;
<br/>      puts lcxy.to_url   
<br/>    end</p>

<p>    # Venn Diagram
<br/>    # Supply three vd.data statements of label, size, color for circles A, B, C
<br/>    # Then, an :intersections with four values:
<br/>    # the first value specifies the area of A intersecting B
<br/>    # the second value specifies the area of B intersecting C
<br/>    # the third value specifies the area of C intersecting A
<br/>    # the fourth value specifies the area of A intersecting B intersecting C
<br/>    GoogleChart::VennDiagram.new(&quot;320x200&quot;, &#39;Venn Diagram&#39;) do |vd|
<br/>      vd.data &quot;Blue&quot;, 100, &#39;0000ff&#39;
<br/>      vd.data &quot;Green&quot;, 80, &#39;00ff00&#39;
<br/>      vd.data &quot;Red&quot;,   60, &#39;ff0000&#39;
<br/>      vd.intersections 30,30,30,10
<br/>      puts &quot;\nVenn Diagram&quot;
<br/>      puts vd.to_url
<br/>    end</p>

<p>    # Scatter Chart
<br/>    GoogleChart::ScatterChart.new(&#39;320x200&#39;,&quot;Scatter Chart&quot;) do |sc|
<br/>      sc.data &quot;Scatter Set&quot;, [[1,1,], [2,2], [3,3], [4,4]]
<br/>      sc.max_value [5,5] # Setting the max value
<br/>      sc.axis :x, :range =&gt; [0,5]
<br/>      sc.axis :y, :range =&gt; [0,5], :labels =&gt; [0,1,2,3,4,5]
<br/>      sc.point_sizes [10,15,30,55] # Optional
<br/>      puts &quot;\nScatter Chart&quot;
<br/>      puts sc.to_url
<br/>    end</p>

<p>    GoogleChart::LineChart.new(&#39;320x200&#39;, &quot;Line Chart&quot;, false) do |lc|
<br/>      lc.data &quot;Trend 1&quot;, [5,4,3,1,3,5,6], &#39;0000ff&#39;
<br/>      lc.show_legend = true
<br/>      lc.data &quot;Trend 2&quot;, [1,2,3,4,5,6], &#39;00ff00&#39;
<br/>      lc.data &quot;Trend 3&quot;, [6,5,4,3,2,1], &#39;ff0000&#39;
<br/>      lc.axis :y, :range =&gt; [0,6], :color =&gt; &#39;ff00ff&#39;, :font_size =&gt; 16, :alignment =&gt; :center
<br/>      lc.axis :x, :range =&gt; [0,6], :color =&gt; &#39;00ffff&#39;, :font_size =&gt; 16, :alignment =&gt; :center
<br/>      lc.grid :x_step =&gt; 100.0/6.0, :y_step =&gt; 100.0/6.0, :length_segment =&gt; 1, :length_blank =&gt; 0
<br/>      puts &quot;\nLine Chart&quot;
<br/>    end</p>

<p>    # Solid fill
<br/>    line_chart_xy.fill(:background, :solid, {:color =&gt; &#39;fff2cc&#39;})
<br/>    line_chart_xy.fill(:chart, :solid, {:color =&gt; &#39;ffcccc&#39;})
<br/>    puts &quot;\nLine Chart with Solid Fill&quot;
<br/>    puts line_chart_xy.to_url</p>

<p>    # Gradient fill
<br/>    line_chart_xy.fill :background, :gradient, :angle =&gt; 0,  :color =&gt; [[&#39;76A4FB&#39;,1],[&#39;ffffff&#39;,0]]
<br/>    line_chart_xy.fill :chart, :gradient, :angle =&gt; 0, :color =&gt; [[&#39;76A4FB&#39;,1], [&#39;ffffff&#39;,0]]
<br/>    puts &quot;\nLine Chart with Gradient Fill&quot;
<br/>    puts line_chart_xy.to_url</p>

<p>    # Stripes Fill
<br/>    line_chart_xy.fill :chart, :stripes, :angle =&gt; 90, :color =&gt; [[&#39;76A4FB&#39;,0.2], [&#39;ffffff&#39;,0.2]]
<br/>    puts &quot;\nLine Chart with Stripes Fill&quot;
<br/>    puts line_chart_xy.to_url</p>

<p>    puts &quot;\nLine Chart with range markers and shape markers&quot;  
<br/>    GoogleChart::LineChart.new(&#39;320x200&#39;, &quot;Line Chart&quot;, false) do |lc|
<br/>      lc.title_color = &#39;ff00ff&#39;
<br/>      lc.data &quot;Trend 1&quot;, [5,4,3,1,3,5,6], &#39;0000ff&#39;
<br/>      lc.data &quot;Trend 2&quot;, [1,2,3,4,5,6], &#39;00ff00&#39;
<br/>      lc.data &quot;Trend 3&quot;, [6,5,4,3,2,1], &#39;ff0000&#39;
<br/>      lc.max_value 10 # Setting max value for simple line chart 
<br/>      lc.range_marker :horizontal, :color =&gt; &#39;E5ECF9&#39;, :start_point =&gt; 0.1, :end_point =&gt; 0.5
<br/>      lc.range_marker :vertical, :color =&gt; &#39;a0bae9&#39;, :start_point =&gt; 0.1, :end_point =&gt; 0.5
<br/>      # Draw an arrow shape marker against lowest value in dataset
<br/>      lc.shape_marker :arrow, :color =&gt; &#39;000000&#39;, :data_set_index =&gt; 0, :data_point_index =&gt; 3, :pixel_size =&gt; 10   
<br/>      puts lc.to_url
<br/>    end
<br/>Which generates the following as output (copy paste the URLs in the browser to view output) </p>

<p>Pie Chart
<br/>http://chart.apis.google.com/chart?cht=p&amp;chl=Apples|Banana|Peach|Orange&amp;chs=320x200&amp;chd=s:oUe9&amp;chtt=Pie+Chart</p>

<p>Pie Chart (with no labels)
<br/>http://chart.apis.google.com/chart?cht=p&amp;chs=320x200&amp;chd=s:oUe9&amp;chtt=Pie+Chart</p>

<p>Line Chart
<br/>http://chart.apis.google.com/chart?chxt=y,x&amp;cht=lc&amp;chs=320x200&amp;chco=0000ff,00ff00,ff0000&amp;chdl=Trend+1|Trend+2|Trend+3&amp;chd=s:yoeKey9,KUeoy9,9yoeUK&amp;chxr=0,0,6|1,0,6&amp;chtt=Line+Chart&amp;chg=16.6666666666667,16.6666666666667,1.0,0.0&amp;chxs=0,ff00ff,16,0|1,00ffff,16,0</p>

<p>Bar Chart
<br/>http://chart.apis.google.com/chart?cht=bvg&amp;chs=800x200&amp;chco=0000ff,ff0000,00ff00&amp;chdl=Trend+1|Trend+2|Trend+3&amp;chd=s:yoeKey,KUeoy9,9yooy9&amp;chtt=Bar+Chart</p>

<p>Line XY Chart (inside a block)
<br/>http://chart.apis.google.com/chart?cht=lxy&amp;chs=320x200&amp;chco=0000ff,00ff00&amp;chdl=Trend+1|Trend+2&amp;chd=s:Pet9,MYkw,9ePt,9YMw&amp;chtt=Line+XY+Chart</p>

<p>Venn Diagram
<br/>http://chart.apis.google.com/chart?cht=v&amp;chs=320x200&amp;chco=0000ff,00ff00,ff0000&amp;chdl=Blue|Green|Red&amp;chd=s:9wkSSSG&amp;chtt=Venn+Diagram</p>

<p>Scatter Chart
<br/>http://chart.apis.google.com/chart?chxt=x,y&amp;cht=s&amp;chxl=1:|0|1|2|3|4|5&amp;chs=320x200&amp;chd=s:MYkw,MYkw,LQh9&amp;chxr=0,0,5|1,0,5&amp;chtt=Scatter+Chart</p>

<p>Line Chart</p>

<p>Line Chart with Solid Fill
<br/>http://chart.apis.google.com/chart?chf=bg,s,fff2cc|c,s,ffcccc&amp;cht=lxy&amp;chs=320x200&amp;chco=0000ff,00ff00&amp;chdl=Trend+1|Trend+2&amp;chd=s:Pet9,MYkw,9ePt,9YMw&amp;chtt=Line+XY+Chart</p>

<p>Line Chart with Gradient Fill
<br/>http://chart.apis.google.com/chart?chf=bg,lg,0,76A4FB,1,ffffff,0|c,lg,0,76A4FB,1,ffffff,0&amp;cht=lxy&amp;chs=320x200&amp;chco=0000ff,00ff00&amp;chdl=Trend+1|Trend+2&amp;chd=s:Pet9,MYkw,9ePt,9YMw&amp;chtt=Line+XY+Chart</p>

<p>Line Chart with Stripes Fill
<br/>http://chart.apis.google.com/chart?chf=bg,lg,0,76A4FB,1,ffffff,0|c,ls,90,76A4FB,0.2,ffffff,0.2&amp;cht=lxy&amp;chs=320x200&amp;chco=0000ff,00ff00&amp;chdl=Trend+1|Trend+2&amp;chd=s:Pet9,MYkw,9ePt,9YMw&amp;chtt=Line+XY+Chart</p>

<p>Line Chart with range markers and shape markers
<br/>http://chart.apis.google.com/chart?cht=lc&amp;chs=320x200&amp;chco=0000ff,00ff00,ff0000&amp;chdl=Trend+1|Trend+2|Trend+3&amp;chd=s:eYSGSek,GMSYek,keYSMG&amp;chtt=Line+Chart&amp;chts=ff00ff&amp;chm=a,000000,0,3,10</p>
 summary : <p>gcheckyGchecky is a library written in python for using Google Checkout Level 2 Integration XML API. It makes it easy to integrate your order processing system with Google Checkout and ensure that all the interactions with checkout servers are automatically validated, converted from python values to XML (and back) and checked for errors - all that is done by gchecky underneath. </p>

<p>With gchecky an order creation is as easy as writing: </p>

<p>gchecky.model import *
<br/>cart = controller.prepare_order(
<br/>  order = checkout_shopping_cart_t(
<br/>    shopping_cart=shopping_cart_t(
<br/>      items = [item_t(
<br/>          name=&#39;Tom photo&#39;,
<br/>          description=&#39;A beautiful photo of my cat Tom&#39;,
<br/>          unit_price=price_t(
<br/>            value=.99,
<br/>            currency=&#39;USD&#39;),
<br/>          quantity=1)],)))
<br/>print cart.html()Order notification processing is as easy. In your code you manipulate python objects, which mimic Google Checkout XML API messages. Gchecky does all the necessary validation and conversion to/from XML on the fly. </p>

<p>Demohttp://demo.gchecky.com/ is a demo django project that demonstrates the usage of gchecky. Source code of the demo is one of gchecky samples. </p>

<p>DocumentationProject documentation is generated from inline docs in the source code. </p>

<p>Current statusA version 0.2 will soon see the light. It will contain a working django project with samples for three type of GC usage: </p>

<p>digital content donations normal items internet shop yet to be completed All three have custom order processing system - a simple one. It will demonstrate the usage of gchecky.</p>

 title : The gclient Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>Development of the gclient script (which manages checkouts and updates for a set of client modules in various SCM repository locations) has been superseded by depot_tools in the Chromium project repository. </p>

<p>To work with the latest version of gclient, svn checkout http://src.chromium.org/svn/trunk/tools/depot_tools.</p>
 title : The gclms Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>Great Commission LMS is an open source e-learning platform (also known as a Course Management System (CMS), or Learning Management Systems (LMS), or Virtual Learning Environment (VLE)). It can also accurately be called an Learning Content Management System (LCMS), since it enables users to create learning content. </p>

<p>Our goals are to: </p>

<p>make the online learning experience enjoyable. Our design and usability philosophy has a focus on perceived simplicity. make it easy and inexpensive for seminaries, churches, and other groups to train and educate. enable and encourage public accessibility to curriculum even without participating in the online classroom experience. enable and encourage the use of empowering Creative Commons licenses so that course content is freely redistributable. deliver SEO-friendly markup.  We use the CakePHP platform for breezy development and better manageability of code. </p>

<p>ChangelogRoad MapInstallationMinimum Requirements for StudentsFirefox 3 or Internet Explorer 7 (will tentatively support Safari and Opera) 1024 x 768 screen resolution</p>

 title : The gdata-issues Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>This project is a place to report and track issues with the Google Data APIs. </p>

<p>Feature requests for new APIs or enhancements to existing Google Data APIs can also be filed here.</p>
 title : The gdata-java-client Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>The Google Data APIs (GData) provide a simple protocol for reading and writing data on the web. </p>

<p>Each of the following Google services provides a Google data API: </p>

<p>Analytics Apps Provisioning Base Blogger Booksearch Calendar Code Search Contacts Documents List Finance Health Maps Picasa Web Albums Project Hosting Sites Sidewiki Spreadsheets Translator Toolkit Webmaster Tools YouTube The GData Java Client Library provides a library and source code that make it easy to access data through Google Data APIs. </p>

<p>If you have a problem or want a new feature to be included in the GData Java Client Library, please submit an issue. </p>

<p>- The Google GData Team</p>

 summary : <p>GData Scheme Client Library</p>
 title : The gdata4me Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>Google Data API for Java Micro EditionBy Alejandro Rivera  </p>

<p>Carnegie Mellon University (Silicon Valley) </p>

<p>DocumentationHTTPClient</p>
 title : The gdatav2rubyclientlib Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>Provisioning API v2.0  Ruby client libraryProvisioning API v2.0  Ruby client library for Google Apps. Based on GData API v2.0. </p>

<p>running even behind authenticated http proxies using REXML (no extra module dependency) Just uncompress the downloaded file in your working directory. </p>

<p>Ruby language : from version 1.8.6 patch-level 111 (just type ruby -v to check your version) </p>

<p>On-line documentation </p>

<p>Example : </p>

<p>     #!/usr/bin/ruby
<br/>     require &#39;gappsprovisioning/provisioningapi&#39;
<br/>     include GAppsProvisioning
<br/>     adminuser = &quot;root@mydomain.com&quot;
<br/>     password  = &quot;PaSsWo4d!&quot;
<br/>     myapps = ProvisioningApi.new(adminuser,password)</p>

<p>     new_user = myapps.create_user(&quot;jsmith&quot;, &quot;john&quot;, &quot;smith&quot;, &quot;secret&quot;, nil, &quot;2048&quot;)
<br/>     puts new_user.family_name
<br/>     puts new_user.given_nameWant to update a user ? </p>

<p>     user = myapps.retrieve_user(&#39;jsmith&#39;)
<br/>     user_updated = myapps.update_user(user.username, user.given_name, user.family_name, nil, nil, &quot;true&quot;)Want to add an alias or nickname ? </p>

<p>     new_nickname = myapps.create_nickname(&quot;jsmith&quot;, &quot;john.smith&quot;)NEW!!! </p>

<p>Want to manage groups ? (i.e. mailing lists)  </p>

<p>     new_group = myapps.create_group(&quot;sales-dep&quot;, [&#39;Sales Departement&#39;])
<br/>     new_member = myapps.add_member_to_group(&quot;jsmith&quot;, &quot;sales-dep&quot;)
<br/>     new_owner = myapps.add_owner_to_group(&quot;jsmith&quot;, &quot;sales-dep&quot;)
<br/>     #     (ATTENTION: a owner is added only if it&#39;s already member of the group!)Want to handle errors ? </p>

<p>     begin
<br/>             user = myapps.retrieve_user(&#39;noone&#39;)
<br/>             puts &quot;givenName : &quot;+user.given_name, &quot;familyName : &quot;+user.family_name, &quot;username : &quot;+user.username
<br/>             puts &quot;admin ? : &quot;+user.admin
<br/>     rescue GDataError =&gt; e
<br/>             puts &quot;errorcode = &quot;+e.code, &quot;input : &quot;+e.input, &quot;reason : &quot;+e.reason
<br/>     endEmail lists ? (deprecated) </p>

<p>     new_list = myapps.create_email_list(&quot;sales-dep&quot;)

 title : The gdpolice Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>GEARMedulaPlataforma para controlar os robôs do GEAR. Recebe informações do sistema de Visão e envia instruções para o Hardware recebidas da IA. </p>

<p>Pode ser utilizada de duas maneiras: Simulado ou Real. </p>

<p>No modo Simulado um simulador é levantado e robôs virtuais são controlados. </p>

<p>No modo Real os robôs reais são controlados e as informações do campo são fornecidas pela Visão. </p>

<p>Os modos Simulado ou Real são transparentes para os clientes. Ou seja, a IA não sabe de antemão qual será o ambiente em que os robôs serão controlados. Isso permite que o mesmo código seja utilizado para os dois paradigmas. </p>

<p>GEARGEAR - Grupo de Estudos Avançados em Robótica é um grupo da Escola de Engenharia de São Carlos, USP, do Departamento de Engenharia Elétrica.</p>
 title : The gearmedula Open Source Project on Open Hub
 title : Page Not Found - Open Hub
 summary : <p>PubTools is a simple collection of JavaScript files that make it easy for content authors to work with Gears without having to delve into  JavaScript themselves. PubTools includes two different libraries and features: </p>

<p>- PubTools Search - A JavaScript library that drops a client-side search engine into your page. You configure it with basic HTML + a list of URLs  to index, and a search form that uses the local Gears full-text search abilities will appear in your page to quickly locally search over the documents in real time as a user types into the search field. </p>

<p>- PubTools Offline - A simple JavaScript library that makes it easy to take static content offline using just basic HTML added to your page, along with  a utility bookmarklet for developers to quickly generate Gears manifest files  for a given web page. </p>

<p>Please note that PubTools is not an official Google project or Gears API; it is a project  Brad Neuberg created on his own to teach and help developers. The Gears team does not support this project. However, email Brad if you have questions, concerns, or patches while working with the code.</p>

 summary : <p>Gears In MotionDescriptionGears In Motion is a user interface to manage Google Gears databases. It is similar in many ways to standard database interfaces, but focus on what really matters: your data ! </p>

<p>It runs within the browser and we provide a standalone version that you can include in the developpement versions of your projects. </p>

 title : The gearsonrails Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>This project plugs Google Gears in Ruby on Rails. </p>

<p>Gears on Rails helps developers to write fully offline functionnal web applications based on Gears without learning a bit of Gears. </p>

<p>Here we provide an demo to show what we have got and illustrate our ideas. </p>

<p>In this page, I am going to show how to make an offline read-only application using GoR Plugin. </p>

<p>In order to use this Plugin, Json should be installed on the system.  </p>

<p>     gem install json_pure
<br/>We need Goolge Gears also installed on your system. You would be prompted to install Google Gears when you first time vist this web application if you havn&#39;t install it. </p>

<p>Now I am playing as a Rails programmer, who wants to make an offline version web app but without how to do this in javascript and havn&#39;t heard of Google Gears. </p>

<p>1. Setup a Rails project and Install Plugin     rails demo
<br/>     ruby script/plugin install http://gearsonrails.googlecode.com/svn/trunk/acts_as_local/1.1 Config the database.yml properly  </p>

<p>2. Generate Controller and Edit Viewscript/generate controller say hello 
<br/>In hello.html.erb in the View folder. </p>

<p>     
<br/>          
<br/>          
<br/>          
<br/>          
<br/>          Online Status:   
<br/>          Gears Status: 
<br/>               
<br/>               
<br/>                    &amp;lt;%= link_to_local &quot;SaySomething&quot;, :update=&gt;&#39;result&#39;, :action=&gt;&#39;saysomething&#39;%&gt;
<br/>               
<br/>               
<br/>                    Rui says:
<br/>                    
<br/>               
<br/>               
<br/>          
<br/>     
<br/>Notes: In order to use &#39;online_status_tag&#39; and &#39;link_to_local&#39; helpers, you must add   in </p>

<p>. </p>

<p>You can add online_status_tag multiple times to the places you need.  gears_status_tag is used to indicate the current offline app status. </p>

<p>3. Edit Controller and add local controllerIn app/controller/say_controller.rb add </p>

<p>     acts_as_localthen add action &#39;saysomething&#39; </p>

<p>  def saysomething
<br/>    render :text=&gt;Time.now
<br/>  endIn app/controller, make subfolder &#39;local&#39; and add file &#39;say_controller.json&#39; </p>

<p>Note that all offline actions in &#39;say&#39; controller are stored in this file in valid json format as &quot;action_name&quot;:&quot;code&quot; </p>

<p>Add saysomething offline version in say_controller.json </p>

<p>     {
<br/>     &quot;saysomething&quot;: &quot;return (&#39;blabla...&#39;);&quot;	
<br/>     }
<br/>4. Done! Start Servervisit: http://localhost:3000/say/hello </p>

<p>The default offline view is the static page of each view.  However, once you define the corresponding local action in json file, the offline response would be the return value of that local action.  If you either don&#39;t want stale pages of your views or write javascript actions, you could simply write like this: </p>

<p>     acts_as_local :except=&gt;[&#39;hello&#39;]Visitors can&#39;t vist these excluded pages when they are offline.  </p>

<p>You can exclude more actions like </p>

<p>     acts_as_local :except=&gt;[&#39;hello&#39;,&#39;aaa&#39;,&#39;bbb&#39;]Not working? </p>

<p>Change TARGET in  vendor/plugins/acts_as_local/lib/gor/javascripts/data_switch.js to your host </p>

<p>The following will show how to create an offline view of a message board application. </p>

<p>Quick Start for Message BoardUse the 4 easy steps to convert your web-application to an offline working web-application. </p>

<p>Step 0 - Installation of GoR Plugin.Install GoR from Googlecode. Inorder to install GoR from google code run the following command : </p>

<p>1.2)Define a new Local action in the controller.  It is important to include the single inverted comma &#39;. Add the following code to the controller. </p>

<p>def new_local
<br/>	&#39;
<br/>		 posts = Post.find_local(&quot;all&quot;);
<br/>	&#39;
<br/>end1.3)Define create_local action. It is important to include the single inverted comma &#39;. Add the following code to the controller. </p>

<p> def create_local
<br/>	&#39;
<br/>        post = Post.build(params(&quot;post&quot;));
<br/>         Post.create_local(post);
<br/>        window.location.reload( false );
<br/>        &#39;

 title : The gekmllib Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>A Java library to ease creation and manipulation of KML files. A KML file can be loaded as simply as this:  Kml kmlRoot = new KMLParser().parse(new File(filename)); Alternatively a Kml document can be built up programmatically, eg by creating new Placemark(), new Folder() etc and adding them to the root, or other Folders. </p>

<p>Kml.toKML() produces the KML document. </p>

<p>KML.toUpdateKML() will produce a KML document representing the updates since toUpdateKML() was last called.</p>

 title : The gelman Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>What is in this release?
<br/>This release includes a couple of bug fixes and enhancements:
<br/>- changed visibility of RemoteServiceServlet::isImplementedRemoteServiceInterface() method from private to protected
<br/>- added RemoteServiceServlet::getObjectToInvokeServiceIntfMethodOn() method to enable StrutsAction style pluggability
<br/>- changed RemoteServiceServlet::processCall() method to get target from getObjectToInvokeServiceIntfMethodOn()
<br/>- added dblclick support to DOMImplIE6::init() to avoid double clicks from getting lost
<br/>- changed visibility of HistoryImplIE6 from packaged to public to support override of history implementation
<br/>- added configurability of history resource location on HistoryImplIE6 by introducing $wnd.gwt_historyResourceLocation variable. change effected the init() and newItem() methods
<br/>- changed visibility of HistoryImplSafari from packaged to public to support override of history implementation
<br/>- added configurability of history resource location on HistoryImplSafari by introducing $wnd.gwt_historyResourceLocation variable. change effected the init() and newItem() methods
<br/>- set widget = null; in SimplePanel::remove() method to avoid a precondition that can never be satisfied once the first widget is added (ie. side-effect)
<br/>- changed overrideability of RemoteServiceServlet::doPost (ie. removed final)
<br/>- changed RemoteServiceServlet::respondWithFailure to be public static with a servlet context passed in such that filters can also call it
<br/>- changed RemoteServiceServlet::doPost to honour the original http servlet do post contract to less restricted overrides
<br/>- changed the DOMImplStandard::getParent() to check whether it is not null before attempting to modify a member variable</p>

<p>Why did you create a separate distribution of the GWT-User library?</p>

<p>Answer:
<br/># There were a number of defects within the library that needed to fixed. These defects were show stoppers for my project&#39;s release plans
<br/># I needed to open the library up more to be able to leverage it and solve the problems that I faced. The user library in its current form was too closed. This is not a critism of the GWT engineering effort, this happens to all frameworks and will happen to the Gems framework too
<br/># I didn&#39;t like the idea of a platform specific distribution in order to do a compile. Only the shell suffers from platform issues, the compiler is free of them
<br/># I didn&#39;t like bundling a fat user lib binary into my war/web application when all I needed was the rpc subsystem.</p>
 title : The gems-gwt-user Open Source Project on Open Hub
 title : The gencron Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>gencron provides the gen_cron server for periodic command execution.  gen_cron is a very thin extension over gen_server, but it was a common pattern in our code worth abstracting (non-overlapping periodic execution with a force-now feature); perhaps you will find the same. </p>

<p>Note this is a library for Erlang development, not a replacement of the OS utility cron. </p>

<p>genexpire is an example using gencron.  It periodically enforces a (per-node) size limit on Mnesia databases. </p>

<p>Another Dukes of Erl release.</p>

 title : The gene-centered-ecosystem-framework-gp Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>OCamL, Genetic Programming (news: currently porting to F# for easier GUI production) </p>

<p>Abstraction-Based Genetic Programming (ABGP)ABGP is a genetic programming system in which the genotype search space is partitioned by the proofs to which each program is linked to via the Curry-Howard isomorphism. The proofs act as species for organsims by specifying a pattern in which typed genes can be plugged in. Organisms are arrangements of gene as specified by the species to which they belong. Each gene is a closed computational block that may be combined with other blocks to form an organism.    </p>

<p>See the Context wiki page</p>
 title : The genedex Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>A simple library to store and query genomic features and sequence.   Find neighbors of a given feature up or downstream, or on a given strand.   Use a feature to slice out sequence from an associated fasta file. </p>

<p>Genedex uses numpy memmaped arrays for fasta slicing of fasta files without creating an new (often very large) sequence file. Instead, it creates a .gdx which is a pickled dictionary where the keys are the headers and the values are the start, stop positions of the sequence in the fasta file. </p>

<p>To do fast feature queries, genedex uses rtree. This does nearest neighbor and overlap queries very efficiently. This requires a  n install of spatialindex as described here </p>

<p>Read the HTML documentation here: http://genedex.googlecode.com/svn/trunk/doc/readme.html </p>

<p>After installing SpatialIndex Install with easy_install: </p>

<p>sudo easy_install http://genedex.googlecode.com/svn/trunk/</p>

 title : The genetic-star-fighter Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>Genetic Star Fighter is a very simple game made in Ruby with the Gosu 2D game library. The game is just an excuse to visualize the undergoing process, which is the enemy&#39;s code improvement through evolution.  </p>

<p>Our goal is to learn about Evolutionary Computing as we go, and not to make an impressive game (just an impressive AI). </p>

<p>The mission is quite simple: you are a Star Fighter and your job is to push out of the map as many other Star Fighters as you can.</p>

 title : The genmap Open Source Project on Open Hub
 title : The genoa Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>Genoa is a open source project management system that focuses on both the initial development of multiple software projects as well as the long-term maintenance of multiple software projects. </p>

<p>Many project management systems today have one of two focuses: </p>

<p> Start - Finish project management - Managing a project with a definite start and end date with no accounting for long-term maintenance of that project. (e.g. Microsoft Project, Basecamp to a degree)  Single Project Tracking - Managing a single project for the life of the project (initial release as well as future releases).  (e.g. Trac) Often times there is a need to both track a project for the original release as well as subsequent maintenance and future releases, without having to create a completely new project (versioning).  You may also be working on more than one release at a time, or have a number of projects you need to track at one time. </p>

<p>The Genoa ApproachThere are a number of projects that need to be tracked. There are releases of a project (aka: versions). a project has a number of goals which are associated with a release each goal may have any number of tasks which are created by the developer assigned to that goal There are a number of addition actions associated with each of these primary points.  For example: </p>

<p>releases can have a date associated with the release goals can be categorized and prioritized tasks are for the users benefit, not the project tracking as a whole users can provide estimates for how long a goal will take to complete goals can move to different releases as needed and more... The functionality of each component and the system as a whole will be documented in the project wiki, and in the future I would like to add features such as subversion integration, calendar integration and more. </p>

<p>I welcome any feedback and anyone interested in assisting.</p>
 title : The genovaproject Open Source Project on Open Hub
 summary : <p>This project will no longer be updated. </p>

<p>This project was supported by Alex Souza Marçal with the help of a few people along in its development. </p>

<p>GeNova Project is based on RunUO 2.0 Server and Scripts and provide a MMORPG Ultima Online (UO) Server with new features and easy configuration, customization, integration with MySQL Database. </p>

<p>GeNova Project is compatible with: GNU/Linux, FreeBSD, Microsoft Windows, MacOSX, Platform 32 and 64 Bits. </p>

<p>GeNova Project runs on: Mono or .NET Framework. </p>

<p>GeNova Project supports the following versions of UO: AOS, SE, ML, Partial support to KR. </p>

<p>Genova Project this is brazilian project. </p>

<br/>This layer is developed in ASP.NET and aims to integrate the SHARD there is a web portal.Download the project in the SOURCE tab.Installation and Configuration? <p>Mono Compatible; Compatible with RunUO 2.0 SVN REVISION 300; Compatible with Project Modain&#39;s Legacy Full Support revision 12; Latest test with UO:ML 6.0.9.2; Latest test with UO:KR 2.54.0.7; </p>
